HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: ON THE STUMP;
As Vibrant Campaigner, Cuomo Has No Equal

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
Is there any politician but Mario M. Cuomo who would devote an entire campaign appearance to an impassioned, detailed history of the labor movement in America?
Is there any other politician who could? 
 The Governor has often been called an old-fashioned progressive in an era of back-pedaling New Democrats, the remnant of an earlier day when Democrats were rousing, Happy Warrior populists. But as he has stumped through New York for the last several weeks, Mr. Cuomo has once again demonstrated a campaign style even more singular than that.
This is a candidate who simply knows things that other candidates do not know, and who says things that other candidates would never dream of saying. Where other politicians around the nation talk vaguely about the need for change, Mr. Cuomo talks about the nature of change, the cycles of history. Where other trailing candidates belittle the polls, Mr. Cuomo does so in a Catskills routine, via the Jesuits.
"These polls, they're wonderful too," he told a group of wealthy supporters in Manhattan Thursday night. "The polls are really great. Here's what the polls say. I don't look at the polls. Why? They tell you your popularity has gone down. Nobody likes you. It's like being spat upon. I don't need that. I'm married."
It may have little to do with how he might govern in a fourth term, but he remains one of the most compelling campaigners in America. Any single sentence of his is likely to veer into a funny ethnic back alley somewhere in prehistoric Queens before emerging into a vast cosmic statement about human morality. He can be bitter and obnoxious and infuriating, but he retains the ability to bring a crowd around to his side -- if only for a few moments -- no matter how many times they've boarded his ride. His own crankiness, in fact, is part of the inside joke, as he demonstrated to a tentful of New York Times executives last week at the groundbreaking for a new printing plant.
"I think some of their editorials are lousy," he said of the paper's opinion pages, savoring the opportunity. "But I have trouble with some parts of the Old Testament, so that doesn't mean anything."
He has always disliked the labored rituals of the stump, the conspicuous consumption of calamari at a street fair while wearing an "I Love Mario" cap and tapping a toe to Italian music. He will occasionally indulge the crowd with such antics, but it is often with little joy, and the creases in his face seem deeper and more pained with each tarantella.
Last week, leaving a converted defense plant in Long Island, he walked across the street to a waiting crowd and listlessly shook a few hands. Within 15 seconds he was deep in an argument with a bystander about the Public Service Commission. After a moment of pointless heat, he waved off the man with a dismissive gesture, got back in his car and left, the handshaking over almost before it started. As if in counterpoint, Vice President Al Gore followed him out the door, tripped when his crutch caught an aide's pants cuff, and fell face down on the ground. He immediately bounded up, plunged into the same crowd, and spent several happy argument-free minutes chatting, handshaking and waving.
Mr. Gore is an effusive campaigner, but he shares none of the Governor's oddly distancing charisma. Where other politicians draw strength from a crowd's body heat, Mr. Cuomo seems truly comfortable only when shielded from them by a lectern. There are clearly variations in his mood -- on Friday he seemed to actually enjoy chatting with bystanders in Penn Station -- but for the most part, he is most alive when a microphone is near his mouth, for it is there that he can work the levers and dials of a crowd, raising and lowering their emotional pitch with the precision of an engineer.
At a breakfast meeting of the Communications Workers of America in Manhattan last week, where Mr. Cuomo delivered his labor-movement history, most of the crowd was his before he walked in the door. The Governor is an old friend of organized labor, and he could have read the newspaper and gotten an ovation. While his listeners expected to be satisfied, however, they did not plan on being enthralled, not after 12 years of his voice swirling through the state's collective consciousness.
Yet there was not a sound to be heard in the ballroom as Mr. Cuomo swept them from African slavery to the sweatshops to the Triangle Shirtwaist fire, from the glory days of labor to the winter of Reaganomics and into a promised golden future of worker-management cooperation triumphant over the global economy. No one in the room learned a thing, and no one's life was changed by his words. But whether they believed in his rosy predictions or not, many of them suddenly felt much better about themselves and their movement, and their applause was fervent and prolonged.
"Man, what a way to start a morning," said Elaine Conchero, a C.W.A. member from Midwood. "He's like a good cup of coffee."
Even his worst detractors have always conceded the raw power of his oratory and his impressive erudition. His Republican opponent, State Senator George E. Pataki, enjoys confessing that he is not Mr. Cuomo's speechmaking equal, and likes to make fun of the Latin phrases and theological hand-wringing that are by now the Governor's trademark. Doing so apparently makes Mr. Pataki more familiar to the average tongue-tied citizen. Seeking to inoculate voters from Mr. Cuomo's spell, Republicans have often tried to paint him as a kind of brilliant Svengali, whose pretty words might bewitch listeners into doing something evil in the voting booth.
But even more than his eloquence, it is actually the sweep of his core themes that has kept what he calls his final campaign so intriguing, even to those who have heard the E. B. White quotes and the old neighborhood memories several dozen times. His great subject is the nature of the American experience, the way the nation's immigrant history is deeply woven into its future, and he is one of the few politicians who can bring it off without sounding shallow or contrived.
"I want a place that has room for everybody," he told a street rally in Long Island City earlier this month, his booming voice at its most emphatic. "I want a place that gives opportunity to everybody. I want a place where your kid can go to school, whether he's black or white or Latino or gay or lesbian or Pole or Russian, what the heck ever he is, we give them opportunity. If you can work, if you're willing to do your job, if you're willing to get an education, then you can be whatever you want. That's where I come from. That's what Queens is."
The words are not merely a throwback, they are an open defiance of the prevailing constrictive mood, a high-wire challenge to the fundamental laws of politics. And as he well knows, there is nothing more riveting than watching to see if the acrobat can survive the act.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo speaking on Saturday at a restaurant in Buffalo. State Assemblyman Arthur Eve is at rear, directly beyond the microphone. The Governor has surpassed his already large reputation as a unique, charismatic campaigner in the current run-up to Election Day. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: The 'Bell Curve' Agenda

 BODY:
"The Bell Curve," a flame-throwing treatise on race, class and intelligence by the late Richard Herrnstein and Charles Murray advances a grisly thesis: I.Q., largely inherited and intractable, dictates an individual's success -- an economic death knell for much of America's black population. The story has America increasingly divided by race and sliding inexorably into castes based on I.Q.
The book has already ignited bitter controversy, and that is no surprise. It declares settled what many regard as an unresolved argument over whether I.Q.'s have scientific merit. Moreover, Mr. Murray's record as a political ideologue who uses social science data to support his policy preferences touches a tender spot in American intellectual history on the issue of race and intelligence. 
 The notion that one group could be genetically superior to another has a long and sordid history in this country and abroad. Bigots purported to find "scientific" evidence that blacks, or American Indians, or Jews, to name three targets, were of inferior stock. Even supposedly objective scholars lent their talents to such racism.
Individual readers can judge the authors' racial attitudes and data. The concern here is the governmental fallout of a book that aspires to set the agenda of social policy debate for the decade. What gives their sweeping generalities poignancy is an overlay of sophisticated statistical tools that create an aura of scientific certitude sure to intimidate ordinary citizens from challenging the alarming conclusions.
That would be tragic. Though "The Bell Curve" contains serious scholarship, it is also laced with tendentious interpretation. Once unlike-minded scholars have time to react, they will subject its findings to withering criticism. At its best, the Herrnstein-Murray story is an unconvincing reading of murky evidence. At its worst, it is perniciously and purposely incendiary. The graphs, charts, tables and data admit of less dire conclusions. But less dire would not have put Mr. Murray on the cover of news magazines, though it would have given America's disadvantaged a more accurate, hopeful glimpse of their future.
The authors argue that there is an underlying core to intelligence, separate from individual talents or skills, that is well measured by I.Q. tests. I.Q. scores are largely inherited and after childhood immutable. In their view, high I.Q. leads to high income and respectable behavior. Low I.Q. leads to social pathology -- poverty, welfare dependency, out-of-wedlock births and crime.
The book says low-I.Q. parents produce large families, dragging average I.Q.'s lower. Its authors belabor the well-known fact that the average I.Q. of blacks is 15 points below that of whites and dismiss arguments that these low test scores reflect little more than biased testing. Their implication is that blacks are trapped at the bottom of society.
But many experts reject these chilling conclusions. For starters, the authors' statistical techniques are insufficiently powerful to distinguish the impact of I.Q. from talents or skills, some of which can be taught. Here, terminology matters. Were Mr. Murray parading around town with a story about skills, he would sound like everyone else who has tried to explain the explosive increase in income inequality in the last two decades. By blaming low I.Q. for poverty, he makes remediation look silly; by blaming skills for poverty, he would have invited society to try. The first finding is obviously the more attractive for Mr. Murray, who has built his career on arguing for the elimination of social programs.
The authors give short shrift to explanations for low I.Q. scores that are less bleak than their own. Some remedial programs have raised I.Q.'s, even if temporarily. I.Q.'s for blacks, as well as whites, are moving higher over time. Black educational achievement is catching up. And other countries do a better job integrating minorities in the economic mainstream than the U.S. does. One of the authors' key measures of innate intelligence, scores on the military's qualifying test, has been shown to be a product of education, an environmental factor. The issue is balanced interpretation. Mr. Murray has created an act of advocacy; he has not built a scientific case.
"The Bell Curve" presumes, but does not prove, that differences in genes account for 60 percent of the differences in the I.Q.'s of children. It is essential to note -- which the authors do but many of their critics do not -- that group differences in I.Q. may have nothing to do with genes even if individual I.Q.'s are largely inherited. An example proves the point. Plants grown together under ideal conditions will achieve different heights based solely on individual genetic makeup. But lock half the plants in a dark closet and the difference in average height of the two groups will be due entirely to environment. So even if I.Q.'s are deemed to be largely inherited, that says nothing about the potential impact on I.Q. of altering prenatal care or aggressive early education.
Mr. Murray's findings are not wrong because they are ugly. They are wrong because they blind us to more compelling interpretations and because they ignore the huge gaps in understanding the precise nature of intelligence. What is right about the book was already well known: skills have taken on increasing importance in the economy and they are difficult to acquire. What is new about the book -- the fixation on genes as destiny -- is surely unproved and almost surely wrong: programs here and abroad produce measurable, if unspectacular, results. These sobering lessons were clear before "The Bell Curve" was published. They remain so afterward.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Clinton's Concessions

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The problem with Bill Clinton's trip to Syria to seek an agreement about the Golan Heights is that he has persuaded himself that his cave-in last week to North Korea was "a very good deal indeed."
Examine that deal. Mr. Clinton's opening position was that untrustworthy North Korea must not be allowed to become a nuclear power; he soon trimmed that to say it must not possess nuclear bombs, and stoutly threatened sanctions if North Korea did not permit inspections of nuclear facilities at Yongbyon, where the C.I.A. and K.G.B. agree nuclear devices have been developed. 
 But as a result of Clinton's Very Good Deal Indeed, I.A.E.A. inspectors are denied entry to those plants for five years -- when some excuse will be found for more secrecy.
Because Clinton backed down, North Korea's first two atomic explosives -- which Administration spinmeisters now dismiss as "low yield," but capable of obliterating everything within a three-quarter-mile radius -- could menace Seoul and, in a few years, be deliverable in Tokyo. That's enough of a mass-destruction threat to preclude a pre-emptive strike by us if North Korea, in the next U.S. President's Administration, breaks its agreement to freeze additional bomb-making.
Well, let 'em have a couple, but see how they've promised to stop producing more plutonium: "The entire world will be safer," Clinton insists. In prepayment for that blackmail, the U.S. has agreed to supply the North with $100 million worth of oil each year and arrange with allies to build -- free -- a $4 billion light-water reactor that apologists claim would make it terribly difficult to produce weapons-grade plutonium, though experts disagree.
But that substitute reactor won't be on-line for nine years. And the victorious North Korean negotiator, Kang Sok Ju, crows that "the complete elimination of the existing nuclear program will only come when we have the light-water reactor in our hands." Meanwhile, the North's "existing nuclear program" goes on -- including work in sites forbidden to I.A.E.A. inspectors.
These inspectors are seething at the U.S. cave-in and the precedent set for future blackmail. Proliferation watchdog Gary Milhollin says: "We're about to rescue North Korea from its poverty, but they don't give up very much." James Schlesinger, a former chairman of the A.E.C. and later Jimmy Carter's Energy Secretary, has this judgment: "While it was not an unconditional surrender, it was a negotiated surrender."
Why pay North Korea billions while it retains a secret bomb capability for at least five years?
"What do you want," replies a Clintonite in a burst of candor, "a war?"
That explains it: Just as the credible threat of war by the U.S. forced out Haiti's junta and forced Saddam Hussein away from Kuwait, the threat of war by North Korea forced Bill Clinton to fold his hand.
But war was a false alternative: another choice was sustained diplomatic pressure, economic sanctions, with benefits to the North only after verified performance. That Reaganesque course was too hard for Clinton.
How does Clinton's willingness to pay dictatorships up front affect his coming visit to Hafez al-Assad in Syria?
We can hope it is not another advance concession. To visit a nation on our short list of terrorist states is to effectively remove it from that list. Clinton's visit is an honor long sought by Assad, who spent 17 years undermining the Sadat-Begin initiative, who harbors Iran's Hezbollah in conquered Lebanon and who made Damascus the world capital of terrorism.
The reason for such substantial payment up front cannot be only to prop up political popularity, recalling Nixon's sad overseas tour after Watergate.
No astute dealmaker would throw away the valuable card of a Presidential visit. Clinton should have an equally dramatic return concession in hand that would speed a territorial compromise on the Golan.
But that's where his recent, unbounded enthusiasm for the disappointing Korean negotiation is most worrisome. Clinton has just proved he can hypnotize himself into fervently believing that any deal at all -- including one that puts his successor as President in a terrible box -- is "a very good deal indeed."

HEADLINE: What Those Figures on New Jobs Really Mean;
Misleading Numbers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Statistics Reveal Bulk of New Jobs Pay Over Average" (front page, Oct. 17) focuses deceptively on average income changes. You quote the economist Paul R. Krugman as saying that "there's something funny about numbers that suggest that the average real wage is declining." (Mr. Krugman also asserts that "workers as a group are fully sharing in economic gains.") 
 But in elementary statistics, students are immediately taught that an arithmetic average can be highly misleading when a distribution is skewed; a median (the middle value) is more enlightening in such a case. On Oct. 7, summarizing a new Census Bureau study, you reported that from 1992 to 1993, median household income (the typical American household's income) declined, that a million more people fell into poverty, and that "while average per capita income was up, by 1.8 percent, most of the benefits flowed to the wealthiest Americans."
In short, there is nothing "funny" about a decline in the wages of typical Americans if we examine the entire income distribution, look at the median instead of average values and can digest the fact that inequality and poverty are continuing to increase from already serious levels.
 
EDWARD S. HERMAN
Narberth, Pa., Oct. 20, 1994
 
The writer retired as a professor of finance at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
Companies
 The comebacks of General Motors and I.B.M. have been strongpoints of the nation's industrial revival. Yet while I.B.M. reported surprisingly strong profit for the third quarter last week, General Motors showed a worrying loss in its crucial North American auto business. Yet what appeared a divergence of fates may serve as a cautionary lesson for I.B.M. It also reflects the travails of reshaping a corporate giant after years of mismanagement in an economy where the direction has been hard to predict. [Page D1.] 
 MCI Communications has decided to go its own way in building a nationwide wireless-telephone network, rejecting any immediate alliance with the regional Bell companies, company executives said. But Sprint was said to be planning to announce the details of an alliance with four big cable television companies to build a new wireless system from the ground up. [D1.]
 Synaptics will introduce a device today that it says offers a more accurate and reliable way to control personal computers and other electronic appliances than the mouse and trackball. [D2.]
 
The Media Business
 Three weeks after Peter Guber departed as chairman of Sony Pictures Entertainment, the studio appears stricken by indecision, high-level turmoil, executive defections and a weak slate of forthcoming film releases -- the same problems, in other words, it has grappled with for years. [D1.]
 News magazine programs, once in such favor among broadcast networks, have become the most depressed genre in network television. Ratings for nearly all the programs are down. [D1.]
 The combined average Monday-to-Friday circulation of New York City's four newspapers has slipped more than 150,000 since 1992, a sign that newspaper circulation in the country's biggest media market is again shrinking after it had seemed to level off. [D10.]
 The financial difficulties behind the collapse of Whittle Communications, a once high-flying alternative media company, were far more severe than previously believed and masked in part by accounting misrepresentations, a published report says. [D10.]
 Time Inc. is testing interactive-media versions of several publications, ranging from Time, Vibe and Sunset magazines to Time Warner Books. [D10.]
 With accurate, saturation reporting of the killings, evidence and legal maneuvering, The National Enquirer has become the bible of the O. J. Simpson case. [A12.]
To know the mind of Generation X, Houston Effler turns to its 26-year-old youth-marketing director. Advertising. [D11.]
 
The Economy
 Having succeeded beyond its wildest dreams in nurturing the Internet computer web into a national information highway system, the Government has begun to transfer to private industry the job of maintaining and operating the network. [D1.]
 
International
 Russia's struggle to get loans from the International Monetary Fund in order to meet its budget and expenses has followed a pattern: the Russians promise fiscal and monetary discipline, while citing the importance of their economic transformation to the well-being and peace of the world. [A5.]
 
Today's Columns
 A hand-held stamp will let people imprint zip codes on envelopes in bar code, speeding delivery. Sabra Chartrand: Patents. [D2.]
 In a tough business climate, Citicorp is again a favorite among banks. Market Place. [D8.]

CORRECTION-DATE: October 25, 1994, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
The chart atop the Business Digest on Monday misstated the major financial indicators for last week in some editions. The Dow Jones industrial average closed the week at 3,891.30, down 19.17 points; the dollar was last quoted at 97.22 yen to the dollar, down 0.88 yen; the crude oil contract for December delivery closed at $17.38 on the New York Mercantile Exchange, up 41 cents; the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond ended at 7.97 percent, up 14 basis points.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Prepares to Reveal Spending Cuts

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
After weeks of quietly drafting ways to keep New York City's $31.6 billion budget balanced, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani plans to unveil a menu of spending cuts this week that officials say will affect programs and services for thousands, if not millions, of New Yorkers.
As he and his aides continued to make adjustments last night, the Mayor's revision of the budget that took effect four months ago was expected to include more than $850 million in spending cuts, sparing virtually no city agency, officials said. 
 At 5:20 this evening, Mr. Giuliani, the Republican who has vowed to make New York finally spend within its means, plans to give what his aides call a major address on the state of the city's finances and the need for still more drastic steps. The Mayor's decision to take to the airwaves for a direct appeal to New Yorkers recalls similar decisions that his predecessor, Mayor David N. Dinkins made at times of pressing concerns for the city, including two during a recessionary budget crisis in 1991 and one on Thanksgiving Day in 1992 to quell tensions lingering from the disturbances in Crown Heights a year before.
In his address, Mr. Giuliani is expected to brace New Yorkers for cuts ahead, appealing, aides said, to a sense of civic sacrifice. At the same time, they said, he will highlight favorable economic signs for the city -- including an increase of 30,000 private jobs since he took office -- that he says are proof of the need to continue his policies of cutting spending and the size of the city's payroll.
"The economy is coming back," the Mayor said yesterday after attending Mass at the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in Astoria, Queens, striking a note he is expected to repeat in the address. "So we really have to continue to reduce the size of government spending, which in New York has gotten out of control, and this is really one more step in that."
The details of the spending cuts have been guarded as secrets, with agency officials under orders not to discuss them publicly. But the measures, city officials say, include cutting such jobs as bridge painters, heat inspectors, civilians in the Police Department and administrators in most agencies.
The Mayor also plans deep cuts in social services like emergency food programs, and less money for the city's subways and its university system, which may ultimately result in fare and tuition increases.
The city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, which has already proposed cutting 3,000 jobs to cope with the first round of cutting, faces a new reduction of about $100 million, as does the Transit Authority. Officials said the Board of Education's cut is expected to be nearly double that.
In all, the Mayor plans to close a $1.1 billion gap in the budget -- $100 million higher than his aides were planning only a week ago -- by cutting about 5,000 more jobs through attrition and a new round of severance packages still to be negotiated with the unions in talks that are to resume early this morning.
The job cuts, coming on top of the 15,000 cuts already budgeted for elimination in the city-financed payroll of 216,000 workers, would reduce the payroll to the lowest level in a decade, when it totaled 194,373 in 1985 under Mayor Edward I. Koch.
In addition to $850 million in spending cuts to the agencies, the officials said, the plan will include nearly $200 million in savings on health care costs for workers and retirees and another $50 million that in part includes more aggressive collection of fees and fines.
The bleak plan could prove politically unpalatable. While the first cuts in spending have affected services in ways large and small, from larger class sizes in schools to fewer repairs in parks, the administration has so far managed to avoid catastrophic service disruptions.
But this time, officials said, the impact will be greater, setting the stage for intense wrangling with the City Council once Mr. Giuliani formally presents his budget revision. He is scheduled to do so tomorrow.
"Since the plan has been formulated in a vacuum, the Council will clearly focus on the service impacts," said Thomas L. McMahon, director of the Council's finance division. "I think there's a real concern on the fiscal side that the city doesn't have the resources to do all the things it does, but also on the service side that the cuts we're talking about will have a real impact on people."
Since Mr. Giuliani took office in January, the city budget has proved to be the bugaboo of his tenure.
After pushing through the Council a $31.6 billion budget that cut spending by $1.1 billion, Mr. Giuliani has watched it come undone. Tax revenues in the first quarter of the fiscal year fell below expectations. The number of people on welfare has kept rising. Overtime has soared and judgments in liability suits against the city are expected to rise to a record $300 million this year, $80 million higher than budgeted.
At the same time, several sources of help anticipated in the budget have not arrived, including new Federal aid and legislation in Albany that was projected to save millions of dollars.
Only 11 days after the budget took effect, the Mayor said he would cut $100 million more in spending. With the city's fiscal monitors warning of a shortfall of $1 billion or more, the Mayor's gap-closing plan has grown steadily since then, reaching $1.1 billion last week.
The Mayor's senior aide, Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers, said that the administration was acting to stay on top of the budget before it turned into a crisis. He declined to discuss the specific cuts, but he said they would fall across the board and indicated that they would cut muscle in the form of programs and services, not just bureaucratic fat.
"Everything we do we know has to be very, very real," Mr. Powers said. "There can't be any softness."
Once Mr. Giuliani formally unveils his plan -- officially known as "a budget modification" -- the Council has 30 days to consider it. Unlike the budget process in the spring, this modification cannot by law be revised by the Council: it must simply vote yes or no, or do nothing and let the cuts take effect anyway.
The Council can negotiate with the Mayor to resubmit the entire plan with revisions. Mr. McMahon said that the Council still held out hope for increased aid from Washington, as high as $200 million, that could be used to minimize some of the cuts.
Even with the new cuts, the city's persistent budget problems will by no means be solved. Projections for the next two or three fiscal years include even larger deficits, because spending on welfare, Medicaid, pensions and other programs continues to grow faster than the city's revenues from taxes.
Echoing the fiscal monitors and other budget experts, Mr. McMahon said that the city needed to persuade the Legislature in Albany to relieve the city of the programs and services it imposes, including its requirement that the city pay a quarter-share of Medicaid costs.
"Otherwise," he said, "we will be back in January making another billion dollars in changes."
Mr. Giuliani's broadcast address will be the third of his administration. The first came as he unveiled his budget plans in February and the second at the end of his first 100 days in April. But his aides said that the scope of the budget problems would give this speech greater import.
In his remarks yesterday, Mr. Giuliani said that much work lay ahead before those problems could be resolved. "It took us 16 years to get here," he said. "It took 16 years of overspending, spending more money than the rate of the growth of the economy. It's going to take longer than one budget, and one budget modification, to cure all of it."
 
CHRONOLOGY
Struggling to Balance the Budget
MAY 10 Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposes a $31.6 billion budget that closes a projected $2.3 billion gap. It cuts $1.1 billion in spending and eliminates 15,000 of the 216,000 city-financed jobs by attrition and a severance program.
JUNE 21 After making only minor changes, the City Council's leadership approves the budget, and the Mayor and Speaker Peter F. Vallone toast the occasion with champagne. The full Council approves the budget by a vote of 43 to 8 two days later.
JULY 1 The new budget takes effect with the start of the 1995 fiscal year.
JULY 11 Facing criticism from the state's Financial Control Board, Mr. Giuliani promises to cut spending by $100 million in the first three months of the fiscal year to build the city's reserves to $250 million.
JULY 25 Mr. Giuliani orders agencies to cut spending by $250 million immediately and prepare for the possibility of cutting $200 million more as he plans to revise the new budget to keep it balanced.
JULY 27 The State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, releases a critique that concludes that the budget still has a projected shortfall of more than $600 million. A day later, the Financial Control Board says the gap is likely to be more than $1 billion.
SEPT. 20 Mr. Giuliani says measures are needed to close a budget gap as large as $600 million, as his budget aides acknowledge lower-than-expected tax revenues, growing welfare rolls and soaring overtime costs, particularly in the Department of Correction.
SEPT. 23 In a private briefing with the City Council, the Mayor says he will have to close a budget gap of $800 million to $1 billion. In a speech to the City Club of New York, he says he cannot solve years of overspending in one budget.
SEPT. 28 Mr. Giuliani summons leaders of the city's municipal unions to Gracie Mansion for a briefing on his plans to close a $1 billion gap, in part with $200 million in savings from health care benefits for unionized workers and with a new round of severance packages to cut as many as 8,500 more workers.
OCT. 14 The city's Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, predicts that the city's budget has a $1.4 billion shortfall, higher than the $1 billion plan being pieced together by the Mayor. The Mayor's aides later increase the gap-closing plan to $1.1 billion.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 2438 words

HEADLINE: Baghdad's Burden -- A special report.;
Iraq Is Near Economic Ruin But Hussein Appears Secure

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Children lie on filthy hospital beds, murmuring in pain as they die of diarrhea and pneumonia. Some of the Arab world's finest artists peddle their work for as little as $12 a painting. A 50-year-old retired policeman, victim of a stroke a year ago, limps from merchant to merchant in a food market looking for what he can afford on a pension driven down by inflation to the equivalent of $2 a month, barely enough to buy one chicken.
In this city, which only five years ago ranked as one of the most vibrant and prosperous capitals of the Middle East, the plight of Iraq is amply evident, but political improvement is not. Gone are the mounds of imported goods, sweets, pistachios and varied nuts that were a fixture of many Baghdad street markets. They have been replaced by spontaneous flea markets where sullen middle-class men and women offer their cutlery, used furniture and family possessions for sale to make ends meet. 
 Cars with broken fenders and cracked windshields for lack of spare parts make their way through dusty, cheerless streets where pavements are collapsing and sewers overflow.
In the two weeks since Iraq moved some of its best-trained troops toward the Kuwaiti border, only to be rebuffed by American military countermeasures, the world has been duly reminded of the stringent trade sanctions imposed four years ago by the United Nations. If that was President Saddam Hussein's intention, he was successful. If it was also his hope that the United Nations could be persuaded somehow to lift the embargo, he was not.
This country of 20 million people -- which sits atop the world's second-largest oil reserves, after Saudi Arabia's -- remains financially broken, lurching from one crisis to another. Unable to sell its oil and buy food, medicine and spare parts except under United Nations conditions that it refuses to accept, Iraq faces famine and economic collapse.
Despite the hardships being heaped on the population, Mr. Hussein, his two sons and potential political heirs, Uday and Qusay, and his Takriti family clan continue to rule Iraq virtually as royalty. Behind the walls of sumptuous palaces and cordons of security men, Mr. Hussein remains invulnerable to public dissent, protected by an intelligence and security apparatus directed by Qusay and a handful of first cousins and other relatives.
The Iraqi President has rarely appeared in public in the last few years, but his presence remains overwhelming. He appears in taped television programs broadcast daily. His face peers down from thousands of posters and statues throughout the country. He continues to claim victories and inveigh against enemies from the United States to Saudi Arabia, promising almost weekly an imminent lifting of the United Nations sanctions. And his Government does not discourage journalists from the West from reporting firsthand on the economic ruin that Mr. Hussein blames on the international community.
"This used to be a rich country," said an Iraqi intellectual who described himself as having been a fervent supporter of the Hussein Government. "Today I'd say not more than one million Iraqis are living in any real sense of the word. They are those who uphold Saddam's rule and those who protect him. They are given food and plenty of money. The rest of us are drifting into this surreal kind of poverty where university professors sell their family's possessions to eat. It is breaking down the very fabric of this society."
"Sometimes, when I hear foreign radio broadcast assertions from America or Britain that the only way to salvation is to get rid of Saddam, I say to myself, 'Do they think we are some kind of video game or what?' " said the man, who like everyone interviewed outside Government circles insisted on the protection of anonymity. "You are looking at a people whose energy is drained simply looking for the next meal."
Abdelrazak al-Hashemi, a senior official who heads the foreign relations bureau of the governing Baath Party, recalled the brief popular uprising that was ruthlessly put down by the Iraqi Army in March 1991 after its expulsion from Kuwait, and said: "That was a time when 14 of the country's 18 provinces were outside government control, but the regime did not fall. Do you think it is going to fall now because of these sanctions?"
Mr. Hashemi, who served as a Cabinet minister and in several other top positions during the last two decades, then added for emphasis: "Listen. The President is managing the country. Those who think the sanctions will bring him down will have to wait for a long time."
 
Social Order
Crime Is Rampant; Middle Class Sinks
 Managing, however, may not be the right word to describe Mr. Hussein's hold on the country. In some ways the Government is notable for lack of control.
While the Government firmly controls central Iraq, where Sunni Muslims and Christian Iraqis live, Mr. Hussein's hold over the north, inhabited by Kurds, and the south, heavily populated by Shiite Muslims, is questionable.
Two weeks ago, a busload of journalists and officials of the Iraqi Information Ministry accompanying them were stopped on the way to the southern city of Basra in the daytime by a group of armed bandits.
They were beaten. Men were stripped of their clothes. Women were roughed up. The bandits took thousands of dollars in cash, photographic equipment and jewelry. Passports and identity cards were confiscated. The bandits, who numbered a dozen or so, shot up the bus tires and left the group after briefly debating whether they should kill the passengers.
Some passengers wondered later whether the incident could have involved a conspiracy between the bandits and army troops in the region who, like other Iraqis, are in dire need of money. "The road was conspicuously deserted, as though someone had blocked it after we passed," one passenger said.
In the north, where the Kurds live, the American-led coalition that pushed Iraq from Kuwait barred Iraqi troops from the region several years ago, declaring it a "safe haven." Mr. Hussein responded by cutting off food rations, but the Government has ceased to have much influence there.
Southern Iraq, where Shiite Muslims dominate the population, has been hostile territory for years as Hussein forces have pursued a systematic campaign since the late 1970's to uproot Shiite militants financed by Iran who are revolting against the Sunni-dominated Government. Today, it is dangerous to travel in the region by night.
The most striking change in law and order is in Baghdad and in the center of the country, where the Government appears uncompromising in its political policing, but unwilling or unable to protect people from ordinary crime.
Thefts, burglaries and rapes are rampant, reported to have increased by 40 to 50 percent above the rate of five years ago. The police force appears unable to cope. As a result, homes are now locked with chains at night, when the streets are deserted in large cities, including this capital.
Fathers and sons take turns at night keeping an eye on the family car. Women rarely venture out alone after dark. Random nighttime shootings are common in some areas, and in the huge Saddam City slum in Baghdad, dominated by Shiites and the poor, the police are virtually absent after nightfall.
Elsewhere, public employees are easily bribed, a surprising development in a country where bribery was rare before.
Bribery begins at the border with Jordan, where a pack of Marlboro cigarettes is enough to get across without an exhaustive search. Like most Iraqis, many customs officials are hardly paid enough to eat. By all accounts, prostitution has been on the rise among the poor and middle classes, too, under the impact of deprivation.
"The gulf war has fundamentally changed the social structure," said an artist. "The middle class is wiped out. Being a doctor or an engineer means nothing anymore since you can't feed your family anymore."
Asked if this posed a threat to Mr. Hussein's rule, the artist responded: "Not necessarily, because people are terrified of what they see. If the regime falls, you can imagine the chaos that will result with the poor attacking the less poor. Nearly everybody here has arms, and the country is slipping into chaos. Sometimes I think the regime encourages the notion of a breakdown. It's like saying, 'See what could happen,' if they were no longer around."
 
The Economy
Food Is Meager And Rationed
 Much of this collapse was caused by a devastated economy. Five years ago, before the sanctions, an Iraqi dinar was worth a little more than $3. Today $1 fetches anywhere from 500 to 600 dinars. But salaries have not increased. An Iraqi engineer, doctor or government employee makes at most 3,000 to 5,000 dinars a month, or $6 to $10. Retirees live on as little as $3 a month.
The only salvation is a remarkable rationing system that guarantees a minimum of essential food every month to every Iraqi. The system was adopted after the sanctions took effect, but as the money to finance it runs out, the program has shrunk.
At his office, the Minister of Trade showed what Iraqis are entitled to since the rationing system was halved on Sept. 29. An Iraqi citizen is now given 13 pounds of wheat flour, 1.6 pounds of sugar, 1.3 pounds of cooking oil, a half pound of detergents and some rice, tea and soap.
"This is the quota for a people who are living on a lake of oil, because the United States and the United Nations will not let us sell our oil to feed our people," the Trade Minister, Saadi Mehdi Saleh, said in an interview.
Iraq takes the position that under one of several Security Council sanctions resolutions Baghdad will have the right to begin selling oil as soon as a United Nations arms monitoring system is in place and tested. Other resolutions cover more broadly Iraq's right to export and import a range of commodities.
The World Food Organization and other agencies concerned with nutrition said these quantities barely met a third of a person's nutritional requirements.
Unicef said that in the last year there has been a 9 percent rise in malnutrition among Iraqi infants. The reduction in rations "constitutes a risk for the health of 2.25 million children and 230,000 pregnant women or those breast-feeding," said Catherine Bertini, executive director of the World International Food Program in Rome, which assists Kurds in northern Iraq.
Clearly Iraq will soon be unable to provide even these meager rations. Mr. Saleh said that even the reduced amount costs the Government between $600 million and $700 million to buy on world markets every year. And, he said, Iraq is running out of the money it has stashed away to withstand the embargo.
Outside the fragile system, Iraqis are left to the vagaries of the free market. A kilogram (2.2 pounds) of meat costs 750 dinars here, and a chicken costs 650 dinars. This represents a third of an average monthly salary, so most people go without meat.
"I know too many families, middle-class families, that were considered by any standard very comfortable only four years ago, who are reduced to eating one meal a day," said Msgr. Emanuel Delli, a Patriarch of the Chaldean or Nestorian Church, to which most of the Iraq's estimated one million Christians belong. "These families have had no meat or chicken in months. They cannot afford to give their kids a sandwich to take to school."
Asked whom they blame for their plight, Monsignor Delli responded without hesitation. "Most of them consider their kids are being starved by the Americans who control the United Nations," he said.
"We are not asking for charity," he aded. "Just let us sell our oil. You cannot punish a people forever."
 
The Response
Extreme Measures Border on Absurd
 Whether people also blame Mr. Hussein's policies is hardly a subject anyone here dares to raise with a journalist, but the Government has made a show of trying to address discontent.
While blaming the United States and its gulf allies, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, Mr. Hussein is also trying to curb conspicuous consumption, largely by his own party cadres and family members. These attempts have pushed the Government to adopt extreme measures that verge on the absurd.
Scores of merchants were hanged for profiteering in a showcase crackdown against corruption. Thieves, Mr. Hussein decreed, would have their hands severed. To gain support among those seeking solace in religion, the Government has for the last year been heavily promoting Islamic culture.
Koranic lessons have been imposed in schools where they were ignored for decades. Alcohol was banned a few weeks ago, largely because members of the ruling establishment were publicly drinking whisky, a bottle of which costs the equivalent of two months' salary for most people.
Iraq has announced that it will build the world's largest mosque. The race track was closed six months ago. All public functions now start with Koranic prayers. These moves toward Islam sharply contradict the fiercely secularist intellectual platform that has been the foundation f Mr. Hussein's Baath Party rule since he took power in a coup in 1968, and many here find these gestures insincere.
Rather than directly address the crisis facing Iraq, Mr. Hussein appears at times disconnected from reality.
Just last month he promised his downtrodden subjects that he would "open the gates of the universe" to them, immediately after slashing the meager rationing system by half. He followed that by ordering his troops on Oct. 6 to move -- again -- toward the Kuwaiti border, bringing the wrath of the United States down on Iraq and postponing any possible lifting of the sanctions.
"The Romans used to say that if you want to quiet the people, give them bread and circuses," said the Iraqi intellectual who described himself as a former supporter of the Government. "Here they are giving them circuses because they can't give bread anymore."
But diplomats who closely follow the gyrations of the Government are not persuaded that they are a precursor of Mr. Hussein's downfall.
"It is always dangerous for outsiders to try and chart a change because no one really knows how it will come out," said an ambassador of an Islamic country here. "This pressure on Iraq, this barbarian policy of starving a whole population to force them into rebellion against the regime, has the contrary effect because it increases the dependence of the people on this Government. Political change is too luxurious a thought to indulge in if you are busy just surviving."

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE PRESIDENT;
Campaigning On Economy, Clinton Plays The Teacher

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CLEVELAND, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Having played to voters' emotions in a weekend of campaigning, President Clinton went for their minds today, giving a group of business people a long tutorial on the Democratic school of economic theory, complete with numbers and charts.
And like a lot of postgraduate seminars, it included some tough slogging. 
 But in the hourlong session, Mr. Clinton seemed to win over his audience by comparing his statistics -- all of them rosy -- with what he called the "proven failure" of the Reagan-style fiscal policies Republicans advocate in this campaign.
What is more, he brought the crowd to its feet with a deft rebuke of a Republican member of Congress, Martin R. Hoke of Ohio, who in a question-and-answer session after the speech tried to show that he was smarter than the professor.
Speaking to members of the City Club, a business group that sponsors speeches and political debates, Mr. Clinton presented the intellectual version of his criticism of the Republicans' "Contract With America" campaign platform.
Among other pledges, the Republicans say they will cut taxes and balance the Federal budget if voters give them control of Congress. Mr. Clinton called such statements "easy promises," and tried to make the case that his economic policies would prove more effective if voters gave him the time to carry them out.
The President loosed a deluge of numbers, led by the Treasury Department's announcement today that the Federal deficit for the fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30 was $203 billion. That is well below the $220 billion the Treasury predicted in July, and far below the $305 billion projected when Mr. Clinton took office 21 months ago.
Furthermore, Mr. Clinton said the United States led the world in automobile production for the first time since 1979; that American automobile exports to Mexico were up 500 percent since the passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement, and that, since he took office, 4.6 million new jobs had been created and private investment in new equipment had grown eightfold.
All this, Mr. Clinton said, could be attributed to the Democratic budget that Congress passed in 1993, and from his Administration's efforts to liberalize world trade, provide more education and job-training programs, help the inner cities and shrink the Federal bureaucracy. The progress, he added, "required a reversal of the policies of the last 12 years."
Mr. Clinton mocked critics of his strategy, starting with Republicans. "When the deficit reduction plan passed," he said, referring to the $450 billion of tax increases and spending cuts enacted in 1993, "there was speech after speech saying, 'Gosh, if we do this, the economy will collapse, the deficit will explode, middle-class taxpayers will be bankrupted, this will be the end of the world.' " None of that happened, the President noted.
Mr. Clinton acknowledged that many Americans still felt their lives had not improved, but for that, he blamed the uneven nature of the economic recovery and a press -- he later called it "attack journalism" -- that celebrated crisis and ignored progress.
Speaking of the Republican platform, Mr. Clinton said, "I don't think this contract is a good idea because it promises everybody a tax cut; it promises a defense increase; promises to revive Star Wars and promises to balance the budget." In contrast, he said, "the responsible thing to do is to take your licks and say, 'Look for the long run; look for the long run.' "
That set up a confrontation with Representative Hoke, who appeared after Mr. Clinton's speech. Noting that the President was on record as supporting some elements of the Republican platform, like welfare reform, the Congressman said he found it "outrageous" that Mr. Clinton had poked fun at the "Contract With America" on the campaign trail by dubbing it the "Contract on America."
"As one of its signers, your suggestion that I would take out a contract on my constituents is a suggestion that I take very, very personally," Mr. Hoke said. "At a time when the public is so concerned about violent crime, why would you resort to using such talk, in such an inflammatory way?"
Mr. Clinton seized the question to repeat his objections to the Republican platform, and to add, "I appreciate your concern about crime and violence." Then he said, "I wish you hadn't voted against the Brady Bill and the crime bill."
That brought the crowd of perhaps a thousand to its feet, and drew the loudest and most sustained applause Mr. Clinton has seen on the speech circuit in some time.

HEADLINE: Aristide Picks a Prime Minister With Free-Market Ideas

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Oct. 24

 BODY:
President Jean-Bertrand Aristide selected an American-educated commodities trader as Prime Minister today, political figures said. They saw the move as placing a strong supporter of the free market in a position to oversee the overhaul of the country's staggering economy.
President Aristide is expected to make the formal appointment of the new Prime Minister, Smarck Michel, on Tuesday. Today's action clears the way for the appointment of a new Cabinet and serves as a compromise between left-leaning figures in the Aristide Government and the business community. Business leaders have been clamoring for a Prime Minister able to oversee a new economic plan acceptable to the World Bank, International Monetary Fund and the business community here. 
 Mr. Michel's pragmatic, pro-market stance and his role as a successful businessman make him a generally palatable choice for the United States and international organizations and a reasonable selection for Haiti's elite, most political experts here agree.
Though not a technocrat, Mr. Michel is expected to be able to steer the Government as it moves to carry out a broad-reaching economic plan that includes privatizing large industries and providing much-needed jobs.
His Cabinet is expected to include people like Leslie Voltaire and Leslie Delatour, two economists who helped draw up the Government's new economic program. The current Finance Minister, Marie Michelle Rey, another architect of that plan, is also expected to assume a prominent role in the Government.
Each has been considered for importnant ministries like finance, commerce and planning, and for the central bank, people close to the Government said. The parceling those positions has not been announced.
Mr. Michel's longtime ties to President Aristide, for whom he acted as an unofficial campaign manager in 1990, make him a trustworthy ally and a reassuring choice to Aristide associates who feared the President might be forced to appoint someone far from their inner circle.
Some of President Aristide's critics, however, were quick to condemn the choice as a repetition of old mistakes. They described the selection of Mr. Michel as a short-sighted move that will allow President Aristide to exert near total control from behind the scenes. And they said they still rankle at what they described as the Aristide Government's inability to guide the country's economy during the President's eight months in office in 1991.
Mr. Michel was the Commerce Minister for the first five months of President Aristide's term. He resigned the post two months before the President was ousted in a violent coup. People close to Mr. Michel said he resigned in frustration over the Government's disorganization and what he perceived to be an unrealistic Government stance on the arbitrary lowering of food prices.
Any bitterness over that split was softened in the intervening years, however. A family member said today that the two men were in frequent contact during the President's exile. Mr. Michel denied requests for an interview. He scheduled a news conference for Tuesday. However, late this evening, when a telephone call was made to the family's house, one of Mr. Michel's daughters alluded to the volatility of the political situation here, saying, "We are still anxiously awaiting the announcement."
Mr. Michel's name was first floated as a leading candidate a week ago, but he resisted the overture and speculation shifted to Mr. Delatour, Mr. Voltaire and Mrs. Rey.
Claudette Werleigh, a more leftist-oriented Aristide loyalist who now serves as Foreign Minister, was also widely considered a contender for the post, though her more radical politics would have made that selection much more difficult at a time when all eyes are on the economy.
Last week, when President Aristide said during a news conference that he was leaning toward appointing a woman, Mrs. Werleigh and Mrs. Rey seemed the two leading candidates. Furious negotiations at the week's end, however, moved the President back toward Mr. Michel, who by then indicated he might be willing to take the post.
In the confusion that reigned in the selection process, Robert Malval, the Prime Minister appointed after the Governors Island accord with the military leaders in July 1993, was put forward. But he has often said he would not accept; his frustrations over the political situation that followed the Governors Island agreement are widely known.
Mr. Michel's position may, in fact, be short lived. According to the Constitution, the Prime Minister must come from the majority party in Parliament. With elections scheduled for later this year or early in 1995, a political shift there could mean that President Aristide will have to go through the entire process again. Even if he does not, the Government has only about 15 months to begin the task of reworking Haiti's economy. President Aristide's five-year term, which began in 1991, expires in February 1996.

HEADLINE: U.S. Weighs Sending Ambassador to Zaire, a Dictator's Fief

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire, Oct. 24

 BODY:
In a sign of support for a new Prime Minister's reform efforts in a country led by one of Africa's most corrupt and repressive governments, Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott made a brief visit here today and said Washington was considering sending an ambassador to Zaire.
Mr. Talbott, who is on a tour of several African countries, met with Prime Minister Kengo Wa Dondo during a stopover between visits to Malawi and Ghana. 
 In carefully worded comments about the visit, Mr. Talbott said United States backing for the new Prime Minister would be closely coordinated with his reform efforts and did not represent an embrace of Zaire's long-reigning dictator, Mobutu Sese Seko.
Officials in Mr. Talbott's party said Mr. Kengo could not succeed in office without a measure of support from Zaire's traditional foreign partners: the United States, Belgium and France. And if he fails, they said, Zaire, one of Africa's largest countries, with one-quarter the land mass of the United States and 41 million inhabitants, is in danger of disintegration.
"We are considering sending an ambassador, which would be a modest step," Mr. Talbott said. "After all, we have ambassadors in a lot of countries where we disagree with things happening there."
Critics of Mr. Kengo say the Prime Minister, who was appointed in July, has already twice led governments under Mr. Mobutu. In the end, they say, Mr. Kengo will prove as unwilling or unable to change Mr. Mobutu's system of tight political control as in the past.
A 1991 conference that sought unsuccessfully to organize a democratic transition in Zaire cited Mr. Kengo for large-scale embezzlement during his two previous stints as Prime Minister in the early and late 1980's. He has also been accused of playing a role in the massacre of students at Lovanium University in Zaire in 1969, when he was Justice Minister.
Mr. Talbott said that for now United States cooperation with Zaire, largely suspended after violent riots in 1991, would remain limited to relief supplies. Even diplomats who support the current opening to Zaire acknowledge that in addition to using Mr. Kengo, Mr. Mobutu has repeatedly used the tactic of presenting putatively reform-minded Prime Ministers to the West as a means of buying himself time to refill his coffers and undo his adversaries.
Western diplomats, including Mr. Talbott's delegation, credit Mr. Kengo with moves to rein in ruinous inflation and to reimpose state authority over a formal economy that has virtually ceased to exist.
Among Mr. Kengo's early reform measures has been a still-unresolved bid to remove what diplomats describe as Mobutu cronies from the Central Bank, and efforts to bring the lucrative diamond mining industry back under state control.
Mr. Mobutu has begun to emerge from his own diplomatic isolation, undertaking a trip to Japan and China in the last week and planning a visit to France next month to take part in the annual French-African summit meeting. Mr. Mobutu was banned from visiting France for more than two years after the French Ambassador to Zaire was killed in the 1991 riots.
In a brief interview at Kinshasa Airport, where he met with Mr. Talbott, Mr. Kengo pledged that he would work toward national elections sometime in the next year. "We are moving toward a rehabilitation of the economy that is capital," he said. "For this we must restore the authority of the state, restructure the army and guarantee the liberty of our citizens."

HEADLINE: U.S. Hints at Better Ties if Syria Signs Peace Pact With Israel

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren Christopher held out the prospect of improved relations with Syria today if Damascus made peace with Israel and cracked down on terrorists along Israel's northern border.
In openly broaching the idea, which could lead to a flow of Western aid to Syria, Mr. Christopher was seeking to coax Damascus to move ahead in its nearly stalled peace talks with Israel. 
 "In an environment of genuine and comprehensive peace in which there'll be no place for terrorists on Israel's borders, we can look to the day when relations between Syria and the United States will improve," said Mr. Christopher in an address at Georgetown University.
With President Clinton scheduled to visit Damascus on Wednesday as part of a trip to six countries in the Middle East, Administration officials sought today to play down the prospects of any major progress toward peace during his visit there, saying any payoff from the visit would be several months down the road. These officials said the most they expect would be some words from President Hafez al-Assad reassuring Israel that he is serious about making peace.
Mr. Christopher did not spell out what improved relations with Syria would mean, but Administration officials said one aspect might be that Washington would stop blocking loans to Damascus from the World Bank and International Monetary Fund. The officials added that the United States was unlikely to resume foreign aid to Syria because of anticipated Congressional resistance.
To improve relations, Administration officials said, Damascus must first get itself removed from the Administration's list of nations that sponsor terrorism. That would require suppressing the pro-Iranian Party of God guerrillas in Syrian-controlled Southern Lebanon as well as the Damascus-based Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine.
Administration officials said that in light of the increased insecurity caused by recent terrorism, they fear that it might take a year to seal a peace treaty between Syria and Israel. Just a few weeks ago they were saying such a treaty appeared to be a few months off.
Explaining the President's decision to visit Damascus, a senior official said, "Having the President go there gives you an opportunity you wouldn't have had to give the process a push."
In his speech, Mr. Christopher called for an international ban on financial aid to Hamas and other terrorist organizations and said he would do everything he could to make sure Hamas receives no financial support, directly or indirectly, from people in the United States.
State Department officials said Hamas was receiving millions of dollars from Americans each year. But one senior official said the Administration would seek to prevent Islamic charities that receive American donations from channeling that money to Hamas. An interagency task force is also looking into proposing legislation that would ban all donations to Hamas.
Administration officials said they would press Americans and Arab countries to cut off funds to Hamas, even though they acknowledged that Hamas was engaged in many civil activities, like building schools. A big problem, the officials said, was that Hamas mixed its money between political and military activities.
Hamas officials have claimed responsibility for several recent terrorist acts, among them kidnapping an Israeli soldier two weeks ago and bombing a bus in Tel Aviv last Wednesday, killing 23 people.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
MINNESOTA MINING & MFG. CO. (MMM,N)

 BODY:
The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings rose 7.9 percent, on strong unit sales and increased productivity.
Net income rose to $341 million, or 81 cents a share, from $316 million, or 73 cents, in the comparable period a year earlier. Sales rose 9.7 percent, to $3.82 billion, from $3.48 billion. 
 The results matched the mean estimate of 11 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research.
Minnesota Mining, which is based in St. Paul and makes Post-It Notes, Scotch tape, sandpaper, floppy disks for computers and audio tapes, said unit volumes increased about 9 percent in the United States and 11 percent internationally.
"We continued to see strong volume gains in Latin America and in most countries and Asia," said L. D. DeSimone, the chairman and chief executive, adding that he expected continued increases in earnings in the fourth quarter.
"We expect to benefit from a strong flow of new products, a sharp focus on customer satisfaction, continuous productivity improvement and continued strengthening of the European economies," he said.

HEADLINE: Andrew D. Kopkind, Writer on Politics And Editor, 59

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

 BODY:
Andrew D. Kopkind, a political journalist whose work appeared in The New Republic, The New York Review of Books and The Nation, died on Sunday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 59 and had homes in Manhattan and Guilford, Vt.
The cause was bladder cancer, said JoAnn Wypijewski, the managing editor of The Nation. 
 Mr. Kopkind was born in New Haven, Conn., and had degrees from Cornell University and the London School of Economics. He began his career at The Washington Post, then was a reporter at Time magazine. In 1965 he joined the staff of The New Republic, covering the civil rights movement and the birth of the New Left on college campuses. He was also the American correspondent for The New Statesman in London.
In 1968 he and James Ridgeway founded the underground newspaper Mayday (later renamed Hard Times), which covered the antiwar, black-power and student movements. He also wrote about the Vietnam War in the magazine Ramparts, where he was a contributing editor.
In the 1970's, Mr. Kopkind also wrote for The Village Voice, The Boston Phoenix and The Real Paper in Boston. Many of his articles dealt with the emerging gay-rights movement. With John Scagliotti, he was the host of "Lavender Hour," a gay radio program on WBCN in Boston.
In 1982, he joined the staff of The Nation, where he wrote many of the magazine's unsigned editorials, as well as articles on politics and foreign policy.
He wrote "America: The Mixed Curse" (1969) and, with Mr. Ridgeway, he edited "Decade of Crisis: America in the 60's" (1972). At the time of his death, he was working on "The Thirty Years' Wars," a collection of his journalism, to be published by Verso next year.
He is survived by Mr. Scagliotti, his companion of 24 years.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: New York's Top Judge Plans Overhaul of the Juror System

BYLINE: By JAN HOFFMAN 

 BODY:
In a major overhaul of New York's jury system, the state's top judge announced a package of revisions yesterday aimed at making jury service more bearable -- tours of duty would be shorter, deliberation rooms cleaner, clerks less snappish.
"We cannot ask jurors to perform their civic responsibility in dilapidated surroundings using outmoded procedures," said Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye in unveiling the state courts' first major changes in the jury system since 1977. 
 Some are to begin immediately, with others to be put in place throughout next year. Among the most dramatic is a plan to test a system in January that would speed jury selection, in part by putting time limits on questioning. In addition, prospective jurors in most counties outside New York City would be sent home after one day unless picked for a trial.
Other changes include using defendants sentenced to community service and parolees to augment court-cleaning crews, a plan recently put in practice in courts in lower Manhattan; training in civility for clerks and others who deal with jurors, and adding a voluntary question about race and ethnicity on juror questionnaires to help determine whether minorities are receiving and responding to the forms.
Judge Kaye said the changes were intended to expand the jury pools, shrink the length of service and make that service not only less onerous but also a more efficient use of the juror's time.
The changes amount to a virtual wholesale adoption of recommendations contained in a March report by a statewide panel that excoriated the conditions under which jurors are summoned and serve.
Judge Kaye has the authority to institute many of the reforms announced yesterday under the administrative rules of New York's court system. But another set of changes that she proposed requires legislative approval and seems guaranteed to meet resistance. One would eliminate nearly 20 professions currently exempt from jury service, including lawyers, podiatrists and embalmers. The judge also wants to cut back costly sequestering of juries and raise jurors' compensation, from $15 a day, to $40, the rate paid to jurors in Federal courts.
The judge is also asking for a reduction in the number of challenges that lawyers can use to reject jurors. The challenges now allowed -- 20 for murder, for example -- are among the highest in the country.
"Some of the changes are state of the art," said G. Thomas Munsterman, director of the Center for Jury Studies at the National Center for State Courts, "and others are state of the nation."
Mr. Munsterman said some of the changes, like exit surveys for all jurors and a phone number, (800) NYJUROR, for complaints (and the longed-for compliment), put New York at the forefront of jury reform. He also cited the state's efforts to diversify the jury pool: last summer the State Legislature added lists of people receiving unemployment benefits and public assistance to juror eligibility rolls. Those rolls are already drawn from lists of taxpayers, voters and licensed drivers.
But the one-day-or-one-trial requirement is widespread outside New York State, he said.
That program is already being used in some New York counties. By the start of 1995, Judge Kaye said, all counties except for the four busiest New York City boroughs -- Manhattan, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens -- will ask jurors to be on call for a week. If not selected for a jury after a day's appearance, they will be dismissed; after finishing a trial, regardless of how short, they can also go home. Now, in some counties, jurors have to sit in courts for up to two weeks.
But to keep jury service short, more bodies are needed, the Chief Judge said. To insure greater compliance on juror summonses, a second notice will be sent out if a form has not been returned within six weeks.
Judge Kaye, who has made jury reform a top priority during her first year and a half as Chief Judge, has also declared war on decrepit juror rooms -- broken chairs, poor heating, peeling paint. In the last year, she apportioned $750,000 for sprucing them up. Yesterday, she announced that crews of parolees and defendants sentenced to community service had begun cleaning up courts in lower Manhattan this fall and that in January more crews would tackle the Brooklyn courts.
Some of the most substantive changes will affect juries in civil cases. New York, Mr. Munsterman of the Center for Jury Studies, in Williamsburg, Va., said, is the only state in which civil lawyers are allowed to select juries free of judicial scrutiny. Jurors complain that the unsupervised lawyers ask intrusive questions and can hold them captive for hours. Then, because lawyers use the threat of a jury verdict as a weapon over their opponents, many cases are settled after a jury is picked but before the first witness is called.
Under Judge Kaye's changes, a pilot project beginning in January in four civil courts around the state, including Manhattan's, will install judges to oversee questioning. The judges will order mandatory settlement conferences just before jury selection begins and give the lawyers time limits on questioning.
Stephan H. Peskin, the immediate past president of the New York State Trial Lawyers Association, said that in theory the plan sounded good but that "the definition of the judge's supervision is unclear." He said he was concerned that some judges might want to dominate the questioning.
The legislative proposals will be a tough sell. Currently, lawyers can excuse prospective jurors either because they have an obvious bias or because the lawyer has a hunch that the juror could not be impartial. In the most serious criminal cases, lawyers on each side get up to 20 chances to exercise that hunch, called a peremptory challenge.
To make proceedings more efficient, Judge Kaye wants to reduce the peremptory challenges. But G. Robert Witmer Jr., president of the New York State Bar Association, said the opposite result would occur. "Lawyers will be forced to take more time to find a good cause to reject someone they feel but can't demonstrate is not impartial," he said.
An important inducement to assure juror response to summonses would be to raise compensation. While court officials privately conceded that it was unlikely that they would be able to increase jurors' daily pay to as much as $40, they expressed hope that incremental raises would be possible.
Earlier bills in the Legislature to eliminate mandatory sequestering of jurors as well as exempting certain professionals have failed. But E. Leo Milonas, the chief administrative judge, gives these renewed efforts a fighting chance.
The courts spend $4 million a year to house and feed jurors and pay overtime for court officers, Judge Milonas said. "But it's about more than saving money," he said. "More people would serve if they could go home at the end of the day."
As for eliminating occupational exemptions, Judge Milonas said New York had more exemptions than almost any other state. "At least we might be able to narrow the list," he said. The current proposal would abolish exemptions for every job category except judges.

HEADLINE: The Rivlin Memo and Fiscal Honesty

 BODY:
Newt Gingrich, the House Republican whip, raised political hypocrisy to new levels this weekend when, citing a leaked White House memo, he accused Democrats of threatening Social Security and Medicare. This from the author of a "Contract With America" -- which, by pledging to whack a trillion dollars out of the Federal budget, would virtually guarantee huge cuts in entitlements.
The decision by the memo's author, Budget Director Alice Rivlin, to put budget options in writing during election season may not have been the brightest political move. But at least she, unlike Mr. Gingrich, tried honestly to confront the nation's fiscal problems. 
 The Federal deficit is expected to rise from about $170 billion next year to about $235 billion by the end of the decade. That would keep the deficit at about 2.5 percent of gross national product, which many economists do not find worrisome. The deficit problem does become threatening after 2010, when it should begin to rise to about 6 percent of G.N.P. Even this level would not hurt the economy if the extra Federal borrowing were devoted to investments like schools, telecommunications and transportation.
But Ms. Rivlin fears the borrowing will siphon money away from capital markets, and thereby from private investment, in order to pay for what she fears would be Congressional frivolities. She favors budget surpluses so that U.S. saving rises closer to the rates of other industrialized countries.
Her memo outlines, without recommendations, dozens of ways to reduce the long-term deficit. For example, it estimates the budgetary savings of limiting cost-of-living allowances for Social Security beneficiaries, cutting tax deductions for mortgage interest on second homes, taxing capital gains (profit on investments) of deceased investors, imposing a national sales tax, eliminating tax deductions for state and local taxes. Her memo also outlines ways to cut taxes on middle-class families. Mr. Gingrich did not emphasize those options.
Ms. Rivlin knew such ideas were incendiary, so she retrieved copies of the memo she distributed at a White House gathering. Apparently, someone -- a senior Administration official, according to William Kristol of the Project for the Republican Future -- leaked a draft copy to Republicans. Mr. Gingrich pounced.
Ms. Rivlin may exaggerate the benefit of deficit cutting -- especially since Congress would probably achieve the goal by eviscerating job retraining, research and development, infrastructure and other valuable investment. But when government, and business, are accused of economic myopia, she deserves credit for taking the long view. Her options include modest ways to control the rate of growth of entitlements; she outlines no bloodletting.
As the Social Security Trust Fund runs dry and health expenditures of an aging population soar, Congress will have to cut spending or raise taxes sooner or later. Made sooner, the cuts need hammer no one hard. Made later, they will hurt.
The political fallout of Mr. Gingrich's opportunistic barrage is that he and a defensive President Clinton have now launched tit-for-tat promises to voters that they would, for example, unalterably oppose touching Social Security or Medicare, even for the rich. By ruling huge chunks of the budget undiscussable -- and ridiculing a public official who dared face unpleasant facts -- Washington threatens to smother serious debate.
