HEADLINE: Indecent Proposition in California

 BODY:
If the polls are right, a mean-spirited, impractical and probably unconstitutional California ballot initiative is headed for easy victory Nov. 8.
Proposition 187 would deny public education, non-emergency medical care and other state and locally funded benefits to illegal aliens. Gov. Pete Wilson has made support for Proposition 187 a central theme of his re-election campaign. The Republican senatorial challenger, Michael Huffington, also backs the measure. 
 Mr. Wilson's Democratic challenger, Kathleen Brown, opposes it, as does Mr. Huffington's opponent, Senator Dianne Feinstein, President Clinton and two leading conservative Republicans, former Education Secretary William Bennett and former Housing Secretary Jack Kemp.
Proposition 187, named "Save Our State" by its proponents, is based on the premise that California's social services are the main magnet drawing illegal immigrants across the border. Turning off that magnet, they argue, will deter new arrivals.
But no matter how harsh benefit policies become, the lure of California's jobs and wages are likely to keep attracting Mexicans, Central Americans and others over the border and keep most of the 1.5 million illegal aliens now estimated to be in the state from voluntarily returning home.
Interestingly enough, when he was a Senator in 1986, Mr. Wilson fought hard for a provision in that year's immigration law that let hundreds of thousands of aliens enter the U.S. for temporary farm harvest jobs. A fair number presumably stayed on to become today's illegals.
Illegal aliens, by definition, have no legal right to be in the U.S. Failures in Federal immigration policy and enforcement put a fiscal burden on the handful of states where most of these people settle, like California and New York. This burden is partly offset by the economic contributions alien workers make and mitigated by the fact that illegal aliens cannot lawfully receive most welfare benefits. But they are constitutionally entitled, according to a 1982 Supreme Court decision, to a public education for their children, and they can now receive medical treatment at publicly funded facilities.
These benefits cost state taxpayers money. But the right answer is not to throw alien children and the ill onto the streets. It is to increase Federal aid to compensate states for the consequences of Federal immigration policies. Yet Senator Feinstein now warns that the punitive provisions of Proposition 187 could lead Washington to cut off as much as $15 billion in health and education aid.
Politicians supporting Proposition 187 concede that portions of it may be unconstitutional under current Supreme Court rulings. But they hope its passage could trigger a court fight to overturn those rulings. Even if successful, that legal fight could cost California taxpayers plenty.
Ms. Feinstein opposes Proposition 187 on pragmatic and financial grounds. Ms. Brown opposes it on humanitarian principle. Mr. Bennett and Mr. Kemp cite traditional conservative support for economic opportunity and opposition to Big Brother intrusiveness.
Governor Wilson brushes off such criticisms and has effectively used the illegal alien issue, which he links to fears about crime and jobs, to revive his campaign. The polls, which once showed him more than 20 points behind, now have him more than 10 points ahead. He is again being talked about as a 1996 Presidential contender.
Whatever his other merits, his handling of this issue should give pause to conservatives and liberals alike.

HEADLINE: Yield on the Long Bond Ends the Day Above 8%

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell in light trading yesterday, with the yield on the long bond ending at more than 8 percent after toying with that significant threshold for two weeks.
A weak dollar and apprehension ahead of the Government's report on Friday on the gross domestic product helped to drag bond prices down. 
 A supply of new Government securities this week is also weighing on prices. The Treasury is selling $55.45 billion in new bills and notes this week. With that much paper to sell, traders said, dealers may want to make yields more attractive to customers by lowering prices.
In when-issued trading ahead of today's two-year note auction, the two-year was being offered at a price to yield 6.87 percent and the five-year was being offered at a price to yield 7.52 percent. The yield on the two-year note is up 6 basis points from Friday, and the yield on five-year note is up 7 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 23/32 to 9329/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 8.04 percent, up from 7.97 percent on Friday and the highest since April 29, 1992, when it was 8.05 percent. At the Treasury's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills yesterday, rates rose to their highest levels in three years.
With bond yields as high as they are now, fixed-income products are now more attractive to investors, Charles Roden, managing director and head of fixed-income investing for Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said.
"Our fixed-income desk is starting to get busy again, people are fishing more for better returns," he said. In the municipal market where investors are waiting for even higher yields, they are already attractive.
"Those who run portfolios are hurriedly reassessing their positions," Mr. Roden said. "The long end of the market is higher than where I thought it would be months ago."
Chris Moore, a fixed-income analyst for Technical Data in Boston, said: "The $64 question now is how far will rates have to go where they will start to affect business. Right now you can ask 10 people and you'll get 10 different answers."
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said on CNN yesterday that the economy was robust, but that he saw no signs of inflation. Some traders said his comments heightened speculation about whether the Federal Reserve would move soon on interest rates after strong economic news and hints of inflation last week.
"Recent economic releases require market participants to anticipate a strong G.D.P. number later this week and that will keep the market on the defensive," Mr. Moore of Technical Data said. "The strength of the economy has most market participants anticipating at least one more Fed tightening before the year's end; the market has taken that anticipation as an excuse to sell bonds."
The market appears to be split on whether the Fed will move on interest rates this week. Some traders and analysts say the chances of a move before the Fed's policy-making committee meets on Nov. 15 are slim.
In other trading yesterday, the Manhattan Card Company, a Hong Kong-based subsidiary of the Chase Manhattan Bank, sold $200 million worth of certificates backed by credit card assets.
The offering was the first time in which credit card receivables originating from Hong Kong have been sold as securities in the United States.
The certificates were priced at par with a floating rate coupon of 25 basis points more than the one-month London interbank offered rate, or Libor. The certificates have an average life of 4.91 years. The deal is being managed by Chase Securities.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
Markets
 Stocks slumped, weighed down by higher interest rates and a weak dollar. The S.& P. 500 fell 4.06 points. [Page D1.] 
 Gasoline prices surged on signs that supplies in the Northeast were being curtailed by two pipeline explosions. [D17.]
 The dollar was weaker against most leading currencies. [D17.]
 The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond finished above 8 percent, at the highest level in two and a half years. [D18.]
 
The Economy
 The prohibition of penalties for paying off mortgages early raises the loans' costs, housing finance experts say. Lenders charge higher rates and fees on new mortgages with no prepayment penalty because it is not clear when the mortgages will be repaid. Such fees weigh heaviest on low-income home buyers. [D1.]
 A global credit crunch could keep interest rates high for the next several years. Federal Reserve officials, who have been trying to hold down rates in the United States, see that their efforts may be thwarted by an unusual convergence of global trends. [D1.]
 The S.E.C. is seeking to revamp the municipal bond market. The agency hopes new regulations will make the market look more like the stock or corporate bond markets. [D1.]
 The Houston Ship Channel reopened after flood debris was cleared from one of the nation's busiest ports. [A16.]
 Microbrewing is rapidly expanding in the New York region. [B1.]
 
Companies
 Piper Jaffray said it would pump $5 million into a mutual fund, the American Adjustable Rate Term Trust fund. [D2.]
 The trial of General Electric on charges that it helped fix prices of industrial diamonds is getting under way. [D2.]
 Du Pont, Shell and Hoechst Celanese will pay at least $750 million to settle a class-action lawsuit stemming from the use of plastic pipes in six million homes in the United States. [D4.]
 Exxon, Amoco and ARCO showed strong quarterly gains from their chemical businesses and from higher crude oil prices. [D4.]
 Cisco Systems agreed to acquire Kalpana, a computer switching company, in a stock swap valued at $204 million. [D4.]
 Two tobacco processing giants agreed to merge. Dibrell Brothers and Monk-Austion will form a $1.4-billion company. [D4.]
 Intel and CNN will offer a service that allows business personal computer users to view news broadcasts on their screens. [D4.]
 To rejuvenate its management ranks, Toyota Motor will set age limits for managers of certain positions. [D16.]
 In a sign of more turmoil at at Time Warner's music group, Lenny Waronker, the president of Warner Brothers Records, said he would not succeed the group's chairman, Mo Ostin. [D20.]
 Barry Diller warned magazine executives at an industry conference to slow their rush to new electronic media. [D20.]
 
Today's Columns
 The key to saving USAir lies with its pilots. Without concessions from the pilots, the carrier seems headed for a bankruptcy filing. But there are many reasons the pilots will probably blink first and help reduce USAir's costs. Market Place. [D1.]
 The managers of Ayer are trying to overhaul the big agency by seeking a medium-sized identity. One sign of change is a new name: N. W. Ayer & Partners. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D20.]

HEADLINE: A Mortgage Penalty, or a Plus?

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT 

 BODY:
What sounds like a consumer-friendly provision -- the prohibition in many states of penalties for homeowners who pay off their mortgages early -- actually raises the cost of mortgages, experts in housing finance say. And that has the effect of forcing low-income home buyers to subsidize high-income home buyers, they add.
The problem, the experts say, is that lenders demand higher interest rates and higher fees on new mortgages with no prepayment penalty because they are not sure how soon the mortgage will be repaid. So all the homeowners who never pay off mortgages early, because they did not move or refinance, wind up paying for a benefit they do not use. 
 A few lenders, including Bank of America, the nation's second-largest bank, and Home Savings of America, California's largest savings institution, are offering mortgages with prepayment penalties. In exchange for giving up the right to repay their mortgage at any time, borrowers get various combinations of a lower interest rate or lower fees.
But most other lenders, including Countrywide Credit Industries of Pasadena, Calif., the nation's largest issuer of home mortgages, do not offer mortgages with prepayment penalties. Bank of America and Home Savings can offer the unusual mortgages because California is not one of the 12 states that ban the practice.
In California, more than $5 billion of mortgages issued by the Bank of America last year, for more than 30,000 homes, included a penalty if they were prepaid within three years of issuance. Those home buyers chose an option, which for a $150,000 loan would require them to pay a penalty of about $2,400 if they repaid the loan within three years, but eliminated $3,003 of cash payments required at closing. In other cases, homeowners accepting a penalty clause received an interest rate three-quarters of 1 percent below the rate of mortgages with no prepayment penalty.
"Low- and moderate-income families have told us over and over again that the biggest problem in obtaining a mortgage is accumulating the cash they need at closing," said Sylvia L. Reynolds, senior vice president at Bank of America. For loans with prepayment penalties, the bank can afford to eliminate fees it normally charges when a mortgage is issued, she said, because it can be more confident that the loan will be outstanding long enough to earn a profit. If the loan is prepaid, then the bank collects a penalty of 2 percent of 80 percent of the loan amount.
Experts say the burden of fees charged by lenders when loans are issued is heaviest on low-income borrowers, often members of minority groups. "The rules of the mortgage market, with the near-total ban on prepayment penalties, amount to more than just a subsidy of the wealthier borrowers by the poorer; it is one of the reasons that restrict poor people from getting a mortgage in the first place," said Peter Chinloy, a professor of real estate at American University in Washington.
Mr. Chinloy said poor people, particularly those of racial minorities, are less likely to prepay their mortgages because they have fewer opportunities to shift jobs or move to new homes.
Of course, the right to repay old, high-interest-rate mortgages with a new, lower-interest mortgage -- without any penalty -- has proved to be a tremendous benefit to millions of homeowners, particularly those with fixed-rate mortgages. The lower interest payments on new mortgages left homeowners with more money to spend elsewhere and helped pull the economy out of its downturn earlier in this decade.
The lack of prepayment penalties also helps homeowners with adjustable-rate mortgages who benefit from lower interest rates without refinancing, but who decide to pay off a mortgage early for other reasons, like moving to a different neighborhood, buying a bigger home or getting a divorce. The prepayment penalty only applies to payments that exceed 20 percent of the mortgage in a single year, and thus does not affect those mortgage holders who make small additional payments to reduce their principal. The prepayment penalties also generally expire after three years.
But for all the homeowners who have not refinanced their mortgage to take advantage of lower interest rates or because they wanted to move, the higher rates and fees on mortgages that lack prepayment penalties force them to pay for a provision that provides no benefit.
"If people were offered loans with prepayment penalties they might well want to opt for them because they could get a lower interest rate," said Robert Van Order, chief economist at the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac. "As a general principle, prepayment penalties ought to be allowed."
Mr. Van Order said borrowers in minority neighborhoods could be among the greatest beneficiaries of loans with prepayment penalties because studies by his agency have found that mortgage loans in such neighborhoods are prepaid only about 75 percent as often as in white neighborhoods.
One big roadblock to widespread use of loans with prepayment penalties is that at least 12 states prohibit them. To simplify record-keeping, the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, and Freddie Mac adopted a ban long ago on prepayment penalties as a standard part of the mortgage contracts they buy.
A recent article in the Journal of Housing Research, written by Mr. Chinloy and Isaac F. Megbolugbe, director of housing research at Fannie Mae, noted that standards for mortgages eligible for purchase by either Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac amount to a "de facto prohibition against prepayment penalties."
Both agencies, which specialize in buying mortgages and repackaging them as securities, have talked with lenders about changing their policies to more readily accept mortgages with prepayment penalties. But interest in that change declined sharply when interest rates began rising earlier this year, and, for now, neither agency encourages lenders to offer home mortgages with prepayment penalties.
Ms. Reynolds of Bank of America noted that the new generation of prepayment penalties was much different from the older penalties that angered enough state legislators to bring on the bans. In the past, she noted, prepayment penalties were included in loans with no compensation to borrowers in the form of lower interest rates or lower fees, and the penalties were even charged to borrowers who had been paying off their loans for decades.
The absence of prepayment penalties on loans that are packaged as securities has not gone unnoticed by investors. In periods of falling interest rates, such as the early 1990's, they lost hundreds of millions of dollars because the mortgage-backed securities they held melted away when homeowners refinanced their old mortgages and the securities backing those mortgages were retired years sooner than expected.
Because of that risk, lenders and investors in mortgage securities require higher interest rates than if the mortgage loans were not prepayable. Mr. Chinloy and Mr. Megbolugbe estimated that the higher interest rate required as compensation for the risk of prepayment is about 63-hundredths of a percentage point for fixed-rate 30-year mortgages and seven-tenths of a percentage point for 15-year mortgages.
Despite that extra cost, organizations that help low-income families obtain mortgages are not proponents of mortgages with prepayment penalties.
Bruce Dorpalen, national director of the loan counseling program of Acorn, an organization that has often pushed for more lending in minority neighborhoods, said the low-income people whom his organization helps in obtaining mortgages hold their loans longer than the general public. But even so, he said, Acorn has not pushed any of the nearly 50 lenders with whom it works closely to modify their mortgages to offer lower interest rates and fees in exchange for some prepayment penalties.
In the Journal of Housing Policy, Mr. Chinloy and Mr. Megbolugbe concluded that greater flexibility in mortgages could help make the loans more affordable and available to low-income home buyers. They suggested that lenders develop mortgages for low-income borrowers with prepayment penalties, and use some of the savings to buy additional default insurance, since the risk of default is one of the primary reasons low-income borrowers are denied mortgages.

HEADLINE: Stocks Fall As Rates Exceed 8%

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market faltered again yesterday as long-term interest rates punched past 8 percent, after flirting with that psychologically important level for three weeks.
The Dow fell 36.00 points to 3,855.30, while the broader S.& P. 500 declined 4.06 points to 460.83. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 4.17 points to 761.21. 
 The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond finished at 8.04 percent, the highest close since April 29, 1992, and the first time long-term interest rates have ended the trading day above 8 percent since April 30, 1992. [Page D18.]
Stocks faltered despite higher operating earnings at Caterpillar and Exxon, both component stocks for both the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500. The dollar did not help. Its continuing fall in international markets has discouraged foreigners from buying American securities.
And stocks slumped in advance of important economic data and Government bond sales this week. September existing-home sales are due today, durable-goods orders tomorrow and the Commerce Department's initial estimate of third-quarter economic growth on Friday.
Also, more than $55 billion in Treasury bills and notes are to be auctioned this week, and uncertainty is apparent.
"Normally, you'd expect money to start flowing from stocks to bonds because the yields are so nice," said David Holt, market strategist for Wedbush Morgan in Los Angeles. "But money's perceptive these days. Why buy now when sheer momentum might get you 8.1 percent next week?"
Terrence Crowe, vice president-fixed income arbitrage at Nikko Securities International, said portfolio managers had been hurt so badly in the bond market this year that when a large fund decided not to buy bonds, it often waited for six months or longer.
"It will take more than 8 percent to change the environment," Mr. Crowe said. "It will take soft economic news and some indication that the Fed has stopped tightening."
A key indicator will be bond traders' reception today of the Treasury Department's $17 billion auction of two-year notes, Mr. Crowe said. How they price that issue will indicate how high the Federal Reserve is expected to raise short-term interest rates in the near future.
If, as seems likely, the yield for the notes is 6.87 percent, that would indicate a premium of more than 2 percentage points over the current Federal Funds rate of 4.75 percent -- an unusually high gap, he said.
That would mean that bond traders were already pricing the two-year notes on the assumption that the Fed will raise its short-term interest rate target to at least 5.25 percent, and perhaps higher. The Fed's next policy meeting is set for Nov. 15, but it could act even sooner, some analysts say.
Stock traders are in a bind. Earnings are better than ever, but the strong economy that produced those earnings is alarming the bond market with inflation fears and scaring the few bond buyers remaining.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was normal with 287.64 million shares changing hands, close to this year's average of 288 million shares. Two stocks declined for every one that rose, or 1,537 losers compared to 698 advancers.
The stock slump came when the New York Stock Exchange established a trading record: the total dollar value of trading to date hit $2 trillion yesterday, fully 17 trading days ahead of the date last year when dollar volume hit that level.
The notable stocks were all related to quarterly earnings reports. Caterpillar rose 1 7/8 to 58 1/4 after the maker of heavy equipment, a favorite cyclical stock, announced third quarter operating profits that beat Wall Street estimates. US Healthcare rose 1 3/4 to 47 after the healthcare company reported sharply higher quarterly earnings.
But not every company with strong earnings was rewarded. Exxon fell 3/8 to 59 1/2 after reporting earnings far ahead of analysts' estimates. But analysts questioned profit margins at key subsidiaries. And Airborne Freight fell 6 3/8 to 19 1/8 when it surprised analysts with a 23 percent decline in quarterly profit.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 2.09 points to 253.5, and the American Stock Exchange market value index fell 2.62 points to 453.73.
Of the 30 stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 20 fell, led by Aluminum Company of America, which was off 2 1/2, to 86 1/4, after a Paine Webber analyst cut his recommendation to neutral from buy. Of the 500 component stocks of the S.& P. 500, 340 fell, led by Coca-Cola, which lost 7/8, closing at 49 3/8, on unconfirmed speculation that it would buy Snapple Beverage. Snapple, in turn, was the most-active stock, at 8.7 million shares; it fell 7/16 to 14 1/4.

HEADLINE: Higher Rates Worldwide Seen by Fed

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Federal Reserve officials, struggling to hold down long-term interest rates in the United States, are increasingly convinced that an unusual convergence of global trends may keep rates high around the world for the next several years.
They and officials at the Treasury Department note that Western Europe and Japan have begun moving simultaneously out of recessions while output in many developing countries expands briskly. In growing economies, the demand for capital to invest in new factories or homes tends to outstrip growth in the money available for lending. This pushes up interest rates as people compete to borrow money. 
 While there have been other periods in recent history when many economies have grown simultaneously, notably in the late 1980's, these officials in Washington fear that holding down long-term interest rates now may be especially difficult. They point to declining savings rates around the world; sharp growth in developing countries that are beginning to borrow large sums, and more government borrowing in many countries, where deficits are growing.
Taken together, these trends are pushing up what economists refer to as real interest rates -- the interest rate that lenders actually expect to receive after subtracting expected inflation, which erodes the value of debt repayments.
To be sure, the position of the Federal Reserve is politically convenient, allowing it to avoid responsibility for the rise in long-term rates so far this year. The Fed's reasoning also provides a possible justification for raising short-term rates, which would tend to support the value of the dollar in international currency markets and help the United States compete for scarce capital.
The American officials also make clear that their views are based on economic theory, not always a reliable predictor of behavior. And any number of unexpected events, like a sudden craze across the industrial world for eliminating government budget deficits, could alter the outcome American economists foresee.
Private economists and analysts generally agree with the prediction of higher rates but differ about the reasons. Most concur that strong growth globally will tend to make investment capital scarcer. But some doubt that developing countries, particularly China, will absorb as much investment as the Administration in particular expects.
Barton M. Biggs of Morgan Stanley & Company, one of the more influential voices on Wall Street, wrote last month in a newsletter that as pension and mutual funds become more common in developing countries, "huge amounts of money will move into formal savings through financial assets in the next 20 years, facilitating investments to make the world economy grow faster."
Allen Sinai, the chief economist at Lehman Brothers, said interest rates might also be rising because of the Fed's own difficulties in convincing financial markets, which determine long-term rates, that inflation is under control.
But Mr. Sinai agreed with the concerns of the Fed and the Treasury about the effect on interest rates of a global economic recovery. "There is a worldwide synchronous business expansion of unknown scope that is emerging, and the heart of that expansion will come in 1995 and 1996," he said.
Because financial markets in various countries are incompletely linked, a trend toward higher interest rates in China or other countries would tend to push up American interest rates but not assure this. Higher interest rates make borrowing more expensive for American consumers, businesses and the Federal Government, which pays interest on the national debt.
Lawrence H. Summers, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, said that real long-term interest rates were likely to be 1.5 percentage points higher around the world in the 1990's than they have been for the last four decades.
Lawrence B. Lindsey, a governor of the Federal Reserve, said a clear pattern seemed to have emerged. "As long as you have depressed savings, high fiscal deficits around the world, new investment opportunities around the world, you will have high real interest rates," he said.
But Mr. Summers, Mr. Lindsey and other senior officials made clear that they were expressing views based on economic theory, and they did not try to make any specific interest rate forecasts.
Not one of the trends now visible is entirely new, but all are reaching levels that make them harder to ignore. According to the International Monetary Fund, for instance, companies and individuals in industrial countries have reduced their savings over the last five years, to 19.4 percent of economic output from 21.4 percent.
At the same time, governments in industrial countries have more than doubled their borrowing to about 4.5 percent of economic output. Companies and individuals who want to make productive new investments like the construction of factories and the purchase of equipment, must pay ever higher interest rates as they bid against each other to borrow from a shrinking pool of savings that governments are draining at an accelerating rate.
To be sure, the I.M.F. figures predict some expansion in savings this year and next year and a modest reduction in government borrowing, as economic growth puts more money in people's pockets and reduces the cost of certain social programs, like unemployment insurance.
But because demand for investment money tends to grow faster than savings in a growing economy, I.M.F. officials are not reassured.
"The world savings and investment situation has, by and large, deteriorated over the last decade to 15 years," said Michael L. Mussa, the International Monetary Fund's research director. "Investment worldwide is competing for a smaller pool of savings than used to be the case."
Another trend that is not new -- but that is beginning to concern American officials -- is the demand for loans and investment from China, Eastern Europe and the former Soviet republics. This demand has been growing rapidly for several years, and was easily accommodated until now only because many Western economies were growing slowly.
Concern about an international shortage of savings relative to investment, and a resulting rise in interest rates, is not limited to American officials. Top finance officials from many countries expressed the same concerns at the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank in Madrid earlier this month, although Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen was the most outspoken on the subject.
"There is concern about the rise in real long-term interest rates," Mr. Bentsen said in Madrid on Oct. 1. "To some extent, it's caused by an increasing gap between what is being saved around the world and investment because of the growing demand for investment capital in many areas."
Mr. Bentsen called for finance officials from 10 large industrial democracies to study the issue in the coming months.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chemicals Units Lift Oil Concerns

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
Exxon, Amoco and ARCO said yesterday that their earnings from operations rose in the third quarter because of a resurgence of their chemical businesses and higher prices for their crude oil.
All three companies, however, had a decline in refining operations because of lower gasoline prices as the industry, preparing to begin refining reformulated gasolines that must be shipped in December, flooded the market with old fuel to reduce inventories. 
 The Exxon Corporation, based in Irving, Tex., reported net income of $1.16 billion, or 92 cents a share, down from $1.36 billion, or $1.09 a share, in the third quarter the previous year. Exxon's earnings were up 10 percent for the current period when $306 million of special items in the previous year's third quarter are excluded. Revenues were $29.6 billion, up from $27.9 billion.
Exxon said it had filed motions to overturn the verdict in the Exxon Valdez oil spill trial, which resulted in an award of $5 billion in punitive damages in September. The company said it had not taken a charge in the quarter related to the verdict "since it is impossible to estimate what the ultimate impact will be."
The Amoco Corporation, based in Chicago, had net earnings of $445 million, or 89 cents a share, for the third quarter, down from $520 million, or $1.05 share, in the corresponding period the previous year.
The results included charges of $32 million for future costs to comply with environmental regulations, while the previous year's quarter included a gain of $70 million for the sale of properties in Canada and tax adjustments. When the special items are eliminated, third-quarter earnings this year rose 7 percent.
Revenues totaled $7.78 billion, up from $7.072 billion last year.
ARCO reported net earnings of $435 million, or $2.67 a share in the third quarter, up sharply from $68 million, or 42 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier.
The company, based in Los Angeles, was aided by about $200 million from the sale of part of its gas business. The period a year earlier included charges of $115 million attributed to increases in taxes and charges for litigation. Without the special items, earnings were up 29.5 percent for the third quarter.
Sales for the third quarter fell to $4.4 billion, down from $4.7 billion.
John Hervey, an oil analyst for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said that while most oil companies showed lower earnings in refining, they had better results in exploration and production, where they were helped by an increase in crude oil prices.
He said that Exxon, Amoco and ARCO, which have large chemical businesses, were greatly helped by a strong recovery in the chemical industry. "It's surprising how quickly it has recovered," he said of the industry, which he said has been helped by a strengthening economy.
Ashland Oil Inc., of Ashland, Ky., also reported earnings yesterday. Ashland, which buys most of its oil and is heavily dependent on refining and selling gasoline, said that lower gasoline prices caused its fiscal fourth quarter net income to fall 8.9 percent to $61 million from the period a year earlier. Excluding special items, income was up 14 percent.
On the New York Stock Exchange, Exxon shares fell 37.5 cents to $59.50; Amoco rose 12.5 cents to $60; ARCO gained 12.5 cents to $101.875, and Ashland dropped $1 to $37.50.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off as Traders Focus On Fall in Stocks and Bonds

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar drifted broadly lower in thin trading yesterday as the bond market weakened and traders concluded that Washington was unlikely to intervene to support the currency.
With no fresh economic data or news to drive the market, currency dealers focused on slumping prices for American securities, a trend that has ground the dollar lower for most of this year. Dealers often follow the bond and stock markets as a gauge of foreign investors' demand for American assets and the dollars needed to buy them. 
 A weak auction of Treasury securities yesterday and concerns that the United States Government's report on Friday on third-quarter economic growth would show a stronger-than-expected expansion prompted inflation-wary bond traders to sell, driving stock prices down.
"The dollar is following bonds, it's that simple," said David Solin, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics.
Currency market participants said the dollar's failure to continue higher after Friday's rally from a series of new two-year lows last week against key European currencies might have inspired some selling yesterday.
"I expected more follow-through from Friday," said Kevin Lawrie, vice president at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. "But we're not getting that either. We're at a pivotal point for the dollar."
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar slipped to 1.4940 German marks, down from 1.4998 on Friday. The dollar was also weaker against the yen, falling to 97.13 yen from 97.22 yen on Friday. In Tokyo early on Friday, the dollar touched a low of 96.55 in intraday trading.
The dollar also fell to 5.1160 French francs, from 5.1388 francs. The British pound rose to $1.6320, up from $1.6260.
Another factor behind yesterday's decline, analysts said, was a conviction that the Clinton Administration would not order a dollar-buying support operation unless the currency went into a chaotic tailspin.
"The question is whether the dollar's weakness has been pronounced enough to upset them," said William Dudley, currency analyst for Goldman, Sachs & Company "If it hurts the bond and stock markets, the Administration will be much more nervous."

HEADLINE: NEW YORK UNIONS AND MAYOR AGREE ON 7,600 JOB CUTS

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the leaders of New York City's municipal labor unions reached agreement yesterday on a plan to cut 7,600 more jobs from the city's payroll by offering a second round of severance packages as an alternative to layoffs.
The Mayor and the unions, who announced the deals at City Hall last night, also agreed on ways to save $190 million in the cost of health care for city workers -- a concession that Mr. Giuliani had sought earlier in the year but that the unions resisted until now. While that is a one-time saving to be accomplished by tapping health reserves, both sides agreed to various changes in benefits expected to save a further $100 million a year starting next year. 
 The agreements, after a day of final negotiations over technical details, came as Mr. Giuliani prepared to introduce a plan today to close a $1.1 billion gap in this year's $31.6 billion municipal budget, which took effect four months ago. Mr. Giuliani said the union agreements, most notably the saving in health costs, had been the final piece.
While the Mayor declined to give details, officials said the plan would include $850 million in spending cuts at agencies ranging from the police to the Department of Social Services, with nearly half coming from reductions in the size of the work force.
With the new severance program and a plan to eliminate additional jobs through attrition, officials said, the Mayor was proposing to bring the city payroll to about 196,000, from 216,000 when he took office. That would be the lowest number of city employees since 1985, when the work force totaled 194,373 under Mayor Edward I. Koch.
Mr. Giuliani, appearing beside the presidents of several unions, praised the labor leaders. "This puts in place the things we need to do, so that we can sensibly and humanely carry out the plan that we're going to announce tomorrow," he said. "It would not be possible to do this without the recognition on the part of the municipal labor unions that the city is facing a difficult time."
The labor leaders said they had shielded workers from layoffs and protected their benefits. "Our main goal is to protect jobs and do it in the least painful way," said Carl Haynes, president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which represents 21,000 city workers.
The severance program, modeled on one that persuaded 6,139 workers to resign last spring, would be offered over three weeks beginning on Wednesday or Thursday to about 70,000 workers, excluding teachers but including police officers, firefighters and other uniformed employees.
The severance offers range from $3,150 for workers with less than a year on the job to $13,500 for those with more than 25 years of service. They include six months of health coverage and cash payments for vacation days and sick leave.
The new offers are roughly 10 percent lower than the first packages, which offered from $3,500 or two weeks' pay for newly hired workers to $15,000 for workers with 30 or more years on the job, as well as nine months of health benefits.
The agreements marked the second time that Mr. Giuliani has sought the cooperation of the unions to reduce the payroll, rather than resorting to layoffs as he moves to balance the city's budget without raising taxes.
The Mayor had planned to make a televised address on his budget plans, including the agreement with the unions, yesterday. But as the talks dragged into the afternoon, his office canceled the address. , Later, when Mr. Giuliani announced his endorsement of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, he said he would deliver the budget message today, but it was not clear if he would make a direct televised appeal.
The new severance packages seek the same number of worker reductions, 7,600, as the first round last spring. Because the first packages, offered to 80,000 workers, attracted only 6,139 takers, the Mayor looked again to a severance program in August to eliminate the remaining 1,500 jobs, even before he decided that still more workers had to be cut as the projected budget shortage grew.
The new agreement allows the city to continue to transfer workers between agencies and job titles -- a concession won in the first agreement.
Like the first, the new agreement requires the approval of the state Municipal Assistance Corporation, which has allowed the city to use a $200 million surplus to pay for the severance packages. The first round used $120 million, leaving $80 million.
The corporation has also agreed to provide an additional $30 million that it had planned to give the city in the future, while Mr. Giuliani said that another $10 million was available from the state for the severance packages.
Beyond the severance program, Mr. Giuliani's office portrayed the savings in health care costs as equally important in reducing the city's soaring costs, particularly the changes in the way benefits are managed, that could bring annual savings of $100 million.
Those savings include using managed care for workers' compensation claims and double-checking eligibility of workers and retirees. Some of the measures require the approval of the State Legislature, meaning the savings could not begin until at least the next fiscal year.
The city would pay workers $1,000 a year if they choose to leave the city's health coverage and join the plans of, say, their spouses, saving an estimated $4 million a year.
The Mayor's Commissioner of Labor, Randy L. Levine, said the recurring savings were the most significant, since the city's fiscal monitors have repeatedly criticized such onetime savings as tapping the benefit reserves.
Stanley Hill, the executive director of the city's largest union, District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, praised the agreements on savings in health costs as a way to avoid deeper cuts in the work force, particular through layoffs, without making workers pay more for benefits.
"We did not lose benefits for our workers," Mr. Hill said.
The unions also won from the Mayor a longstanding demand that would allow workers to contribute extra money to retirement funds, to qualify for larger pensions.
While the Mayor and labor leaders hailed their cooperative spirit, there were signs of division within the unions. Arthur Cheliotes, president of Local 1180 of the Communications Workers of America, did not appear at City Hall and issued a statement denouncing the agreements.
"New York City's economic problems flow from the Mayor's policies," he said, "and he must stop coming to the working people of this city for relief."
Officials said the Mayor's plan to cut the budget would hit virtually every agency except the Department of Parks and Recreation, which is already straining.
The city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, which has already proposed cutting 3,000 jobs to cope with the first round of cuts, faces a new reduction of $100 million, as does the Human Resources Administration, which administers programs for the city's more than 1 million poor people.
The Board of Education will receive a cut of nearly $200 million, officials said, and the Police Department, until now shielded from cuts as Mr. Giuliani made law enforcement his top priority, will be cut $67 million, the vast majority of it from cuts in civilian workers.
In anticipation of the Mayor's plan, New Yorkers across a wide spectrum -- from members of the City Council to John Cardinal O'Connor to Eugene J. Keilen, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation -- have raised questions about the ability of the city to sustain large, repeated budget cuts.
For his part, Mr. Giuliani yesterday portrayed the cuts as "an opportunity" for the city to continue on the road to fiscal stability.
"We've been able to retain more businesses in the last 10 months than all of the last four years combined," the Mayor said in remarks he is expected to repeat when he unveils his menu of cuts. "And some of that, I believe, has to do with the reductions that we're creating for the budget of the city. So this will be very, very effective to create more growth in the city, and that's what I have to explain to the people."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 26, 1994, Wednesday

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN;
Giuliani Talks of Agonizing Over Best Man for the City

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's endorsement of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo yesterday, with excerpts from the question-and-answer session that followed, as recorded by The New York Times.
The election this year presents a fundamental dilemma causing many of us probably to do the same thing, agonizing over a decision we have to make, the choice we have to make for Governor. The choice will have a lot to do with the future of New York City and New York State. I think we all know that the question is compounded by the risk that we take if we make the wrong choice. My problem is further complicated because as the Mayor of New York City, I have to think about the entire city and not just my own personal position. 
 On the one hand, I'm a voter just like all the rest of you. On the other hand, my responsibility is to be as honest and as truthful about what I believe is in the best interest of the City of New York.
More and more I'm convinced that voters want the political gridlock and the partisan politics to come to an end. The voters want politicians to be like them -- straight, honest. Sometimes we vote for Republicans, sometimes we vote for Democrats, sometimes we don't vote. The voters want change, not politics as usual. I campaigned on a platform of change. I believed in it and I believe that's why I was elected. It was an affirmation that the voters want elected officials to look at what is best for them, not at what is best for political parties.
I have one of three choices. Do I vote for an incumbent governor who has served for 12 years, a governor with whom I don't always agree? Or with my vote do I ask him to step aside in favor of somebody else, somebody who will bring a different point of view, somebody who is a member of my own political party? Or do I conclude that neither one of the candidates is really that different, just ignore the whole thing, either not vote or vote for a third-party candidate like Thomas Golisano? I've made my decision and I want to share it with you and give you my reasons.
To begin with, I'm proud to be a Republican. I've already endorsed the Republican candidates for attorney general, comptroller and the United States Senate. But the next governor of New York must do more than just advance a few ideas and assist a political party. He must be a leader capable of articulating his own view of where the state is headed.
The city and this region, Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, face a very troubling four years. America's economy is recovering. New York's is also but it's a slow and a very delicate process. The governor must understand and appreciate the crucial importance of the city and this region to the state.
For many people living outside of this region and living beyond it, New York City is often considered to be a drain on the economy of the state and the nation. I have and will continue to do everything that I can to introduce accountability and to make the tough choices that have to be made to reduce whatever inefficiencies that we have, and we certainly have many. But the money that we are spending here in New York City is our money. It's not Albany's and it's not Washington's.
For all of the problems of this city, its position as the nation's business capital means that we produce more money for Albany than we receive from Albany and we produce a lot more money for Washington than we receive from them, about $8 billion more.
So from my point of view as the Mayor of New York City, the question that I have to ask is, 'Who has the best chance in the next four years of successfully fighting for our interests? Who understands them and who will make the best case for it?' Our future, our destiny is not a matter of chance. It's a matter of choice. My choice is Mario Cuomo.
A moment ago I mentioned the risk we take if we fail to choose wisely. I am well aware of the risk that I take as a Republican Mayor endorsing a Democratic Governor, but I've concluded that the risk is worth taking for the sake of the City of New York and the State of New York.
Mario Cuomo will simply be a better governor than George Pataki. Mario Cuomo understands our quest for equity from Albany and Washington to recover some of the deficit in the balance of payments to the City of New York. He's already reduced some of the deficit. He's committed to continuing to do it. And he understands and has the same commitment to the entire region.
Senator Pataki has almost uniformly voted against the interests of the city and often the metropolitan region. As a candidate for governor, as I have said often, he has the right to broaden that viewpoint, to change that viewpoint and to show that he understands better the position of the city in the way it way it operates in the entire state. He has not done that. He's vacillated. He's been ambiguous and he's been inconsistent in his responses as to what he would do about these important issues.
It's difficult to ascertain for me where he stands on Medicaid takeover, which costs the city $2.3 billion. I don't understand it. I don't understand his position on the watershed. There have been several different positions. This is a matter of even more billions and billions of dollars to the City of New York. And there's a similar ambiguity on a wide range of issues that are important and critical to the city and the region. As the Mayor of this state's largest city, I can't speculate, I need to know.
This is not to say that I have no disagreements with the Governor. There are basic areas of philosophy in which I disagree with the Governor and I will continue to. But this race has been a challenge for him. And if he wins, I believe he will govern more effectively, more wisely, certainly more willing to step beyond partisan stereotypes and help break some of the gridlock that infects our politics. He will have one more chance to use the years of his experience and his enormous talent to set New York on a course that will help insure our future.
Mario Cuomo, I'm certain, has learned a great deal from this election. And that new insight will give him the strength and the determination to establish his place in history. I think he's entitled to that chance. It is for these reasons that I'm endorsing Mario Cuomo.
But I must emphasize three things I know about Mario Cuomo which underline my endorsement and make it certain. First, Mario Cuomo loves the city of New York and he loves this region of the state. He understands its importance. Whenever I've made appeals to him for equity for us, he has supported it. He will continue to.
Second, Mario Cuomo is his own man. I prefer dealing with someone who is his own man, even if we disagree on some important issues. Third, Mario Cuomo has a much better appreciation of where the economy of the city and the state are going. And he has the maturity and balance to guide it correctly. He is not making promises which he may not be able to fulfill.
For example, the Pataki tax cut proposal. I support tax cuts. Along with Governor Cuomo I've been able to reduce the hotel occupancy tax. I've reduced the commercial rent tax and I have a financial plan that proposes to reduce taxes in future years depending on the performance of the economy, but only depending on the performance of the economy.
I haven't pledged it and I haven't promised it. And when I ran for Mayor of New York City, I resisted making any such pledges because I think they're irresponsible to make. No one knows what is going to happen to the economy next year or the year after.
I've waited for several weeks for George Pataki to tell us how he will effectuate his tax cut plan. The answer from the Pataki campaign is the economy will grow, so we can raise spending and we can lower taxes. Anyone entering office today with the idea of raising spending as a method of lowering taxes is headed for a major reversal of a campaign promise early in his administration. It's happened before. We really don't need it to happen again. This troubles me because I'm a Republican and I'd like to see my party produce candidates who can and will stand on their own.
I've often said that I would not be the Republican Mayor or the Democratic Mayor, but just a mayor of New York City. I also said that most often I would support Republicans, but occasionally like Fiorella La Guardia, a Republican, and Ed Koch, a Democrat, I would support members of the other party if I thought it was critically important for my city to do so. It is.
Although I am by no means the most partisan member, I do believe that there are principles of the Republican Party in need of much greater emphasis in New York and in America and I will continue to fight for them, emphasizing government as a last resort, not a first; placing responsibility on individuals; focusing on stricter enforcement of the law; using principles of property ownership and small business to give hope to people who are poor. Republicans in government can give reality to these principles. They are worth fighting for.
Q. Mr. Mayor, you made two references. One to Mario Cuomo being his own man and George Pataki being guided and scripted by others. Is that a reference to Senator D'Amato?
A. It's actually a reference to the way in which the two campaigns have been conducted. Having been through two campaigns, I have a really good sense for a scripted campaign and a more natural campaign and I don't think anyone really runs Mario Cuomo's campaign. Mario Cuomo gets advice, he has people who help him and you get his ideas whether you like them or not.
And the sense that I've gotten from George Pataki is that it is very much a campaign out of a political consultant's playbook. There are cliches, there are slogans, there's the right sound bite, there's the right position. You become specific only for as long as you have to and then you become general again. . .and that's what I mean by the difference in the two campaigns. And I think the American public, Republican or Democrat, is tired of campaigns like that and if they're not, they should be. And I prefer someone who has their own ideas, can tell you what those ideas are and you can disagree with them if you want to. It's also easier for me as Mayor to deal with somebody like that.
Q. Mr. Mayor, can you say how much you were influenced by George Pataki's close association with Senator D'Amato?
A. The reasons for my endorsement are exactly what I said they were. This was an analysis of their positions, most importantly it was an analysis of who do I think will be more helpful to the people of the City of New York over the next three, three and a half years? Who will do a better job for the people of the city and the people of this region and it is my firm conviction that Mario Cuomo is the right person to do that.
I weighed the possibility of voting for Mario Cuomo and being neutral in the election. And I thought that that wasn't right for a mayor to do that. I thought it was right for me to tell people for whom I was voting and why I was voting for them and maybe, and this may be surprising to some very partisan politicians, I think many people throughout the course of their lives, even if they're Republicans or Democrats, sometimes vote for a member of the opposition party. I think many politicians do.
I think I know some Republicans that are going to vote for Mario Cuomo this year, except they feel, because they're so tied into partisan politics, they can't tell you the truth about it. It's kind of circumlocutious, but I think that's one of the reasons why people are so turned off about politics today. Because we don't act like we're real people.
Q. Mr. Mayor, when did you come to your decision and what was going on at the time. . . ?
A. I said it yesterday, probably over the last two weeks. It's very hard to say when I exactly decided. I decided maybe about two weeks ago that I thought the Governor would be for the city. I thought probably I would vote for him. But I weighed the option of remaining neutral and not expressing an opinion on the governor's race.
Maybe a couple of times during that period I went back and forth about it a little bit and finally decided over the weekend that, No. 1, that I would support him but, No. 2, that I would publicly state it because I felt that that was the appropriate thing to do as the Mayor. I think the people of the city and the region are entitled to know who I'm voting for and why in such an important race.
Q. Mayor, do you -- do you convey what you were going to do today to the Republican leadership . . . your friend Guy Molinari?
A. I didn't -- I tried to treat everybody exactly the same. I talked to people on my staff. I talked to my wife about it. I did not convey to anyone precisely what I was going to do except the people that were very close to me.
Q. Mr. Mayor, you were elected at the same time Governor Whitman . . . (give me your thinking) on the role of the promises of tax cuts. . .
A. First of all, you can't compare two states and it does not make any sense to compare two states. States have very different tax structures, they have different economies. . . . When I ran for Mayor both times, I was asked very, very often to do the following:
Pledge that you will never raise taxes. I refused to do that.
Pledge that you will lower taxes. I refused to do that.
I did it because I'm aware of the burdens that exist in the city and the state, the fact that there is a law that requires a balanced budget and that I believe not only the most honest approach but the one that would give you the most flexibility to govern is one where you talk about the things that you want to cut, the things you want to readjust, the ways in which you're going to try to save money and then talk about your intention to lower taxes. But don't lock yourself into a very, very ambitious specific plans to do it because here's what believe happens if you do that:
If you do that, at some point over the next two to three years given the vagaries of the economy, it's likely you may not be able to do what you promised. And then you make people even more disillusioned about government than they already are.
 But this campaign has not materially advanced those principles. The candidate, a genuinely nice man, has studiously taken as few positions as possible. This is wrong. It's the wrong direction for the Republican Party. I believe our party should be about a substantive campaign with candidates running with their own specific ideas which make the better case for the electorate.
In my view -- a little bit more -- in my view Mario Cuomo has made the stronger case. George Pataki's only essential characteristic is that he offers an alternative. Strangely, however, after lengthy analysis and, I assure you, a lot of soul searching, I've come to the conclusion that it is George Pataki who best personifies the status quo of New York politics -- a candidate taking as few positions as possible, all of them as general as possible, taking no risk and being guided, scripted and directed by others. He has simply not made the case in any way at all that he's the agent of change.
It's Mario Cuomo who offers us the best opportunity for change, for a different reason, because of what he's been through and because of his vast intelligence, his unquestioned integrity and his honesty. I believe he can apply those talents to the solutions for our problems and even see his way to different solutions. In any event, the ideas expressed by Mario Cuomo will be his own. He's a leader. This time is our time to make hard choices. I've made my choice. It's been a difficult one.
The rest of it is up to the electorate, and I urge people not to sit back on Election Day. Don't succumb to the feeling that you can't make a difference. You can and you will by voting. And please don't succumb to the notion that politics cannot change. It can. It's vitally important that we meet all of our probabilities with dependable leadership.
Thank you.

HEADLINE: Is a Team of Clydesdales Next?;
In Heady World of Microbreweries, Growth Is the Word

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 22

 BODY:
The New Haven Brewing Company's line of beers is about as local as it gets. Who is the guy on the label of Mr. Mike's Light Ale, grinning behind the bar with the big sloshing tankard of suds? It is Mike Gettings, the company president. The dignified face on the label of Blackwell Stout? Blackwell himself, the brew-house dog, who even contributed a paw print of approval.
But the big question is, can Mr. Mike and Blackwell travel? Can a company that has reveled in its connection to the community sell its products nationally, head to head against the big players, in places where Blackwell is just another dog on a beer bottle and where nobody knows his name? 
 That anyone would even ask is a sign that things are changing for microbreweries in the New York region, which has been slow to accept the distinctive small-batch beers that battle for local palates elsewhere.
Microbrewed beers, which vary from sweet and malty stouts to yeasty ales, are the cappuccinos and lattes of the beer-drinking crowd: stronger, more complex in character than mass-brewed products like Budweiser or Miller and about twice as expensive. Their share of the national beer market is small, less than 1 percent, and in New York -- for reasons no one is quite sure of -- it has been smaller still.
But the operative word now is expansion.
Over the next few months, thousands of barrels of local beers, including the first pub-brewed beer in New Jersey since Prohibition, are expected to begin pouring forth from taps and bottles as microbrewing picks up steam. Breweries from Brooklyn to Norwalk, Conn., are putting in more and bigger brewing vats, plotting new lagers, ales and stouts.
Nationally, the microbrewing industry -- which includes bottlers brewing less than 15,000 barrels a year and brew-pubs that brew behind the bar and sell on tap -- has been growing at a rate of about 40 percent a year. The New York region will clearly exceed that pace over the next six months, with at least five new brew-pubs in New Jersey, Connecticut and Long Island, and expansions by at least three microbottlers.
"New York is awakening," said Stephen Hindy, president of Brooklyn Brewery, which began selling its beer in 1988, brewed by another company in Utica, N.Y. Next month, Brooklyn Brewery plans to open its first wholly owned and operated brewery in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.
Nowhere are the plans more ambitious than inside the former steamship terminal that houses the five-year-old New Haven Brewing Company here. Where some new local brewers are measuring their distribution by how many seats are filled at the bar, New Haven Brewing is planning national conquest.
Backed by a new investor, New Haven Brewing's whimsically named beers -- still difficult to find as near as New York and New Jersey -- will soon be shipped to Florida and California.
If the pieces fall into place as planned, production levels will soar, from 4,300 barrels of beer last year, or about 135,000 gallons, to perhaps 150,000 barrels within three years, vaulting the company to within the top handful of small beer makers in the nation. A second brewery will have to be built.
"We've gone legit," said Jim Gordon, a co-founder and vice president for marketing at New Haven Brewing.
Survivors of the local brewing scene caution, however, that expanding into new markets is risky.
The Vernon Valley Brewing Company in Vernon Valley, N.J., one of the region's earliest microbrewers, thought it had caught the wave in 1985. It failed in 1992 and now sits empty. The short-lived Connecticut Brewing Company in Hartford failed with its Nathan Hale Golden Lager in the early 1990's. The Manhattan Brewing Company, one of the oldest brew-pubs in New York City, is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, although it remains open.
For New Haven Brewing, a more than 20-fold expansion means essentially creating a new company, changing from the old shoestring mom-and-pop days to something more structured. Expansion will also mean, for the first time, contracting out to a another brewer to make some of the company's products, at least temporarily.
Big-name brewers have also entered the microbrewing game. Anheuser-Busch, for example, recently invested in a small Portland company, Red Hook Brewing, and plans to distribute the company's beers to markets on the East Coast for the first time.
To add to New Haven Brewing's worries, the co-founder who developed the company's recipes, Blair Potts, has quit to open a brewery-pub in New Haven, thus ending New Haven Brewery's status as the city's only local beer.
"It's bittersweet, because it was my baby," Mr. Potts said. "But I only enjoy the start-up phase of companies. I'm a big fan of small business."
The changes at New Haven Brewing, he said, were necessary for the company's survival, and he believes the distribution team brought in by the new investors has a good chance to succeed. But he thinks there is a price to pay for that success. "I don't see it staying small and personal," Mr. Potts said. "I don't see how it could."
Within the culture of the microbrewers, the question of size has always been a major issue, touching on everything from philosophy to economics. There are lessons from companies that have made it big, like Anchor Steam in San Francisco, or collapsed, like Boulder Beer in Boulder, Colo., after launching a national distribution plan in the 1980's.
Jay Misson has seen both sides. He was the brewmaster at Vernon Valley Brewery -- later the Clement Brewing Company -- in New Jersey in the late 1980's, trying to expand when "the market hadn't hit yet." Since early this year, he has been brewing and bottling at the small Mountain Valley Brew Pub in Suffern, N.Y. He measures his distribution by towns: From Albany to New Brunswick, N.J., and New York City west to Morristown, N.J., with no plans for anything more.
"It's more in keeping with the mom-and-pop nature of the microbrewing business," he said.
In Norwalk, the New England Brewery is finishing work on a $2 million waterfront brewery that will more than triple its capacity, to about 20,000 barrels a year. But the company's president, Marcia L. King, said that while she may add one or two states to her distribution area, she wants the company's beers to be distinctly regional in New England and the northeast.
"That's the important thing, quality and regionality," she said. "This is a risky business to begin with, and when you start to spread yourself out too much, it just would make me nervous."
The Ship Inn in Milford, N.J., plans to begin brewing ales next month as the first legal brew-pub in New Jersey since a Prohibition-era state law was changed last year. The law prohibited retail sales and brewing at the same location. A co-owner, Ann Hall, said there were no plans to bottle, no plans to expand.
"Our prime concern is to serve the customers we already have," she said.
At New Haven Brewing, on the other hand, company officials said that it became clear over the last few years that a larger scale was the only way to survive. The company was undercapitalized and deeply in debt.
"I wanted to buy an Aston Martin, and I knew I would never get there if I just stayed doing what I was doing," said Jim Gordon, a pony-tailed co-founder who shares an office with New Haven Brewing's new chairman, Carmine Melchionna.
Mr. Melchionna is a New Haven businessman who made his first fortune building, then selling, a company that helped supermarkets collect and recycle deposit bottles and cans. He invested in New Haven Brewing earlier this year, becoming the new majority shareholder. He plans a catering business and a beer museum. He even had the front of the building landscaped.
Mr. Melchionna said he wants to keep the brewery here operating as a showplace. The new brewery, he said, will be just for production.
"Ultimately, if we get the distribution that we think we'll get, we'll need to make a lot of beer," he said. "It's a volume business."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 27, 1994, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about microbreweries referred incorrectly to the location of one in which Anheuser-Busch has become an investor. The company, Red Hook Brewing, is in Seattle, not Portland.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: MASSACHUSETTS;
Kennedy and Romney Meet, And the Rancor Flows Freely

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
In a vivid piece of political theater, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts attacked his Republican challenger, Mitt Romney, tonight for his views on abortion, health care and Social Security.
"I am pro-choice," Mr. Kennedy said during an exchange on abortion. "My opponent is multiple choice." 
 Mr. Romney, calm under fire, gave as good as he got during most of a 60-minute debate, but he failed to dent the composure of Mr. Kennedy, who came into the confrontation buoyed by a new poll showing him with a substantial lead. The challenger scored with jabs at the Senator's use of religion in the campaign and with depictions of Mr. Kennedy as the spokesman for an outdated brand of liberalism.
"I am tough on crime," Mr. Romney said. "He is not."
But Mr. Kennedy managed to make his opponent look inexperienced in the intricacies of Federal finance and the way legislation is enacted. He forced Mr. Romney to admit he did not know how much his ideas on health care would cost. And perhaps most important for the Senator, he demonstrated that he was not a has-been, although Mr. Romney took every opportunity to argue that it was time for a change after the incumbent's more than three decades on Capitol Hill.
Several of the Republican and Democratic politicians who critiqued the debate for local news outlets called it a draw in which no knockdowns, let alone knockouts, were scored by either candidate. If television viewers agree, that would tend to favor Senator Kennedy because he has no ground to make up.
In one protracted wrangle, involving accusations by Mr. Romney about the Senator's personal finances, Mr. Kennedy said stonily: "Mr. Romney, the Kennedys are not in public service to make money. We have paid too high a price."
The debate, telecast statewide, was staged in Faneuil Hall, a red-brick structure dating from pre-Revolutionary times, whose cupola is crowned by a gilded metal grasshopper. It was the highlight so far of the midterm election campaign -- far more robust, in keeping with Boston's liking for politics as spectator sport, than the tepid exchanges that have taken place in many states.
Much of the first half centered on jobs, a central issue in Massachusetts, and things quickly degenerated into a shouting match that the moderator, Ken Bode, had some trouble controlling. Mr. Romney said he knew how to create jobs because of his "skill and experience in the private sector," while Mr. Kennedy argued that his seniority in the Senate better qualified him to provide the training and education needed to guarantee well-paying employment in the state.
Then the Senator accused Mr. Romney of denying medical care to part-time workers he employs. Mr. Romney called that hypocrisy and said the Kennedy family did the same thing at its Merchandise Mart in Chicago, and the shouting began.
Afterward, the Kennedy forces distributed a news release, prepared in anticipation of Mr. Romney's accusations, saying that the mart's 400 full-time employees were given medical coverage and that its seven part-time workers were all covered to some degree. The rebuttal, of course, had none of the drama of Mr. Romney's heated words in the debate, which appeared to be extemporaneous.
Mr. Kennedy, who is 62 years old, allowed Mr. Romney to seize the initiative during the summer and found himself in a dead heat by Labor Day. Mr. Romney, trim and darkly handsome at 47, was transformed from a little-known venture capitalist (albeit one with a famous name) into a David who might slay Goliath.
The last of three political brothers, Senator Kennedy is one of the Democrats whom the Republicans would most like to defeat on Nov. 8, along with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York and House Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington.
Mr. Romney accused Mr. Kennedy of misrepresenting and distorting his record, demanding, "When will this end?" In turn, Mr. Kennedy said he would provide documentation of his assertions and called upon Mr. Romney to talk instead about his views on the economy and "the pain of the people in Massachusetts."
"Give me a break, Mr. Romney, give me a break," the Senator said angrily after his rival accused him of being soft on crime for opposing some mandatory sentence guidelines and noted his longtime opposition to the death penalty.
Despite the spirited exchanges and fleeting looks of anger, the two men shook hands afterward and exchanged a few pleasantries.
Both Mr. Kennedy and Mr. Romney prepared carefully. In the customary dry runs, Charles Baker, the Human Services Secretary in the Cabinet of Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts, played Mr. Kennedy for the benefit of Mr. Romney. For Mr. Kennedy's rehearsal, David Smith, a former Kennedy aide, took the part of Mr. Romney.
Several hours before the debate began, supporters gathered on the plaza between Faneuil Hall and Quincy Market, a popular tourist attraction in downtown Boston. The Kennedy backers carried blue placards, the Romney partisans red-and-blue ones.
A poll carried out over the weekend by The Boston Herald showed Senator Kennedy widening his lead, largely because of defections from Mr. Romney by independents. They hold the key to any Republican's chances in predominantly Democratic Massachusetts. In The Herald survey, which had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus five percentage points and was based on interviews with 447 likely voters, Mr. Kennedy led 50 percent to 32 percent, with 18 percent undecided.
Mr. Romney needed a strong showing tonight and another in a second debate scheduled for Thursday night in Holyoke to stage a comeback. So he probably had the most at stake.
For Mr. Romney, a son of George W. Romney, the former Governor of Michigan whose ill-advised comment about having been brainwashed in Vietnam prematurely ended his bid for the Presidency in 1968, the debates also offered a chance to demonstrate that he could deal effectively with issues of substance.
A political neophyte, Mr. Romney had scored earlier in the campaign mainly by attacking Senator Kennedy and arguing that it was time for a change. Like many other challengers in this year of anti-incumbent fervor, Mr. Romney had spent little time defining a program of his own.
One of his most biting commercials, which ran last week, accused Mr. Kennedy of making big profits on a real estate deal in Washington "at taxpayers' expense." The Senator, who denied the accusations, had himself run a slashing series of advertisements accusing Mr. Romney of making big profits on a deal that cost hundreds of workers' jobs in Indiana. Mr. Romney had issued a denial in that case.
For Mr. Kennedy, first elected in 1962, the debate offered a chance to show that three decades in the Senate had not dulled his zest for political battle or public service, and to rebut his opponent's contention that years of hard living had enfeebled him.
In political circles in Washington, Mr. Kennedy is considered a legislative craftsman of great skill. He has long been viewed as the Senate's leading advocate of liberal causes, and he is admired for his hard work, even by adversaries like Senator Alan K. Simpson, a conservative Republican from Wyoming.
But in Massachusetts, his standing has been eroded by such episodes as the drowning of Mary Jo Kopechne in the Senator's car on Chappaquiddick Island in July 1969 and the trial of his nephew William Kennedy Smith on rape charges after he and Senator Kennedy had gone bar-hopping in Palm Beach, Fla., on Good Friday, 1991.
For many years his considerable influence in the halls of Congress -- his ability to deliver jobs for his constituents -- has to some degree obscured his personal troubles, including his divorce from his first wife, Joan.
But in late middle age he has proved vulnerable, and Mr. Romney has proved a vigorous challenger, even in South Boston, where rancor over the court-ordered school busing that began in 1974 remains a force, and where Mr. Romney has found a ready audience for his argument that "the 1960's liberal agenda has not worked."
