HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE CAMPAIGN;
Endorsement? Pataki Seeks Other Topics

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

 BODY:
Campaigning in the heart of Giuliani country, State Senator George E. Pataki worked hard yesterday to change the subject from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's newest strength -- his endorsement by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani -- to one of his oldest vulnerabilities -- his passionate opposition to the death penalty.
At stops in Staten Island, Borough Park, Bensonhurst and Nassau County, Mr. Pataki played down the dramatic endorsement of the Democratic Governor by the Republican Mayor, never diverting from a simple, scripted response that he, like Mayor Giuliani, would bring change to government. And whenever possible, he said that what he really wanted to talk about was the death penalty, specifically Mr. Cuomo's refusal to allow Oklahoma to execute Thomas Grasso, who had killed people in both states and has said he wants to die. Mr. Cuomo has insisted that state law requires that Mr. Grasso serve his 20-year-to-life sentence in New York before being extradited. 
 Ever since Mr. Grasso became an issue for Mr. Cuomo last year, Democratic strategists have assumed that the Republicans would play the Grasso card during this year's campaign. But the Pataki campaign has largely held back until today, when Mr. Pataki threw his ace with gusto.
"This is the borough where Thomas Grasso committed his second murder, a crime for which he is not only not paying a penalty but is in fact avoiding the death penalty in Oklahoma because of the acts of Mario Cuomo," Mr. Pataki said in Staten Island at a news conference that he ostensibly called to promote his pledge to reduce tolls on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge.
Mr. Cuomo, meanwhile, devoted his day to making sure that Mr. Giuliani's endorsement would mean as much as possible.
The Mayor provided the photo opportunity that his announcement on Monday had not, appearing with Mr. Cuomo on the City Hall steps with representatives of law-enforcement unions that were endorsing the Governor. Rather than wilting in the face of criticism and potential ostracism from Republican officials, Mr. Giuliani seemed only to strengthen his support.
His selection of Mr. Cuomo over Mr. Pataki, he said, was "not a close choice."
"If it were close," he said, "I would cut it in favor of the Republican Party." The only difficulty in his decision, he said, was understanding "the hurt that it causes to some very partisan Republicans, some of whom helped me a lot."
At each of Mr. Cuomo's public appearances, the Governor offered a host of reasons that the Mayor's endorsement should matter.
"If you are concerned about who is in the best position to help people in this state live better, then the Mayor of the largest city -- where there are eight million people, who happens to be of a different party, who I opposed twice -- the idea that he says that I'm better for this state than his own party member has to have a persuasive influence," Mr. Cuomo said after delivering a speech in Manhattan about violence in the media.
Sounding at times like a door-to-door salesman hawking Mr. Giuliani's endorsement instead of encyclopedias, the Governor said that undecided Democrats in particular should ask themselves: "What am I hesitating about? This guy's a Republican Mayor. He says Cuomo's the best for us."
Mr. Cuomo rejected the argument, repeated frequently yesterday by Republican legislators around the state, that the endorsement must have hinged on a deal between Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Giuliani that would drive money to the city at the expense of other parts of the state. "What are they suggesting," that if Mr. Giuliani had endorsed the Republican candidate, "that then they would have been able to abandon the city?" he asked.
Similarly, he turned away the Rev. Al Sharpton's warning that black voters who dislike Mr. Giuliani may hold the endorsement against Mr. Cuomo. Would black voters have preferred that Mr. Giuliani endorse Mr. Pataki "so Mario can lose, so they can devastate the city budget with a $7 billion tax cut in Albany?" he asked. "It doesn't make sense."
But Mr. Cuomo also refused to say that he would return Mr. Giuliani's favor by endorsing the Republican Mayor if he seeks re-election in 1997. "Are you serious?" he asked in response to the question. "If I'm Governor after Nov. 8, we'll talk."
It remained uncertain, of course, exactly how Mr. Giuliani's endorsement ultimately would affect the race, with Democrats saying it should be worth at least a few percentage points and Republicans saying that any gains might be offset by its potential to galvanize Pataki supporters upstate.
But one thing the endorsement clearly provided, according to several Democratic leaders, was a dose of positive attention for a campaign that sorely needed it.
The Governor received other good news yesterday in the form of new statistics released by his administration that showed a drop in the state's unemployment rate from 6.7 percent in August to 6 percent in September, the lowest rate this year. Another state report released yesterday showed that major crime declined by 9.2 percent in New York State in the first six months of 1994, compared with the same period in 1993.
Mr. Pataki, however, sought to use the crime issue to his advantage. He chose to confront the Giuliani endorsement by appearing in neighborhoods where Mr. Giuliani won heavy support in last year's mayoral election, and by speaking about the issue that helped him win that support.
"You have the right," Mr. Pataki said at the Amico Senior Citizen Center in Borough Park, "for all you have contributed to this city and this state, to live in peace and safety on the streets, in the parks, in the centers and in your homes."
Mr. Pataki also tried to rebut one of the most stinging criticisms in Mr. Giuliani's endorsement: the Mayor's suggestion that Mr. Pataki is not his own man and is controlled by United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.
"I am very much an independent person and I will be an independent governor," he said in Staten Island.
But Mr. Cuomo sought to exploit the attention drawn by Mr. Giuliani's endorsement to the relationship between Mr. Pataki and Mr. D'Amato.
"I can tell him how to be his own man," he said, referring to Mr. D'Amato's aid to the Pataki campaign. "Give back all the money. Give back all the staff. Give back the endorsement. Give back the advice. You know, he'd have to do a lot to be his own man."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Continues Its Slide, Touching New Low vs. Yen

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar came under renewed attack yesterday, setting a record low against the Japanese yen and a fresh two-year low against the German mark. But the dollar recovered somewhat in late New York trading.
"We broke to new lows but we didn't have any follow-through selling," said David Durst, vice president at Bear Stearns & Company. He said that traders who had sold dollars at higher levels rushed to buy them back as the currency touched new low points. 
 The dollar declined to 96.42 yen early in New York trading, falling through the previous postwar low of 96.55 yen in intraday trading last Friday. In late New York trading, the dollar settled at 96.82 yen, down from 97.13 yen on Monday.
It also fell to new two-year lows against the mark, falling in Europe as low as 1.4853 marks after a group of economic research institutes raised their growth forecasts for the German economy. In New York trading, the dollar declined to 1.4860 marks, its lowest level since Oct. 19, 1992, before finishing at 1.4970 marks, up from 1.4940 marks on Monday.
The British pound rose to a two-year high of $1.6405 in New York, before settling at $1.6357 from $1.6320 on Monday.
The dollar had come under pressure in overnight trading, despite repeated intervention by the Japanese central bank aimed at supporting it. Selling continued as New York traders entered the market this morning. As the dollar edged down, the Japanese efforts alone were not sufficient to combat the negative sentiment that has forced it lower.
Still, many traders were wary about the possibility that the Federal Reserve might also step in to try to support the dollar if it fell too far.
 "Although people are itching to make the lows, there are still lingering concerns about central bank intervention," said Amy Smith, analyst at consulting firm Idea.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen helped to reinforce some of the fears. Speaking on the cable television network CNBC, Mr. Bentsen reiterated the Government's desire for a stronger dollar.
Some traders, however, are skeptical. "The U.S. and others can talk the dollar up all they want, but the market needs more commitment," said Jack Griffin, vice president at Fuji Bank.
In other trading, the dollar rose yesterday to 1.2495 Swiss francs from 1.2425 francs on Monday, and to 5.1225 French francs from 5.1115 francs. It dropped against the Italian lire at 1,531 from 1,527, and rose against the Canadian dollar to 74.14 cents from 74.00 cents Monday.

HEADLINE: Petrochemical Profits Are Helping Oil Companies

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
An increase in demand for petrochemicals, used in making plastics, synthetic rubber and fibers, is causing a shortage of supplies and a jump in prices.
Although the demand for chemicals historically rises during an economic recovery, the industry was taken by surprise by the sudden surge in demand during the third quarter -- and producers are now scrambling to increase production. And for the country's big oil companies, most of which have huge chemical subsidiaries, profits from chemicals have been jumping sharply, helping to give the companies higher earnings from operations for the quarter. 
 The growing demand has forced up prices for some chemicals by about 50 percent and is expected to put pressure on the prices of thousands of consumer products from automobiles to plastic bags to washing machines.
"What we're seeing is a big recovery in the volume plastics business," said John Akitt, the executive vice president of the Exxon Chemical Company, the world's ninth-largest chemical concern and a division of the Exxon Corporation.
He said a series of disruptions at major plants, including a fire at Exxon's plant in Baton Rouge, La., in August, had also put a pinch on products including ethylene, which is used in plastics.
Disruptions have also had an effect on chemical production at the Amoco Corporation, which has cut customer deliveries of ethylene to about 60 percent of what they had ordered.
Jim Fligg, executive vice president in charge of chemical operations for Amoco, estimated that about 3 billion out of a total of 42 billion pounds of ethylene capacity were taken out of production in the last few months because of fires, floods and plant shutdowns for maintenance.
"This has caused an industry tightness," he added. "We're selling every pound we produce."
Most plants, he said, are increasing production, and Amoco's plant at Chocolate Bayou, Tex., which makes ethylene and was shut down for maintenance, is now back at 80 percent of capacity.
The disruptions came as demand increased, both in the United States and in Europe, for basic chemicals used in products like plastics and synthetic rubber. Demand in the United States alone is up 9 percent from last year for chemicals including ethylene, benzene, styrene, polyethylene and polystyrene.
William R. Young, a chemical industry analyst for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said these trends had pushed up prices for ethylene from 16 cents a pound at the beginning of the year to about 25 cents now. Polyethylene, used widely in packaging, has risen from 24.5 cents a pound in January to about 37 cents, he said.
Mr. Young said the demand had been particularly strong for so-called commodity chemicals, which oil companies produce from the byproducts of natural gas and the refining of crude oil.
For the oil companies, the surge in demand and prices has been a boon.
The Chevron Corporation, for example, said yesterday that its third-quarter net income rose to $425 million, or 65 cents a share, up 1.2 percent from the corresponding period a year earlier. The company said the operating profit of its chemical operations rose to $72 million in the third quarter from $15 million in the period last year.
And the Phillips Petroleum Company said yesterday that its net income of $119 million, or 45 cents a share, was nearly triple that of last year's third quarter. Its chemical unit had operating profits of $66 million, nearly double those of the period last year.
Texaco Inc., which sold off its worldwide chemical business last year, said its third-quarter net income nearly doubled, to $281 million, or 98 cents a share.
On Monday, the Exxon Corporation reported that its chemical operations earned $198 million in the third quarter, up from $68 million in the period last year.
Amoco said its chemical earnings were $154 million, up from $60 million, and ARCO said its chemical profits rose to $77 million from $55 million.

HEADLINE: GIULIANI PROPOSES $800 MILLION MORE IN SPENDING CUTS

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday proposed a second round of budget cuts that would squeeze almost every government service in New York City, from schools to hospitals to prisons, from recycling to bridge painting to food programs for the poor.
Saying the cuts would be difficult but necessary to keep the city on a course to economic recovery, Mr. Giuliani outlined a plan to close a $1.1 billion gap that has opened in the $31.6 billion budget the Mayor and the City Council balanced just four months ago; more than $800 million of the $1.1 billion would come from cutting spending already budgeted for the city's agencies this year. 
 The cuts come on top of the $1.1 billion in spending reductions the Mayor pushed through the City Council as the budget took effect last July. With the new cuts, Mr. Giuliani has now proposed cutting city spending by nearly $2 billion, or more than 6 percent, the deepest reductions since the fiscal crisis of the 1970's.
Once Mr. Giuliani's plan is introduced as legislation, the City Council has 30 days to approve or reject it as a whole, or negotiate changes with the Mayor and ask him to resubmit the plan.
The latest cuts fall most heavily on the Board of Education, whose current $7.7 billion budget the Mayor has proposed slashing by $190 million, with steps like trimming 504 assistant principals and raising the price of a school lunch by 28 cents, to $1. The Department of Social Services faces a cut of $102 million, or 1.4 percent, while the Mayor plans to snatch away $113 million from a surplus the Transit Authority had built as ridership on the subways increased.
Mr. Giuliani said his commissioners would manage the cuts to minimize the service impact, but several elected officials, union leaders and advocates criticized the Mayor's plan as too Draconian, saying it would hurt the city's poorest residents the most, and spare almost no one.
In contrast to the budget he unveiled last spring, the Mayor's new plan includes significantly more details on exactly where cuts would fall, proposing, for instance, to save $200,000 by seeking to eliminate a court ruling that city jail windows be cleaned four times a year.
The plan would also phase out money for soup kitchens, end a counseling program to keep addicted mothers with their children, and cut 1,900 openings in day-care centers. At the same time, the city's three police departments would lose 2,000 civilian workers, a decision that elected officials and fiscal monitors warned could mean more police officers filling desk jobs instead of patrolling the streets.
The Mayor's plan also proposed cutting 800 correction officers in the city's already strained jails, while slashing recreational and counseling services for inmates -- a situation that the head of the officers' union, Stanley Israel, said would push the jails "into the danger zone."
In all, the Mayor said he would eliminate 5,153 jobs in addition to the 15,000 he has already cut in the city's payroll of 216,000 workers when the he took office. That would leave the city with the fewest workers since 1985, when the total was 194,373 under Mayor Edward I. Koch.
Anticipating a public outcry in the coming weeks, Mr. Giuliani said that New York would continue to spend more money than any other city "on children, the elderly, people who are sick, people who are homeless, people who have AIDS," as it had for more than a century.
"It will continue to," Mr. Giuliani said, announcing the plan in the old Board of Estimate Chambers at City Hall, "but we have to ask for more accountability in the way we spend that money, and we have to make some reductions in it to allow New York City to continue to function as an enterprise that can continue to grow through jobs on the private side."
But the Mayor's plan provoked an immediate and strong response from the City Council, where Democrats outnumber Republicans 43 to 7 and where members vowed to challenge many of the most drastic proposals.
The Council's Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said the Mayor had not laid out a realistic strategy for balancing the budget now or in the future. Instead, he said, the Mayor's plan simply imposed across-the-board cuts as "a shortsighted expediency."
"Just as we cannot tax our way out of fiscal problems, we cannot simply cut our way out either," said Mr. Vallone, the Democrat from Astoria, Queens, whose voice at times bristled with anger.
Mr. Giuliani said he was willing to negotiate changes with the Council, but only if its members came out with alternatives to close the $1.1 billion shortfall. The Council has already begun drafting some of those, though its leaders declined yesterday to say what exactly they entailed.
The Mayor attributed the budget shortfall to factors largely out of the city's control. Those, he said, included a drop in tax revenues because of the summer slump on Wall Street, the inability to win anticipated aid from the Federal and state governments, and soaring costs from pensions, welfare rolls and liability claims against the city. The largest shortfall, however, came from overtime, which has soared, particularly in the jails, forcing the Mayor to find $150 million more in savings.
In addition to the cuts in agency spending, the Mayor's plan includes $190 million in savings from the city's municipal unions by tapping health benefits reserves and $10 million more in various changes in the way benefits are administered.
To reach his goal of cutting the municipal work force by a total of 20,000, the Mayor and the unions also reached an agreement on Monday to offer a second round of voluntary severance packages instead of layoffs to cut 7,600 more jobs. The payroll now stands at 207,000 workers. The rest of the reductions to the planned level of 195,872 would come through attrition.
The plan also calls for increasing revenues by $42 million in several ways, like collecting fees from sidewalk cafes more aggressively, and reducing the amount of time that money will buy on parking meters. City Councilman Noach Dear, the chair of the Council's transportation committee, said the latter amounted "to nickel-and-diming."
Even after the Mayor's steps to close the $1.1 billion budget gap, the total budget has grown to $31.8 billion since the fiscal year began on July 1, because the city has received $200 million more in Federal aid earmarked for various programs.
The bond raters on Wall Street praised the plan as a prudent step toward restoring stability in the city's finances. "It's a good plan," said Richard P. Larkin, managing director of Standard & Poors, one of the major raters. "After looking at at least five years of budgets with varying degrees of gimmickry and one-shots, this plan addresses the problem head-on."
Mr. Larkin said that the outlook on the city's rating -- all important to the price the city can hope to charge for its bonds -- would continue to improve if Mr. Giuliani continued with his plans to control spending.
Others saw it differently. City Councilwoman Ronnie M. Eldridge, who represents the West Side of Manhattan, said the cuts would hurt virtually everyone. The only major agencies spared deep cuts were the Department of Health and the Department of Parks and Recreation.
With agencies already strained under the first round of cuts, Ms. Eldridge said the city now had to consider changes in the tax structure to increase revenues and protect services -- something Mr. Giuliani has explicitly ruled out.
"This budget reminds me of the Grimm's fairy tale of Cinderella, where the step-sisters cut off their toes and feet to fit into the slipper," she said. "I think it's going to hurt everyone."
But Mr. Giuliani said he had to keep cutting spending or the city would no longer be able to afford the services it does provide. He added that the city's spending had grown faster than the rate of the economy for the last 16 years.
"If you sit where I sit," he said, "what you have to be concerned about is: if you allow that process to go on, then where is the money going to come from to care for people who need care and who need help, who are in sickness or who are elderly, 5 or 10 years from now?"
A few hours after he formally announced his plan, the first protest of what will probably be many more began, with members of Act Up, the AIDS rights organization, marching in front of City Hall shouting that people needed help right now.

HEADLINE: Hunger and Dissent Stalk a Struggling Ethiopia

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Oct. 22

 BODY:
After two decades of war and famine, political oppression and mass killings, the recipe for restoring a shattered economy under a democratic government remains elusive here.
In the three years since rebel troops overthrew a Marxist regime and committed themselves to democratic rule, there have been measurable gains. The government of President Meles Zenawi has cooperated with the World Bank, devalued its currency and begun to open its markets. There is general stability and peace. 
 Inflation is down to single digits. There are 60 registered political parties. More than 120 newspapers are registered here in the capital, including many that yearn editorially for the days of the dictator Mengistu Haile Mariam, who ruled in a campaign of terror until his overthrow by rebels. And Government officials say they remain committed to raising living standards.
But Ethiopia today is still the second-poorest African country after Mozambique, stalked perpetually by famine and so divided by political dissent that some critics fear it will slip back into violence, even civil war.
"The writing is on the wall, no doubt," said Nebiyu Samuel, head of the Ethiopian National Democratic Party, an opposition coalition that is included in the present transitional government. "All the factors, all the recipes are there for this country to go to pieces. The temptation is there every day for me to quit. None of us should be quitters. But the road is getting narrower and narrower."
Several thousand people died this year when rains came late and the harvest failed in the south, but by most measures this represented a kind of success. The Government and international relief agencies prevented a higher toll by rushing food to the stricken area. Yet even with good rains and successful harvests, the country will continue to require aid amounting to hundreds of thousands of tons of food a year, Western relief officials say.
In this desperately poor land of 50 million, where more than half live below poverty level and an estimated 20 million are unemployed, economic hardships have always defined most Ethiopians' existence.
After South Africa, Ethiopia is the second-largest recipient of United States foreign aid in sub-Saharan Africa. By May, the United States had provided more than $135 million in economic assistance this year, of which about $110 million was emergency food aid. The World Bank disbursed $325 million this year, $200 million more than in the previous year.
Because of the economic restructuring, Addis Ababa has been flooded with more than a million people since 1991, most of them unemployed and with no future as farmers in the countryside. More than 20,000 street children roam the city, and their numbers are expected to soar to 40,000 by the end of 1995.
In the countryside, about 60 percent of the children under 5 are malnourished, one of the highest rates in Africa. In such a context, bringing prosperity and multiparty democracy in the space of a few years is an extraordinarily difficult task.
"You can't apply Western logic to what is happening in Ethiopia," said one diplomat. "The Western donors are expecting too much, too fast."
But there is dissatisfaction inside Ethiopia as well. Critics of the Government call the official tolerance of a political opposition a whitewash. They say the Government, controlled by the members of Tigrean ethnic minority in the ruling party, the Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Defense Front, has fulfilled only a few of its promises.
Diplomats and Ethiopians also say the Government has become increasingly autocratic and threatening as it tries to neutralize threats to its stability, moving its loyalists into top positions in the Ethiopian Orthodox Church, the university, the state airline, banks and industry.
"We have a cultural tendency towards extremism," said a senior Ethiopian official. "You can't introduce democracy by undemocratic means."
Many opposition parties have refused to take part in the country's first elections, to be held early next year. The other parties that remain in the present transitional government say they have little access to radio and television, which are controlled by the Government, and are not allowed to campaign freely in the provinces.
Several parties have organized military affiliates that have fought Government troops, particularly in the east. Officials officially dismissed this opposition as unorganized "bandit activity," but relief workers and diplomats say that in some instances the fighting was fierce enough that the Government used tanks.
Diplomats and United Nations officials say the Government has harassed and sporadically cracked down on the opposition and the press, which sometimes publishes irresponsible reports, and more than a dozen journalists have been arrested in the last few months. Scores of political demonstrators were arrested here in September; the Government accused them of inciting a riot.
"Freedom should entail responsibility," said Netsannet Asfaw, the presidential spokeswoman. "If they incite violence, religious and ethnic, they are taken to court. In the West, you accept only peaceful struggle. The same should apply here. How did governments deal with the Black Panthers or the I.R.A.?"
The political dissent is also fueled by factors beyond the Government's control. The opposition is deeply divided and many of the parties have made outrageously unrealistic demands in an effort to feed unrest. And some of the Government's moves, like giving any nationality the right to secede, have heightened ethnic tensions.
Another major source of tension is land, which was nationalized during the previous regime. The current Government has said it will not permit peasants to own the land they farm because of fears that they might be tempted to sell to speculators.
But Ethiopia's biggest hurdle to survival and political success is food production. The Government says it is overhauling agriculture and hopes to be self-sufficient in food in a decade, but acknowledges that is optimistic.
Barely eight months ago, for instance, millions of Ethiopians were on the brink of starvation as rains and crops failed in the south. With one million metric tons of food aid, the Government managed to bring help to 6.7 million people. Now the rains have been plentiful and the fields are lush, but the country will still need 700,000 to one million metric tons of food a year. If the temperamental rains fail, the situation will be disastrous.
Even with sufficient rain, food production is low because of severe land degradation, low use of fertilizers and a lack of improved seeds. Ethiopia has the lowest per hectare production of grain in the world, officials say, and after years of war and drought, many farmers no longer even have oxen to till their fields.
"We're not making any progress at all," said a senior Western relief official. "The same amount is being imported as in 1984 for the famine where one million died. That's the kicker, that's the tragedy. You have a beautiful crop and you still need a million tons."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Three years after rebel troops overthrew Marxist rulers, Ethiopia remains the second-poorest country in Africa. In Addis Ababa, the capital, homeless men washed their laundry in a puddle in the road. (Elizabeth Gilbert for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Germans See Growth; Markets Drop Anyway

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Reporting that the German economy was driving itself out of deep recession, a group of leading economic research institutes significantly increased projections today for economic growth this year and predicted that the output of Europe's largest economy would rise further in 1995.
But the forecast of strong growth did not stop the German stock and bond markets from falling. Touched off by fears of renewed inflation in the United States and continuing weakness in the dollar, stocks on the benchmark DAX index fell 2.51 percent and bonds had one of their worst days in weeks. 
 "Everyone is bearish on the dollar," said Jeff Hochman, a strategic analyst at Deutsche Bank. "And unfortunately, as goes the dollar these days, so go German stocks and bonds." This is in part because a weaker dollar creates a stronger mark, which makes the exports upon which German industries depend more expensive abroad.
The dollar hit another two-year low here during the day at 1.4853 marks, moving up at the end of trading here and in New York, ending the day there at 1.4970 marks. But German analysts saw little reason for the dollar not to drop again.
At a semiannual ceremony in which six research institutes issue a joint economic forecast for the Government, five of the six said the economy would grow 2.5 percent this year -- up from a projection six months ago of 1.5 percent growth in the economy.
They projected that overall growth in 1995 would be 3 percent, that western Germany would grow 2.5 percent, and that eastern Germany -- which is being rebuilt through infusions of aid from western Germans -- would grow 8.5 percent.
The sole dissent came from the German Institute for Economic Research in Berlin, which predicted much slower growth.
The institutes also said that unemployment in both parts of the country would come down, but very slowly. German joblessness reached a high of four million workers in January and is expected to fall to 3.72 million by year's end, and only to 3.6 million by the end of 1995. That still represents a persistently high jobless rate for Germany of 9.3 percent.
"In the west and east, the fall of employment and the growth of unemployment has come to a standstill," the report said.
Though the economic analysis is made by nongovernmental institutes, it is done for the Government in Bonn. Officials of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's administration were quick to say that the findings reinforced their economic policies, and opposition politicians, quick to parry such contentions.
But the report emphasized that the German recovery could be brought to a quick halt by either tax increases or high wage increases from next year's labor negotiations.
The institutes also called on the Government to cut taxes and spur investment and consumer demand.
But the markets here today were not excessively influenced by the report. Their concern has been that the United States economy is growing so fast that the Federal Reserve will raise American interest rates again in an effort to dampen inflation.
For now, a stock analyst at a big German bank said, no one wants to buy dollars.
"There is a lot to be worried about right now," the analyst said. "The main concern is the trend of United States interest rates. As long as that is the main concern, there is nothing to cheer about in the equities market."

HEADLINE: Labor Costs Up Slightly

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Labor costs showed a small increase in the third quarter, the Government said today in a report that provided little evidence of accelerating inflation.
The Labor Department said its employment cost index for the quarter rose seven-tenths of 1 percent, compared with a gain of nine-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter. "Inflation numbers have been quite benign," said Raymond Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J. 
 But forward-looking economic indicators, like strong consumer spending and rising raw material prices, point to a faster pace of inflation ahead, he said.
For example, a report today from the National Association of Realtors showed sales of previously owned homes increased 1 percent in September even as mortgage rates climbed to two-year highs. As a result, home resales this year could reach the second-highest level on record, the real estate industry group said.
Such strength is expected to persuade the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates in November for the sixth time this year.
Home sales rose to an annual rate of 3.97 million units in September, aftera 1 percent drop in August to a 3.93 million rate. August sales were originally reported as a 1.8 precent decline.

HEADLINE: As China Upgrades Its Nuclear Arsenal, It Debates Need for Guns vs. Butter

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
In the next few months, as American and Russian reconnaissance satellites watch, China's nuclear weapons agency will lower a hydrogen bomb into an 1,800-foot shaft beneath the Gobi Desert.
Then, at the most politically opportune moment, the order will go out to detonate it.
Like one exploded earlier this month, the warhead may be the prototype for China's new submarine-launched ballistic missile. Or it may be a miniaturized warhead that could be bolted to China's first multiple-warhead missile able to reach Russian and American cities. 
 Whatever the design and function of its latest nuclear weapons, the question is: where is China's strategic enemy?
China, the world's third-largest nuclear power in terms of explosive strength, is wrestling with basic choices about the financing and deployment of its nuclear forces.
Should it build a fleet of ballistic missile submarines to give the Government added assurance that it could fire a retaliatory strike in a nuclear war, even if building such a fleet requires the diversion of billions of dollars from pressing domestic needs?
Does it need new mobile intercontinental missiles able to reach Moscow and Washington, or should it channel that investment into railroads, highways, bridges and power plants, which are all desperately needed to develop the economy?
 
Who Is the Enemy? What Is the Target?
 "It is clear that there is a great debate in China over who is the enemy and what is the target," said Prof. John W. Lewis of Stanford University, an authority on China's defense establishment and a close associate of Defense Secretary William J. Perry, who has been pressing China to stop its nuclear testing program.
Referring to China's strategic arsenal, Mr. Lewis said, "There is no consensus of what all these weapons are for anymore."
A State Department specialist on China said, "They do face an awful lot of the same kinds of questions as we do, as the French do and the Russians."
The end of the cold war has caught China's military leaders in midstream as they try to modernize their first generation of nuclear weapons and delivery systems, which were deployed in the 1970's and 1980's. The second-generation improvements in mobility, reliability and overall survivability are essential, China's military leaders assert, if China's modest deterrent force is to be credible into the next century.
By comparison, the nuclear inventories of Russia and the United States are each 20 times as large as China's. France reportedly has more warheads, but the total explosive power of China's 300 to 400 weapons makes it the third-largest nuclear weapons state by most estimates.
 
The 'Triad': Aircraft, Missiles and Subs
 China has a "triad" of strategic nuclear forces: bombs that can be delivered by aircraft, warheads on ballistic missiles and other nuclear-tipped missiles that can be fired from China's single strategic submarine.
Still, the gap between China and the superpower arsenals of Russia and the United States is huge. China's military leaders worry that their small missile force could be rendered impotent by a proposed antimissile system under study by the Clinton Administration.
Nevertheless, the perceived threat of China's nuclear might has fed fears in India, which regards itself as a potential target and uses that fear to justify its own weapons program.
The Chinese, who rarely speak in public about their nuclear weapons policy, have on rare occasions met privately with American scientists and arms control specialists. In one such discussion, in 1991, the country's leading nuclear physicist, Zhu Guangya, said, "China developed nuclear weapons for no other purpose than preventing the use of them."
"What is important," he added, is that nations "should all have adequate confidence in their security."
To the Chinese leadership their force is modest, but Western arms control experts and Chinese scientists warn that a decision by Washington to deploy antimissile systems that could defeat China's retaliatory ability could lead to a new nuclear arms race.
China might seek more warheads, and multiple-warhead delivery systems with decoys and other "penetration aids" designed to fool an American defense system.
 
U.S. Could Touch Off A New Arms Race
 Professor Paul H. B. Godwin, a specialist on the Chinese military at the National War College in Washington, says that if the United States proceeds with missile defense systems, the Chinese "will be pressed to increase the number" of their long-range missiles aimed at the United States.
Hua Di, a Chinese missile scientist who spent 20 years inside China's strategic programs and now lives in California, said in a recent interview that to prevent new enmities from arising, the United States, Russia and Japan should tolerate China's completion of its nuclear modernization program and then proceed with new arms control measures.
"The worst case would be if China became hostile to the United States," he said.
Though its economy is expanding at a rate of more than 10 percent a year, China will require vast amounts of capital to develop further and to overcome daunting problems of rapid population growth.
Huge investments in subways, airports and sea terminals are needed to sustain the economic growth that must continue if China is to provide for a country that swells by the size of the population of Australia every year.
Facing a large development bill, China's leaders are asking what kind of forces they should maintain and at what cost.
In strategic forces, "They are still building for a world that does not exist," said a senior United States analyst who specializes in China. "Their strategic programs are running under their own momentum, and they really haven't gone through a reassessment."
 
Chinese Leadership Faces Transition
 In China, this reassessment is falling upon a leadership in transition from the era of Deng Xiaoping to the generation now led by Jiang Zemin, 68, an automobile engineer who received his technical training in Moscow and rose to be Mayor of Shanghai before Mr. Deng selected him in 1989 as a compromise candidate to hold the top posts in the party and the military.
Whereas Mr. Deng as a young revolutionary commanded an army in the field and helped to nurture China's military strength over three decades, today's leaders, including Mr. Jiang, Prime Minister Li Peng, and senior Vice Premier Zhu Rongji, have never served in or commanded military forces.
Western officials are beginning to question who will chart China's military strategy in the next century. Will it be these new civilian leaders? Or will the military leaders, whose power and influence has grown since their tank and infantry forces crushed the Tiananmen Square demonstration in 1989, decide how China's resources will be spent?
"Jiang Zemin is working overtime to get the military on his side," said a former United States Ambassador to China, James Lilley, "but Jiang is a transitional figure."
A White House official interviewed in Washington said: "After Tiananmen, no politician in China is going to move very far away from what the military wants. If it were not for them, the politicians would not be there."
Though the world's other nuclear powers stopped testing in 1992, one Chinese expert estimated that there would be as many as four more tests of the miniaturization and reliability of China's new warhead designs.
Thus China is racing against time and technology, trying to deploy a modernized and more credible deterrent nuclear force for the kind of conflict that is increasingly difficult to contemplate after the end of the cold war.
"No one in China thinks that the United States is going to attack them," said Mr. Lewis, the Stanford professor, "but to maintain any effective strategic program, you have to modernize it."
 
Willingness to Sign A Test Ban Treaty
 Despite continuing underground tests, Communist Party leaders have all but committed themselves to signing a test ban treaty by 1996.
In Washington this month, China also made a commitment "to promote the earliest possible achievement" of a convention "banning the production of fissile material for nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices," said a statement signed by Foreign Minister Qian Qichen and Secretary of State Warren Christopher.
But even if these agreements are signed, they would leave a sizable Chinese nuclear arsenal intact.
Still, for China to complete its modernization, time is short.
Ever since Mao Zedong said that "power grows out of the barrel of a gun," China's Communist leaders have believed that nuclear weapons are the only instruments of mass destruction that have kept the superpowers from attacking China. As Mao put it: "If we are not to be bullied in the present-day world, we cannot do without the bomb."
Presidents Truman and Eisenhower weighed using nuclear weapons against China during the Korean and Taiwan crises of the 1950's.
"Mao said that we must have these weapons to be counted," Hua Di, the Chinese missile scientist, said in a recent interview. "China can never be an equal to either Russia or the United States. They never thought that they should have that kind of quantity or quality."
All China has ever wanted, Mr. Hua said, "is a survivable second strike," even if that meant "sending a soldier riding a bike or a horse to the missile troops to tell them to launch." That means that enough of China's arsenal would have to survive a nuclear attack, or first strike, by an enemy to make retaliation possible.
"The Chinese military is very primitive," Mr. Hua continued. "We don't need a lot of sophisticated control over our weapons. The briefcase carried by the man behind your President, we don't have that."
 
Goal Is Enough Force To Deter an Attack
 China's greatest fear for its future security, a number of specialists say, is the survivability of its strategic missiles.
United States intelligence agencies now fear that Russia, and perhaps Ukraine, are assisting China by transferring technology from the advanced SS-25 mobile missile made in Ukraine. American analysts also fear that China is getting similar assistance with the technology for multiple and independently targetable warheads.
Perhaps China's largest national investment to date in strategic delivery systems has been its only nuclear-powered ballistic missile submarine, equipped with a nuclear-tipped missile that has a range of 1,100 miles.
But the future of the ballistic missile submarine program is a mystery to outsiders.
The first submarine, which has undergone repeated sea trials since 1988, appears to have had serious technical problems. The current United States assessment is that it cannot go out on patrol with its missiles loaded and spends most of its time at its mooring.
Still, many experts, including Professor Lewis and senior American analysts, believe that China is committed to building a fleet of these submarines able to fire a new and more powerful missile with a 4,800-mile range.
"They'll build that boat, and they'll then proceed with a class," one United States official said, "and they'll get a lot of prestige from it and security, because no one can be sure that a first strike will get enough of them. There will be a sufficient handful to retaliate."

HEADLINE: Regulators And Lilly In Accord

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Bowing to the Federal Trade Commission, Eli Lilly & Company agreed yesterday to accept restrictions on operating the giant PCS Health Systems drug marketing unit, which Lilly plans to buy from the McKesson Corporation in a $4 billion deal.
Lilly, based in Indianapolis, said it would sign a consent agreement assuring that other drug makers would have access to the PCS lists of preferred drugs, according to people familiar with the case. PCS is the largest of the prescription drug benefit managers, which employers and insurers hire to make price-cutting deals with drug manufacturers. 
 Lilly would also be forbidden from seeing the bids of competitors in seeking to have the lowest-priced products on the PCS lists, which would give their drugs preferential status. Otherwise, Lilly would have the information to always submit the lowest bids.
As part of such agreements, the commission generally requires the company to get advance approval of future marketing deals that might raise antitrust concerns.
A spokesman for Lilly declined to confirm the agreement, but said the company had agreed to extend the waiting period for closing the deal under the Hart-Scott-Rodino antitrust law to Nov. 3. The company said discussions with the agency were progressing and it was "hopeful" that it would get final clearance from the commission by that date.
The agreement yesterday opens the way for Lilly to complete the purchase next month. It came as the commission prepared to take up a staff proposal to impose the restrictions, which were demanded by druggists and consumer advocacy groups, who said the deal would ultimately increase the prices for drugs.
The same issues were raised by two senators. Senator David Pryor, the Arkansas Democrat who is chairman of the Special Committee on Aging, and Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, the Ohio Democrat who is chairman of the Judiciary Committee's antitrust subcommittee, asked the commission to reopen its investigation of previously approved acquisitions of drug marketing companies.
Merck & Company bought Medco Containment Services last year for $6.6 billion. SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. bought the Diversified Pharmaceutical Services unit of United Health Care for $2 billion last spring.
The F.T.C.'s staff has been reviewing the Merck-Medco records, which were obtained by a group of California pharmacies in a lawsuit contending that the Merck-Medco pricing system discriminated against their businesses, a lawyer for the group said.
In a letter about the Lilly deal yesterday to Janet D. Steiger, chairwoman of the commission, the senators urged the agency to "scrutinize this deal closely and, if appropriate, challenge it under the Federal antitrust laws."
Companies like PCS arrange purchases of drugs at discounted prices from the manufacturers. People in these plans typically pay $5 or $10 a prescription when they present a drug-benefit card at a drugstore; their employers or insurers pay the rest.
In these health plans, the members' choices are limited. Their per-prescription payment may be $5 or $10, but only if the brand of drug is on a list of those for which their plan has arranged a discount. For drugs not on the list, called a formulary, plan members pay all or a substantial part of the retail price.
By buying the drug-benefit managers, pharmaceutical companies are trying to regain control of their markets. Such deals enable them to push their products onto the drug lists.
Mitch Daniels, head of North American pharmaceutical operations for Lilly, said in an interview that the concerns about the deal were based on "a total misunderstanding of the market place."
"The paying customer is driving this market," he said. "We will only succeed by satisfying that customer's demand for more cost-effective health care."
He said some employers still wanted their health plans to be open to all drugs in what is called an open formulary, so Lilly has always intended to offer that choice "among a variety of formulary options."
Mr. Daniels added that Lilly had told the commission from the beginning of the negotiations that it intended to maintain "strict confidentiality of pricing information," which the company already required in its own dealings with Merck and SmithKline and other drug benefit management companies.
But Stephen W. Schondelmeyer, a University of Minnesota economist who has been a consultant for the National Association of Chain Drugstores, a trade group, said the F.T.C. would have difficulty enforcing a consent agreement with Lilly because the agency's staff lacked "expertise in evaluating this market."

HEADLINE: Japan Hints at Conditions on Aid for North Korea Atom Plants

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Japan's Finance Minister hinted today that Tokyo might make its pledge to help pay for modern nuclear reactors in North Korea contingent on contributions by European countries.
In what could be the first of many debates over how to pay for the politically sensitive, multibillion-dollar project, Finance Minister Masayoshi Takemura argued in Parliament that Europe had an obligation to contribute to the North Korea project because Japan had helped to pay for the cleanup of the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear disaster. 
 Previously, it had been suggested that roughly 90 percent of the more than $4 billion cost of the project would come from South Korea and Japan, with contributions from an international consortium. South Korea's share has been estimated as high as 70 percent because the plants would eventually be merged into a broader Korean power grid if and when the two hostile neighbors are reunified.
There had been no previous explicit mention of European financing. Nor had Japan indicated before that it was putting conditions on its critical role in the project, which is aimed at eliminating North Korea's suspected nuclear weapons program and drawing Pyongyang out of its menacing isolation.
Japanese Foreign Ministry officials sought to soften Mr. Takemura's stand, saying that he was merely expressing his expectation that other major industrial countries would play a role in the project.
"This was not a precondition, in the strict sense," said one official.
But another official conceded: "Ultimately, it is a political decision. And it's not clear yet what is politically acceptable to the Japanese people."
The United States and North Korea signed an agreement last week stipulating that the North will dismantle its nuclear weapons program in return for a reliable source of electricity for its energy-starved economy and the opening of low-level diplomatic relations with the United States.
If the plan is carried through, it would represent an unprecedented level of engagement for North Korea with its neighbors and the United States.
The critical element will be construction of light-water nuclear reactors that produce substantial amounts of power but little weapons-grade plutonium, the key element in bomb production.
North Korea currently has one small reactor, and two larger ones under construction, that generate significant amounts of plutonium. Those would be dismantled under the agreement.
The United States concluded the deal only after coming up with a very general understanding with Japan and South Korea on their role in underwriting construction of the reactors. Now, some of the potential problems in settling the details may be surfacing.
One little discussed problem that some government officials have mentioned here in recent days is that the cost could reach as much as $10 billion because of the primitive nature of North Korea's economy and its road and rail system.
Hundreds of millions of dollars of roads and rail lines may have to be constructed or upgraded even before construction on the new plants can begin.
And several experts have said that several billion dollars may have to be spent to construct a new power transmission system in North Korea, because the current one is inadequate to handle a huge increase in the electricity supply.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: COMPTROLLER;
Candidates Continue Angry Tone

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN 

 BODY:
In their fifth debate, H. Carl McCall and Herb London kept up the already angry tone of their battle for the state comptroller's job, trading insults and mocking each other's platforms.
Mr. London, the Republican candidate, called Mr. McCall, the Democratic incumbent, "the Hans Christian Andersen" of New York politics, saying he was revising the facts of his tenure. Mr. McCall, in turn, accused his opponent of vigilantism because he is against tougher gun laws. 
 The two, who have debated each other more than any two opposing statewide candidates in the Nov. 8 election, have become more hostile with every meeting. Much of what they say is warmed-over quips from past debates or stump speeches, but neither passes up opportunities to take jabs at the other's record or make promises in the contest to become New York's chief auditor. Yesterday's debate, before the Long Island Association in Commack, was no exception.
Mr. London, a conservative Republican, said he would work to cut taxes in the state, and said his opponent is part of an administration that has been bad for business. Mr. London said New York has gone from being the Empire State to the "Vampire State," because its tax structure has driven businesses and jobs away.
For his part, Mr. McCall called Mr. London's proposal to eliminate the personal income tax "fiscal fantasy," and argued it would actually cause an increase in other taxes. Mr. London made the proposal in a recent interview with The Rome Daily Sentinel, but he backed off the plan later, telling reporters at a press conference that it was an "ideal" plan, but "never a realistic proposal."
"My advice to Mr. London: When in Rome, tell the truth," Mr. McCall said.
Mr. McCall said that contrary to Mr. London's contentions, he too favors tax reductions.
"When the Governor put out his executive budget in January, I criticized it because I felt it did not go far enough in providing tax relief for the citizens and particularly the businesses of New York," he said. "At my urging, the Governor did amend the budget and the legislature did pass tax cuts."
One of the comptroller's primary jobs is to act as trustee of the state's pension fund. Mr. London criticized Mr. McCall for once having said that he would consider making investments in companies with "appropriate affirmative action and other social policies."
"You want to invest in those firms that have appropriate investment stategies that are generating maximum accruals on that investment," Mr. London said. "That should be the first overarching concern when you consider your investment strategy."
Mr. McCall disagreed with the characterization of his investment strategy.
"We have made prudent, sound investments that have brought about the best possible returns to the people in the pension system," he said. "We've never even looked into the social policies or other conditions in terms of where we have made our investments."
Mr. McCall said his office is conducting an audit of the state's economic development programs to assess whether they are doing the best possible job to keep and attract businesses.
"Rather than rolling out the red carpet for business, we have rolled out the red tape," he said.
Mr. London said that as comptroller, he would be more involved in the state's budget process. He would issue an economic impact statement when the budget was announced, he said, that would show what effect it would have "on the economic landscape of New York."
"The real key to the future of this budget is a comptroller who is willing to exercise that kind of authority and use his platform as a bully pulpit for bringing about the requisite reforms," he said.

HEADLINE: Giuliani and Cutbacks: How Much Will Voters Bear?

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
The sweeping new reductions in municipal government proposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday were praised by fiscal monitors as another large step toward bringing the city's finances into structural balance. But the question that quickly emerged was, how long will such cutting remain politically sustainable?
Faced with a $1.1 billion gap in the city budget that was enacted four months ago, Mr. Giuliani acted swiftly, outlining a new round of cuts that on top of those already enacted, amount to the deepest since the fiscal crisis of the 1970's. And for the most part, the monitors said, he relied on 5,300 new work-force reductions and on program cuts, avoiding the kinds of gimmicks and one-time asset sales that can help close an immediate budget gap but do not provide any continuing savings. 
"It will not only attack this year's problem but help with the problem they have in the future years," said Eugene J. Keilin, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation.
The riskiest assumptions in the plan were intended to try to force the state to assume some costs and tasks from the city. Mr. Giuliani described his $113 million reduction in aid to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority as an effort to get the state to pay half the costs of subway passes for schoolchildren as it had just a few years ago. He also counted on a state takeover of some mental-health and alcohol-abuse services.
While such state aid may not materialize, Mr. Giuliani still won lavish praise from fiscal experts and bond raters who said that if he continued on his course, he would soon be close to achieving structural balance.
But the questions are, at what cost and for how long will the voters go along? The Mayor still faces a $1 billion deficit next year and a $1.5 billion one the year after -- although a large chunk of that deficit stems from his determination to push through a tax-cut plan.
Mr. Giuiani said yesterday that he was maintaining core services and that over time his course would lead to economic growth in the city.
But other officials were increasingly asking how Mr. Giuliani's reductions will affect the quality of life, not only for the poor but for the middle-class tax-paying base that the Mayor is seeking to keep in the city.
Will voters rebel against reductions in the pickup of recyclables? The elimination of bridge painters and maintenance workers? Cuts at the City University that could lead it to turn away students? And further deep reductions at the Board of Education, under which children have had long waits simply to get into kindergarten and some overcrowded high schools are on triple session?
Mr. Giuliani's first hurdle will be the City Council, which went along docilely with his first round of reductions last spring, unwilling to suggest a tax increase and stymied by the huge size of the city's deficit. Yesterday, City Council leaders seemed much less accepting of the second round of cuts.
"Just as we cannot tax our way out of our fiscal problem, we cannot simply cut our way out either," said Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, who pronounced, "Thanks, but no thanks," to the Mayor's new round of budget cuts, although the only alternative he suggested was unspecified cuts in bureacracy.
Outside City Hall figures as disparate as John Cardinal O'Connor and Felix G. Rohatyn, the influential municipal banker, have begun raising questions about the Mayor's course. The Cardinal spoke out last week against cuts that hurt the poor. And Mr. Rohatyn suggested to the Mayor earlier this fall that he needed a plan that would finance the sizing down of government over several years and ease the pain of repeated cutting.
Under Mr. Rohatyn's proposal -- looked at skeptically by the credit rating agencies in the past -- the city would get an infusion of borrowed cash and in return develop a multiyear, predictable scheme to further pare its work force, reduce some taxes to spur the economy and shed some services to the state.
'I don't believe you can go back and slice the salami a little thinner every three months," he said yesterday. "I think the Mayor has been doing a terrific job. But the reality of life is this structural deficit is out there. From both the psychological and morale and practical point of view you just cannot keep on doing this."
Mr. Keilin, who succeeded Mr. Rohatyn as head if the Municipal Assistance Corporation, told his board just last week that he thought it likely over time, as more cuts hit, that the momentum would build for Mr. Rohatyn's approach. And Giuliani aides have suggested that for their second budget plan next year, they are looking at a much more fundamental change in the structure of government, seeking to go beyond their piecemeal cuts.
But any plan is likely to require extensive support from the state government, either through mandate relief or a willingness to assume responsibility for some city services or agreement to allow M.A.C. financing -- which means that Mr. Giuliani will have a lot to ask from Mario M. Cuomo, the man he so dramatically endorsed this week, should the Governor win re-election.

HEADLINE: In a Mixed Session, Dow Drops 4.71

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market closed mixed yesterday as a key sale of Treasury securities indicated that short-term interest rates were headed higher.
But some soft economic data, which many traders interpreted as good for stocks and bonds, helped cushion the blow of the Treasury auction. A modest recovery by the dollar against most other leading currencies also helped. 
 Bond traders had worried about the Treasury Department's $17 billion auction yesterday of two-year notes, expecting a high yield of 6.87 percent for the notes. Instead, they got an even higher 6.88 percent. Such small shifts are closely watched by bond traders for what they portend for future rates.
The premium of 2.13 percent more than the Federal Reserve Board's 4.75 percent target for the Federal funds rate is high by historical standards, bond traders said. But that is because investors are already betting that the Fed will raise the target for the funds rate by at least half a percentage point. The Fed's policy-setting committee meets Nov. 15, but could act sooner.
Investors also reviewed the mixed reports on the economy. The Conference Board reported the fourth consecutive monthly drop in consumer confidence, while the Labor Department said wage and other costs rose a modest seven-tenths of 1 percent in the third quarter, indicating little inflation pressure. The news prompted a brief rally, in which the Dow rose by as much as 8 points. Shortly after 12:30 P.M., though, the Dow began falling in earnest.
Still, the housing market continued to show strength. September existing-home sales rose 1 percent, instead of falling three-tenths of 1 percent as analysts had expected. Earlier this month, housing starts also showed surprising strength.
The dollar recovered after setting a new low against the Japanese yen and a two-year low against the German mark. It also closed up against the French and Swiss francs.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 4.71 points to 3,850.59, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 0.69 point to 461.52. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 2.95 points to 758.26.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 326.1 million shares, about 13 percent above this year's average of 288 million shares.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.01 point to 253.51, with declining stocks outpacing advancers 1,408 to 799. The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 0.88 point to 452.85.
Among issues with notable activity yesterday were the American depository receipts for Telefonos de Mexico, the Big Board's most active at more than 11 million A.D.R.s. Telmex fell 3 1/8, to 57 3/8, after the company posted lower-than-expected quarterly earnings. A.D.R.s are sold by foreign companies in the United States in lieu of shares. One Telmex A.D.R. equals 20 ordinary shares.
Shares of Compuware, a maker of specialized computer software for computer maintenance, fell 9 3/4, to 37 3/4, also on disappointing earnings.
Dr Pepper/7 Up rose 2 1/8, to 24 1/2, after traders speculated that Cadbury Schweppes would either raise its stake in the company or initiate a takeover. In a Government filing, Cadbury said it had had unspecified talks with Dr Pepper.
Capital Cities/ABC rose 1 3/8, to 79, after an analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons raised his earnings projection and his stock assessment to "buy."
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 15 stocks fell, led by International Paper, which fell 1 5/8, to 75 1/4.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Less Demand For New Bills At Auction

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Government securities were little changed yesterday after a mildly disappointing auction of two-year notes. Retail demand was significantly lower than in recent two-year sales, traders said, disappointing many market participants who had thought the sale would be more popular.
Over all, the market remained sour. A weak dollar in the currency markets and expectations of further Federal Reserve rate increases contributed to the mood. 
 Looking beyond today's auction of five-year notes, usually a harder sell than the two-year notes, the market will be waiting for the Government release on Friday of data on how the economy performed in the third quarter.
The 30-year bond held at 9329/32 to yield 8.04 percent, unchanged from Monday. And in bills of shorter maturity, rates were virtually unchanged except for the three-month bill, which was down 4 basis points to 5.02 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
At yesterday's $17.27 billion Government auction, the two-year notes were priced to yield 6.88 percent -- the highest level in more than three years. The 6 7/8 percent coupon and the maturity date on the two-year note are identical to those of a five-year note issued on Oct. 31, 1991.
To avoid duplication, the Treasury issued new versions of the existing five-year note, which has only two years to maturity, instead of a new two-year note. Ahead of yesterday's auction, traders were expecting a yield of 6.87 percent. The 6.88 percent yields was 33 basis points greater than the yield last month of 6.55 percent.
Kevin McClintock, manager of fixed-income portfolios for Aeltus Investment Management, predicted that the bear market would continue. "The question is, where does it stop?" he said. "I personally think it won't stop for a while."
While Mr. McClintock said the market could enjoy a brief respite, he said the Fed had not yet tightened monetary policy enough to turn the tide. "Without a 100-basis point move by the Fed, we're likely not to see a change to the up trend in interest rates," he said.
The market did receive some support from the Labor Department, which reported that businesses' wage, salary and benefit costs rose a modest seven-tenths of a percent in the third quarter. That bolstered the case that there is little evidence of accelerating inflation. What's more, the consumer confidence index slipped to 87.7 for October, slightly lower than anticipated. The October index included a rise in current conditions to 90.3 from 89.5, but a decline in expectations to 85.9 from 89.5. That helped the market to recover from some early losses.
But the consumer confidence measure for the previous month was revised up to 89.5 from 88.4. Putting it all together, analysts said there was not enough change in the index to warrant a shift in the outlook for consumer spending.
Despite slight improvement as the day moved on, the potential for any meaningful gains was limited. That is because bondholders viewed any uptick in the market price as an opportunity to sell before prices dipped further.
Later in the afternoon the bond slipped back, with few buyers willing to come in before today's tougher five-year auction. They were also nervous that Friday's report on gross domestic product might not meet expectations of an advance of 2.5 to 3 percent in the third quarter.
In the municipal bond market, the City of Chicago sold $274.7 million of general airport second-lien refunding revenue bonds for O'Hare airport. The bonds were issued through Merrill Lynch. The tax-exempt financing produced a maximum yield of 6.78 percent for a bond due in 2015.
For another long maturity, investors were offered a bond due in 2012 that was priced to yield 6.735 percent. Shorter-maturity serial bonds were priced to yield from 6.10 percent in 2005 to 6.50 percent in 2009.
Underwriters said that because interest and principal were insured by the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corporation, the financing was rated triple-A by rating agencies.
