HEADLINE: New York Seeking To Retake Housing Fixed by Squatters

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
When Peter Spagnuolo first saw the building on East 13th Street that he now calls home it was little more than a roofless hulk -- burned by arsonists and stripped by vandals of its wiring, windows and bathroom and kitchen fixtures.
The city, which owned the building, paid little attention as Mr. Spagnuolo and others who needed places to live dug out the garbage and debris, rebuilt the roof, reconnected plumbing lines and wiring and put back kitchens and bathrooms. 
 But now, six years later, New York officials want it back. Having already rehabilitated most of the abandoned apartment buildings it took over in the 1970's and 80's, the city is now planning to take over buildings occupied by Mr. Spagnuolo, his neighbors and other squatters as a way of providing housing for low-income families and the homeless.
The squatters, though, are fighting back, pledging not to be moved.
"When we got here, these buildings, this street was dangerous and dirty," said Mr. Spagnuolo, a poet, who added that he had lived in the building at 541 East 13th Street since 1988. "We cleaned up the buildings, chased away drug dealers and helped to make this street a decent place to live again. That deserves recognition."
Although hundreds of squatters are encamped in about 50 abandoned city-owned buildings, over the years officials have largely let them alone and in a few cases actually helped them make homes out of the decrepit buildings. But housing officials say that with thousands of people on waiting lists for low-rent apartments, they have no choice but to go after the buildings that the squatters call home.
"These are very thorny issues, how to balance the equities," said Deborah C. Wright, Commissioner of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development. "It would be different if their argument was that we were doing nothing to expand housing opportunities for low-income people. But it is unfair to ask people who have been waiting for the housing there to just continue to wait. We can't sanction what these folks have done just because time has passed."
The building where Mr. Spagnuolo lives, for example, is to undergo total rehabilitation before being sold to a nonprofit community organization that will rent apartments to low-income families and the homeless. Altogether, there are five buildings on the block, now occupied by squatters, that the housing agency wants to redevelop at a cost of $3.9 million.
Though the city is determined to reclaim buildings where squatters have nested, evictions will not be easy, especially on East 13th Street. Many of the squatters have been in the buildings for years and are likely to dig in their heels. Moreover, they have vocal supporters who have disrupted meetings and who have promised to challenge the city with force if the squatters are removed.
The city is also being challenged in court.
In June, a State Supreme Court judge ordered the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, which has jurisdiction over the apartment buildings the city has taken in foreclosure, to return four families to the building they had been occupying illegally on 168th Street.
At the behest of the housing department, the police had removed them in April. But Justice Carol H. Arber State Supreme Court in Manhattan said the squatters were entitled to court hearings.
Earlier this month, the squatters on East 13th Street, believing that eviction proceedings were imminent, obtained a temporary restraining order from Judge Elliott Wilk of Civil Court, barring the city from ejecting them until a hearing is held on Nov. 2.
Urging that the city reach a compromise with the squatters, Judge Wilk said it seemed "pointless to me to take people there, to throw them out into the street to replace them with people from the street."
Housing officials say the court action has not deterred them. They say the squatters on East 13th Street are trespassers whose occupancy is not only illegal but dangerous to them, their families and others on the block. The electric and plumbing systems in the buildings, the officials contend, have not passed the city's building code inspections.
"We see no legal basis that prevents us from developing these city-owned buildings as permanent housing for 41 low-income and former homeless families," said Mara Neville, a spokeswoman for the housing department.
But the squatters argue that without them the buildings would have long ago decayed beyond any hope of repair.
"It would be a wrecking ball, not renovation crews that the city would be bringing here if it were not for us," said Sam Smith, a carpenter and plumber who helped rebuild the building at 539 East 13th Street, where he has lived for five years. "You can't neglect buildings the way these were and expect to come back years later and to turn them into housing again."
The squatters and their friends have transformed some apartments from dank hovels into decent living spaces where floors have been sanded smooth and where plasterboard, paint and new linoleum conceal the scars of years of neglect.
Still, the buildings have no boilers and are chilly even on warm, sunny days. Some residents use illegal heaters in winter. Visitors must navigate staircases with missing steps and banisters. The buildings have no intercoms or security buzzers, and visitors often announce their arrival by shouting from the street.
The occupants of the five adjacent buildings to be renovated -- 535, 537, 539, 541 and 545 East 13th Street -- have hired a lawyer, Jacqueline Bucowski, to fight eviction in court. One argument she will make, the squatters say, will be for rights by "adverse possession." It is a legal principle that holds that someone who has had the continuous use of someone else's property without a formal objection or notice to vacate has a right to keep using it.
The squatters will present telephone and utility bills and citations from the city's Sanitation and Fire Departments as evidence that their occupancy has been acknowledged. In fact, the morning some squatters met a reporter to discuss their court case, a Con Edison worker arrived to read the electricity meter in one building.
Affordable-housing advocates estimate that there are as many as 2,000 people encamped in loosely organized communities in the South Bronx and on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.
It was in these neighborhoods during the 1960's and 1970's that thousands of landlords abandoned their apartment buildings amid growing urban blight and a declining economy. Over the years, squatters moved into some buildings, but the city looked the other way. There was little interest from a nearly bankrupt government in turning squatters out of buildings the city could not afford to repair.
Beginning in 1980, the city even sanctioned squatting to a certain degree through a homesteading program that allowed some community groups to take over abandoned buildings. Groups like Banana Kelly in the South Bronx and Acorn in Brooklyn started as homesteading organizations.
But when the city's economic health improved in the 1980's and the struggle to cope with a growing homeless population increased, housing officials began to look to the hundreds of vacant buildings it owned. In 1986, when the city announced its 10-year housing plan, the goal was to reclaim 53,000 units in abandoned or dilapidated buildings. At the end of last year, only 6,000 apartments were left to be renovated.
The availability of Federal tax credit money, which helped pay for renovations, made these vacant properties more valuable still. And a recent effort by the Giuliani administration to turn city-owned buildings over to private owners puts even more pressure on housing officials to reclaim the buildings.
"I have sympathy for anyone in a housing crisis," said Ms. Wright, the head of the housing preservation department. "But we are at a stage in our effort to recover this housing where there are no more easy jobs."
She added, "With the money available now for renovating these buildings, we need to move forward."
In the South Bronx, many of the squatters are newly arrived immigrants from Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic. For them, settling in abandoned buildings is their way of staying out of city shelters.
By contrast, many of the squatters on the Lower East Side are artists and bohemians who were pushed out of the historically cheap living spaces in their neighborhood when gentrification spread to the area about 10 years ago.
"These buildings represented my only opportunity to stay in my community and continue to work in the theater," said Xavier Muhammad, an actor and playwright who said he has lived at 535 East 13th Street since 1986. "The city really needs to maintain housing opportunities for people like me. And besides, people on the Mayor's staff can get breaks on housing; why can't we?"
Mr. Muhammad was among the residents of East 13th Street who gathered on the block one day recently to hear Mr. Spagnuolo report on the previous day's court proceedings. Mr. Spagnuolo told them that Judge Wilk, who issued the restraining order, seemed to be urging a compromise when he asked the attorney for the Department of Housing Preservation and Development if the agency would consider giving squatters whose incomes qualified them for subsidized housing an opportunity to return to the buildings after the renovations had been completed.
"That is really not a solution as far as we are concerned," said Chris Schaffer, a squatter who joined the discussion. "We don't consider L.E.S.H.C. part of this community," he said, refering Lower East Side Housing Coalition, the group slated to take the buildings from the city and operate them as housing for the poor.
Ms. Bucowski, the squatters' lawyer, insisted that none of her clients have been part of the disruptive confrontations over squatters' rights that have taken place at some community meetings. But last month, the police were called when an angry crowd confronted members of Community Board 3 when it gathered to vote on the city's housing plan on East 13th Street. In an earlier incident, protesters locked board members into the community center where they were meeting and tossed stink bombs in through windows.
"We are not looking for a fight," Mr. Spagnuolo said. "We want amnesty and to be allowed to live and work here."

When he moved in there was no roof, and vandals had taken the building's wiring, windows and bathroom and kitchen fixtures. (Photographs by Edward Keating/The New York Times) (pg. B3)

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Copper Near a 4-Year High; Lumber Is Off and Cotton Up

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Copper reached its highest price in almost four years yesterday with rising world demand depleting supplies. Inventories have tumbled this year, the result of record consumption in the United States and of rising use in Europe and in growing economies of East Asia.
Inventories on the London Metals Exchange have dropped 45 percent so far in 1994. In the United States, Commodity Exchange copper inventories have plunged 82 percent to the lowest level since February 1991. 
 "Everyone's using base-metal products," said Michael Frawley, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds in New York. "We're seeing signs of improved consumption in Germany, France and the U.K., and also from the Far East."
Comex copper for December delivery rose 1.35 cents to $1.1925 a pound yesterday, the highest price for an active futures month since January 1991.
On other markets, lumber futures fell and cotton rose while gasoline was unchanged. The Commodity Research Bureau index was down 0.79 point, to 232.25.
Lumber dropped the daily trading limit, as demand weakened with building activity expected to slow during the winter.
"There's still a fair amount of housing activity out there," said Jim Sterrett, general sales manager for lumber and plywood at Boise Cascade. Even so, "nobody wants to get caught with extra wood" when winter curtails building activity, he said.
Lumber for November delivery fell $10 to $321.70 per 1,000 board feet on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
Cotton rose to its highest price in more than a month amid concern that the cotton crop in the Mississippi Delta might be smaller at a time of rising international demand.
December cotton rose 1.37 cents to settle at 71.97 cents a pound on the New York Cotton Exchange, the highest price for an active contract since Sept. 14.

HEADLINE: What's for Lunch? American

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
IT was lunch time at Public School 144 in Forest Hills, Queens, and nearly 200 youngsters crowded along the beige picnic-style tables, tearing into brown bags and plastic boxes as if they were birthday gifts.
Others lined up for hot food served on trays as two cafeteria workers dished out sandwiches and pizza and gently prodded the children to take some salad and not to forget their milk. 
 The school's 600 students may speak a total of 62 languages, but when it comes to lunch, American is the food of choice. Indeed, the lunches consumed by this group of ethnically diverse youngsters are not all that different from what children in the 1950's might have packed in their Howdy Doody lunch boxes, right down to the Tootsie Roll pops.
"A cheese sandwich," Janece Lee, 7, said in between bites. "I also got Cherrios and M & M's. Oh, yeah, and water to drink."
"Peanut butter and jelly," exclaimed Nalik Zeigler, 11, smacking his lips for emphasis. It's his favorite sandwich in the "whole wide world." He takes a peanut butter and jelly sandwich -- the hands-down favorite among children -- for lunch every day. "I also got a chocolate doughnut, a Slim Jims and Tootsie pop," he said.
Radhika Chopra, 7, had a British-style version of peanut butter and jelly.
"It's butter and jelly," she said.
Butter and marmalade to be exact.
Regardless of gender, race, region or socioeconomic class, most children in the country seem to eat the same things for lunch. More than two dozen children interviewed recently about their school lunch preferences followed the patterns of children across the United States, a nation of peanut butter and jelly eaters.
Sydell Kane, the principal at P.S. 144, at 93-02 69th Avenue, has noticed, for example, that when new students from immigrant families first attend her school, they often bring lunches that reflect their ethnic backgrounds.
"The Japanese kids would bring sushi, and children from the Caribbean might have beef paddies," she said. "You'd see sandwiches on pita bread or tortillas. But after a few months, those same children would be eating cheese or bologna sandwiches or pizza from the hot lunch menu."
The most popular items children carry for lunch, aside from sandwiches, include fruits (with apples and bananas topping the popularity chart), followed by potato chips, cookies, candy, cake and crackers, says Harry Balzer, the vice president of the NPD Group Inc., a market-research company in Park Ridge, Ill., that conducts periodic surveys on national eating trends. The favorite beverages are fruit juice or fruit drinks, followed by soft drinks and milk.
He says that children are no different from adults when it comes to lunch.
"We don't change what we eat all that much," Mr. Balzer said. "The sandwich, by far, is still the most popular carried item. It's the last big homemade meal in America."
In public schools, about 18 percent of the children take lunch from home, according to the United States Department of Agriculture's 1993-94 figures. Nearly 56 percent eat lunch provided at school through the National School Lunch Program, compared with 49 percent in 1969, the first year such rates were recorded. The rest eat lunch in a restaurant or at home or eat no lunch at all.
Even though the food taken to school has remained American, foods served in school cafeterias are becoming more diverse. But the children don't quite see it that way.
"Pizza comes from . . . from . . . Domino's!" Christina Guadalupe, 10, said with a giggle, when asked the origins of the pizza she was eating.
What might have been considered ethnic cuisine 10 years ago, like tortillas, pizza, fried rice and beef paddies, seem American to students today. Taco chips are as likely to be found in lunch boxes and cafeterias as potato chips. Food experts attribute the trend to the rise of fast-food chains featuring ethnic foods.
And despite an ever-growing emphasis on nutritionally balanced, low-fat, low-cholesterol meals, parents, dietitians and school administrators often find themselves yielding to the culinary whims of youth.
Along with pizza and tacos, pancakes, hot dogs, sloppy Joes and hamburgers appear on school lunch menus from Denver to Forest Hills.
"How can I compete with Taco Bells and Domino's?" asked Suzanne Brown, a Denver mother. The two franchises supply items from their menus to certain schools in Denver. When school opened last month, Mrs. Brown painstakingly prepared lunch for her 6-year-old son, Cody, to carry to school. Two weeks ago, he told her to bag lunch for the rest of the year.
"I want to buy lunch at school," Cody said. "I love Upside Down Day -- we get pancakes on waffles."
In fact, breakfast seems to have become a popular lunch.
At P.S. 144, Krista Pedernera, 12, brought a cheese and egg sandwich. Pop Tarts are a virtual must for Jamie Rodgers, 6, of Chicago. And Lauren Williams, 6, of Washington, said she'd take poached eggs for lunch any day over hot dog and beans.
Children are at a loss for words to explain their taste buds and quirks -- like not eating their sandwiches unless they are cut diagonally with the crust intact.
"I just like tuna," David Geller, 7, said after a brief thoughtful pause, when asked why he chose the tuna over pizza, ham and cheese, chicken paddy and fish sticks on P.S. 144's hot lunch menu. "It tastes good," he said. "It's, it's just good, that's all."
Patrice Williams, 11, was eating pizza. "I hate fish," she said.
Why?
"I just don't like it," she squealed.
A recent study by researchers at the University of Washington School of Medicine in Seattle, who examined the food choices of students at 16 elementary schools in Bellevue, Wash., found that children will choose a low-fat lunch 30 percent of the time if it is presented as an option, rather than a must. But Royal Rodgers doesn't plan to leave that option to her 12-year-old son, David.
"His school cafeteria is like a short-order cook," said Mrs. Rodgers, whose son and daughter, Jamie, attend Francis Parker School in Chicago. "There are sandwiches on the menu, salads, hot dogs, fries. I know David. If it's left up to him, he'd eat hot dogs and french fries every day."
So Mrs. Rodgers does her "Mommie thing" and prepares lunch to be taken to school. She tries to make it balanced, with fruits or vegetable sticks, a sandwich and juice or milk, rather than soft drinks. Sometimes, she conceded, it's a losing battle.
Jamie, her mother has observed, would be content with one of those Oscar Mayer Lunchables, a packaged snack of crackers, cheese, ham, turkey or bologna, and David has taken to buying subs, occasionally, at a sandwich shop. "They make good ham-and-cheese subs there," he explained.
Perhaps an examination of untouched leftovers best explains what children prefer.
At the end of the lunch hour at P.S. 144, a case of low-fat milk had barely been touched, but the whole-milk and chocolate-milk cases were half empty. The salads, served with French dressing, were not very popular; many were tossed in the trash. The fruit cups outranked the cole slaw.
It's easy to see why some foods are left alone: some children have a taste all their own.
Kate Ekman, 7, explained her lunch of a sandwich of white bread slathered with melted chocolate, along with chocolate chip cookies, chocolate milk and raisins. "I like chocolate," she said simply.

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW: THE LAST SEDUCTION;
A Femme Fatale Who Lives Up To the Description

BYLINE: By JANET MASLIN 

 BODY:
A hired assassin, an innocent fall guy and a husband and wife intent on killing each other made a sterling film noir spectacle out of "Red Rock West," John Dahl's recently released sleeper. Now Mr. Dahl, whose work will never again fall into the sleeper category, is back with "The Last Seduction," which makes his earlier miscreants look like a collection of cream puffs. "Red Rock West" was memorably smart and steely. But it's a walk in the park picking buttercups compared with this.
Nothing else about "The Last Seduction" is as polite or colorless as its title. Certainly not Bridget Gregory (Linda Fiorentino), the hot, slinky monster who is this film's central character. There were 1940's noir heroines with Bridget's brand of undiluted self-interest, but she also throws in a few tricks from the "Basic Instinct" school of interpersonal relations. Only in the insect or animal worlds are there comparable models for feminine behavior. And the female praying mantis is nicer to her mates than Bridget is to the men in this movie. 
 It takes about five minutes for Mr. Dahl to establish Bridget's breathtaking ruthlessness, as she robs her husband Clay (Bill Pullman) of the proceeds from a drug deal. Maybe she does this because Clay treated her a little badly, and maybe she's just ready for new scenery. Anyway, Bridget takes the money and leaves New York City, winding up in Beston, a friendly little town near Buffalo. No one in Beston has ever seen anything like Bridget, and neither have you.
Both Mr. Dahl, who directs this film with stunning economy, and Ms. Fiorentino, whose performance is flawlessly hard-boiled, exult in the sheer wickedness of Bridget's character. What make this easy to do are Bridget's stony seductiveness and her spellbinding talent for getting exactly what she wants. For instance, she soon appropriates Mike Swale (Peter Berg), a naive Beston resident who's wowed by Bridget's drop-dead sophistication. Their meeting alone, with Bridget unceremoniously unzipping Mike's pants in a crowded barroom, is guaranteed to make every man in the audience squirm. And wonder what's next.
Bridget, now using the name Wendy, lures Mike into one-half of an intense affair. (She herself remains maddeningly aloof.) Meanwhile, she puts down a few tentative roots in Beston, despite the fact that the neighbors' neighborliness is enough to make her cringe. She rents a house in suburbia (Mr. Dahl has great fun with that little contrast) and finds a job at the insurance company where Mike works. But she wants to keep their relationship a secret, so she slaps Mike when he tries talking to her at the office. "A woman loses 50 percent of her authority when people find out who she's sleeping with," Bridget declares.
Bridget will not be mistaken for a crusading feminist. Her outlook is much too selfishly pathological to have a political edge, and her glamour is too scarily seductive. Besides, Bridget is a more darkly fascinating anomaly, with old-style killer instincts along with a liberated aggressiveness that suits the present day. The audience can only sit back and watch in astonishment as Bridget embroils Mike in an intricate, deadly scheme that harks back to James M. Cain, while also doing her best to keep Clay off her trail.
"Red Rock West" had a mostly nocturnal look and eventually bogged down under the weight of its genre affectations. "The Last Seduction," which opens today at Sony Village Theater VII, looks sunnier and sounds less derivative. That's because its malice is so nonchalant and springs from the depths of Bridget's character, not from the machinations of an overloaded plot. Steve Barancik's clever screenplay builds up carefully and delivers a perfect payoff, one that suits the story while also acknowledging Bridget's very special toughness.
"Why do I have to turn off the lights?" Mike asks, when Bridget tries to give him orders about how to commit a murder. But of course: that's the heart of any noir-based love story.
"Pop psychology," she answers. "Let yourself know you've finished an unpleasant chore."
"The Last Seduction," a devilishly entertaining crime story with a heroine who must be seen to be believed, is as satisfying an ensemble piece as "Red Rock West." J. T. Walsh, who was also in "Red Rock," shows up as Bridget's lawyer and asks her the question on every mind: "Anyone check you for a heartbeat lately?" Mr. Pullman is especially good as a man who really did deserve to be married to Bridget, and clearly gave as good as he got while the union lasted, with all the dark humor that job demanded.
Mr. Berg is gently appealing and makes the perfect chump, which is no small compliment in such a story. And Bill Nunn has some fine scenes as the private investigator who thinks he can get the best of Bridget. Maybe male praying mantises feel that way, too.
Mr. Dahl's early admirers will find the promise of "Red Rock West" (and one other film, "Kill Me Again") furthered by a gripping story and a tight, suspenseful directorial style, not to mention a heroine who's literally to die for. Mr. Dahl was good to begin with, and now he's badder and better.
"The Last Seduction" is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It includes profanity, explicit sexual situations and partial nudity.

THE LAST SEDUCTION

HEADLINE: Necessary Budget Pain

 BODY:
Confronting a real budget crisis, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has offered a new plan for more spending cuts. The supposedly balanced budget that the New York City Council adopted barely four months ago has already developed a huge gap -- $1.1 billion according to Mr. Giuliani, and possibly even more. The Mayor has made impressive headway in reducing the city payroll and negotiating better contracts with city unions. But it is time now to squeeze harder.
If the June reductions were painful, the new cuts will be more so because they carve deeper into programs that have already been trimmed. For the first time, there is a small cut in the police budget. Indeed, the new plan is page after page of mostly small trims, a little here, a little there. The Mayor is headed in the right direction, but the big savings that could right the basic imbalance in the city's finances have yet to happen -- for example, major productivity gains in labor contracts or fundamental welfare reform. Likewise, his search for programs that can be terminated is moving slowly. 
 The pain in the new spending plan is everywhere. City funding for soup kitchens would be phased out gradually to allow time for private funding to take over, assuming that it will. Snatching $113 million from the Transit Authority's current surplus may not hurt immediately, but the Mayor means it as a permanent cut in the city's subsidy for students' bus and subway fares.
Such cuts illustrate the dilemma confronting the Mayor and Council. The choices are open to criticism. They eliminate services that have clear merit. Similarly, the loss of 2,100 civilian employees at the Police Department will make it harder to put more cops out on the street. But there are no easy economies to be had. Another mayor might have made different choices, but Mr. Giuliani's overall approach seems prudent if painful.
On the day he took office in January, Mr. Giuliani faced a daunting $2.3 billion deficit in the budget year beginning July 1. It was worse than any gap since the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's. He closed it with cuts for most city agencies, notably exempting the police and fire departments, and with hopes for more tax revenues and more state and Federal aid than actually developed. His overall plan came to $31.6 billion, and the Council adopted it in June with little substantive change.
Within a few weeks, however, state authorities estimated that the new budget was seriously short because the Mayor was counting too heavily on savings and outside aid that looked unlikely. He now acknowledges they were right in large part, but his $1.1 billion estimate of the gap is still $300 million smaller than the latest estimate by Alan Hevesi, the City Comptroller.
By law, the City Council can only approve or disapprove the Mayor's entire plan, but in reality there will be negotiations and further modifications. The bottom line must be the same, though, because there is a $1.1 billion gap that must be closed. After that, still bigger gaps loom in years to come. This painful round is only a beginning.

HEADLINE: A Choice and an Echo

BYLINE: By Robert Eisner; Robert Eisner is author of "The Misunderstood Economy: What Counts and How to Count It."

DATELINE: EVANSTON, Ill.

 BODY:
Just when the Democrats seemed to have something going with their attacks on the Republicans' "Contract With America," the Republicans have pounced on a counterweapon -- an internal Administration memo prepared by Budget Director Alice Rivlin. Titled "Big Choices," the memo is a list of largely unpopular options to hold the deficit in check and permit adequate financing of programs like the new national service corps, welfare reform and Head Start.
There is a fundamental difference, though, between the two documents. The Republican contract was signed by more than 300 candidates for Congress and presented by their leader, Newt Gingrich. The memo by Ms. Rivlin, a distinguished economist, is a set of hypothetical choices, with no endorsement from President Clinton or anyone else. 
 There is another difference: the Republicans tell us we can increase military spending, cut taxes and balance the budget at the same time and asks us to endorse that impossibility with our votes. Ms. Rivlin is at least honest. She says we have to choose.
But this does not necessarily mean that deficit reduction should be placed above all else. It is hardly clear that the tremendous deficit reduction Mr. Clinton has already achieved -- down this year to $203 billion from a Bush Administration forecast of $270 billion -- has won the Democrats many votes.
The Clinton Administration's focus on deficit cutting has caused it almost as much difficulty in enacting its programs as have Republican filibusters. The White House and the Congress are in a straitjacket that prevents them from spending more for one program without cutting something else. It is like telling your daughter that she cannot have a college loan and her education will have to be financed out of her brother's food money.
More important, curbing Social Security benefits is simply a bad idea, whether it is mentioned as a possibility in an internal Democratic laundry list or whether it is implicit in a Republican contract. Reductions in cost-of-living allowances would not only hurt the elderly, they would hurt the economy by reducing purchasing power just when our growth may be in danger of collapsing. And cutting Medicare or Medicaid, by leaving people sicker, would also undermine economic health.
Yet there could be a White House memo that the Democrats would be happy to see leaked. This one would set forth a comprehensive well-financed program to prevent and not merely punish street crime. It would include measures to bring up a new generation of educated citizens whowould be productive in a technologically advanced economy. It would include a program to support the basic research necessary for scientific and economic progress. It would include money for public investment on which economic growth depends.
I'll bet there are many such memos floating around the Clinton Administration. Perhaps if one or two were leaked, the voters could begin to see more clearly some of the real choices they have to make.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 5; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 280 words

HEADLINE: Debate on Race and I.Q. Recalls Past Prejudice;
No Evolutionary Reason

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Jim Holt's article on "The Bell Curve" (Op-Ed, Oct. 19) made a number of important biological points about race and intelligence. His perspective becomes even richer if we consider the context of our evolutionary history. 
 Until about 150 years ago the vast majority of all people on all continents were illiterate subsistence agriculturists. Before 10,000 years ago we were all hunters and gatherers. The modern era has not existed long enough to cause genetic change.
For the majority, pre-modern conditions probably did not require different levels of intelligence. And the tiny pre-modern literate elites were not independent breeding populations. In short, there is no evolutionary reason to expect genetic difference between races or classes.
Furthermore, evidence from mitochondria DNA suggests that the line leading to present-day Asian populations split from the line leading to Africans and Europeans before Africans and Europeans split from each other. So if Europeans and Asians are more intelligent than Africans, increased intelligence would have had to evolve independently on two occasions, which is highly unlikely and very hard to explain.
It seems odd that in the 19th century, when Europe dominated the world economy, whites scored higher than Asians on intelligence tests. According to "The Bell Curve," Asians are now smarter. So who was smartest in the ninth century A.D., Muslim Spaniards? In 4000 B.C., the Egyptians? I doubt we have evolved a mechanism that varies intelligence with gross national product in 50-year intervals.
 
WILL PFLAUM
Professor of Anthropology
Medgar Evers College, CUNY
Brooklyn, Oct. 19, 1994

HEADLINE: New Jerseyans Learned the Hard Way About Cutting Taxes;
A Levy on Vacant Lots

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Promises and Deficits" (column, Oct. 19), Bob Herbert notes the ominous implications for New York City in the income tax cuts proposed by George E. Pataki, the Republican candidate for governor of New York. Mr. Herbert quotes City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone: "If you're going to cut the personal income tax, you're going to have to make it up with real estate taxes and sales tax increases. Those are the only other broad-based taxes." 
 The effect of such tax increases has always been to depress business activity and the tax base. However, there is one broad-based tax that increases economic activity: a tax on the unimproved value of land, coupled with a reduced tax burden on structures. This would increase the holding cost of vacant or underused land and lower the penalty for construction or renovation.
About 10 percent of the land in Manhattan is vacant. At least an equal area is grossly underused -- by rundown tenements, parking lots or peep shows.
New York City could take a solid step toward fiscal self-sufficiency with an increased levy on land assessments. Our city does not need to go begging to Albany or Washington just to meet its legitimate expenses.
A higher tax on land, coupled with a reduced levy on buildings, is working today in Pittsburgh and 14 other Pennsylvania cities, as well as in major cities in Australia, Denmark and Taiwan. How long can New York afford to ignore this potent economic remedy?
 
LINDY DAVIES
Astoria, Queens, Oct. 19, 1994

HEADLINE: THE JORDAN-ISRAEL ACCORD: THE OVERVIEW;
Israel and Jordan Sign a Peace Accord

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ARAVA CROSSING, Israel, Oct. 26

 BODY:
At this desert outpost along their border, desolate except for their hopes, Israel and Jordan signed a peace treaty today to put behind them 46 years of war, mistrust and fear for tomorrow.
Israel's second full peace with an Arab country, coming 15 years after its treaty with Egypt, was witnessed under a lacerating midday sun by more than 4,500 guests and by President Clinton, who added his signature to documents signed by the two countries' Prime Ministers. 
 With Israel also having agreed to the start of Palestinian self-rule in parts of the occupied territories, it is now closer than ever to a long-held goal of coming to terms with all of its immediate Arab neighbors.
"This vast bleak desert hides great signs of life," Mr. Clinton said against a backdrop of sand and sage brush in an area known as the Arava Valley. "Today we see the proof of it, for peace between Jordan and Israel is no longer a mirage. It is real. It will take root in this soil. It will grow to great heights and shelter generations to come."
Speaking before the President, King Hussein of Jordan said the countries had turned the Arava into "a valley of peace." Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel referred to the many mine fields that speckle the border and said they should be supplanted by "fields of plenty." [Excerpts from speeches and the agreement are on pages A12 and A13.]
With their treaty, the two sides settled long-standing land and water disputes, agreed to broad cooperation in tourism, trade and other areas, and pledged that neither would let its territory be used as a staging area by third countries for military strikes against the other.
But even as the principal figures talked of displacing old sorrows with new aspirations, they were bluntly reminded that full Middle East peace remains elusive.
At about the time that the signing ceremony began this afternoon just north of the Gulf of Aqaba, guerrillas in southern Lebanon fired mortar bombs into northern Israel. It was not clear who had done the firing, but suspicion focused on the Iranian-backed Party of God, an Islamic group opposed to Arab peace with the Israelis.
In response, Israeli forces and their Lebanese militia allies unleashed artillery rounds at hills said to be guerrilla strongholds. While no casualties were reported on either side of the border, the incident underlined the distance that Israel must still travel for peace with Lebanon and its patron, Syria.
It is also far from full peace with the Palestinians, a point reinforced by a general strike in East Jerusalem and the West Bank called by three factions of the Palestine Liberation Organization and by the militant Islamic group known as Hamas. Thousands of Palestinians also marched in the West Bank town of Hebron and Nablus to protest the Israeli-Jordanian treaty, which has been denounced by Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman.
Specifically, Mr. Arafat was angered by a section of the treaty that recognizes Jordan's "historic role" as guardian of Islamic shrines in Jerusalem. To the P.L.O. leader, that represents a direct challenge by both Jordan and Israel to his own claims to primacy over the holy sites and to his desire to establish East Jerusalem as the capital of his hoped-for state.
But in the Arava, that anger seemed remote, easily absorbed by the ceremony's warmth and by the desert's shimmering heat. Thousands of soldiers and police from Jordan and Israel had sealed off the area, and there were no incidents reported.
Temperatures were in the high 90's as the ceremony got underway on the dot at 1 P.M. -- hardly the best time to be under the Arava sun but perfect for the network morning news programs just beginning on the East Coast in the United States.
In that sense, it was Mr. Clinton's show from the moment he stepped out of a black limousine and on to a red carpet stretching before him alongside a black Bedouin tent that briefly gave the major figures the only shade they enjoyed during the 90-minute ceremony.
The President was accompanied by his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, who even in an age when such things are not supposed to matter caused a rustling in the crowd by turning out in a suit of the same turquoise shade as the one worn by King Hussein's wife, Queen Noor.
The guests, roughly 2,000 each from Jordan and Israel and 500 or so more from the United States, formed a Who's Who of politicians, diplomats, business leaders and clergymen, from black-hatted rabbis to Imams in flowing robes.
Foreign Ministers from 10 nations attended, not counting Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev of Russia. Their countries, despite the clear American dominance, are formally co-sponsors of Middle East peace talks that began in October 1991, producing little until Israel, the P.L.O. and Jordan basically took matters into their own hands.
Significantly, in front rows of white plastic chairs spread before the carpeted podium were representatives of eight Arab or other Muslim countries. Egypt was the only one to have diplomatic relations with Israel. The others were Tunisia and Morocco -- both of which recently established lower-level ties to Israel -- Oman, Qatar, Algeria, Malaysia and Mauritania. They all entered the ceremony area from the Jordanian side of the border.
Conspicuously absent were President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, a leading patron of Middle East peace, and Mr. Arafat, even though without their agreements with Israel it was unlikely that King Hussein would have been so bold as to strike his own separate deal.
Neither was invited, Mr. Mubarak because the King had not been on good terms with him and Mr. Arafat because neither side really wanted him. And after he was snubbed, the P.L.O. leader made sure that no one else from his organization went.
But definitely on hand was the past.
It came in the persons of graying guests on both sides who had been wounded in wars between the countries, from Israel's creation in 1948 to its spectacular triumph in the Middle East war of 1967.
That war marked the start of King Hussein's acceptance of Israel's permanence, and despite often rocky, even hostile, relations over the decades, he has maintained regular contact with Israeli leaders. It was only this year, though, that he decided to strike out on his own, leaving more powerful Syria behind, to bring his relationship with Israel into the light.
The past was there, too, with victims of terrorism who were in the viewing stands, and with their relatives, and with two young girls -- an Israeli and a Jordanian, each the granddaughter of a soldier killed in 1967 -- who handed flowers to the leaders on stage.
And it was there, a dogged ghost, in the words of the Jordanian King and the Israeli Prime Minister, aging war horses who have grown old together and have visibly grown to like one another.
"We will always cherish the memory and honor of all those people who have fallen over the years from amongst all of our peoples," the King said, adding:
"I believe they are with us on this occasion and at this time, as we come together to insure, God willing, that there will be no more death, no more misery, no more suspicion, no more fear, no more uncertainty of what each day might bring, as has been the case in the past."
Taking his turn and reading from notes, Mr. Rabin also spoke of the "many days of sorrow" that led to today.
"For nearly two generations, desolation pervaded the heart of our two peoples," he said. "The time has now come not merely to dream of a better future but to realize it."
Each man -- the ever-beaming King and the often-dour Prime Minister -- noted that peace had been made not only by their countries but also by them personally. They each had something to gain.
For King Hussein, the day brought full rehabilitation with the United States, after the isolation he had brought on himself four years ago by seeming to side with Iraq in the Persian Gulf war. For Mr. Rabin, in the rough and tumble of Israeli domestic politics, he now has a peace treaty that bears his Labor Party's imprint. The 1979 accord with Egypt was Likud's. Now, he, too, is a full-throated peacemaker -- not to mention 1994 winner of the Nobel Peace Prize along with Mr. Arafat and the Israeli Foreign Minister, Shimon Peres.
The treaty was signed by the Prime Ministers, Mr. Rabin and Abdul-Salam al-Majali.
Under their agreement, the countries are to establish full diplomatic relations and exchange ambassadors within a month. They also committed themselves to broad cooperation in areas like tourism, water, energy, transportation, environmental protection, agriculture and economic development. As a sign of how quickly they moved this fall to sign a deal, they gave themselves six more months to negotiate trade, banking and other financial arrangements.
For Jordan's benefit, Israel recognized the Hashemite Kingdom's claims to Islamic shrines in Jerusalem and said it would be given "high priority" when Israel and the Palestinians eventually negotiate the city's fate. For Israel's benefit, Jordan agreed that it would not join any anti-Israel alliance or allow its territories to be used as a launching pad for military attacks on Israel.
Two contentious issues were land and water.
On land, the Israelis acknowledged Jordanian sovereignty over 115 square miles of disputed territory, mostly in the Arava. But to protect their farmers, they got Jordan to agree to a swap of 11.5 square miles and to lease back two small patches of land -- a total of 700 acres in the Arava and near the Sea of Galilee.
As for water, Israel agreed to make 50 million cubic meters, or 13.2 billion gallons, available to arid Jordan each year, mostly by diverting flows from the Jordan River. The two sides also agreed to try increasing the total water supply by an extra 50 million cubic meters a year through dams to be built on the Jordan and Yarmuk Rivers.
A key point, both sides said, is that this peace will be warm, unlike the "cold peace" that Israel often complains it has had with Egypt, with few business or cultural exchanges.
Jordan supports "every word and every letter" of the treaty, King Hussein said. He noted that the two countries will have no foreign monitors on their border, unlike the situation in the Sinai Peninsula between Israel and Egypt or the likely arrangements on the Golan Heights if Israel and Syria come to terms.
"This is peace with dignity," the King said. "This is peace with commitment. This is our gift to our peoples and to generations to come."

Chart: "CHRONOLOGY: Decades of Dealing at Arm's Length"
 
NOVEMBER-DECEMBER 1947 King Abdullah of Jordan and Golda Meir of Israel hold two secret meetings in Palestine and Jordan.
 
MAY 14, 1948 The State of Israel is proclaimed. Jordan joins other Arab countries in declaring war against it.
 
AUG. 15, 1952 Hussein, Abdullah's grandson, becomes King of Jordan.
 
JUNE 6, 1967 After war breaks out, Israel captures the West Bank, including East Jerusalem, from Jordan; the Sinai Peninsula and the Gaza Strip from Egypt, and the Golan Heights from Syria.
 
SEPT. 25, 1973: Hussein reportedly meets secretly with Prime Minister Golda Meir in Tel Aviv, a week before the third Arab-Israeli war breaks out. Syria and Egypt combine forces against Israel; Jordan keeps border quiet during the war, but sends token force to Syrian front.
 
OCT. 30, 1991: Middle East peace talks open in Madrid, seven months after the Persian Gulf war. Israel, Jordan, Syria, Lebanon and the Palestinians take part.
 
SEPT. 13, 1993: The Palestine Liberation Organization signs a peace plan with Israel in Washington.
 
SEPT. 14: Jordan and Israel sign an agenda in Washington for their own negotiations.
 
JULY 18, 1994: Jordanian and Israeli delegates meet at the border and vow to make a permanent and public peace.
 
JULY 25: Hussein and Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin sign a declaration in Washington officially ending their 46-year state of belligerency.
 
AUG. 6: Israel starts pumping water from the Jordan River into Jordan, the first tangible result of the peace process.
 
AUG. 8: Jordan and Israel establish direct telephone links and inaugurate the first road directly linking the the two countries.
 
OCT. 11: Hussein says Jordan will sign a full peace treaty as soon as the border and water questions are settled, rather than wait until Syria and Lebanon reach accords with Israel.
 
OCT. 17: Israel and Jordan initial a draft peace accord.
 
OCT. 26: Israel and Jordan sign the peace treaty.

HEADLINE: Small Rise In Orders Of Durables

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
Prospects for further brisk economic growth remained bright today as the Government reported a small rise in orders for long-lasting factory products for September and revised still higher the very big August jump.
Orders for durable goods moved up one-tenth of 1 percent, buoyed by strength in ships and tanks that more than offset declines in automobiles and aircraft, the monthly tabulation of the Commerce Department showed. Although the gain was relatively meager, analysts said they were impressed by its breadth and by the fact that nonmilitary capital goods other than aircraft advanced 1.3 percent. 
 "You do see evidence of continuing momentum" in the economic expansion, said David J. Greenlaw, an economist at Morgan Stanley & Company, who called the report a bit better than expected. He cited in particular the second straight gain for capital goods, up 1.9 percent in August, a gauge of future production plans at factories.
The overall August rise for durable goods, big-ticket items ranging from camcorders to F-15 jets, is now put at 6.4 percent, compared with 6.1 percent in the first report a month ago.
The bond market largely shrugged off today's report as it continued to assume that the Federal Reserve would engineer a fresh round of increases in short-term interest rates at its next scheduled policy meeting on Nov. 15. The Fed's aim this year has been to throttle back an economy growing at an unsustainably rapid pace before such activity causes inflation to accelerate.
Spurred by inventory building, the economy grew at a 4.1 percent annual pace in the second quarter of the year, well above the 2.5 percent that many analysts see as its long-term potential.
On Friday, the department will issue its first estimate of the growth rate for the third quarter, with Mr. Greenlaw and many other economists now predicting 3 percent or more.
"We're surprised at how little effect higher interest rates have had" on the auto market, Joel H. Pitcoff, research manager at the Ford Motor Company, said today as the auto maker announced exceptionally strong profits for the third quarter.
Merrill Lynch, however, said it was sticking with its forecast for a rise in gross domestic product of 2.5 percent.
The durable-goods report showed new orders for transportation goods up 2.1 percent last month while orders for the smaller electronic equipment and primary metals industries rose 3.2 percent and 2.7 percent, respectively.
Orders for industrial machinery and equipment, however, fell 2.5 percent after a 4.6 percent surge in August.
Excluding military goods, total orders eased eight-tenths of 1 percent, the department's report also showed, but orders for capital goods alone rose five-tenths of 1 percent.
Shipments of durable goods fell seven-tenths of 1 percent last month, the third decline of the year, after a 6.2 percent burst in August. Unfilled orders were virtually unchanged after small declines in July and August.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

 
Companies
 
Earnings more than doubled at Ford, helped by vigorous demand for the Windstar mini-van, Mustang sports coupe and four-wheel-drive Explorers. The performance contrasted sharply with last week's disappointing results from General Motors. [Page D1.]
 
Lehman Brothers ousted Elaine M. Garzarelli, one of Wall Street's most prominent and flamboyant stock market forecasters. She was widely hailed for calling the 1987 market crash. [D1.] 

Why do regional phone companies want to go Hollywood? Consider Bell Atlantic, which, at a $200 million digital video-production center in northern Virginia, is introducing technology that goes beyond the staples of cable television. [D1.]
 
F.T.C. scrutiny of Eli Lilly's deal for PCS is raising questions about other deals for drug marketers. News Analysis. [D2.]
 
A criminal complaint against Prudential Securities is expected to be filed today, people with knowledge of the inquiry said. [D2.]
 
General Motors is recalling almost 13,000 cars and trucks in 21 model lines to replace a faulty transmission.[D5.]
 
Tenneco said earnings jumped, helped by strong gains at its Case farm and construction equipment unit. [D5.]
 
A public offering by Carver Federal Savings Bank resulted in losses in one day of trading for depositors who bought stock. [D5.]
 
I.B.M. briefly halted production of a new operating system. [D5.]
 
Borden reported a loss of $130.5 million for the quarter. [D5.]
 
The Economy

Orders for durable goods rose one-tenth of 1 percent in September, adding to signs of brisk economic growth. [D7.]

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Not Party, But Need Led Mayor

BYLINE: By Joyce Purnick 

 BODY:
IT was dramatic, all right, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's endorsement of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. His news conference this week drew nine television cameras (two short of the unofficial City Hall record), what seemed like the entire mayoral staff and reporters so caught up in the moment that some lost all pretext of objectivity. "This is exciting, it's HUGE," enthused one, almost dropping her microphone.
But the most surprising thing about the Mayor's break with his party is that he got around to it so quickly, not that he did it. All New York mayors cross party lines. They have to if the other party holds sway in Washington or Albany. The City needs friends in both places. 
 "The Mayor must have a cooperative and helpful relationship with Albany," said Edward Sadowsky, former chairman of the City Council's Finance Committee. "Must! It can't work otherwise. We're creatures of state. What they can do to us in terms of mandates, tax revenues, is just monumental."
WHATEVER other reasons may have figured in Mr. Giuliani's decision to endorse Mr. Cuomo over State Senator George E. Pataki -- his feud with Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, or ambitions to maybe seek higher office unencumbered by a powerful Republican in Albany -- the city's position as municipal mendicant clearly topped his list. As goes New York City, so goes Rudy Giuliani. And New York City always needs help.
The funny thing is, the Mayor's politics are closer to Mr. Pataki's. To close a budget deficit, for instance, Mr. Giuliani is relying solely on cuts. The Governor, by contrast, has faced his stringencies with cuts, tax increases and fiscal gimmicks.
The more Albany spends, of course, the better for the city. A fiscal conservative as governor, reducing state taxes as Mr. Pataki proposes and cutting in Albany as Mr. Giuliani is in City Hall, would hobble the city and force it to raise local taxes. And that is what the Mayor's endorsement of Mr. Cuomo was fundamentally about -- money. It's the same reason Fiorello H. La Guardia, the fusion-Republican mayor, allied himself with President Franklin D. Roosevelt, Democrat.
"This is the historic conundrum of New York City, the relationship of the city to Albany and Washington," says Richard C. Wade, professor of urban history at the City University Graduate Center. "How do you run a city which does not have the revenue to provide the services people expect? You can raise taxes, or spend someone else's taxes."
Not that Mr. Cuomo has delivered on the big-ticket items most important to the city. But he wants to. The Governor supports every position Mr. Giuliani considers important, including a state takeover of local Medicaid costs; a fairer distribution of state education aid, which now favors the suburbs, and limiting development around the upstate watershed, to help New York avoid building an $8 billion filtration plant.
Mr. Cuomo has not gotten any of those things, thwarted by what critics say is his failure to forcefully overcome the opposition of the Republican State Senate. The Governor has persuaded the Legislature to make some incremental changes. Mr. Giuliani found no evidence that Mr. Pataki would even try.
THE State Senator says he supports Medicaid takeover but offers no details. He voted to strip the city of its ability to regulate watershed development, and he indicates that the school aid formula seems fair to him. The city gets 35 percent of the school budget although it has 37 percent of the students, but the city gets a lot of other state aid, he notes. It does. But it has a lot of needs, too -- something Mr. Pataki has not had to consider too closely as a resident of Garrison in Putnam County. If anything, his community considers New York City the adversary. Upstate and suburban New York always has.
"It became very obvious to us, and I think it's becoming obvious to Giuliani, and frankly he's learned it very quickly, that the base of the Republican constituency is so different," says Richard Aurelio, Time Warner New York City Cable Group president and a deputy mayor for Mayor John V. Lindsay, Republican-turned-Democrat. "How can you possibly go to the Republican leadership in the state, who represent suburban and upstate communities, many of whom dislike New York City, and say, 'Do something for New York City'? It's not in their interest."
A Governor Pataki might change his attitude toward New York City, which, despite its costly problems, is still the state's economic engine. Then again, he might not. "I can't speculate," Mayor Giuliani said to New York through those nine television cameras. "I have to know."

HEADLINE: Commercial-Fishing Halt Is Urged for Georges Bank

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
Faced with a fishery on the verge of collapse, a Federal council today recommended virtually shutting down commercial fishing in the Georges Bank off Cape Code, once one of the world's richest fishing grounds.
While some fishing could continue, the council, the New England Fishery Management Council, directed its staff to come up with measures that would reduce the catch of cod, haddock and yellowtail flounder, the principal species sought on the Georges Bank, to as close to zero as practical. 
 Because many of the affected species are caught in the nets of vessels fishing for other species, the restrictions will cut deeply into all kinds of fishing, especially by those using small-mesh nets, which often kill juvenile groundfish before they can grow to market size.
"It means almost no fishing," said Pat Fiorelli, the council's spokeswoman.
The council, meeting in Danvers, Mass., said previous restrictions on fishing that took effect in May in an effort to reduce fishing by 50 percent had not been adequate to save the principal species caught in the American waters of the Georges Bank.
The council, an industry-dominated group that under Federal fishing law greatly influences the regulations governing commercial fishing fleets, set in motion an administrative process intended to all but close the Georges Bank to fishing for groundfish, including the species that gave Cape Cod its name and reputation.
The council's recommendations must be approved by the Commerce Department to take effect.
Conservation groups said the actions showed that the fishing industry itself now accepted what its critics have said for years: that to save the industry, it is necessary to first save the fish.
Although the council and the Commerce Department will take months to put the regulations into effect, the consequences will last for years, fishing experts predicted.
"This is a real watershed event," said Peter Shelley of the Conservation Law Foundation, which sued the Commerce Department in 1991 for failing to stop overfishing in the waters.
The fishery council acted after a science advisory group reported in August that the situation on the Georges Bank had worsened. The scientists said the fishery could be saved only if mortality in certain fish stocks was reduced to practically zero.
The council's actions came at a meeting crammed with angry fishermen, and the effect on the already severely depressed fishing industry in New England is expected to be serious. The Clinton Administration has already begun to put tens of millions of dollars into economic aid programs meant to compensate the industry for the losses it is facing.
"It was a very heated meeting, with many, many fishermen very concerned about what this meant for them," said Doug Hopkins of the Environmental Defense Fund, who was at the meeting. "But it is the right decision and the council voted unanimously."
Shutting down the Georges Bank would probably put thousands of fishermen out of work, while others would probably move to other heavily fished areas like the Gulf of Maine or to waters off the Mid-Atlantic states.
The actions are only the latest sign of a broad crisis in commercial fishing, both in the United States and abroad.
The National Marine Fisheries Service has estimated that more than 40 percent of the nation's commercial fish species are too heavily fished. In New England, the agency has estimated that overfishing of cod, haddock and flounder have already cost 14,000 jobs and cost the economy $350 million a year.
Big parts of the Georges Bank have been closed temporarily before, in the effort to cut the catch in half. But the council's staff told it recently that the scientific basis for that plan, which among other things cut the number of fishing days 10 percent, was "no longer valid" in light of more recent surveys.
The council's recommendations come as Congress approaches major revisions to the main law governing the nation's fisheries, many of which are in bad shape.
The council is one of eight regional bodies that set fishing limits and allocate catches between competing fishermen.
For many years, the New England council was unable to agree to reduce catches of the principal ground-feeding fish -- cod, haddock and flounder -- though data showed the fishing stocks to be in a profound decline.
It adopted quotas in 1977, but dropped them five years later under pressure from fishermen. In the meantime, the Government made cheap loans to help build up the fishing fleet, increasing pressure on the fish stocks at a time when prices and consumer demand were both increasing.
Ultimately, the New England fisheries council and the Commerce Department did impose tough restrictions last year, but it was too little and too late. Already, under those restrictions, the New England fleet has started to move into new waters, including those of the Long Island area, where the stocks are healthier, fishing for species like squid, whiting, scup and fluke.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Angry fishermen attending a meeting yesterday at which the New England Fishery Management Council recommended the virtual closing of commercial fishing in the Georges Bank off the New England Coast, once one of the world's richest fishing grounds. The Federal council, meeting in Danvers, Mass., will present its recommendations to the Commerce Department. The fishery is on the verge of collapse. (Associated Press)
 
Map shows the location of Georges Bank.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: The Incumbent, Running in the Past;
Can Giuliani Chase the Musty Smell From Cuomo's Campaign?

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

 BODY:
It was the day after he had unexpectedly won the endorsement of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was flying high -- flying as high, that is, as his wary, pensive, rather equivocal nature would let him.
"Don't shove those things in so close," he said as the photographers and reporters thrust their cameras and microphones into his face, launching one of those rugby-scrum news conferences that are the hallmark of New York City campaigns. "You'll kill me, and just when my chances are starting to look good." 
 The Mayor's backing, the Governor said later, "ought to help a lot" in his uphill campaign for a fourth term against State Senator George E. Pataki, especially among independents.
"This is not simply one politician trying to transfer his popularity to another politician in the same party, which usually doesn't work," Mr. Cuomo reflected as his car inched along a Manhattan street without benefit of police escort. "A sizable number of people of all labels and categories are worried about this city and want help for it. Now the Mayor comes along and says this guy who belongs to the other party, who tried to beat me twice, and succeeded once, I think he'll help us and the other guy won't. People will think about that."
It is a measure of the hole Mr. Cuomo had dug for himself that Mr. Giuliani's support means so much. Although the latest polls have been showing the race too close to call, professional politicians had been telling each other, here and in Washington, that the Governor was not going to make it, and a slightly valedictory tone, plus a tendency to look back instead of forward, had crept into his speeches.
The thunderbolt of Mr. Giuliani's announcement sharply altered the mood of the Governor's campaign, banishing the musty smell of impending doom. But it meant that if Mr. Cuomo wins, Mr. Giulani, and not the Governor, not the old minor league outfielder, will occupy what Red Barber called the catbird seat. Mr. Cuomo will owe the Mayor a lot, if not everything, though he does not like to admit it. "Not if I have the strength to be an ingrate," he said. "I may have to start working on that."
Graveyard humor aside, the Governor's predicament is amazing. Seven years ago, and again three years ago, Mario Cuomo was considered a prospective President. A year ago, he was considered a prospective Supreme Court justice. Now, suddenly, he is considered a prospective has-been.
Governor of New York since 1983, he is acknowledged -- still -- as the premier American political orator and as one of the most intelligent people in American public life. The son of an immigrant grocer, he has retained the common touch that has been considered, since the days of Alfred E. Smith, the sine qua non of success in the raucous politics of New York City and New York State.
So what happened to him in the first place? How did he ever manage to fall behind a 49-year-old legislator about whom 40 percent of the voters in a poll taken less than a month ago said they knew too little to make a judgment? Is it just the wounds accumulated and the enemies made in three terms in Albany?
Has he been victimized by the intense (if perhaps temporary) national distaste for incumbents? Or has time passed him by? Has the sun set even in New York for the urban liberals, those devout believers in using government to fight social injustice? Has the tradition of Lehman, Wagner, Rockefeller and the two Roosevelts evaporated so quickly?
One of the Governor's predecessors, Hugh L. Carey, said the other day: "There is nothing wrong with his ideas. There are just no resources any more, and that makes it hard for him or anyone else in government to show results."
That is a benign view of liberalism's plight. A more hostile attitude is represented by the comment of B. Thomas Golisano, a third-party candidate, who summarizes the Cuomo credo (and problem) this way: "If it moves, you tax it; if it still moves, you regulate it; when it stops moving, you subsidize it."
At 62, Mr. Cuomo tends to blame his stars and not himself, although he said this week that he had "utterly failed to communicate what we have accomplished in the last 12 years," which sounds a lot like President Clinton explaining his own lack of popularity. One Governor's aide carries around a sheet of paper summarizing what he has done, to show to anyone who might need reminding.
Mr. Pataki's very anonymity has proven an advantage in a year when outsiderhood is revered almost like old age in Asian cultures. The Governor said at a meeting at a Manhattan synagogue one night recently, "It's very hard to box with a cloud of smoke, you know."
The mood in New York, Mr. Cuomo says, is as ruinous for incumbents as the mood anywhere else, and he rattles off the reasons, the words coming as ever in a seemingly unstoppable stream:
"The middle class hasn't gone anywhere in a long time . . . there's no uplifting distraction, like a war, and there are no heroes, no Joe DiMaggio or Martin Luther King or Bobby Kennedy, not even old Ronald Reagan, that genial man they grabbed because there was nobody else . . . they conclude that government has failed to solve problems, like crime and the homeless and drugs, which is certainly true, so why, they ask, should they give government any more money? . . . the American people are in a mood to pay a quarter and throw three balls at the clown's head, and I keep sticking my head into the circle."
All this is practiced, and he had said similar things to a British reporter the day before, but he is taken aback by a question about his legacy. In an interview at The New York Times earlier in the campaign, he finally said, laughing, that he wanted to be remembered for having served four terms. This time, he responds with a mixture of exasperation and fatalism: "My son told me in 1983 to think about my legacy, and I was offended by that. Now I guess it will be: I fought the death penalty."
A prominent New Yorker active in past Cuomo campaigns, but sitting this one out in disillusionment, thinks that the Governor is a big part of the problem, "just too damned self-centered, too isolated, unable to see beyond himself after 12 years in harness." He calls Mr. Cuomo "the most intellectually and emotionally frustrating politician, and maybe person of any kind, I have ever known."
"Ordinary voters instinctively recognize these problems," the former associate said, on condition of anonymity. "They know he's brilliant, they know he has this power, they know he has the capacity to deliver, and he doesn't. They are sick of the mess in the streets, and they are sick and tired of the rhetoric."
There is certainly plenty of the latter. The well has not run dry. And, as a state legislator commented, there is also an ample supply of a kind of soaring idealism that is missing from Washington these days. However apprehensive Mr. Cuomo may be about his future, he still wows audiences -- with his big vocabulary (what other candidate talks about homiletics and eschatology?), with his references to the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire and to black history, with his passionate delivery, his emphatic hand-claps, his self-addressed questions ("So what are you going to do about that, Mario?"), his jokes told in the cadence of the city's meaner streets.
But travel with him for a day or two, and you realize how much of his time the Governor spends in telling stories about the past. He talks about his poor, illiterate parents, about his mentor, Judge Adrian Burke, about Fishhooks McCarthy, Al Smith's legendary fixer, about the rabbi who helped give him his start and especially about his past electoral successes, "always as the underdog." He talks about New York State as "the tabernacle of democracy," as the engine of the economy, as if it were 1950 and California and Texas were still the sticks.
He lists for a meeting of Teamster leaders the strikes during which he has stood beside them. He does not mention that all were failures. He derides the idea that any politician can supply "some magic solution that will descend from the heavens." Mario M. Cuomo, proud professional, like his brother Democrats Edward M. Kennedy in Massachusetts and Thomas S. Foley in Washington, knows how complicated these problems really are.
So he rails, like the elderly Lear, at the troubles that have befallen him, at the rules of modern politics he is compelled to live with, at the impossibility of "discussing in a 28-second commercial the complexities of fighting the crime in our streets."
What he does not talk about very much are his plans. Pete Wilson, the Governor of California, a Republican of Mr. Cuomo's generation, was equally unpopular a year ago, probably more so. He has staged a comeback by finding dramatic ways to identify himself with the deep-seated public resentments that Mr. Cuomo also talks about, in Mr. Wilson's case crime and illegal immigration.
Mr. Cuomo has not done that. Mr. Cuomo hates oversimplification; Mr. Wilson considers it inevitable, the very crux of modern political communication in a large state like his.
David Garth, the Governor's campaign consultant, says Mr. Cuomo would be far better off if he had spent more money on earlier re-election efforts; he spent only about $5 million on each, compared with Nelson Rockefeller's outlays 30 years ago, at least $15 million every time he entered the fray.
But at least as important is the image of himself that Mr. Cuomo has built up, piece by tiny piece, over all the years and all the miles since he was elected for the first time in 1982, two Presidents and who knows how many speeches ago.
People hungry for quick fixes, the Governor acknowledged at one point this week, may ultimately be put off by "the very things I say and the way I say it, being as complicated as I am and trying to be as subtle as I sometimes do."

HEADLINE: Livable City Ponders Its Outburst of Anger and Unrest

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 26

 BODY:
This central Kentucky city rising out of rolling fields of horse farms, burley tobacco fields and bourbon distilleries is perennially near the top of magazine lists of the nation's most livable cities.
It is the home of the University of Kentucky, five medical centers and a score of clean manufacturing companies, and it boasts an annual per capita income of $18,142, which is 60 percent higher than the state average and about 30 percent above the national average. Unemployment is 3.2 percent this year, and by all accounts the city is thriving. 
 But amid the bluegrass expanses divided by black and white wooden fences, there are equally vivid contrasts here between the haves and the have-nots. And on Tuesday some of those differences were cast in stark relief when a roving band of about 100 black youths from a housing project near downtown briefly occupied the City Council chambers, stoned police cars and menaced motorists in reaction to the killing of an 18-year-old black by an officer earlier in the day.
Leaders in Lexington like Mayor Pam Miller and Porter G. Peeples Jr., the head of the local Urban League chapter, agreed that the disturbance was mild by the standard of most urban unrest, but they nevertheless saw it as a wakeup call to this otherwise prosperous city that some citizens remained alienated and frustrated.
"We're making considerable efforts," said Mayor Miller, who is the chief elected official of the combined Lexington and Fayette County Urban County Government, "but it's just that a lot of youngsters are frustrated because they have not gotten the education that they need to get good jobs and make a future. Those teen-agers came downtown angry and looking for answers from us, and it was a more visible display of anger than we are used to seeing."
The nine minor injuries, four arrests and 18 damaged car windshields and two broken store windows that grew out of the events were a modest toll, but many are taking them to heart as a warning.
Mr. Peeples said that he and other leaders of black organizations in this city of 225,366, which is 12 percent black, had talked for years about Lexington's social ills as signs of trouble brewing -- the high dropout rates for black students, the climbing teen-age pregnancies, the nascent youth gang scene and increasing drug involvement among the young. But people called them alarmist, he said, or accused him of trying to keep alive an outmoded civil rights organization.
"Lexington likes to pride itself on having a high quality of life," Mr. Peeples said. "Although there is a black middle class here, there really hasn't been a lot of inclusiveness. There are just a lot of young people here who don't feel that they have a good chance at the good life."
The unrest in the city started after police officers, bearing an arrest warrant, entered an apartment at the Bluegrass-Aspendale housing project shortly before 10 A.M. on Tuesday seeking Antonio Orlando Sullivan, an 18-year-old wanted in connection with a gang-related shooting last month in which one person was wounded.
Mr. Sullivan, the police said, hid in a closet and emerged only after four police officers, their guns drawn, repeatedly ordered him to come out. As he emerged, a shot was fired, apparently by Officer Philip H. Vogel, striking Mr. Sullivan in the head and killing him, the police said.
After initially calling the incident an "accidental shooting," Chief Lawrence E. Walsh today backed away from that description and announced that the Federal Bureau of Investigation as well as the state's Commonwealth's Attorney for Fayette County would be conducting independent investigations. Dottie Bean, a spokeswoman for the city, said Officer Vogel, a 22-year veteran, had been "relieved of duty with pay" pending the outcome of the investigations. Three other officers who were with Officer Vogel have been temporarily transferred to office duties.
The Rev. Michael Wilson, a former member of the Lexington-Fayette Urban County Council, said he knew of at least one witness, Joy Thomas, a 25-year-old baby sitter, who asserted that Mr. Sullivan was shot while his arms were raised.
Word of the shooting spread quickly through the housing project, a mostly quiet and well-kept complex of one- and two-story garden apartments, each with a small backyard surrounded by a wrought-iron fence. By about 3 P.M., a number of young people, angry at the news, had gathered and begun the nearly milelong trek to the 12-story building that houses city government offices.
Mr. Wilson, who saw the march, said that the youths, shouting but still peaceful, had surged into the City Council chambers and demanded a meeting with the Mayor and an explanation for the shooting. It was only after Chief Walsh had read to them his statement calling the shooting accidental that the crowd turned ugly, with many of the youths storming into the streets.
Today, many people here expressed a determination to look more closely at social conditions and to try to ease tensions. Mr. Peeples talked of meeting with other leaders of black groups on improving opportunities for young people as well as relations with the police. Mayor Hill seemed receptive, saying she, too, would meet with black organizations and church groups.
Still, along the leaf-strewn walkways of the Bluegrass-Aspendale project, anger and bitterness lingered. Ann Arnold, 26, a resident for nine years, speculated that it was partly the stereotype of housing project residents as "terrible people" that inspired a fear of Tony Sullivan in the white police officer who shot him. She said the same fear and stereotyping was behind news reports that made it appear that the entire housing project was attacking downtown.
"It was all overdramatized, like this was Haiti or something," Ms. Arnold said. "They make us up here sound so terrible, and that's what made that cop afraid. But there are just a lot of hard-working people up here trying to make a better life for our kids."
