HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE CHALLENGER;
Pataki and Peekskill: Reviving a City, Then Profiting in a Realty Boom

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER and MATTHEW PURDY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PEEKSKILL

 BODY:
When George E. Pataki describes his tenure as Mayor here in the early 1980's, he emphasizes his role in resuscitating a shabby Hudson Valley river town with a dwindling tax base. Using his pitchman's skills and government subsidies, Mr. Pataki lured several major developers to this city of barely 20,000 people, igniting a real-estate boom that built more than 1,100 new middle-class homes during the decade.
There is a second chapter to the story of Peekskill's boom. In 1984, after he resigned as Mayor to become a State Assemblyman, Mr. Pataki, the most powerful politician in this Republican-controlled town, began seeking the financial benefits of the real-estate boom he helped create. He set up a law office in Peekskill with his brother and attracted at least $160,000 in work from developers, including some of the same people he brought to the city as Mayor. 
 There is little mystery why the small Pataki law office, which earned most of its income from these developers, was attracting this business.
As Louis Pataki, the Republican candidate's brother, said: "The business from the developers came because he knew the developers. I don't think there's any doubt about that. I assume it's from the time he was Mayor."
Mr. Pataki's tenure as Peekskill's Mayor -- his only leadership role in a 13-year political career -- and the years afterward as a dominant presence here offer a concrete look at his vision and priorities as he seeks the governorship of New York State. In many ways, it provides a clearer picture than his Albany record as a four-term minority-party Assemblyman and one-term State Senator.
In an interview, Mr. Pataki said he saw no conflict in his work for the same developers he brought into Peekskill since he never represented them before any city agency. "Never did I use political influence to benefit anyone other than the city of Peekskill," he added.
While Mr. Pataki was Mayor, real-estate development defined him politically and it has also shaped his private finances, to the point that sometimes the line between his public and private roles has blurred.
One developer whom Mr. Pataki helped as Mayor to win a $3 million government loan said that after leaving the Mayor's job, Mr. Pataki solicited legal business from him. The developer, Victor Weingarten, said Mr. Pataki's firm represented his company in the sale of 175 condominiums, a job that brought the Pataki brothers' law firm roughly $61,250.
Another Peekskill developer turned to Mr. Pataki's firm to handle the closing for about 200 home sales, at charges of $300 to $425 each -- worth somewhere between $60,000 and $85,000. And he also did closings for both those developers in Putnam and Orange counties.
"My recollection is that almost every developer let them do the closings," said Mr. Weingarten, who called the legal work "relatively simple boilerplate." He added: "They almost had a lock on closings. They went after that business very aggressively and did it very cheaply."
 
A Matter of Influence
A Role in Decisions As an Ex-Mayor
 Peekskill officials said Mr. Pataki did not violate local ethics laws, and even in municipalities with stricter codes, like New York City, such transactions fall into a cloudy category, according to experts.
But what is clear is that long after he stepped down as Mayor, Mr. Pataki continued to have a major role in city decision making and there were times when people in Peekskill were not sure which hat Mr. Pataki was wearing -- public official or developer's representative.
Joseph Seymour, the Peekskill city manager, said that in the decade since Mr. Pataki left the Mayor's post, "he met with me once a month: 'Joe, you've got to do this, you've got to do that. This building's got to come down. Try this.' "
And Edmond F. Schorno, the city planning director, recalls a 1986 incident when Assemblyman Pataki called him to make inquiries about a developer's request to build more homes per acre than initially planned. Mr. Schorno said that he assumed Mr. Pataki was calling as an Assemblyman but that regardless, the call had no effect on the application. Only recently, when Mr. Pataki made his financial statements available to reporters during the governor's race, was it revealed that the developer was also a law client of Mr. Pataki's.
Mr. Pataki acknowledged in the interview that he made this inquiry for the development company, which had hired his law firm to do all its closings in New York State. But he said, "I was not being paid to make the call" to the planning director.
There are also aspects of Mr. Pataki's tenure as Mayor that seem to clash with positions he has taken as a candidate for governor.
For example, though he now calls for a reduced role for government, as Mayor he used his political contacts to win scarce Federal grants to subsidize private developers building homes for middle-class residents. The Pataki administration was able to get these grants with the aid of Republican lawmakers like Representative Hamilton Fish and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Mr. Pataki's main supporter in this year's race for governor.
City officials said the construction begun under Mr. Pataki increased the city's total assessed value of real estate 11 percent from 1981 to 1993, while that of other Westchester County cities like Mount Vernon and Yonkers were declining. As in most places, that development rode the economic tides. Developers invested in flush times, but in the recession of the late 1980's some went bust and had to sell.
In at least three instances, developers failed to repay their debts to the city. While the city lost out, Mr. Pataki, after he left the Mayor's office, benefited from two of those same developers. From one, he earned a $40,000 broker's fee, and from another he received a $60,000 personal loan to help plan the development of his family farm.
His campaigns also benefited. For example, over a 10-year period, four developers who worked with Mr. Pataki when he was Mayor and their associates contributed at least $22,000 to his legislative and gubernatorial races.
As important as Mr. Pataki's role was in the boom of the early 1980's, parts of the boom were not his inspiration. A turning point for Peekskill was the opening of a plant that converted Westchester County's garbage to energy. Mr. Pataki was there at the ribbon cutting, but the deal for the plant, which brought Peekskill and its schools an extra $2.9 million in tax revenue annually was cemented by the previous Democratic Mayor and the previous County Executive.
"I'm the one who did that," said Alfred B. DelBello, the former County Executive, who said he completed the deal with Mr. Pataki's predecessor, Fred J. Bianco.
 
From Slump to Boom
A Forceful Role In City's Rebound
 In the late 1970's, Peekskill was on a prolonged downhill slide. Malls in surrounding towns had sapped life from the downtown, creating a bleak landscape of boarded-up shops. The city's largest employer, Standard Brands, the manufacturer of Fleishmann's yeast and whisky, had closed, resulting in a loss of more than 1,000 jobs. Just weeks before Mr. Pataki was inaugurated as Mayor in 1981, the City Council raised taxes 21 percent to pay police officers and firefighters.
Mr. Pataki recalls that one developer told him: "Peekskill isn't dying. Peekskill is dead."
Mr. Pataki, educated at Yale and Columbia, had returned to his native city in the 1970's and become the local Republican chairman, spearheading a return of Republican power after six years of City Council control by Democrats.
"Look at our city," Mr. Pataki said at the time. "Look at the town we grew up in. Nobody has the same feeling about our city anymore."
To enthusiastic supporters like Robert Flower, a former Republican Councilman, Mr. Pataki "changed the attitude of most of the active people in the community from an attitude of 'things are bad and we can 't do anything about it' to an attitude that 'yes, something can be done.' "
Although the mayoralty was not a full-time job -- daily operations are run by the city manager -- Mr. Pataki was a forceful presence. He viewed Peekskill as overburdened by poor people and greatly in need of middle-class development.
"We were looking to change the demographics of the community," said Mr. Seymour, the city manager.
Mr. Pataki saw fresh opportunities in Peekskill's four moribund church-owned institutions that sat on large tracts of land and paid no taxes. He remembers "talking to almost every builder I could find active in Westchester" and aggressively seeking Federal aid.
In 1982, when St. Peter's, an Episcopal preparatory school, was put up for auction, Mr. Pataki devised financial incentives that allowed a private developer from Long Island to outbid two religious groups that would not have paid as much in taxes.
Mr. Pataki also helped a seasoned Westchester builder, Victor Weingarten, convert Villa Loretto, a defunct Roman Catholic home for delinquent girls, into apartments and develop the surrounding land. Mr. Pataki persuaded Peekskill's school board to sell the developer land he needed for a low price. Then his administration lobbied Mr. D'Amato and other Federal officials for hefty renovation grants.
Under Federal guidelines, projects in Peekskill were restricted from receiving more than $445,000 in renovation grants. But after city leaders lobbied Mr. D'Amato and local members of Congress, Housing and Urban Development officials gave Mr. Weingarten a $3 million loan -- nearly seven times the limit and the largest such loan ever given in the Northeast.
Adam Glantz, a regional H.U.D. spokesman, said using the money for a middle-income project did not violate department regulations because Peekskill was eligible as one of the poorest municipalities in Westchester. Hard lobbying also helped.
"I'd fly to Washington once a month," Mr. Seymour said. "I'd go see the Congressman and the Senator. That's where the money was coming from."
 
Real-Estate Deals
Making Money On Sale Closings
 Mr. Weingarten eventually defaulted on his project's mortgage after completing 175 condominiums -- but not before Mr. Pataki benefited financially.
After resigning as Mayor in December 1984, Mr. Pataki opened a satellite Peekskill office of Plunkett & Jaffe, a Manhattan and White Plains law firm where he had worked since the mid-1970's. On Peekskill's ragged Main Street, Mr. Pataki and his brother Louis handled mostly real estate and wills. Michael C. Finnegan, who is Mr. Pataki's Senate and campaign aide, worked as a paralegal.
"It was a small-town practice," said William F. Plunkett, the firm's founding partner. "All of the time he had one foot in government."
Louis Pataki said the lawyers wanted to build a dominant practice in the Hudson Valley, but "it blew up in our face." Mr. Plunkett said George Pataki never earned more than $30,000 a year and his brother more than $45,000.
Handling real-estate closings -- transfers of property -- became a staple of the office's business.
Mr. Weingarten said he used the law firm as "a matter of economics." The firm's price of $350 a closing, Mr. Weingarten said, was one that even his son-in-law, who usually did his closings, could not beat.
One of the Northeast's largest home builders also came to Peekskill and used the Pataki firm. The company, K. Hovnanian, built 340 condominiums in two spreads known as Society Hill and Mr. Pataki's firm handled those closings as well as others for the developer in two other counties.
Mr. Plunkett said he saw nothing wrong with Mr. Pataki's representing developers he had dealt with as Mayor. "If I'm a developer, I want to make sure I have someone who knows what he is doing," Mr. Plunkett said.
Peekskill's laws only restrict former city officials from appearing before city agencies on behalf of clients they dealt with while in office, said William J. Florence Jr., Peekskill's Corporation Counsel.
New York City's code is stricter. Mark Davies, executive director of the Conflicts of Interest Board, said former city officials were not only permanently barred from appearing before the city on any matter they dealt with while in office but were also barred from receiving any money stemming from those matters. However, the issue of receiving payments for property closings is a "murky" one, he said.
Still, Mr. Pataki said that by 1989, as an Assemblyman he was concerned that political foes would criticize his association with Plunkett & Jaffe, not because of his work for developers but because lawyers in the firm's other branches were representing state agencies.
"People could take political potshots at me," Mr. Pataki said. "You just never know."
For that reason, Mr. Pataki said, he closed the Plunkett & Jaffe office in Peekskill and began practicing on his own down the street.
But William Florence interprets the closing of the firm's office in basic economic terms. "When the boom was over, they closed the door and went home," he said.
 
Turning a Profit
From Defaults To Law Fees
 In two instances, Mr. Pataki personally profited from arrangements with developers who defaulted on grants from Peekskill.
As Mayor, Mr. Pataki helped a group of New York City investors win a $815,000 Federal loan to convert a defunct Episcopal school for girls into an apartment house known as Chateau Rive.
After most of the 56 apartments were completed in 1986, the investors, including D. Kenneth Patton, a former New York City economic development administrator, declared bankruptcy. The city never recouped $720,000 of the Federal grant.
Still, Mr. Pataki benefited. In 1989, he arranged a sale of part of the property and was paid a $40,000 broker's fee by the same Patton group he had recruited as Mayor.
Another developer who defaulted on a city loan was Paul Guillaro. His company, Unicorn Industries, failed to repay $85,000 of a $100,000 loan issued in 1988 to help construct a four-story downtown office building, which is still only half-occupied.
Unicorn was active in Peekskill while Mr. Pataki was Mayor, though Mr. Pataki does not recall if he met Mr. Guillaro then. Nevertheless, their relationship turned personal in 1991, when the developer gave him a $60,000 loan to finance engineering plans for subdividing the 17-acre Pataki family farm in Peekskill. Then this spring Mr. Pataki and his brother sold Mr. Guillaro part of the farmland for $75,000.
But perhaps Mr. Pataki's most lucrative real-estate transactions took place away from Peekskill. The sale of investment properties in Putnam and Washington Counties in 1986 allowed him to buy a graceful old Victorian mansion in the upscale village of Garrison seven miles from Peekskill for a price of $700,000. In 1991, Mr. Pataki moved his family into the Garrison house, leaving behind the city he set out to rescue a decade earlier.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Decline Ahead of G.D.P. Report

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Government securities were lower in choppy trading yesterday, despite an auction of five-year notes and a durable-goods report that were both slightly better than expected.
Both the economic report and the auction sparked small rallies that were soon cut short by investors waiting to unload securities ahead of the report on third-quarter gross domestic product on Friday. Market investors were selling on every uptick of 5/32 or 6/32 in bond prices, traders said. 
 Investors are concerned that the G.D.P. report will indicate that the economy is heating up and that inflation is ready to accelerate, sending prices lower.
The price of the 30-year bond ended down 6/32, to 93 23/32, for a yield of 8.06 percent, up from 8.04 percent on Tuesday. Shorter bill rates were lower, suggesting that investors were moving off the long end of the market to the relative safety of the short end.
Prices of Government securities rose briefly in early trading after the Commerce Department said orders for durable goods -- big-ticket items ranging from television sets to jets -- rose one-tenth of 1 percent in September. Excluding transportation, orders fell by six-tenths of 1 percent, slightly weaker than expected, while shipments fell seven-tenths of 1 percent, as expected.
But analysts said the report did not detract from the overall strong economic picture, given a big jump in durable goods in August.
"In fact, the details of the latest report indicate continued growth in manufacturing, with little evidence of overheating," said Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
Investors later turned their focus to the five-year note auction. The when-issued yield for the five-year was at 7.52 percent in early trading before the auction, down from 7.57 percent the day before. Many traders began to think the auction would attract buyers at 7.52 percent, and were satisfied when the notes were awarded at a high yield of 7.55 percent. Analysts speculated that in many cases, fund managers did not want to stretch maturities in portfolios to five years, while dealers would probably only buy to cover short positions.
Although not a big factor in the price slump yesterday, commodity prices did exert some downward pressure, as gasoline continued to lead the Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities higher, up 1.05 point, to 233.30.
Tighter supplies on the East Coast after the pipeline rupture in Texas have raised prices in the energy sector.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Ford Profits Up Sharply In Quarter

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., Oct. 26

 BODY:
With car and truck sales climbing in the United States and manufacturing costs falling in Europe, the Ford Motor Company today reported that its earnings had more than doubled to $1.12 billion for the three months ending Sept. 30.
Vigorous demand for products like the Windstar mini-van, Mustang sports coupe and four-wheel-drive Explorers enabled Ford to cut marketing costs in the quarter, fattening its profit on every vehicle sold. 
 The record profit came to $1.04 a share, compared with 40 cents, or $463 million in total, a year ago. Ford's revenues rose 25 percent, to $30.6 billion.
Ford, the nation's No. 2 auto maker, was the last of the Big Three to report its third-quarter results. Like the Chrysler Corporation's record quarterly earnings of $651 million, Ford's performance stood in sharp contrast to the disappointing results reported last week by the General Motors Corporation, which earned more than $500 million dollars over all but lost $328 million in its core North American auto operations.
Ford expects the money to keep rolling in. Though the company anticipates another increase in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve, Ford said today it sees no signs the United States auto market is weakening.
"Sales appear to be continuing to go up, and we believe we still have a number of good years to go," said David N. McCammon, Ford's treasurer and vice president for finance.
Ford's results exceeded most analysts' expectations. In heavy trading, the company's stock closed at $29.25 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, up 37.5 cents a share.
David M. Garrity, auto analyst with Smith Barney in New York, said Ford's profit margins in North America were almost twice what he had anticipated. "The company clearly shows a demonstrated ability to increase production year over year at a pretty rapid clip," Mr. Garrity said, "but at the same time to introduce a new model without substantial impact to profits, unlike G.M." Analysts have criticized G.M. for taking too long to introduce new models, losing potential sales.
The third quarter tends to be the weakest for the auto makers because of plant shutdowns for vacations. But Ford's sales to dealers in North America were up 17.5 percent in the quarter over last year, to 1.08 million vehicles.
"Volume is the big driver," Mr. McCammon said of Ford's profits. Ford received a boost from its long-troubled European operations. Excluding Jaguar, the British luxury car maker that Ford bought in 1989, the European operations made $25 million, reversing a loss of $217 million last year. While sales are rising in Europe, industry analysts said that Ford appeared to benefit mostly from aggressive cost-cutting.
Ford said Jaguar is on the verge of profitability, but the unit continued to drag in the quarter, losing $53 million, compared with a loss of $108 million last year. Last year's loss was exacerbated by a $65 million restructuring charge.
Ford's financial services operations contributed almost as much to the quarter's bottom line as its automotive units. The financial group earned $523 million, up 33.8 percent from last year.
Unlike those of G.M., Ford's domestic operations remain far more profitable than its overseas units. Ford's net profit margin on auto sales was 2.4 percent -- 3.3 percent in the United States and four-tenths of 1 percent abroad.
In general, though, Ford's plants worked at 109 percent of straight-time capacity, meaning they were running on overtime, Mr. McCammon said. In the fourth quarter, Ford expects its plants to run at 111 percent.
In the United States in the quarter, Ford earned an average of $575 on every vehicle it sold compared to $390 a year ago.
Chrysler made an average of $1,000 on vehicles it sold worldwide in the quarter, not including earnings from its finance arm. Chrysler does not determine the per-unit profit for just the United States, a spokeswoman said.
Ford's increased profit in part reflects the reduction of rebates and other sales incentives. Ford's average incentive for the quarter was $725, down from $865 a year ago. Because Ford was clearing out its 1994 models in the quarter, incentives rose from the second quarter, when they averaged $550 a vehicle.
Ford lost a percentage point of car market share because of new-model changeover, but its share of the light- truck market in the United States held during the quarter, at 31.2 percent. In the competitive mini-van market, Ford gained almost 8 points of share, to 32.9 percent, because of its new Windstar. Chrysler, the segment leader, had 38.8 percent, down 3.5 percentage points.

HEADLINE: Mary Roebling, 89, First Woman To Head Major U.S. Bank, Dies

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Mary G. Roebling, former chairwoman of the National State Bank, one of New Jersey's largest independent banks, and a former governor of the American Stock Exchange, died on Tuesday at her home in Trenton. She was 89.
The cause was renal failure, The Associated Press reported. 
 Mrs. Roebling retired in 1984 as chairman of the National State Bank in Elizabeth, N.J., which then had assets of $1.2 billion.
Earlier, she became the first woman to head a major American bank, the Trenton Trust Company. In 1937, at the age of 30, she was named its president. It grew substantially and she was its president or chairman or both until 1972, when Trenton Trust was acquired by National State. She was then elected chairman of the combined institutions.
Mrs. Roebling was also a founder, in 1978, of the Women's Bank N.A. of Denver, the first nationally chartered bank founded by women. She went on to serve as its chairman until 1983. In addition, she was the American Stock Exchange's first woman governor, from 1958 to 1962.
Mrs. Roebling also served as a director of numerous other corporations over the years, was active in many civic, charitable and educational organizations, and was a tireless advocate of a greater role for women in the country's economic affairs.
In a speech in 1965, Mrs. Roebling said: "As a woman who for years has competed in the business world, I would be the first to agree that the American woman has almost unbelievable economic power, but American women, like women of all civilized nations, do not use the influence their economic power gives them."
Mrs. Roebling's own economic power came initially through inheritance, but she increased it vastly once it fell into her hands. She was bequeathed a large block of Trenton Trust stock by her millionaire second husband, Siegfried Roebling, whose family had long been prominent in engineering and cable manufacturing. He was a great-grandson of John A. Roebling, who designed the Brooklyn Bridge, and a grandson of Col. Washington A. Roebling, who completed its construction.
Siegfried Roebling died in 1936, of a heart attack. Mrs. Roebling's father and father-in-law then urged her to try her hand at running the bank. She had preparation for the job: she had worked for a Philadelphia investment house while taking business courses at night and, the two men told her, she had another important qualification, common sense.
The rest was banking history. She took her husband's seat on the bank's board and, on Jan. 21, 1937, was elected president.
"Mary G. Roebling didn't wait for women's lib," Forbes magazine once wrote, "she was ahead of it, way ahead."
By 1970, Mrs. Roebling estimated that 300 other American women had become presidents or chairwomen of banks. But in 1978, when she became chairwoman of the Women's Bank, she argued that there still was a place in the business world for banks that were operated specifically for female customers.
"Women's banks can be better listeners for women and give them more time, advice and direction than an ordinary bank would give," she told an interviewer. "It's a psychological thing, really."
She continued to be active in male-dominated spheres, however: in 1978, after having served as a civilian aide to the Secretary of the Army in several administrations, she became the founding president of the newly formed Army War College Foundation. It was set up to support the college's fund-raising and other activities.
She was born Mary Gindhart in 1907 in West Collingswood, N.J., the daughter of Isaac D. Gindhart Jr., a telephone company executive, and Mary Simon Gindhart, a music teacher. She went to public schools in Haddonfield and Moorestown, N.J., and earned pocket money picking strawberries for a penny a box.
While still a teen-ager, she married a musician, Arthur Herbert, but he died three years later, leaving her with a daughter to support. She went to work in Philadelphia and took evening courses in merchandising and business administration at the University of Pennsylvania.
She left her job when she married Mr. Roebling, becoming a housewife again until his death.
Over the years, Mrs. Roebling was variously a director of the Tattersall Corporation, the Standard Fire Insurance Company and the Colonial Operating Company, in Trenton, among other concerns; an officer of the New York World's Fair Corporation in 1964 and 1965; a member of the National Business Council on Consumer Affairs and of the Boy Scouts of America's national advisory council, and an active participant in other nonprofit organizations. She was awarded numerous honorary degrees and other honors.
She is survived by a daughter, Betty Hobin of Palm Beach, Fla., and Hopewell Township, N.J.; five grandchildren; six great-grandchildren, and a sister, Margaret G. Finley of Haddonfield, N.J. A son, Paul Roebling, died in July.

HEADLINE: Minority Home Loans Rise, But Many Are Still Rejected

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
Financial institutions in New York City and its suburbs sharply increased their home mortgage lending to minorities last year but continued to reject black applicants more often than whites, according to figures released today by a group of Federal regulators.
The group, the Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council, found that the number of home mortgages issued to blacks in the New York area soared 44.8 percent last year over 1992 and the number issued to whites climbed 19.9 percent. Loans to Asian-Americans and Hispanics increased at roughly the same rate as loans to whites. 
 Banks, savings institutions, credit unions and mortgage companies, however, still denied mortgage applications from blacks in the metropolitan area twice as often as they rejected whites.
The gap between whites and blacks narrowed slightly from 1992; 11.9 percent of mortgage applications from whites were turned down, while 20.5 percent of applications from blacks were rejected, according to the council.
In New York, the rate at which blacks applied for home loans rose twice as fast as for whites.
The New York metropolitan area's trends closely followed the pattern of mortgage lending across the country, for which the council published preliminary figures in late July and nearly identical final figures today. Nationally, mortgage lending rose 35.8 percent for blacks and 17.5 percent for whites.
The sharp rise in minority borrowing was a result of new community outreach programs at banks and last year's low interest rates, which made it much easier for less affluent blacks to buy a new home.
"People who weren't able to afford a home are now buying them," said Lawrence B. Lindsey, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board.
But mortgage interest rates have risen by about two percentage points this year, in part because the Fed has raised short-term interest rates five times since February.
Robert L. Gnaizda, the general counsel of the Greenlining Coalition, a group of civil rights and minority business organizations based in San Francisco, said the mortgage lending figures displayed a mixed picture.
"Most of the major banks and S.& L.'s are improving in their outreach to minorities, but have a long way to go," Mr. Gnaizda said. And some other institutions, he added, "will not go far until they bear the brunt of more Justice Department suits."
The department filed and simultaneously settled an antidiscrimination suit in late August against Chevy Chase Federal Savings Bank, based in Chevy Chase, Md., which agreed to step up its lending and establish new branches in predominantly black neighborhoods in Washington.
The council's member agencies are the Fed, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the National Credit Union Administration and two Treasury Department agencies, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and the Office of Thrift Supervision.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
BOEING CO. (BA,N)

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The Boeing Company said yesterday that its third-quarter net income fell 2.1 percent from last year. Still, the results exceeded analysts' expectations despite recent delays in aircraft orders from major carriers.
Boeing earned $185 million, or 54 cents a share, compared with $189 million, or 56 cents a share, a year earlier. Wall Street had expected earnings of about 40 cents a share. Sales fell slightly to $5.1 billion. 
 The Seattle-based company -- the nation's biggest exporter and the world's biggest aircraft maker -- said sales and earnings continued to drop for the most part because of sales of fewer commercial planes, and to a lesser degree, because of higher debt expenses and lower investment income.
The decline was partly offset by Boeing's ability to lower its Federal income tax rate to 24.7 percent in the first nine months of the year from 31.6 percent in 1993. The third-quarter tax rate was even lower, 21 percent, as the company included the year-to-date effect of tax benefits from research and development.
Boeing's chairman and chief executive, Frank A. Shrontz, said sales for all of 1994 were expected to be about $21.5 billion, 15 percent below last year's, and that 1995 sales were likely to be at "relatively low levels." (Bloomberg Busines News)

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A deficit plan becomes the Administration's latest scandal.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
ONCE again, we learn, the Clinton Administration is racked by scandal. More haircuts on the runway? More sports tickets for high officials, courtesy of the Tyson chicken barons? No: the Rivlin memo.
In a confidential note to President Clinton dated Oct. 3, Alice M. Rivlin, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, provided specific options for coping with the Federal budget deficit. Not surprisingly, they discussed what Ms. Rivlin called "big choices" about raising taxes and slashing spending. 
 Congressional Republicans, who purloined the memo and faxed it to anybody who asked, were shocked to discover that the White House would actually consider taking caviar from the mouths of rich pensioners. Taking no chances, William Kristol, head of the Project for the Republican Future -- affectionately dubbed "Dan Quayle's brain" in an earlier incarnation as the former vice president's chief of staff -- called the options "Yikes!" and "Yikes again!," lest anyone miss their nefarious import.
But not everyone is upset. Paul E. Tsongas, the former Senator from Massachusetts and Democratic Presidential candidate who is now co-chairman of the Concord Coalition, denounced the "unmitigated cynicism of a partisan opposition that won't talk about taxes or entitlement reform." And Robert D. Reischauer, the director of the Congressional Budget Office, added that the "O.M.B. would be derelict in its duty if it did not lay out the options for reducing the deficit."
The Contract with America, the Republican's pre-election wish list constructed by the House minority whip Newt Gingrich, was seized by the White House earlier this month as evidence that Republicans still believed in the free lunch. "They can run, but they can't hide the fact that they have to pay for a trillion dollars in promises," said Gene Sperling, a senior aide to the President. "They don't have a clue how to do it without deep Social Security or Medicare cuts."
But what does the Budget Director's memo really say? "Our attacks on the Republicans for evasiveness about how they would pay for their 'contract' have been effective," Ms. Rivlin wrote, "but they make it imperative that we continue our established policy of explicit and paid-for proposals."
It seems the budget deficit, which fell after the economy started growing in 1992 and the Clinton Administration rammed through a deficit reduction package in 1993, is set to rise again in the near future. White House numbers show it creeping back up, starting next year, and then taking off as Medicaid and Medicare outpace revenues. When the baby boomers retire, Social Security will also slip into the red. That will lead to an estimated $4.1 trillion budget deficit in 2030, if nothing is done to reverse the trend.
And what could be done? Ms. Rivlin offered an "illustrative range of packages," which run from eschewing new programs that would add to the deficit to an overhaul of the tax system to phasing out the most generous Social Security benefits. They also included an all-out attempt to balance the budget by 2000.
When the memo was leaked by a person Mr. Kristol referred to as "a public-spirited senior Administration official," President Clinton moved quickly to contain the political damage. "I do not support cuts in Social Security," he told reporters, "and I believe any savings we achieve in the Medicare program should be used in health care."
That, however, does not leave many options for coping with deficits. Closing what used to be called tax loopholes -- from mortgage deductions on second homes to the failure to tax capital gains at death -- is a possibility. But there are good political reasons those loopholes survived the last rounds of tax reform. And besides, the Administration seems inclined to ease the sting of any tax increase by spending the proceeds on social investment or a middle-class tax cut.
It is also conceivable that the deficit will fade as a policy concern. From economists' perspective, the real issue is the overall level of savings in the economy, and increases in private savings could more than offset increases in public deficits. But don't count on it: There is not a hint that private saving rates are on the rise.
Arguably, the Republicans won the give and take. In this political climate, pretending that deficits will vanish into a Reaganite ether presumably beats sacrifice of any sort.
But deficit reduction is a game in which those most affected by the outcome -- the young -- have no direct say. And Mr. Tsongas, for one, is angry that the Republicans passed up "a golden opportunity" to become the party of fiscal prudence and that President Clinton is "willing to do what is necessary" to hold the allegiance of myopic voters.
Mr. Tsongas hopes you are, too.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Steadies as France Makes an Offer of Support

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar steadied yesterday after the French Economics Minister said France was ready to help the United States support the dollar if necessary.
The comments by Economics Minister Edmond Alphandery countered speculation that European central banks are reluctant to spend more money supporting the dollar after a costly, failed attempt in June. 
 Asked at a news conference whether France was willing to participate in concerted action to support the dollar, Mr. Alphandery said: "Yes, we are ready to do it. The dollar needs to be strong."
After Mr. Alphandery's remarks and statements from United States Treasury officials last week that the United States would buy dollars if necessary, "people are nervous about intervention," said Amy Smith, senior currency strategist at Idea, a consulting firm.
Intervention means the large-scale selling or buying of a currency in return for foreign currencies. In the United States, the decision to intervene is made by the Treasury Department, in consultation with the Federal Reserve. Once the Treasury authorizes an intervention, traders at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York call up the larger banks that deal in currencies and place orders to buy or sell dollars.
Traders said that were it not for speculation that the United States and its allies would mount a dollar-buying spree, the dollar would probably plunge. The last such invervention was on June 24, when the Fed purchased $1.56 billion, a one-day record. Traders and analysts branded the action a failure because the dollar ended the day lower.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.4909 marks, from 1.4970 marks on Tuesday. The dollar was unchanged against the yen, at 96.82 yen. The British pound rose to $1.6382 from $1.6357 on Tuesday. The dollar fell to 1.2429 Swiss francs from 1.2495 francs and to 5.1045 French francs from 5.1225 francs.
Despite the speculation about intervention, "people still want to sell dollars," said Koichi Takenaka, assistant vice president at Industrial Bank of Japan. "This is no reason to buy the dollar aggressively."

HEADLINE: Furniture Circus Comes To Town

BYLINE: By MITCHELL OWENS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HIGH POINT, N.C., Oct. 21

 BODY:
Mario Buatta, the New York society decorator, strolled from one cocktail party to the next with a gag toupee on his head. In front of the La-Z-Boy showroom on Main Street, a crowd of button-down business people waiting for the light watched a bevy of suspiciously well-endowed young women promote the Tiki Club topless bar. And across town, in the parking lot of the National Guard Armory, a 5,000-pound African elephant named Laura gently lowered her wrinkled gray flanks onto a specially built daybed to test the strength of a new laminated lumber product made from aspen saplings.
It's business as usual at the International Home Furnishings Market, equal parts theme park, trade show and Robert Altman film. 
 Twice a year, for nine days in April and nine in October, this sleepy city of 70,000 and its equally somnolent sister, Thomasville, are transformed into Bible-Belt Brigadoons as visitors roam the streets from individual showrooms to about a dozen multistory exhibition centers.
Hotels are booked months in advance, restaurants are packed, there isn't a rental car to be found in 50 miles and traffic reports on the local morning news programs warn that parking spaces begin disappearing at dawn. Worse yet, said Evan Cole, the president of ABC Carpet and Home in New York, the Krispy Kreme doughnut shop (home of what he calls "a little sugar-coated confection that's the best thing in High Point") is so crowded that it puts Manhattan's lunch-hour deli snarls to shame.
Manufacturers, 2,100 of them, gather to show off their latest furniture and accessories, and 69,000 buyers, designers and journalists come from around the world to inspect and order merchandise that will arrive in stores and showrooms roughly from January to April. The show, which is for to the trade only, opened on Oct. 20 and closes tomorrow at 1 P.M.
The American furniture industry, with $17.98 billion in sales in 1993, seems to be buoyant, encouraged by factors ranging from an increasingly healthy national economy to the dawning recognition by mid-range manufacturers that style-conscious consumers live in all parts of the nation, not just New York City and Los Angeles. Analysts at the American Furniture Manufacturers Association, which is based here, predict that by the end of 1994, business will reach $19.83 billion, an increase of more than 10 percent over last year's.
As the market opened, it was apparent that the showrooms of High Point and environs, where more than 60 percent of all the wooden furniture in the United States is made, were rolling out some of their freshest, most appealing wares in years.
"It's like they're taking a cue from the fashion world," said Nan Riggs, the owner of Riggs & Company, decorators in Richmond. "Home furnishings used to be all about a look you had to buy, top to bottom. This time, it feels like they're presenting a real-live wardrobe, great-looking things you can use and move around to really create your own style."
Companies famous for the home-suite-home look of matching furniture shook out the starch. Baker's dependable line of stiff-upper-lip Williamsburg standards got a Club Med make-over: pickled-white wooden pieces upholstered in grass cloth, in leaf-green linen or in raw silk that has the fluffy texture of chenille. The company's room settings, known for being as sumptuous and unreal as a "Masterpiece Theater" set, were invigorated with sharp blasts of color and cinematic details: white tulips bursting from old crystal decanters, and side chairs dressed in rich murky satins of cobalt, grape, bronzy brown and charcoal that recalled the outre glamour of the 1950's, from Venetian glass to Balenciaga ball gowns.
Even when the designs weren't new, the presentations were often bold enough to revitalize furniture lines that had begun to seem passe. Staid 18th-century neo-classicism remained intact at Henredon, for example, but the innovative way the showroom was styled caused visitors to reconsider how compatible formality and reality could be: in one display, plastic children's toys were tossed amid the cabriole legs.
"It was a really surprising way to present a traditional line," said Steve Carlino, the fashion director of the Home Store at Macy's in New York. "It wasn't a museum, it was like real life." Most surprising to him, however, was the market's general repudiation of the 1980's stratospheric price tags. There may not have been any bargain-basement prices at this fall's market, but major manufacturers clearly tried to keep prices down and style high.
"That was what really struck me, as a buyer," Mr. Carlino said. "You don't have to be a genius to design a $4,000 sofa, but you have to be really talented to design what people keep asking for: a beautiful sofa that retails for less than $899."
Situated in a former children's game factory, the new 40,000-square-foot Mitchell Gold showroom, one of the biggest in town, was full of upholstered sofas and chairs that taught old silhouettes new tricks. A proper camelback sofa wore a rumpled leather slipcover. Another sofa was swathed in what Bob Williams, the company's head designer, called "pajamas," a loosely woven, heavy cotton slipcover in material that looked like thermal underwear. There was also the Jasmine sofa, a breezy, boxy salute to a classic design by the 1960's style master Billy Baldwin. In wicker-print cotton and creamy white denim (Baldwin's original featured Madagascar grasscloth and white canvas), the sofa will cost less than $900.
"The average consumer doesn't want to be cool and avant-garde, and a lot of designers forgot about that in the 1970's and 1980's," said Mr. Gold, whose products are staples at chain stores like Crate and Barrel, Pottery Barn and Jennifer Leather. "Most people want something new but familiar, something that refines their eye and gives them an air of fashion, but without throwing them up against a wall to prove the point."
Affordable glamour was also the order of the day at Directional, which was known a decade ago for its costly, momentarily fashionable modernism.
The company's new president, Robert Fernbacher, hired Larry Laslo, the designer responsible for the Zen Deco interiors of the Takashimaya department store on Fifth Avenue, to create a swank line of furniture at low, low prices.
Mr. Laslo apparently succeeded.
"Where else could you get something that great-looking for $900?" said Michael Formica, a New York interior designer. He was referring to the wholesale price of Mr. Laslo's romantic Casino sofa ($1,795 retail), a deep-dish, button-tufted extravaganza that looked like a collaboration between Stanford White and the 1930's decorator Syrie Maugham.
The 60-plus-piece Laslo Part 1 collection is also replete with oddly engaging accents. "They wanted me and all my jewels," said Mr. Laslo, known for elaborate drawer pulls and other Cartier-like embellishments. In practice, many of the things presented at High Point are trial balloons: buyers' reactions can influence the final shape of the product lines, and the rule of thumb is that approximately 80 percent of the items at the show go into production.
Price was a paramount concern at Universal Furniture Industries, too, whose showroom had been painted in rich, crayon-box colors for the debut of Alexander Julian Home Colours, a 35-piece collection of home furnishings created by the Coty Award-winning mens-wear designer. The least expensive piece is a wood occasional table ($250); the most expensive is a 1940's-style sofa covered in worn, bomber-jacket-style leather ($2,000).
The collection is not only inexpensive, but also autobiographical. Many of the woven jewel-toned fabrics used on the sofas and chairs (several of which are based on 1940's flea-market originals at his Connecticut home) copy textiles that Mr. Julian designs for his mens-wear line.
Its signature piece is the Haberdasher's Cabinet, a glass-fronted pine storage unit with shallow drawers for sweaters and socks ($1,299), a homage to the display furniture in a clothing store that Mr. Julian's father operated in Chapel Hill, N.C.
Jill Chapman, the buyer for Portico Home in New York, raved about the J & R Collection, a Chicago company that was making its High Point debut. "It was the best new line, the best new booth, no question," she said. Known for oversize display furniture and accessories used at Nordstrom's, Federated and other department stores, John Houck and Roger Plaster, the company's owners, scaled everything down for residential use. The look? Jean-Michel Frank meets Elsa Peretti, as in a side table with comma-shaped brushed aluminum legs ($650) and a sleek undulating metal Marco table lamp ($275).
At La-Z-Boy, however, home of the big, bodacious, all-American recliner, some buyers were grumbling. The company's statement for fall was a new small recliner collection, called Small Comforts and designed for people under five feet, five inches tall.
"I can't sell this stuff," complained one man who didn't want his name used because he is a La-Z-Boy dealer. "It's a joke, like kid's furniture. How could they make something so stupid?" But Otto Smoktonowicz, a La-Z-Boy spokesman, said he hoped the line would be popular with women and with customers in Asia, where people tend to be smaller than in the United States and where apartments almost always are.
For Gayle Christ, however, Small Comforts was a revelation.
"The theme from 'The Wizard of Oz' does keep going through my head," said Mrs. Christ, a co-owner of Christ Furniture in Eagle Grove, Iowa, "but it is going to open up a lot of options for us."
She added: "When a man sits in a recliner and his feet don't touch the floor, it's humiliating. It's like he thinks he's not a real man."

HEADLINE: GOING HOME WITH: Heather Whitestone;
Placing the Person Ahead of the Crown

BYLINE: By ALEX WITCHEL 

DATELINE: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.

 BODY:
AT the Summit Club, here in her hometown, Miss America has been on her feet for almost two hours, smiling, shaking hands and reading lips. Heather Whitestone, the first Miss America with a disability (she lost her hearing after a bout of Hemophilus influenza at the age of 18 months), could teach the ramshackle House of Windsor a thing or two about dignity and grace. But doesn't she ever get to sit down?
Apparently not. "They just cut that part of their brain out and don't think about it till they get home," purrs an official of the Miss Alabama Pageant. And she's one of the milder middle-aged belles running this show. Welcome home, Heather. 
 This mid-October weekend is the official homecoming of Alabama's newest star, still awash in her victory in Atlantic City last month. The state hadn't won the crown since 1951, so these are big doings. Among the events are a parade; a visit to Jacksonville State University, where Miss Whitestone, 21, is an accounting major; a trip to Hoover High School, her alma mater; Sunday services at her Baptist church, and a tribute by a local ballet company (Miss Whitestone's talent in the pageant was ballet, which she dances by feeling the vibrations of the music).
So far today, there have been some glitches. The limousine that was to drive Miss Whitestone and her entourage the whole block and a half from the Tutwiler Hotel to the Governor's reception at the Summit Club never turns up, so a red Chevy is commandeered instead. The police escort sounds its sirens, jumps the five cars waiting at the one red light and safely leads the car crammed with women into the garage.
Miss Whitestone emerges unruffled. In her red suit and rhinestone-crown pin, she is strikingly beautiful, with glossy brown hair pulled back to reveal the hearing aid behind her left ear (in which 5 percent hearing remains), perfect skin and a dancer's body. When she speaks, she is easy to understand. Asked about her pin, she starts to answer when another pageant official intercedes. "You have to see the Governor now," she snaps. "You don't talk now. The interview comes later."
Miss Whitestone looks wounded. "She only asked about the pin," she says pleadingly. The woman turns her back.
Upstairs, the receiving line has been set in a dimly lighted lobby where it is exceedingly difficult to read lips. Miss Whitestone peers intently at the mouths in front of her (she does not use an interpreter) until someone from the Governor's office tunes in and moves the group to a brighter room.
Among the guests today are members of the Economic Development Partnership of Alabama, which means, the pageant officials say, corporation presidents and their wives. Some of whom have Ivana Trump's hair.
Miss Whitestone gets a break from the receiving line in time for a presentation. The Governor, Jim Folsom, says: "This summer we had Forrest Gump all over the nation, then Miss Alabama became Miss America. You have represented our state so well. Everyone loves you." Especially since an advertisement in USA Today picturing Miss Whitestone's win generated more than 700 good-will calls to the Economic Development Partnership. "The connection is a tremendous positive for the state," says its president, Neal Wade. "She is a great ambassador."
Back at the Tutwiler, Miss Whitestone and her mother, Daphne Gray, who teaches seventh grade math, are staying in the Presidential Suite which, oddly again, has very little light.
Miss Whitestone seats herself at a round table in the living room next to a lamp. A large white box of leftover hors d'oeuvres grows cold nearby, but she doesn't eat. She has what is known in pageant jargon as a platform to discuss.
"When I first competed in Miss America three years ago, my message to schoolchildren was that anything is possible if you believe in yourself and are willing to work hard," she says. "But sometimes they would forget, they're so young. I realized I had to think of some way for them to remember. And with the help of my family and friends, came up with my Stars platform. A star has five points: to have a positive attitude; to believe in your dreams, especially education; to face your obstacles no matter how great; to work hard; to build a support team. It's to promote their positive self-esteem."
Has her physical beauty helped with her own? "I have seen a lot of young ladies who are beautiful but with a hard heart," she says. "Nobody wants to be around them. When your heart is beautiful, you become more beautiful, your smile becomes more beautiful." She answers without artifice, believing what she says because it is what her mother taught her. And what this mother says, goes.
"After the doctor told her I would not go past the third grade, my mother made the decision for me to speak, and she spent hours working with me on my speech and my schoolwork," Miss Whitestone says. "She never let me use my deafness as an excuse. We had a positive environment, where if you fail, just try again. She gave the same advice to my two older sisters, who both went to the Air Force Academy."
But her childhood could not have been devoid of playground cruelty. "Of course, it's natural to make fun of a hearing aid," she says evenly. "It was a box with a cord coming out of it. I was upset. But the teacher said, 'No, they just think it's a radio.' " She smiles graciously. "When you are so young, there is so much to learn."
Though her attitude is admirable, it is also, inevitably, sad. How quickly and eagerly she excuses other people's cruel behavior while demanding only perfection from herself. She spent six years learning to pronounce her last name alone.
"My mother fought all her life for me to achieve my dreams," she says. "They would tell my mother: 'Heather will never learn to speak. And she doesn't need to take ballet.' But my mother put me in dance class to help me with my speech. To learn to count to the rhythm of the music and for me to do the same with my voice when speaking." She demonstrates. "My mother went to the store," she says rhythmically, tapping the table on each emphasis. "But she didn't realize I'd fall in love with ballet."
"When I dance," she continues, "I feel like I'm in a safe world. I remember when I was little, the other children making fun of me, but when I danced I felt free. I was most joyful when I danced in the church and praised God with my dance. Everybody sang in the choir, and I wanted so badly to become part of the worship service."
The wish to be a part of the hearing world is an issue of debate among some deaf activists who are opposed to lip reading and speaking, and advocate the use of universal sign language only. "O.K.," Miss Whitestone says carefully. "Everybody has a different opinion how to communicate. I would encourage people who are deaf or hard of hearing to pursue a broad wedge of communication options. The one they choose should help them to build self-esteem and achieve their goals. And they should think twice before saying what is wrong. There is a freedom of speech in this country. They should do whatever is best for them.
"It is best for me to speak, but that's for me. It doesn't bother me to sign. It's a beautiful language which I didn't learn until I was a senior in high school. So it is a new language for me." She giggles. "I remember I gave testimony at the church once, and I meant to talk about being baptized, and I signed 'dead.' Oh, no!"
It's a relief to see a sense of humor lurking under all that purpose.
"When I was in high school," she says, "I didn't have a date for the prom. But I looked at the positive side. I went out and asked a guy because I did not want to regret it the rest of my life. I said: 'Do you have a prom date? Would you like to come with me?' His face turned so red I thought something was wrong. But he was shy. And he said, 'Oh, yes, of course.' We had a great time. He drove a BMW car with a phone, and we went to a fancy restaurant."
She is quick to add: "But I always worked hard because you needed a 3.0 average or higher to get a scholarship. If I made bad grades I pushed myself, no TV, nothing. Good grades are so important. Because if I have wisdom, no one can take advantage of me and make me feel less important."
When Miss Whitestone is asked questions about her parents, she speaks only of her mother, never mentioning her father, Bill Whitestone, who is a partner in a furniture store in a nearby town and was divorced from her mother eight years ago.
She says that besides her mother, she looks up to the Chicago schoolteacher Marva Collins, who was the subject of a television movie. "She had the desire to help younger people with no hopes and no dreams, to make them feel unique. I want to do what she did. To look at abilities first, disabilities second."
Does she plan to marry? "Eventually," she says. "But only to a one-woman man. An honest person and also a Christian." Well, that could be tough to find. She nods. "But anything is possible," she says, laughing.
While she finally starts to eat, Ms. Gray sits down at the table, too. When she and her daughter speak to each other, their bodies bend forward, then away, like plants underwater.
If Heather had not been deaf, how different would both their lives have been?
"We don't play the 'if' games," Ms. Gray says firmly. She is 48, also brunette and elegantly dressed in a dark teal suit and taupe blouse. "Heather is deaf. Therefore, Heather is a product of her deafness because that is part of her. I have always believed God gives each one of us unique gifts, and not to fulfill that potential is a terrible wrong." A faraway look comes to her eyes when she speaks about what Heather can do, as if she hears something no one else can. As if having a deaf daughter means she hears extra.
"Since Heather became Miss America, it's made my job easier," she continues. "When I say there are no excuses, the students believe me." Miss Whitestone signed a poster for her mother's classroom that reads: "As you can see, I am a result of my mother's action and determination."
Which, Ms. Gray concedes, were initially hard won. "I went through the whole gamut of feelings when Heather lost her hearing," she says. "Angry, hurt, lost, devastated. The good Lord and I had six months of a real hard time. But I believe you grow in character during hardship. Good times are the reinforcers. I am grateful the good Lord didn't give up on me. Why not me? I could handle it, once the peace was gotten in my heart. It was a new challenge. I could feel sorry for myself or see what we could get done. If you concentrate on a negative you get no results."
At 7:30 the next morning, the white stretch limousine has actually arrived. Miss Whitestone enters the scene in a magenta coat dress. The police escort has returned, and the posse sets off for Hoover High School in a Birmingham suburb, where 2,200 students plus faculty members are waiting to welcome Miss America.
They do it in style, with a red carpet leading into a gymnasium. The school band plays, and the crowd gives her a standing ovation. She is presented a bouquet of red roses and sits in a chair with her crown in a box next to her. A group of students stands in front of her signing a song.
When they are finished, her former teacher Lisa Armstrong says: "Heather, you are our hero. We are so proud of you, so happy for you." She hugs her.
Left alone on the gym floor, miked but without a podium, Miss Whitestone begins to speak. "I have a unique opportunity to make a difference in many people's lives," she begins. "I am so excited to talk about my platform. There is no limit to what we can achieve." Then she holds up her crown, to loud applause, which cuts off the snickering by a clique of girls high up in the bleachers. If she has noticed, she does not let on.
"I didn't wear the crown, so you could see me as the person first and Miss America second," she explains. "So many people think they are not worth it, I can't stand it. I understand frustration. But America gives us wonderful freedom to be ourselves."
She goes on, explaining her platform clearly and succinctly with nothing to hide behind, no place to put her hands. She is poised, articulate, genuine. Her mother and teachers look on, proud.
"God bless you all, work hard and I wish you the best of luck," Miss Whitestone says. The applause starts. But not from everyone.
"Is that it?" a girl asks, watching the crown disappear in its box. "Is that all we get?"

LENGTH: 1137 words

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
It's a Grim Message: Dummies Fail More Often

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:

THE BELL CURVE
Intelligence and Class Structure in American Life
By Richard J. Herrnstein and Charles Murray.
845 pages. The Free Press. $30.
Charles Murray, best known for attacking welfare, and Richard Herrnstein, an experimental psychologist who argued that intelligence is largely in the genes, built public careers as the dark angels of social science. And with the publication of "The Bell Curve," their reputations have apparently been secured: The 845-page tract has driven liberal editorial writers to rug-chewing and led the editors of The New Republic to elicit 17 separate rebuttals. 
 The idea behind "The Bell Curve," as many readers must know by now, is that I.Q. is destiny, determining how individuals get along in school, jobs and social relations. Since little can be done to raise "cognitive ability," the argument goes, little can be done to change the socioeconomic pecking order.
This is a grim message, the authors acknowledge, but someone must deliver it. "There can be no real progress in solving America's social problems," Mr. Herrnstein and Mr. Murray explain, "when they are as misperceived as they are today."
Not everyone has been charmed by the pair's appeal to sweet reason. Indeed, some critics have been inclined to hang the defendants without a trial: merely entertaining the idea that I.Q. tests predict economic performance, they believe, breeds complacency about racism because just one black American in six scores above the average for whites.
That is unfortunate, for the authors' look at the nexus between measured intelligence and life outcomes is the most original and interesting part of the book. The analysis deteriorates sharply when it moves on to the question of whether intelligence can be raised through government intervention, and the implications for public policy if it cannot. Indeed, what begins as provocative research on the plight of the losers in a meritocracy ends in a sloppily reasoned rationale for letting them eat cake.
Look again at that unpalatable first premise. Standardized tests of intelligence have been widely condemned for cultural bias, and their use as sorting devices has been discouraged by the courts as well as by liberal opinion. But whatever the tests measure, Mr. Herrnstein, who died last month, and Mr. Murray correctly remind us that the scores predict success in school for ethnic minorities as well as for whites.
What works in predicting school performance apparently also works for predicting success on the job. Even when other key variables (education, parents' social class) are accounted for, scores on one widely administered examination, the Armed Forces Qualification Test, are a potent factor in predicting differences in later earnings. It seems that the growing role of intelligence in determining economic productivity largely accounts for the widening gap between rich and poor.
If all this rings a (different) bell, go to the head of the curve. A number of commentators, including Secretary of Labor Robert B. Reich, have fretted in public about the unhealthy consequences of rewarding citizens according to their skills when so many have so few skills.
The authors of "The Bell Curve" go much further, however, slipping a moral dimension into the argument. They say intelligence also predicts crime rates, welfare dependence, poor parenting and indifference to civic responsibility. And they cleverly trump their race-conscious critics by looking solely at the evidence of differences among whites.
Unlikely as this direct link between intelligence and character may seem, the analysis is scientifically respectable. What comes next, though, is heavily compromised by ideology.
Since they say I.Q. is the key to success, they agree it would be tempting to give the dullards a helping hand. But, alas, they conclude, a better society cannot be built on good intentions and taxpayers' money alone. "For the foreseeable future," they write, "the problems of low cognitive ability are not going to be solved by outside interventions to make children smarter."
Why not? Efforts to raise intelligence through improved childhood nutrition, the authors explain, have been inconclusive. The measurable benefits of preschool enrichment programs dissipate when the youngsters return to the mean streets. A week's worth of prepping for the S.A.T.'s raises average math scores by only 25 points.
Note the disconnect here: The ambiguous evidence from America's on-again, off-again efforts to cope with the consequences of poverty and racial prejudice hardly squares with the authors' deeply pessimistic conclusion. But a belief in genetic determinism would explain it. And while they never make a fuss about heredity, they don't bother to conceal it. It is "beyond significant technical dispute," they write, that "cognitive ability is substantially heritable, apparently no less than 40 percent and no more than 80 percent."
Does that put the authors beyond the scholarly pale? Many biologists think so, dismissing the possibility that a group characteristic as complex as heritable intelligence could have diverged so sharply between races in what amounts to a single tick of the evolutionary clock. But this reviewer is not a biologist, and will leave the argument to experts.
It takes less expertise to analyze the Herrnstein-Murray policy prescription. With society increasingly dominated by its meritocratic elite, they predict the winners will create a "custodial state" in which the underclass will be stripped of rights and responsibilities. "We have in mind a high-tech and more lavish version of the Indian reservation for some substantial minority of the nation's population," they write.
And what is the alternative that follows from their full and frank discussion of the plight of those not fortunate enough to have been born in Lake Wobegon? They would give the losers a chance to "find valued places in society."
All Mr. Herrnstein and Mr. Murray seem to have in mind, however, is getting Big Brother off the backs of the intellectually challenged. Simpler economic rules, they say, would free the underclass from regulation and taxation intended to protect the perquisites of the elite. Clearer rules about the vices of crime and dependence would provide disincentives for theft, violence and procreation outside marriage. Decentralization of government responsibility to the neighborhood level would help restore community (racial?) pride and traditional values.
If this seems a bit underwhelming, join the crowd. After wading through a long, quasi-academic examination of the statistical links between intelligence, character, race and poverty, the reader's reward is a hoary lecture on the evils of the welfare state.
At least Rush Limbaugh has a sense of humor.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Charles Murray; Richard J. Herrnstein (The Free Press)

HEADLINE: Cold Hearts in France

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis; Flora Lewis is a former foreign affairs columnist of The New York Times.

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
What is a country to do when it prides itself on being "a land of asylum" -- a haven for the persecuted, dedicated to human rights -- yet feels threatened by a flood of hundreds of thousands of refugees?
I am not talking about the United States but about France. These painful questions have become urgent here, too, and the wrenching demands of conscience versus expediency have brought the Government under attack. 
 The source of the biggest trouble is Algeria, which is as much a part of France's backyard as Haiti is of America's, although the French don't say that. Of course Algeria is no hapless Haiti but rather a big oil producer and major French trading partner. And it is shuddering on the brink of civil war. Estimates vary from 10,000 to 30,000 people killed since the conflict began nearly three years ago, after elections were canceled because the Government feared that the Islamic fundamentalists would win.
A particularly nasty feature of the warfare is the assassination of intellectuals and foreigners by armed fundamentalist groups. The toll rises almost daily; it has reached 22 journalists and 64 expatriates, many of them French. It seems to be an adaptation of the Che Guevara strategy of fomenting revolution by murders that will provoke government reprisal and thus sharpen public anger against those in power.
France has warned its citizens to leave Algeria unless their presence is essential, in effect bowing to the fundamentalists' determination to drive foreigners out and thus weaken the economy's links outside.
But France has virtually stopped giving visas to Algerians whose lives are threatened and who want even temporary refuge.
This has aroused an outcry in France, particularly among intellectuals who feel obliged to show their disgust at lethal attacks on the arts and freedom of speech, and their solidarity with the victims.
Apart from Algeria, the occasions for their outrage are frequent. Taslima Nasrin, the Bangladeshi writer who fled to Sweden because of a fatwa calling for her death, was invited to appear on a French television show but refused the Government's humiliating offer of a visa limited to 24 hours. Its excuse was that she was such a big security risk. Publicly denounced for hypocrisy and cowardice, the Interior Ministry relented and promised her a week's visa "once the security situation permits."
Officials are loath to make exceptions for fear of an outpouring of refugees as the Algerian war intensifies and of a sudden increase in France's Muslim population. Islam is already the second religion in France, and some of its rules and practices conflict with French laws and customs.
Traditionally, France treats migrants as individuals, to be offered assimilation and protected from persecution. French moral principle and prospects for social harmony argue for relying on the country's egalitarian educational system to promote assimilation, and to apply laws on the basis of individuals, not groups.
But there are political pressures from the right wing, which blames the migrants for crime, unemployment and abuse of welfare. The Government, trying to avoid losing support to the right, has made concessions to these views.
That's a mistake. The answer has to be to continue to offer refuge, to preserve national pride in inclusiveness and the welcome to citizenship.
The right incites fears about loss of French identity. But that identity is founded on "liberty, equality, fraternity." It would be lost if that base were undermined.

HEADLINE: Journal;
Getting Real

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
"One of the reasons why people are so turned off about politics today," said the Mayor of New York on Monday, is "because we don't act like we're real people."
Amen. But I must confess that I never considered Rudolph Giuliani a real person, either, until I heard his endorsement of Mario Cuomo. 
 Much has been said about how shocking it is for a Republican Mayor to embrace the state's longest-running, longest-winded Democrat. Mr. Giuliani didn't just stand up for the man he believes to be the city's best hope in Albany, but he stood up to his own political allies, from Guy Molinari of Staten Island to Phil Gramm to Mortimer Zuckerman's editorialists in The Daily News, all of whom promptly fell into a flabbergasted snit.
Even so, not enough has been said about the eloquence with which Mr. Giuliani succinctly laid out the logic behind his tough decision at his press conference. Whatever the outcome of the New York governor's race, the Mayor has single-handedly elevated political discourse in an election season when voters of both parties are as turned off as he said.
Mr. Giuliani did not indulge in euphemisms. Speaking of George Pataki, the Republican he spurned, and Alfonse D'Amato, Mr. Pataki's patron, he reviled "a candidate taking as few positions as possible, all of them as general as possible, taking no risks and being guided and scripted by others."
So pungent were the Mayor's remarks that they transcended the narrow political culture of New York. He decried anyone who runs on cliches, slogans and sound bites and summed up the appeal of content-free campaigns in a sentence: "George Pataki's only essential characteristic is that he offers an alternative." Any C-Span viewer who has shared my masochistic inclination to surf among local political debates in recent days knows that this description of an empty suit also fits Democrats and Republicans alike in statewide races in Texas, Florida, Maryland and Illinois.
What sort of candidate rises above the dreary norm of '94? Mr. Giuliani's simple answer: "I prefer someone who has their own ideas, can tell you what those ideas are and you can disagree with them if you want to." By contrasting Mr. Cuomo's specificity with Mr. Pataki's vacillation on crucial economic issues, the Mayor made a more effective case for a fourth Cuomo term than the Governor himself has marshaled thus far.
Still, Mr. Giuliani didn't hypocritically try to flatter or fake out his strange new political bedfellows by pretending to be the next John Lindsay. He proudly reiterated his own faith in Republican conservative dogma, which is the antithesis of Mr. Cuomo's Democratic orthodoxy. As the Mayor's new round of budget cuts dramatized a day later, his route to a fiscally recovered New York is a painful 12-step program in which the poor and disenfranchised must enroll first.
But in a party now synonymous with Newt Gingrich, Mr. Giuliani's intellectual integrity makes him a hero. And in a year when Democrats are hardly made of sterner stuff -- who among them has the courage of his 1992 convictions? -- he joins a small but conspicuous list of Republicans who believe in something besides self-advancement. Arlen Specter, a pariah among liberals since the Clarence Thomas hearings, is now a G.O.P. pariah for speaking out against the religious right. John Warner refused to support Oliver North in Virginia from day one. William Bennett and Jack Kemp came out against the immigrant-bashing ballot Proposition 187 beloved by Republican candidates in California.
Contrast these exceptions with a party leader like Bob Dole, who, after correctly dismissing Oliver North as "a loose cannon," tossed aside principle to campaign for him anyway. "You have to be flexible sometimes," said Mr. Dole by way of explanation.
Not so, says Rudolph Giuliani. "The voters want politicians to be like them -- straight, honest," is how he put it this week, and he's right. I didn't vote for Mr. Giuliani; maybe I never will. But by acting like a real person, by speaking straight and without slogans, he started an open-ended adult conversation that engaged me, and certainly not me alone, as few other politicians have in this foul election year.

HEADLINE: Aunt Jemima Is Least of U.S. Blacks' Worries

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Aunt Jemima Gets a Makeover" by Brent Staples (Editorial Notebook, Oct. 19): It amazes me how some African-Americans misplace their ire on racial inequality issues and perceptions of inferiority. As an African-born American, I cannot comprehend how the picture of a black man on a box of rice demeans my sense of being or harms my status and capability in the society. 
 I do not intend to disregard factual incidents of racism. Neither am I ignorant of history. The reality is that a black child born in America today has a lower life expectancy than a Bangladeshi similarly born. As the father of a 10-year-old son, I am bothered by that a lot. Insofar as the same oddity does not apply to a Caucasian born in America, I am perplexed at this inequality.
Furthermore, within the course of his lower life expectancy, we are told, the African child born in America may very likely not earn as much as his Caucasian colleague, and he is more likely to be killed as a result of a criminal act perpetrated by a member of his race.
It seems to me that the issue that impacts the dignity, survival and prosperity of an African-American is more a matter of equal opportunity in the areas of academic excellence and economic well-being than it is of whether an Uncle Ben or a Betty Crocker adorns the package of a food item or a household product. Ken Smikle, the publisher of Target Market News, should get a grip on the real issues that confront African-Americans in today's America.
 
KINGSLEY SOSOO
Brooklyn, Oct. 20, 1994
