HEADLINE: The Works To Watch At Auction

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
LIKE traders who compulsively watch the stock market to see where the smart buys are, collectors, dealers and curators peruse Sotheby's and Christie's catalogues in hopes of discovering either bargains or great works they haven't seen on the market before. This will be especially true in the next two weeks as the important round of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art auctions takes place in New York.
This fall's sales, which begin on Tuesday at Sotheby's, offer a smattering of everything. But taken as a whole, the artworks, thought to be worth more than $140 million, are nothing to crow about. While the offerings, which go on view starting this weekend, include works by masters like Monet and van Gogh, Warhol and Lichtenstein, the sales are generally thinner than they have been in years. Gone is the glamour of the $50 million masterpiece that epitomized the boom years. Instead, these sales reflect the way the auction world used to be 15 years ago: a serious arena for trading art. 
 To the credit of both auction houses, each has taken a conservative approach, trying not to give in to stubborn sellers who demand unrealistically high estimates. They have also tried not to pad sales with too much middle-market merchandise, the kind that was once relegated to the lower-price day sales. "We both said after the last sales we would tread very carefully," said Christopher Burge, the chairman of Christie's in New York. "We've made a conscious effort to offer salable things and not stretch the market with aggressively priced works that have been offered around before."
Not that either Sotheby's or Christie's had much choice in its offerings. After poor sales in May, sellers who can wait do, until they are confident prices will go up. As a result, both auction houses have been at the mercy of fate. The age-old reasons art finds its way to auction -- death, divorce and debt -- still keep the business afloat.
"It's been difficult to get anything for sale," said David Nash, the director of Impressionist and modern art at Sotheby's. "There is a perception that the recession is ending and that things are better, but most people are still putting off selling, which is an impediment to putting together a crackerjack sale. There are a few good things out there, but not many."
Price is on everyone's mind. "The most competition is going to be for the lower-valued works," said Michael Findlay, the senior director of Impressionist and modern art at Christie's in New York. "Art priced in the $300,000-to-$400,000 range will probably get spirited bidding. Anything over $1 million, regardless of quality, may not be so easy going."
The number of multi-million-dollar paintings up for sale this fall is small. In contemporary art, there are fewer than a handful. The paintings on the covers of both Sotheby's and Christie's contemporary-art catalogues are the most expensive works in their sales. They are also exceptional examples of Pop art. "Pop is the most undervalued section of the market," said Anthony Grant, who heads Sotheby's contemporary-art department in New York. "It was the most inflated in the 80's. But just as it went straight up, it also came straight down."
 
A Test of the Market
 The cover of Sotheby's catalogue, Roy Lichtenstein's "I'm Sorry," from 1965-66, depicts one of the artist's famous comic-strip-style images of a prototypical blonde. (This time she's shedding a tear.) The painting is being sold by Holly Solomon, the SoHo dealer, and has been in her private collection since 1966. While Sotheby's wasn't willing to print an estimate in its catalogue, Mr. Grant says he is telling those who ask that he believes the painting will sell for $2 million to $2.5 million.
The auction of the Pop artwork on the cover of Christie's contemporary-art catalogue will no doubt provide the most dramatic moment of the next two weeks. It shows one of the best-known images in contemporary art, the face of Marilyn Monroe. But this isn't just any portrait of the movie star: it's the famous "Shot Red Marilyn," the brightly colored 1964 Warhol silk-screen that fetched $4.07 million at Christie's in New York in May 1989, at the height of the market. Now Masao Wanibuchi, a Tokyo-based tailor and collector, is selling the work. But he's willing to take a lot less than he paid for it. This time it is expected to fetch $2.5 million to $3 million, about 40 percent below its record price.
The silk-screen is one of several images that were stacked against a wall in Warhol's Factory in 1964 when a woman entered with two friends and a Great Dane and aimed a pistol at the movie star's forehead, shooting a hole through the stack of four Marilyns. Then she departed. (The bullet hole, above Marilyn's left eyebrow, was subsequently repaired by the artist.)
How "Marilyn" performs next week will be of great interest, and not just to Warhol collectors. Determining the value of Warhol's art has been at the center of a bitter legal battle between the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts, the main beneficiary of the artist's estate, and Edward W. Hayes, the estate's former lawyer, who contends he is owed 2 percent of the value of the estate. Christie's has also been involved in the suit: it was hired to appraise the artist's estate, an appraisal that the judge, Surrogate Eve Preminger, said in a ruling had undervalued Warhol's work by nearly $300 million. Now Christie's valuations are about to be put to the harshest test of all: the art market. The outcome may speak volumes about how Warhol prices are holding up.
 
Cream of the Crop?
 Both contemporary-art sales have some interesting offerings and some impeccable provenances. Sotheby's is continuing to sell works from the collection of S. I. Newhouse Jr., the publishing magnate. Among them are Cy Twombly's "Untitled (Roma)," a classic gray-and-white blackboard painting from 1970. The auction house estimates it will bring $800,000 to $1.2 million. (It is considered risky to sell works the same year an artist is having an important exhibition, like Mr. Twombly's retrospective now at the Museum of Modern Art.) Mr. Newhouse is also selling Jasper Johns's "Screenpiece No. 3 (The Sonnets)," from 1968, estimated at $600,000 to $800,000.
Sotheby's is also selling a group of paintings and drawings that belonged to Harold Rosenberg, the critic and writer for The New Yorker, who died in 1978. Among the cream of his collection is Willem de Kooning's "Monumental Woman" (1953), a forceful charcoal study for the artist's Woman Paintings.
In addition to the Warhol, Christie's plum offerings are from the estate of Gerald S. Elliott, the Chicago lawyer, who died in March. Mr. Elliott had amassed significant holdings by American and European artists including Bruce Nauman, Donald Judd, Richard Serra and Anselm Kiefer. At his death, he left the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago the bulk of his collection. The estate is selling the rest. "What's unusual about this collection is the combination of intelligence and passion with which it was assembled," said Diane Upright, who heads Christie's contemporary-art department. Among the highlights is Frank Stella's "Ileana Sonnabend" (1963), a trapezoidal painting named for the SoHo dealer. It is expected to bring $40,000 to $600,000.
In the past, Sotheby's has been the most aggressive auction house, offering sellers a wide choice of financial arrangements. But this fall, Diana D. Brooks, who heads Sotheby's auctions worldwide, says Sotheby's has given no financing to any sellers in either the Impressionist and modern art sale or the contemporary-art sale. "Sometimes it's worth taking the risk," she said. "Sometimes it's not. I sleep a whole lot better at night this fall."
This season Christie's has the most estate property. But it has paid the price: the auction house has given sellers financing. It guaranteed the works from the estate of Alice Tully, the philanthropist, for example. (A guarantee is an agreed-upon minimum price paid by the auction house to the seller. If the art does not sell, it becomes the auction house's property.) While the auction house declined to comment on the specific amount, word circulating among art experts is that Christie's has guaranteed the Tully heirs considerably more than the $22 million low estimate for the entire estate, which includes art, jewelry, furniture and other objects.
One painting belonging to Miss Tully is the star offering in Christie's Impressionist and modern sale on Nov. 9. It is Monet's "Waterlilies" (1907). The round painting, in soft pastel hues, is estimated at $4 million to $6 million.
Another work with a special provenance is Brancusi's "Kiss," executed by the artist in Paris between 1907 and 1908. It is from the property of Blanchette Rockefeller and is expected to bring $900,000 to $1.2 million.
 
A Portrait, a Landscape
 Sotheby's Impressionist auction on Nov. 8 is less impressive. Its star painting is Modigliani's "Portrait of Jeanne Hebuterne," being sold by an unidentified South American collector. The 1919 portrait of the artist's pregnant mistress is estimated at $6 million. Another important work, Miro's "Woman in the Night" (1945), is being sold by Leslie Wexner, the chairman of the Limited, who bought the painting for $2.5 million in 1986 at Sotheby's in New York. This fall, Sotheby's estimates it will bring $3.5 million to $4.5 million.
Sotheby's is also selling van Gogh's "Wheat Field With Sheaves," one of a group of drawings done in 1888. It may bring $2 million to $3 million. Of less interest will be the four paintings by Tanguy that Sotheby's sold three years ago from the collection belonging to the Yaseen family of Harrison, N.Y. Each brought $247,500. Now they are back on the market with estimates of $175,000 to $225,000 each.
"I'm more optimistic about the market than our Impressionist sale shows," said Mrs. Brooks. "The buyers are out there, but they want everything to be just right."
 
 
Where and When
 Some of the artworks to be auctioned at Sotheby's and Christie's in Manhattan in the next few weeks will be on view beginning this weekend. Admission to viewings and to the afternoon sales is free. Reserved tickets, also free, are required for the evening sales at Sotheby's and Christie's.
Sotheby's is at 1334 York Avenue, at 72d Street. Ticket information: (212) 606-7171. General information: (212) 606-7000.
Christie's is at 502 Park Avenue, at 59th Street. Ticket and other information: (212) 546-1127.

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Donald G. McNeil Jr. 

 BODY:

The Drought of Leading Men
Lincoln Center Theater has dropped "Tonight at 8:30," a two-night cycle of seven Noel Coward one-act plays, from its Broadway plans this year. And why? Because New York isn't a big enough town to produce the right leading man. At least, not one who isn't committed to a bigger town called Hollywood.
"A handsome leading man over 40 -- that's the toughest assignment in the theater," said Andre Bishop, the theater's artistic director. "We already had Blythe Danner, Nancy Marchand and Simon Jones. But this needed someone in his mid-40's or older, attractive, who sings well, who dances, who can do English for real -- not a phony-baloney accent -- who can partner an actress as wonderful as Blythe Danner, and has a certain . . . um . . . Cowardian insouciance." 
 Whom did they talk to? "Oh, everyone from God down," said Mr. Bishop, careful to avoid hurting anyone's feelings.
Finally he said there were "eight or nine" actors who filled the bill, and that Kevin Kline would have been perfect, but that all had scheduling conflicts or couldn't make a five-month commitment at the roughly $1,000-a-week salary Lincoln Center was talking about.
"We retained the rights with the Coward estate," Mr. Bishop said, the regret in his voice obvious. "We'll do it eventually."
 
Metronome Humor
 Andrew Lloyd Webber was interviewed on stage at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Saturday -- at the Broadway-style ticket price of $30 -- and although he told stories full of self-deprecating humor, it became clear why he does not write musical comedy. His idea of comedy is so musical that, unless you have a degree from Juilliard, he has to poke your ribs black and blue with his elbow explaining the punchline.
For instance: "My favorite line in 'Phantom,' " he told Martin Gottfried, "is the repetiteur saying, 'Now, once again, if you please, Signor Piangi, after 7 . . . 5, 6, 7 . . .' "
A pause. "Meaning, do it in 7/8 time, as it's written."
He paused again. "I've only once heard a loud laugh at that one. And it turned out to be a rather famous conductor in the audience."
 
Neil Simon, Lost in Manhattan
 When Neil Simon snubbed Broadway last week, announcing that its economics would force him to produce his newest play Off Broadway, he also wrote a plot problem for himself. Although 1,000-seat Broadway theaters are available, most of the theaters of 450 or more seats, the size he wants, are booked, at least tentatively. (Needless to say, a theater owner offered the New York premiere of "London Suite" might break a contract -- or push his grandmother off a pier -- to get it.) The show could be shoe-horned into the season of an established company, but that's pretty disruptive.
As it turned out, there are plenty of offers out there. None have been accepted, and some weren't exactly what Emanuel Azenberg, Mr. Simon's producer, had in mind. "We got a movie theater," he said. "And a guy who had a couple of garages he said we could put together." Another had a big apartment and suggested rewriting the play so the audience could follow it from room to room. The oddest of the serious offers was of a collapsible 420-seat theater made of velvet-on-steel panels, supposedly by the same Soviet industrial group that built the Mir space station. The catch: it's in storage in a hangar in Russia.
 
Saving Money on Costumes
 In its vicious pan of "Hair" in 1968 as a phony, sell-out vision of hippie counter-culture, The East Village Other got off a line that might have been quoted in the ads, since it was what much of the excitement was about: "If you have never seen a nude boy before -- from the front! -- and you don't mind bringing a flashlight (suddenly the stage gets very, very dark), then go . . . "
Back then it was shocking: a brief moment of the cast standing there like kouri, and then everyone scurrying off in the blackout to get dressed.
Recently, a press release for "Automatic Telling" arrived with the note: "Contains full frontal nudity." The publicity agent later admitted it was partly a warning, partly a come-on.
One wonders why they bother. This is the season for wall-to-wall naked men on stages from Central Park to Broadway to Off Broadway. "Passion," "Automatic Telling" and "Killer Joe" have women naked in sex scenes and "Girl Gone" opens in a topless bar, but it's guys who are flaunting it in crowds and wisecracking about it. It's not shocking anymore. Sometimes it's funny, sometimes it's tender, sometimes it's essential to the plot. And sometimes it isn't.
Terrence McNally's "Love! Valour! Compassion!," with its six gorgeous male bodies sunning in Dutchess County, is the season's "Sirens" for Playgirl subscribers (although the comic high point is the seventh, Nathan Lane, in a tiny apron). Paul Calderon, a boxer, towels off after a shower in "Blade to the Heat." There's a similar after-bath scene by a young man in "Les Parents Terribles," coming from London in the spring. Daniel Jenkins, in the Steven Spinella role in "Angels in America," strips for a medical exam, showing the wasting effects of AIDS.
And what were those poor guys doing skinny-dipping during one of the coldest Augusts on record in the Shakespeare-in-the-Park production of "The Two Gentlemen of Verona"? Helping sell free tickets, presumably, because they were echoed on the cover of the Playbill, an 1883 Thomas Eakins painting of bare-bottomed Victorian gents bathing that otherwise had nothing to do with Verona or Shakespeare.
What's going on? Why this year? George C. Wolfe, who directed "Blade" and "Angels" and, as head of the Papp Public Theater, oversaw "Two Gentlemen," is probably as responsible as anyone for the trend. "Nudity can disarm an audience," he said. "That's the idea, not to assault. In 'Blade,' you see Paul out of the shower after he's just lost his title. It's a stripping down; it reveals the frailty in the human flesh."
"What's fascinating," he went on, "is that now men are nude in these innocent situations, while for the women it's only in sexual ones."
Joe Mantello, the director of "Love! Valour!," echoed the "innocent flesh" idea: "I think it's just a happy coincidence that there are so many."
Is there a double standard operating? "The real double standard is in film," he said. "It's routine for an actress to be asked to bare her breasts for movies. But you can count on one hand the male actors who appear nude."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Theaters of War" -- Yolande Bavan is in "Voices From Sri Lanka," a play now at the Theater for the New City. The playwright, Toby Armour, began writing her one-acts about police killings and widows of assassinated politicians during a 1993 stint in Sri Lanka as a human rights observer. On Sunday, a suicide bomber killed 52 people there, including a presidential candidate, and Ms. Armour is putting herself at risk again. She flew there yesterday to be an unarmed escort for election monitors: "Where else can someone like myself, by merely being there, make someone feel less afraid?"

HEADLINE: Give President Credit for Restoring Tax Equity

 BODY:
To the Editor:
President Clinton has been criticized for waffling and wavering and providing ill-defined leadership, although his legislative accomplishments are actually quite impressive. One Clinton achievement that deserves but doesn't get much attention is the revival of progressive taxation, now reflected in a tax rate structure that begins at 15 percent and rises in four bracket-jumps to a top of nearly 40 percent. 
 President Reagan, who once denounced progressive taxation as a Marxist plot and contrary to the will of God, succeeded in 1986 in putting through a flat-tax structure under which, roughly speaking, individuals earning $30,000 a year paid tax on their last dollar of income at the same rate -- 28 percent -- as individuals earning 10 or 100 times more. This reversed an equitable feature of our tax law that had been in place virtually from the beginning of the income tax.
The Budget Act of 1993, enacted at President Clinton's urging despite a tidal wave of misinformation from its opponents, in effect restored this mildly redistributive device -- appropriately, in the name of fairness.
Faced with more dramatic domestic issues -- crime, health care, welfare reform -- should we care about our Federal tax structure? We should. As is well known, the distribution of national income has grown increasingly unequal over the last dozen years, at least in part as a consequence of the tax legislation that President Reagan put over on a gullible public.
We are constantly told that American voters are disaffected, that they suffer from a political malaise, that they no longer trust their political leaders, and so on. Surely one reason is a growing sense that economic progress has been for the few. Progressive taxation won't solve the problem. But it helps, both actually and as a symbol of our national ideals.
 
MARVIN A. CHIRELSTEIN
Professor of Law
Columbia University
New York, Oct. 22, 1994

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (79%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (79%);

HEADLINE: Give President Credit for Restoring Tax Equity;
Official Jobless Policy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Answering a news conference question on Oct. 21, President Clinton outlined his efforts to overcome the "loss of economic opportunity" by many citizens, according to your Oct. 22 transcript. He included moving people "from welfare to work," "bringing this economy back," creating jobs and establishing "community development banks and empowerment zones in our inner cities." 
 The President said nothing about the bipartisan policy to maintain an official unemployment rate of at least 6 percent in order to control inflation.
His own economic policies consider the present situation to be one of "full employment." If significant numbers of jobs are to be created in the inner cities, jobs will have to be lost elsewhere to maintain the desired unemployment rate.
Why does an otherwise sophisticated White House press corps never question Presidents about these policies, and why do headlines repeatedly praise job losses as an indication that inflation is under control?
 
FREDERICK C. THAYER
Pittsburgh, Oct. 22, 1994
The writer is a professor emeritus at the U. of Pittsburgh Graduate School of Public and International Affairs.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE CAMPAIGN;
Upstate, Pataki's New Message: Giuliani Endorsement Has Price

BYLINE: By CHARISSE JONES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 27

 BODY:
State Senator George E. Pataki's campaign allies suggested today that they would use Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's endorsement of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to their advantage, telling voters outside the city that Mr. Cuomo would have to pay Mr. Giuliani back with fiscal help to the city after the election.
As the governor's race focused on the split between New York City and upstate, Mr. Pataki campaigned from Albany to Syracuse to Binghamton, and Mr. Cuomo debated everyone except Mr. Pataki in Buffalo. 
 Mr. Pataki's campaign worked to retake control of a campaign that politicians say was shaken by the decision by Mr. Giuliani, a Republican, to go against his party and support Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat. Polls taken since that decision show the race tightening, but Mr. Pataki's supporters said that they could turn the endorsement back on Mr. Cuomo.
"Frankly, it plays into our hands in the suburbs and upstate," said State Senator George Bruno of Saratoga Springs, who appeared with Mr. Pataki in Albany. "Giuliani is looking for more money from the state and where is that money going to come from? There is only so much to go around."
Mr. Pataki, meanwhile, seized upon an old standby issue -- crime -- as he flew around the state to hammer home his support for the death penalty. He again and again blasted Mr. Cuomo's decision to grant clemency to a convicted murderer, Gary McGivern, and return another convicted killer, Thomas Grasso, to New York when he faced the death penalty in Oklahoma.
Mr. Pataki has pushed the crime issue hard ever since Mr. Giuliani endorsed Mr. Cuomo on Monday. The Cuomo campaign released a new ad today to counter some of those attacks, even as Mr. Giuliani continued to attack Mr. Pataki's tax cuts and planned to campaign for Mr. Cuomo upstate and in Brooklyn and Queens this weekend.
Three new polls, one released by the Marist Institute for Public Opinion in Poughkeepsie, another by Newsday and WABC-TV and a third conducted for The Daily News and WNBC-TV by Louis Harris & Associates, show Mr. Pataki's lead over Mr. Cuomo disappearing amid Mr. Cuomo's negative advertising and the heavy spending of the Independence Fusion candidate, B. Thomas Golisano.
The Newsday-WABC survey was the first major poll to show Mr. Cuomo ahead, with 43 percent of respondents supporting him and 36 percent supporting Mr. Pataki. The Harris poll, in the Friday issue of the Daily News, likewise showed 43 percent of those polled supporting Mr. Cuomo, with 42 percent for Mr. Pataki.
The Marist poll shows that the race has narrowed, with 37 percent of those polled supporting Mr. Pataki and 36 percent backing Mr. Cuomo. A month ago, a Marist poll showed Mr. Pataki leading by six percentage points, 44 to 38 percent. The poll showed Mr. Golisano receiving 8 percent of the vote. Marist did not ask voters about Mr. Golisano in September.
Lee M. Miringoff, the institute's director, said the salient point of the poll was that while Mr. Cuomo's support seems frozen, Mr. Pataki's numbers are slipping. "Mr. Pataki has reversed momentum," he said. "Nothing is moving toward Cuomo, just away from Pataki."
Mr. Miringoff said Mr. Cuomo's attack ads, coupled with the fact that most voters still have only hazy impressions of Mr. Pataki, had driven up Mr. Pataki's unfavorable ratings. "There is no reservoir of positive public opinion for him to fall back on," Mr. Miringoff said.
Mr. Pataki chose to emphasize his opponent's numbers rather than his own, saying that the Marist poll showed that after 12 years in office, Mr. Cuomo did not have the support of the majority of New Yorkers.
He also said that a vote for Mr. Golisano would be wasted, because, "There is no question in my mind that everyone in this room and voters in this state understand that next Jan. 1, either George Pataki or Mario Cuomo is going to be governor."
Mr. Pataki received a boost tonight with the endorsement of The New York Post. The endorsement, which had been expected, said Mr. Pataki "has succeeded in articulating a vision for the state."
At a public-television debate in Buffalo tonight, Mr. Cuomo traded mild barbs with Mr. Golisano, the Rochester millionaire whom polls show is drawing considerable support away from Mr. Pataki. . The Governor bridled at a chorus of suggestions that the state's economy and social fabric was falling apart.
"One gets the impression we're the only ones with a job in this state," Mr. Cuomo said, after listening to Mr. Golisano reel off statistics about job losses. He said he was amused with Mr. Golisano's complaints, wryly wondering how he had prospered so well in a state with such a terrible business climate.
The Pataki campaign has launched efforts on several fronts to win back support from Mr. Golisano upstate. At times, the effort has caused his campaign to send different messages to voters depending on where he was campaigning.
For instance, in radio advertisements that began running in some communities upstate earlier this week, Mr. Pataki attacks a Cuomo proposal to reduce utility rates in Long Island by having the state purchase the Long Island Electric Company. In the commercial, Mr. Pataki accuses Mr. Cuomo of wanting "to buy votes on Long Island by putting our children nine billion dollars further in debt" and denounces the proposal as "corporate welfare."
Yet during a campaign stop in Nassau County on Tuesday, Mr. Pataki said that while he was skeptical that the proposal could save much money, he was still evaluating its "pros and cons." He also said that he did not know anything about the commercial -- even though his voice is on it.
In Albany today, Mr. Pataki acknowledged calling the idea "corporate welfare," but he denied that he had softened his criticism while campaigning in Long Island, where Mr. Cuomo's proposal has sparked widespread interest, even if few officials have yet to endorse it.

HEADLINE: U.S. ECONOMY GREW 3.4% IN QUARTER; INFLATION IN CHECK

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28

 BODY:
Despite a series of interest-rate increases this year, the American economy grew at a surprisingly rapid 3.4 percent annual pace during the summer, Government figures showed today. Consequently, 1994 is now shaping up as possibly the second-best year in a decade.
Yet inflation still showed no acceleration and, at least by some gauges, slackened a bit during the July-September quarter. 
 The Clinton Administration, which has gained little public credit for the robust economy, exulted in the Commerce Department report, which provided timely ammunition for Democrats in the midterm elections 11 days away.
"It's the best of all possible worlds," said Vice President Al Gore, who appeared in the White House briefing room between campaign swings to trumpet "strong economic growth with historically low inflation."
While some experts on Wall Street remained worried that the economy was too strong for its own good, the Vice President's comments echoed those of several private analysts. And the bond and stock markets reacted positively to the figures. [Page 37.]
After several upbeat readings on the economy in recent weeks, Mr. Gore said, "The wind is at the back of Democratic candidates."
At the same time, however, the economy has not been as central to the debate in the midterm elections as it was when growth was slower and unemployment was higher. Even though this year could be better than any year since 1988, when gross domestic product rose 3.9 percent, the candidates are concentrating more on issues like crime and welfare that seem to be in the forefront of public concern.
The economy's best year of the last decade was 1984, when G.D.P. grew 6.2 percent.
Not to be upstaged while traveling in the Mideast, President Clinton summoned American reporters to a room in the Emir of Kuwait's palace to call attention to what he called "good news on the home front." The expansion, he said, this year has produced "more high-wage jobs than the previous five years combined."
In welcoming the latest results involving the broadest of all economic gauges, the financial markets appeared reassured by the continued mild inflation. Investors were also comforted by the fact that much of the economy's recent strength was a result of higher inventories in warehouses and on retail shelves. To some extent, those gains may have been borrowed from the future because they reduce the need for additional production.
After initially sagging, the 30-year Treasury bond rose sharply today to drive its rate back under 8 percent, finishing at 7.95 percent. And by surging more than 50 points, the Dow Jones industrial average set off curbs on computer-generated stock trading; the Dow ended with a gain of 55.51 points, or 1.4 percent.
Analysts generally agreed that the Federal Reserve would move at least once more this year to raise short-term interest rates to head off inflation pressures. That will probably be a half-point increase at its Nov. 15 policy meeting.
The figures released today on the July-September quarter were preliminary and will be followed by at least two revisions, which could change the economic picture offered by the Government report. But recent revisions, which have tended to show stronger growth than initial reports, have been fairly modest.
Some experts said that today's strong report -- which also showed sales of goods to their ultimate consumers rising at more than double the second-quarter pace -- guaranteed a Fed rate increase and perhaps would make it come sooner.
Others expressed confidence that the Fed would recognize the potential drag from buildups in inventories and move cautiously. And they are counting on the central bank not to overreact, even though the economy continues to expand faster than the rate of 2.5 percent or so that is widely thought to be the most growth it can sustain over time without pushing up inflation.
Booming investment in new plants and equipment, which has been advancing at record postwar levels for three years, should also tend to keep prices in check, analysts noted.
The inflation figures that were part of today's report were reassuring, analysts said. The fixed-weight price index for gross domestic purchases -- measuring prices of what residents buy as distinct from what they produce -- rose 3.2 percent, the same pace as in the second quarter. Excluding the wide-swinging food and energy sectors, the inflation rate fell to 2.5 percent in the third quarter from 3.6 percent in the second.
The so-called deflator for the G.D.P. tumbled to a 1.6 percent rate from 2.9 percent. But it is not a pure measure of prices, since it reflects changes in the composition of output, and the improvement was mainly a result of a quirk from higher oil prices. Increases for imported oil -- which provide nearly 50 percent of American needs -- are subtracted to calculate domestic accounts.
As in the second quarter, when the dollar value of the nation's output of goods and services jumped at a 4.1 percent pace, inventories were a dominant factor in the growth.
Stocks swelled at all levels, with buildups in the distribution chain suggesting to Donald H. Straszheim, chief economist at Merrill Lynch, that the coming holiday season "may end up being very promotional as retailers try to push the goods on their shelves."
Nonetheless, analysts said, it became increasingly clear over the summer that most stockpiling was voluntary. It was created intentionally, they argued, by producers, wholesalers and stores confident that they could sell the goods.
Some economists said that businesses began to build inventories only after it became obvious, sometime within the last year, that the sluggish recovery that began officially in early 1991 had reached cruising speed and was no longer in danger of stalling out.
Businesses raised their stocks of goods at a $64.5 billion annual pace in the third quarter, surpassing the $59.2 billion spring pace and more than doubling the rate of last winter. Still, observed Ed Yardeni of C. J. Lawrence/Deutsche Bank Securities, the ratio of factory and trade inventories to the current pace of sales is at a record low, suggesting that accumulation will continue.
Eventually, however, this process will end and production will be throttled back, perhaps abruptly.
Some analysts expressed surprise at how freely consumers spent over the summer. For example, personal spending on durable goods climbed at a 7.9 percent rate after rising four-tenths of a percent in the spring. The rise in spending on services rose a point, to a 2.1 percent annual pace, while spending on nondurable goods was also up at a 2.1 percent clip, about unchanged.
Data included in the gross domestic product for the third quarter of 1994 follow, expressed in constant 1987 dollars to adjust for inflation. All dollar amounts are in billions at seasonally adjusted annual rates. Percentage changes are from the previous quarter at seasonally adjusted annual rates.

HEADLINE: Decline on Wall Street Hurts The City's Fragile Recovery

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Having led the New York metropolitan area out of recession, the financial industry now faces mounting troubles that are adding to the billion-dollar budget woes of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. At the same time, Wall Street's travails threaten to cast a pall over the fragile recovery in New York City and its suburbs.
Unlike the crash of 1987, which ended a speculative frenzy in stocks, Wall Street's current traumas are largely a consequence of a steep fall in the less-visible bond market, which once provided a cushion of stability for the volatile securities business. 
 "The big event of 1994 is that we have had a crash in the bond market at least as great as the stock market crash of 1987," said Donald P. Marron, chairman and chief executive of Paine Webber.
The decline in Wall Street's fortunes this year is particularly bad news for City Hall. While the securities industry represents only 4.2 percent of New York's employment, its average annual salary last year of $134,456 accounted for nearly 14 percent of the city's total wages.
Jobs lost and bonuses cut on Wall Street have an even greater impact throughout the region, eroding local and state tax revenues because the affluent pay a substantially larger share of their income in taxes.
No one believes that another economic downturn is imminent in the New York region so soon after the last recession ended. Indeed, other sources of growth -- an array of new business ventures in media and entertainment, a stronger national economy and rising exports to Europe -- have already emerged to pick up some of the slack.
Still, Wall Street workers have become more cautious spenders, and that ripples through the metropolitan economy, affecting businesses large and small -- from real estate and restaurants to art and automobile dealers.
Beyond the relatively modest job cuts so far, the region's economy faces a potentially greater impact from an expected decline in year-end bonuses, which make up as much as 75 percent of Wall Street's total compensation. Analysts estimate that bonuses may fall 25 to 30 percent on average, holding down spending throughout the metropolitan area.
"The income-multiplier effect is enormous," said Rosemary Scanlon, the assistant deputy state comptroller who tracks the city's economy. "One job either gained or lost has such a big bang on the system."
Nobody knows this better than Naomi Friedman, who had been making an especially nice living in the early 1990's from Wall Street's prosperous young securities traders and analysts at her luxury real estate agency in Saddle River, N.J. Earlier this year, four traders from the same firm were looking to buy homes in the area ranging in price from $1.5 million to $2.5 million.
"Suddenly, there was a downturn in the market and they were gone," she recalled recently.
Wall Street traders are good customers, Ms. Friedman explained, but you have to grab them while they are hot. "When the market is good, they fly high," she said. "Then as soon as they see evidence of the market weakening, they hold back."
The experience in the financial sector this year is a sharp break from the record profits of the previous three years. Earnings plummeted at most securities companies over the last eight months. Across Wall Street, net income is expected to decline by as much as 50 percent this year, Moody's Investor Services reported recently.
Layoffs have either already been announced or are being contemplated at most of the major firms. And employees at Kidder, Peabody, the brokerage and investment bank that is being acquired by rival Paine Webber, are bracing for the elimination of as many as 2,000 jobs.
For those who remain on the job, cost-cutting is the order of the day. Once-coddled traders at Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers, who received free lunches from carts on the trading floor, were recently forced to start buying their own. Executives at Smith Barney must now pay for parking. Elaine Garzarelli, the strategist who made her reputation by predicting the 1987 crash, was ousted by Lehman Brothers this week partly to cut costs.
Wall Street's weak performance was cited by Mayor Giuliani last week as a driving force behind his plan to cut an additional $800 million in spending after imposing cuts of $1.1 billion in his maiden budget, which was passed by the City Council only four months ago.
While other factors, like growing overtime costs, contributed to the widening budget chasm, tax revenues from personal income and the profits of commercial banks are now expected to fall $300 million short of earlier estimates, according to Abraham H. Lackman, New York City's budget director.
So far, analysts say, there is little indication that the securities industry is facing a slump as serious as the one that began after the global stock market crash in October 1987. From 1987 to 1991, more than 28,000 Wall Street jobs were eliminated, helping to send the local economy into a tailspin in 1989 from which it only began to recover last year.
"If it doesn't deepen, there is a sense that this is like a speed bump," Mr. Lackman said.
City officials appear to have been misled by Wall Street's recent boom into expecting the blistering profit gains of the last two years to continue. Wall Street accounted for one-third of the 32,400 new jobs in New York during the first eight months of this year, according to a recent report on the city economy prepared by the state comptroller's office. Since July, though, industry employment figures are flat.
"The first half of this year was unbelievable," said Gary Goldstein, president of the Whitney Group, an executive search firm.
Much of the growth was pent-up demand. Wall Street managers who presided over the painful job cuts of the late 1980's were careful not to let job gains get out of control when the industry began to pick up again in the early 1990's. But as the profits piled up, their discipline waned. That led to a brief hiring boom that was cut short as the bond market fell.
Wall Street is still adding jobs in certain specialties, Mr. Goldstein said, like emerging markets in developing countries. Foreign and domestic commercial banks are also eager to expand into businesses traditionally dominated by Wall Street firms. But any increase in those areas will likely be swamped by layoffs elsewhere.
"I think the total headcount will be down at the end of the year compared to 1993 as firms take the opportunity to make cuts across the board," said one manager at a Wall Street firm, who insisted on anonymity.
Unlike the drama of a sudden stock market collapse, this year's bond market plunge has been a slow, seemingly inexorable decline. Since Oct. 15, 1993, the value of a 30-year Treasury bond, including principal and interest, has plunged 21 percent. That is the worst yearlong performance since proper records were first compiled in 1927, said James A. Bianco, the director of research at the Arbor Trading Group in Barrington, Ill.
The downturn began when Wall Street lost its source of free profits. Beginning in 1990, the cost of borrowing money from banks on a short-term basis dropped far below the income earned from investing in long-term bonds.
"All Wall Street had to do was carry goods in its inventory and the difference between their yield and what they cost to finance represented a profit," said James Grant, a financial historian and editor of the newsletter Grant's Interest Rate Observer. "It was the easiest money in capitalism, while it lasted."
As the spread between short- and long-term rates widened, the industry's biggest participants -- from firms like Goldman, Sachs to investors like George Soros and Michael Steinhardt -- magnified their profits by borrowing billions of low-cost dollars to buy bonds in the United States and Europe.
When the Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates in February, few saw the end in sight. As bond prices began to fall, speculators were forced to sell to cover their bank loans. That in turn lowered prices further, creating a downward spiral.
By the time the smoke cleared, investors had lost hundreds of billions of dollars. Higher interest rates also put an end to a bond and stock underwriting boom, cutting into a major source of Wall Street's income. The market for mortgage-backed bonds, one of the biggest money makers of the early 90's, virtually dried up. Nine consecutive quarters of rising profits for the industry gave way to pretax losses of $622 million in the second quarter of this year.
But just as the bond market helped sustain Wall Street after the stock market crash of 1987, stocks have remained relatively healthy in the face of this year's bond plunge. Strong corporate profits fueled by the national economic recovery lifted the prices of stocks close to previous records. Some Wall Street firms, like Merrill Lynch and Dean Witter, Discover & Company, have performed well by managing money for private clients, issuing credit cards and other operations.
And even firms that were hit hard by the bond market downturn -- among them Goldman, Sachs, Bear Stearns & Company, and Lehman Brothers -- are still expected to operate in the black this year. "They're not making nearly as much money as the previous year," Mr. Lackman said, "but they are making money."
The question is whether they will continue to do so. Most securities analysts predict that interest rates will remain stable next year. If they are wrong, the stock market could weaken in the face of a threat to the national economy, further harming Wall Street firms.
"The scenario that worries me is that this turbulence continues into 1995," said David Hensley, an economist at Salomon Brothers who follows the New York region. "You have to entertain the idea that growth in New York may stall out."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The economy grew at a robust 3.4 percent annual pace during the summer. But inflation showed no sign of acceleration in the Commerce Department's report on gross domestic product for the third quarter. The Clinton Administration trumpeted the data as portraying a healthy, stable economy. [Page 1.]
Wall Street's woes threaten a fragile recovery in New York City and its suburbs. The financial industry, which had led the local economy out of recession, is suffering a downturn nearly as sharp as the stock market crash of 1987. But this time the losses have been in the less-visible bond market, which once provided a cushion of stability for the volatile securities business. [1.]
 
Markets
Bonds staged a surprisingly strong rally, pushing the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond below the psychologically important level of 8 percent. Investors were heartened by the report on third-quarter economic growth, which showed inflation in check. [37.]
Stocks surged, bolstered by the G.D.P. report. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 55.51 points, or 1.4 percent. [38.]
The dollar strengthened as currency dealers took their cues from the advances in bonds and stocks in the United States. [47.]
Gasoline prices rose sharply after two refineries halted operations, heightening concerns about tight supplies. [47.]
 
Companies
Metropolitan Life is seeking to put a sales scandal behind it by shaking up its ranks and moving to improve training of its sales force. A cautious and conservative approach helped the company avoid the kinds of investment mistakes that have plagued some other insurers. But that tendency to avoid rocking the boat also allowed some bad sales and management habits to fester. [37.]
Johnson & Johnson hopes sucralose will rival aspartame. But the no-calorie sweetener must first win F.D.A. approval. [37.]
The head of Atlantic Records will take over the helm of Warner Brothers Records, its sister label, in an effort to quell turmoil within the company's corporate ranks. [37.]
McDonnell Douglas pleased investors, who sent its stock soaring. The company plans to repurchase 18 million shares, split the stock 3 for 1 and increase the dividend 71 percent. [37.]
Paine Webber sued two rival brokerage firms, accusing them of raiding Kidder, Peabody for its top brokers. Paine Webber agreed to acquire Kidder earlier this month. [39.]
Tenneco plans to sell more of Case, reducing its stake in the farm and construction equipment subsidiary to 49 percent. [39.]
Carson Pirie Scott is seeking to buy Younkers, in what would be a merger of two Midwestern department-store chains. [39.]
G.E.C. made a hostile bid for VSEL, Britain's leading submarine maker. The move pits the company against British Aerospace, which had reached a takeover agreement with VSEL. [39.]
Deutsche Bank plans to move its investment banking operations to London and merge them with Morgan Grenfell. [39.]
 
Your Money
The way banks sell mutual funds has been criticized by a number of customers, who contend they were misled about the risk, pushed into inappropriate investments and not told of the fees involved. Recent surveys by researchers suggest that many banks could do a better job of informing customers. [33.]
New rules limit escrow surplus requirements on mortgages. Millions of dollars may be refunded to home buyers. [34.]
Timing is important when selling shares of a mutual fund. For tax reasons, financial advisers urge people who are planning to sell to do so before the fund's distribution. [33.]
A second mortgage or a home equity line of credit? With interest rates rising, the traditional loan may be a better choice. [33.]

HEADLINE: Clinton Visits U.S. Troops In Kuwait

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CAMP DOHA, Kuwait, Oct. 28

 BODY:
At a final public stop of his Middle East tour, President Clinton today paid tribute to thousands of soldiers he rushed here just three weeks ago and warned anew that Saddam Hussein would pay a heavy price if he tried again to menace Kuwait.
"The United States and the international community will not allow Baghdad to threaten its neighbors now or in the future," the President declared from a platform erected on the backs of two M1-A1 Abrams tanks. "That is not our threat; that is our promise." 
 The display of foreign policy swagger accomplished a political feat 11 days before the election at home, enabling Mr. Clinton to make a triumphal address in a stage-managed setting and deliver what sounded like a promise to withdraw all American combat troops from Kuwait by Christmas.
Beyond the tanks, the backdrop for his speech included an armored personnel carrier and a Patriot missile launcher moved into place for the occasion. At the entrance to what only a few days ago was a patch of empty desert, a bent-backed military bridge had been positioned to open a gate to what looked like a movie set.
For Democrats who watched with apprehension this summer as Mr. Clinton's public approval ratings hit rock bottom, Mr. Clinton's performance today may have offered some reason for hope. Twice, the President clambered atop the Abrams tanks to stand perched on the turret, dispelling, at least for some, a bad political memory from 1988. In the presidential campaign that year, the Democratic candidate, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, was widely ridiculed when he boarded a tank to show his support for the military.
Mr. Clinton's advisers have made no secret of their hope that calling attention to his successes may contribute to Democratic successes at home. Tonight, as he headed for home, Mr. Clinton even paused in the Emir of Kuwait's palace to announce that he had "good news from the home front" -- figures showing solid growth and limited inflation in recent months.
But what was most plain on this last day of a nearly nonstop Middle East tour was the eagerness of Mr. Clinton and his White House to bask in acclaim for putting an end to the latest confrontation with Iraq.
At the Emir's palace tonight, the President bowed his head to receive the highest medal Kuwait can bestow on a foreigner. Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, the Emir, told Mr. Clinton that the award was meant to honor the speed with which he sent American troops "to stand side by side with our friends."
And before the troops in the desert, Mr. Clinton won throaty cheers as he cited their mission as the leading example of what he portrayed as recent foreign policy successes.
"One of the things that will go down in the history of this encounter is that you got here in a very big hurry," he said. "And because of that, Iraq got the message in a very big hurry."
A White House advance team had worked for days to arrange for telegenic pictures from Mr. Clinton's afternoon stop in the desert, which marked the first time in his Presidency that he has visited troops deployed in a battle zone.
At the direction of Col. John Brown, a brigade commander in the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division, which makes up nearly half the 9,000 American combat soldiers in Kuwait, a company of engineers spent four days building a special stage on the backs of two M1-A1 tanks.
And Mr. Clinton himself was prepared when the applause after his speech was broken by a soldier who shouted, "When are we going home?" With a grin, he returned to the microphone to offer just one piece of advice: "Don't forget your Christmas shopping!"
Asked tonight about that comment, Mr. Clinton said the timing of withdrawals would depend on troop movements by Iraq in coming weeks. That message was reiterated by both Anthony Lake, his national security adviser, and Gen. Binford Peay, the commander of the United States Central Command, who stressed that no decision was final.
But General Peay said he hoped that even if some logistical units had to stay behind, all the combat forces now in place in Kuwait could be home by Christmas.
Mr. Clinton's strong hint of a Christmas homecoming set off scenes of jubilation among the troops who heard his address, and dozens of them thrust scraps of paper, notebooks and even their Kevlar helmets toward him afterward as he spent nearly an hour shaking hands and signing autographs.
The President began his journey today in Jerusalem, where he visited Yad Vashem, the Holocaust museum. And even after leaving Kuwait, he made one stop in Saudi Arabia, where he met with King Fahd at the northern military base.

Clinton Meets King Fahd
(Special to The New York Times) -- HAFR AL BATEN, Saudi Arabia, Oct. 28 (Reuters) -- President Clinton arrived in Saudi Arabia tonight and went into talks with King Fahd, who met the President at the airport.
American officials told reporters that the two leaders would discuss the cost of the American military buildup in the Persian Gulf that was prompted by Iraqi troop movements near Kuwait this month.

HEADLINE: Dow Has 55-Point Jump, Reacting to G.D.P. Data

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The stock market surged yesterday after the Government reported that the gross domestic product grew at a surprisingly rapid 3.4 percent annual rate in the third quarter.
The bond market, which opens earlier than stocks, also jumped, and yields, which move in the opposite direction from prices, fell sharply. 
 Stocks finished near their highs of the day, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 55.51 points, or 1.4 percent, to 3,930.66. For the fourth time since August, the Dow is making a run at its record close of 3,978.36, set on Jan. 31. But many analysts are hesitant to predict whether a new high will be set amid the volatility that is expected ahead of the next meeting of the Federal Reserve's chief rate-setting committee on Nov. 15.
The Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 7.92 points, to 473.77. Only 5 of the index's 88 categories declined: gold, health care, metals, photography-imaging and tobacco. In addition, the Nasdaq composite index increased 8.68 points, to 776.15, and the American Stock Exchange market-value index advanced 3.07 points, to 458.16.
"The implicit price deflator in the G.D.P. was shockingly low, at 1.6 percent, versus expectations of 2.5 percent to 3 percent," said Bernard Spilko, senior vice president of Bank Julius Baer. "This means that inflation is not a troublesome number and so there was a calming effect on the market."
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was very heavy, with 381.6 million shares changing hands, compared with 327.8 million on Thursday. Advancing stocks exceeded those declining on the Big Board by 1,661 to 616.
When the Dow moved up 50 points at 12:31 P.M., the New York exchange put into effect its rule limiting program trading. It was the third time this month that the exchange had taken this action.
"Program buying in the morning was a large factor in the market and accounted for 41.71 points of the surge in the industrial index," said Jeffrey Rubin, an analyst for Birinyi Asssociates. "We also saw significant retail inflows, as well as institutional inflows."
The oilfield-service sector was strong, led by Halliburton, which reported better-than-expected third-quarter profits, in contrast to a loss in the year-ago period. It closed at 36 3/8, up 4 1/4; Dresser Industries closed at 21 3/8, up 3/4; and Noble Drilling closed at 30 1/8, up 1 1/4.
Airline stocks rallied for a second day on higher earnings. UAL, the parent of United Airlines, advanced 6, to 95; Delta rose 2 1/8, to 51 3/8, and AMR, the parent of American Airlines, increased 2 1/2, to 55 1/4.
Precious-metal stocks, which usually decline when inflation expectations diminish, were weak throughout the session. Battle Mountain was down 5/8, to 11; Cyprus was down 7/8, to 26 5/8; American Barrick was down 5/8, to 23 3/8, and Homestake Mining was down 5/8, to 19.
In addition, American depository receipts of Mexican companies were lower, in keeping with a decline of eight-tenths of 1 percent in Mexico's Bolsa index. Telefonos de Mexico dropped 3/8, to 56 1/8; Groupo Tribasa fell 1 1/2, to 32, and Vitro declined 1 7/8, to 21.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: MAINE;
In an Unpredictable State, the Senate Race Appears Predictable

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 27

 BODY:
One of the familiar criticisms of politicians this year is that they are afraid to take the tough stand, to cast the courageous vote.
Here in Maine, where Ross Perot won 30 percent of the vote in the 1992 Presidential election, his strongest showing in any state, Representative Thomas H. Andrews, a Democrat, has time and again taken positions that he said were in the best interest of the nation, though they might have seemed disadvantageous to Maine. 
 And now he is so far behind Representative Olympia J. Snowe, a Republican, in their race for the Senate seat left vacant by George J. Mitchell's retirement that few people outside Mr. Andrews's immediate camp give him any chance to catch up.
Mr. Andrews said in an interview that he had come from behind before to win, and he expected to do so again. Senator Mitchell said he thought Mr. Andrews still had a good chance.
But Maine's Republican Senator, William S. Cohen, expressed the prevailing view here. "Barring something that falls out of the sky," he said, "she should win handily."
An experienced political organizer in the state, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, did not even allow for meteors. "There is no circumstance in which she can lose," he said.
Other Republicans are not faring so well here this year. The race for Governor is a tight one between former Gov. Joseph E. Brennan, a Democrat, and Angus King, a businessman and television commentator who was once a Democrat and is running as an independent. The Republican, Susan M. Collins, a former official of the Small Business Administration, is running a distant third.
Everyone who follows politics in this unpredictable state has been somewhat surprised by the turn of events that have left Ms. Snowe with such a comfortable advantage.
When Mr. Mitchell, the majority leader in the Senate, made the stunning announcement last spring that he would not run for re-election, Mr. Andrews seemed well positioned to keep the Senate seat in Democratic hands.
He had been elected twice with large majorities in the First Congressional District, which covers southern Maine and is centered on Portland. Some of Mr. Mitchell's popularity seemed likely to rub off on the 41-year-old liberal Congressman. And President Clinton is quite highly regarded here, not the drag on Democratic candidates he is in many Southern states.
Ms. Snowe, on the other hand, had barely squeaked through in her last two elections to Congress from the Second District, which covers all the rest of the state and is the largest Congressional district east of the Mississippi. She had the reputation of being somewhat cold and distant. And her husband, Gov. John R. McKernan Jr., was expected to be a liability. He is extremely unpopular as he leaves office after two terms, mostly because of the way he handled budget problems that forced the state government to close temporarily.
So much for the early handicapping.
Ms. Snowe, who is 47, worked hard to improve her image. In her television advertisements and campaign appearances, said Sandy Maisel, a political science professor at Colby College in Waterville, "she now comes across as warm and cuddly."
Ms. Snowe said in an interview that her tough Congressional races had turned out to be a blessing. They forced her, she said, to form an organization, to learn how to raise money and to "sharpen my message." And while her husband has helped direct her campaign, he has mostly remained out of sight.
She was also helped because her moderate-conservative views appealed to Perot supporters, who remain well organized here.
Mr. Andrews, on the other hand, has run a campaign that he describes as principled. "The interests of Maine are directly linked to the interests of the country," he said in an interview.
Others see his campaign almost as suicidal.
He has much less money than Ms. Snowe for the final push, largely because of his refusal to take money from political committees affiliated with organized labor. Mr. Andrews supported the labor position and voted last year against the North American Free Trade Agreement. He is not taking labor money now, he said, because he wants to demonstrate that the unions did not buy his vote on the trade agreement. This decision, he estimates, has cost him $600,000 in contributions.
Though his state is heavily dependent on military spending, Mr. Andrews has used his position on the Armed Services Committee to support leaner military budgets.
While others in the state's Congressional delegation fought the closing of Loring Air Force Base, the economic underpinning of northern Maine, Mr. Andrews accepted it as a price that had to be paid. He has said he will take a similar stand if the base-closing commission recommends next year that the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard in Kittery be shut.
He also opposed a program that would have provided loan guarantees to allow Turkey to buy frigates that might have been built at Bath Iron Works, the ship-building company that is the state's largest private employer.
In a television debate with Ms. Snowe on Wednesday night, Mr. Andrews said, "We've got to stop spending money on cold war weapons systems, for example, or obsolete military facilities that simply are not necessary to meet the needs of our defense in this new era."
When Senator Mitchell arranged for some additional highway money for Maine this year, Mr. Andrews called it unnecessary pork. And in a state filled with gun lovers, he has been a strong advocate of gun-control laws.
"He is pointing his finger at you every minute," said Mr. Maisel, an Andrews supporter. "He's always screaming at you. He just doesn't seem like someone you would like."
Ms. Snowe is taking subtle advantage. "I will worry about America's place in the world," she says at the conclusion of her latest ad. "But I will also worry about Maine's place in America."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rallies on Release Of 3d-Quarter Growth Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The depressed dollar rallied broadly yesterday in concert with stocks and bonds as the markets welcomed United States economic data depicting growth accompanied by mild inflation.
The Commerce Department reported yesterday that gross domestic product grew at an unexpectedly high rate of 3.4 percent in the third quarter. Inflation gauges tied to the G.D.P. came in below estimates. 
 After overcoming some initial weakness, stocks, bonds and the dollar all headed higher. Currency traders have been tracking the performances of bonds and stocks to gauge foreign demand for American assets and the dollars needed to buy them.
Some traders, however, contended that internal market forces favored the dollar and accounted for the bulk of the buying.
Despite gains since Wedneday, the dollar remains near record lows against the Japanese yen and the German mark. Many traders expect selling pressures on it to return.
"Nothing fundamentally has changed," said Hubert Pedroli, manager of foreign exchange trading at Credit Suisse in New York. "I really think the dollar rally was technical. The market has been very negative on the dollar but we never made progress on the downside today so people bought to cover short positions."
Traders establish short positions by selling a currency, hoping to buy it back more cheaply in the future. Short-covering would mean buying dollars to eliminate those positions.
David Durst, a vice president in Bear, Stearns & Company's foreign exchange department, said buying had also been sparked by rumors that an emergency meeting of the Group of Seven -- the United States and its main trading partners -- was being scheduled to address the dollar's condition. The rumors proved unfounded but by then the dollar rally was in motion, Mr. Durst said.
The dollar advanced against the mark, settling in New York at 1.5102 marks, up from 1.4987 on Thursday. It edged up against the yen, at 97.27 yen from 96.99 on Thursday.
In other currency trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 1.2595 Swiss francs, up from 1.2429 francs on Thursday. The British pound fell to $1.6240 from $1.6360 on Thursday.

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES;
Two Ways To Tap A Home's Equity

BYLINE: By Nick Ravo 

 BODY:
Which makes more sense: a second mortgage or a home equity line of credit? That's the perplexing question for people who want to tap the equity in their homes for college, a car, business or any other purpose.
Even though rising interest rates have made lines of credit slightly less appealing this year, they are still popular, mainly because of relatively low initial rates and fees. 
 But with rates caught in what seems to be a never-ending upward spiral, the old-fashioned loan may be a better choice. Not only does it usually lock in a fixed rate, but some lenders are waiving the fees as well.
And those low initial rates advertised on a home equity line can quickly -- usually in six months or a year -- climb higher than those on a comparable fixed-rate loan.
"Consumers with home equity lines of credit should know that that sexy looking number in the ad is an artificial introductory rate," said Robert K. Heady, publisher of Bank Rate Monitor, a newsletter in North Palm Beach, Fla.
The primary lure of both loans is a tax deduction for interest paid because the home is used as collateral. With a traditional loan, or second mortgage, a borrower takes out a lump sum for a set term. With a home equity line of credit, a borrower can use as much as needed.
For a line of credit, a borrower generally pays a single upfront fee, often about $250. Fees on a second mortgage, by contrast, can amount to thousands of dollars, covering credit checks, appraisals, legal costs, title insurance and closing costs known as points (with one point equal to 1 percent of the loan amount). In New York, there is a 1.75 percent tax on the loan amount.
Aggressive lenders, however, are abandoning many charges on fixed-rate loans. The Queens County Savings Bank in Flushing, for example, is waiving all fees except for a small recording fee, generally $44, and the New York mortgage tax. Its five-year loan is available at an interest rate of 8.25 percent with no points.
The average interest rate for all fixed-rate equity loans surveyed on Oct. 5 by HSH Associates, a mortgage research company in Butler, N.J., was 9.22 percent. The terms are usually 5, 7, 10, 15 and 20 years, with rates lower on shorter-term loans. "The rates vary widely from lender to lender," said Keith T. Gumbinger, an analyst with HSH.
On a credit line, the bigger the amount, the lower the initial rate. Then the rate adjusts periodically to a level of one to two percentage points above the prime rate, a banking benchmark now at 7.75 percent. The average rate on home equity lines is 9.36 percent, though some lenders may offer the first year at two points below the prime; a few go as low as 4.99 percent.
The biggest danger with lines of credit, of course, is that rates will rise substantially. Unlike adjustable-rate mortgages, lines of credit rarely have annual limits on rate increases. The lifetime cap is usually about 18 percent, but may be higher.
Long-term borrowers should go with a fixed-rate loan, Mr. Gumbinger said, and people who intend to borrow the money for three years or less should go with either a line of credit or, if a very small amount, a short-term fixed-rate loan.
"If you're going to get out real quick, you don't have to worry about a rising-rate scenario," he said.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Borrowers' Choices" shows percentage of homeowners with traditional second mortgages and with home equity lines of credit (Source: Univeristy of Michigan Surveys of Consumers)

HEADLINE: Business Failures Decline

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Fewer businesses failed in the first three quarters of 1994 than in the corresponding period last year, according to a survey by the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation.
Nearly 55,000 businesses have closed so far this year, down 19 percent from the 67,500 that shut their doors a year earlier. An especially low percentage of companies in three industries -- mining; manufacturing; and finance, insurance and real estate -- are failing this year, the survey said. 
 Regionally, the New England states reported the greatest decrease in business failures, down 31.2 percent from last year. Business failures in Connecticut were down 47 percent, and failures in Rhode Island and New Hampshire were down 39 percent.
The survey's statistics include businesses that went bankrupt, were assigned or foreclosed upon, went out of business leaving debts to creditors or were involved in court actions.

HEADLINE: Baseball;
Yanks Give O'Neill $19 Million Contract

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY 

 BODY:
One day before Paul O'Neill would have filed to become a free agent and started a process that could have ended his association with the Yankees, the club signed him yesterday to a four-year contract worth $19 million.
There has been limited signing activity throughout the major leagues because of the continuing labor strife, but the Yankees made a bold, calculated move when they prevented O'Neill, the American League's top batter in the strike-shortened season, from bursting into the open market. Mindful that they need O'Neill's powerful hitting and dependable defense to duplicate their first-place standing of 1994, the Yankees made the 31-year-old outfielder an offer lucrative enough for him to spurn free agency. 
 General Manager Gene Michael had targeted O'Neill as his priority in the off season, obviously realizing the risks if 27 other teams had been allowed to bid for him.
"Paul loves playing in New York," said Joe Bick, his Cincinnati-based agent who estimated that he had 15 conversations with Michael. "The last two years have turned out to be a great experience for him. He said, 'If we can get a deal worked out with the Yankees and it's a reasonable deal, I'm not afraid to sign a contract without going out on the market.' "
Because the economic climate in the majors is a very delicate issue these days, the Yankees were hesitant to discuss O'Neill's contract. Neither Michael, Manager Buck Showalter nor George Steinbrenner returned phone calls, O'Neill was unavailable, and Bick said the Yankees would probably hold a news conference in two weeks.
When Bick was asked if O'Neill's contract averaged to about $5 million a year, he said, "I'm not going to be the source for that."
The terms of the $19 million deal, according to a source familiar with it, call for O'Neill to receive a $2.2 million signing bonus, with $1.2 million payable on Dec. 15, 1994, and the rest on Jan. 5, 1996. O'Neill's salaries will be $2.25 million for 1995, $4.75 million for 1996 and $4.9 million in both 1997 and 1998.
O'Neill's annual salary will average $4.75 million, up from $3.5 million in 1994 and second on the Yankees to Danny Tartabull, who averages $5 million.
O'Neill will receive a $150,000 bonus if he is named the league's most valuable player (he finished fifth in this year's voting), $50,000 for being named the League Championship Series m.v.p., World Series m.v.p. or is selected for the All-Star team, and $25,000 for being named Divisional Series m.v.p. or winning the Gold Glove or Silver Slugger awards.
Interestingly, the owners' Players Relations Committee asked teams to be wary of paying any contract signing bonuses because the money, in effect, will fund the players during the strike, now in its 12th week. The $1.2 million bonus O'Neill receives in two months falls into that ticklish category.
"Paul is thrilled with the deal," Bick said. "Paul wanted to stay in New York. I think everyone knew that going in."
O'Neill's timing has been impeccable. When he was acquired from Cincinnati for Roberto Kelly on Nov. 3, 1992, he was considered a talented player known for stellar defense, adequate power and temper tantrums. But in two seasons with the Yankees, O'Neill improved his game, heightened his reputation as one of baseball's best players and now is reaping the financial rewards.
Following a season in New York in which he batted a career-best .311 with 20 homers and 75 runs batted in, O'Neill had a more stupendous 1994 with his .359 average, 21 homers and 83 r.b.i.
Nevalee O'Neill, who was fielding questions in the absence of her husband yesterday at their home in Ohio, told one Yankee official that there were no plans for a huge celebration last night.
"We're going to a minor league hockey game," she said. "We're going to see the Cincinnati Cyclones."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
Stanley Files for Free Agency
On the day the Yankees signed Paul O'Neill and kept him from becoming a free agent, catcher Mike Stanley attempted to become one, disturbing the Yankees, who thought they had already signed him for 1995.
The Yankees claimed they exercised the $562,500 option on Stanley's contract on Sept. 22, but his agent, Jim Bronner, contends that the team had tried to pick up the option too soon and violated the deal. Gene Orza, the associate general counsel of the Players Association, said Stanley's contract called for the Yankees to exercise the option within 10 days after the World Series.
David Sussman, general counsel for the Yankees, said the owners' Player Relations Committee had rejected the attempt by the union to have Stanley file for free agency yesterday and claimed the option was exercised properly.

HEADLINE: Pentagon Acts Openly on Base Closings

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Your Oct. 18 editorial erroneously claims the Pentagon is "Cheating on Base Closings." To save billions of dollars, the United States Department of Defense is closing bases -- hundreds of them -- and restructuring its operations. Only by doing so can we save funds to maintain the training and equipment essential to our armed forces.
 
 You base your argument on a claim by a business group that the Defense Department "quietly reopened" a third of the bases that have been slated for closure. The authors of the report decided not to check their facts with those who are responsible for base closings. As a result, the report is replete with errors.
 For example, the report claimed that the Norfolk Naval Depot in Virginia was not closed because the Defense Department placed a satellite accounting office in one building.
After the removal of more than 4,000 military personnel and civilians and the closing of 70 buildings, I would argue that, in theory, putting 700 accountants into an empty, free office building on the base would be a smart use of taxpayer funds. But there isn't one, so the accounting office is going into a commercial building that isn't on the base at all.
 The report also charges that the department's actions are taken in secret. This is bizarre: the base-closing process is one of the most carefully analyzed and public processes ever undertaken by the Government.
 Every action recommended is based on an analysis of the costs. Each analysis is provided to the independent base-closing commission, the General Accounting Office and the public.
 Even the decision to locate single office buildings for accountants was made after public announcements of the criteria, the methods of analyzing cost and the sites under consideration.
 Closing dozens of large bases across the country is not quick or easy, but we are doing it. The first round of closings is saving an estimated $760 million annually. When the hundreds of installations that have been agreed to are closed or restructured, this figure will grow to more than $4 billion a year.
 The department is already working on the next round of closing and restructuring recommendations, to be proposed -- publicly, of course -- in 1995.
JOSHUA GOTBAUM
Assistant Secretary of Defense
for Economic Security
Washington, Oct. 22, 1994

HEADLINE: New York Can Do More to Cut Bus Pollution

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 New York City's alternative-fuel vehicle program has suffered some problems (news article, Oct. 21). Although it is the largest such program in the country, it has failed to reduce air pollution and the use of foreign petroleum and to enhance local economic development.
 
 Many light-duty cars and vans in the program fail to fulfill those goals. However, the buses that run on compressed natural gas being purchased by the Transportation Department are an example of how the city can better meet these goals.
 Natural gas buses eliminate the toxic plume trailing most diesel buses. The Environmental Protection Agency and the Harvard School of Public Health estimate that more than 60,000 premature deaths annually nationwide are attributable to breathing these emissions.
 Natural gas is a domestic fuel, supplied by local fuel providers who employ local workers. Evidence from transit operators around the country shows there may be additional savings on fuel, maintenance and other operating costs. By taking advantage of available Federal assistance, the cost for each natural gas bus can be a fraction of the purchase price for a diesel bus.
 New York lags behind in its commitment to replacing its diesel fleet with natural gas or other alternative-fuel buses. Los Angeles, Seattle and Houston have committed to switching from diesel and are providing the funds to build the refueling infrastructure. New York must do the same.
RICHARD A. KASSEL
Senior Project Attorney
Natural Resources Defense Council
New York, Oct. 24, 1994
