HEADLINE: HOW THEY DO IT;
Hiring a Spouse and Slashing Medical Costs

 BODY:

UNEMPLOYED
 When John Williamson, of Menlo Park, Calif., lost his job as an applications engineer for a semi-conductor manufacturer in 1992, the loss of health care benefits for his family was a big blow, he said.
 
WORKING FOR HIMSELF
He initially looked for a job with full benefits, but found he was in more demand as a consultant. So he started his own home business. White Eagle Consulting, which does semiconductor tests and measurements.
 
A TANTALIZING TAX BREAK
His financial adviser told him of a ruling earlier this year by the Internal Revenue Service that allows sole proprietors to write off medical expenses. The catch is that the business owner must employ the spouse at a reasonable wage and then provide health benefits to substantially all employees.
 
A GOOD FIT
Mr. Williamson's wife, Jan, had been keeping the books anyway. All he had to do was put her on the payroll and establish a plan to reimburse employees for medical expenses. The plan covers family members, so his wife's coverage extends not only to their two children, but also to Mr. Williamson.
 
MEDICAL COSTS IN 1993
Total medical expenses were $6,848.
 
Insurance payments - $4,248
Deductibles - $800
Chiropractor - $1,320
Dentist - $264
Other - $216
 
SETTING UP THE PLAN
Now, White Eagle will pay Mrs. Williamson a salary of about $15,000 a year - a move that is a tax wash for the couple. It will aslo spend about $500 to establish a written medical benefits plan.
 
SUBSTANTIAL SAVINGS
 Mrs. Williamson will pay the family medical bills, and the company will reimburse her. The money is a tax-deductible expense for the business, and free from personal income tax for Mrs. Williamson.
Beacuse White Eagle pays about 50 percent in Federal, state and self-employment taxes, the plan effectively results in a 50 percent savings for the Williamsons.
 
Larry Pon of IDS Tax and Business Services says certain restrictions apply.
 
 * Reimbursements are limited to $5,000 per household.
 * The employer must be a sole proprietor.
 * The spouse must be a bona-fide emplyee.
 * The medical plan must cover nearly all employees.
 * The spouse's salary must be reasonable.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 5, 1994, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
The "How They Do It" chart in Your Money last Saturday referred incorrectly to the rules on how much an employer can reimburse employees for medical expenses. There is no limit on the amount that sole proprietors can reimburse employees for medical expenses.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gasoline Prices Up Sharply After Refinery Shutdowns

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Gasoline prices jumped yesterday after two refineries halted operations, increasing concerns about supplies that have already been reduced by two pipeline ruptures in Texas.
 On other commodity markets, gold fell and lumber rose. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities fell 0.48 point, to 234.48. 
Conoco Inc. said an explosion would delay production at its refinery in Lake Charles, La., which produces 45,000 barrels of gasoline a day. And British Petroleum P.L.C. said a leak on Thursday night forced it to shut a 50,000-barrel-a-day gasoline unit at a refinery in Marcus Hook, Pa.
 Gasoline supplies on the East Coast fell to a three-year low last week and further declines are expected as a result of the Colonial Pipeline ruptures last week. Traders are concerned that there will not be enough conventional gasoline available before a new, cleaner grade reaches retail pumps on Jan. 1.
 "There seems to be a lack of conventional gasoline in the New York Harbor and there is still some demand for it," said Mike Hiley, a trader with Smith Barney Inc.
 On the New York Mercantile Exchange, gasoline for November delivery rose 3.88 cents, its largest one-day gain since March 1993, to 58.56 cents a gallon. The November contract expires on Monday.
 Other energy prices gained. The December crude oil contract rose 8 cents, to $18.23 a barrel, while November heating oil fell 0.09 cent, to 49.31 cents a gallon.
 Gold prices fell for a sixth day as concerns dimmed that inflation would pick up. The Commerce Department, in its report yesterday on economic growth in the third quarter, said that inflation showed no acceleration.
 December gold fell to $388 an ounce, its lowest price in a month, before rebounding to close at $388.70, down $1.50, on the Commodity Exchange of New York. December silver fell 8 cents, to $5.367 an ounce, while January platinum lost $2, to $425.80 an ounce, on the Mercantile Exchange in New York.
 Lumber rose after the Commerce Department report eased concern about rising mortgage rates that could stifle home-buying demand.
 On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, lumber for November delivery rose $4, to $319.80 for 1,000 board feet.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 52; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 949 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By Laurel Graeber 

 BODY:
CHRISTMAS IN JULY: The Life and Art of Preston Sturges
By Diane Jacobs. University of California, $18.
This book celebrates one of Hollywood's first writer-directors, a man who supervised the filming of his own screenplays long before Woody Allen. Sturges's heyday in the 1940's produced "The Lady Eve" and "Hail the Conquering Hero" as well as the film that gives the book its title. This is "by far the best critical biography . . . of one of America's most treasured makers of film comedy," Peter Bogdanovich said here in 1992.
BAND OF ANGELS 

By Robert Penn Warren.
Louisiana State University, $12.95.
Originally published in 1955, this novel is narrated by Amantha Starr, a young black woman who doesn't realize she was born a slave until her father dies and she is forced to face a future as someone else's property. The New York Times's reviewer, Arthur Mizener, said, "There is certainly no one writing in America today who can dazzle us as Robert Penn Warren can by the way he tells such a story; he brings to it the most penetrating and most beautifully disciplined historical imagination we have." Louisiana State University is also restoring to print the works of other noted writers in its "Voices of the South" series. THE WIDOWS OF THORNTON, by Peter Taylor ($11.95), consists of eight stories and a play about black and white families who once lived in the town of Thornton, Tenn. The pieces are "outwardly simple, but psychologically complex and powerful," F. H. Lyell said in The New York Times in 1954. THE GAUDY PLACE, by Fred Chappell ($9.95), refers to a rundown area of Braceboro, N.C., where two desperate teen-agers -- a gambler and a prostitute -- conspire with a local con man. In 1973 our reviewer, Jonathan Yardley, called the author "a serious and uncommonly skillful writer."
CHICAGO '68
By David Farber. University of Chicago, $14.95.
The author analyzes the political climate that led to the violent street protests during the Democratic National Convention in Chicago in 1968, noting that the self-destructive tendencies of the New Left and the blue-collar rage of the city police force made confrontation inevitable. Mr. Farber "meticulously dissects the motivations of all the principals," Nelson Lichtenstein said here in 1988. One of the Chicago protesters was James Miller, author of "DEMOCRACY IS IN THE STREETS": From Port Huron to the Siege of Chicago (Harvard University, $14.95). Mr. Miller's book reconstructs the beginnings of the New Left, concentrating on the men and women who drafted its seminal manifesto in 1962: the Port Huron Statement. In 1987 our reviewer, Hendrik Hertzberg, said, "He makes a fine guide -- accurate, sympathetic, critical, learned." The birthplaces of the student movement are the focus of CAMPUS WARS: The Peace Movement at American State Universities in the Vietnam Era, by Kenneth J. Heineman (New York University, $17.95). This "useful book examines the outside forces . . . that led to antiwar protests on campus," Herbert Mitgang said in The New York Times last year. The legacy of the 1960's is carried on in NO MORE NICE GIRLS: Countercultural Essays, by Ellen Willis (Wesleyan/University Press of New England, $16.95). These pieces, most published in the 1980's, deal largely with feminism. Last year our reviewer, Claudia Ricci, praised the author's "rich historical perspective."
THE TANGO PLAYER
By Christoph Hein. Translated by Philip Boehm.
Northwestern University, $13.95.
This novel explores the emotional state of Hans-Peter Dallow, an East German academic trying to reconstruct his life after nearly two years of imprisonment in the late 1960's. His crime? Playing the piano at a club while a seditious skit was performed. "Mr. Hein's work is a skeptical and troubled inquiry into the nature of freedom," Rand Richards Cooper said here in 1992. Northwestern University has also reissued a fictional view of totalitarianism, THE FOUNDATION PIT, by Andrei Platonov, translated by Mirra Ginsburg ($12.95). Voshchev, the novel's unemployed Russian hero, joins a group of workmen digging the foundation for a huge building that represents Stalinism at its height. In 1974 our reviewer of an earlier translation, Paul Theroux, called it "obviously a masterpiece."
JOSEPHINE HERBST
By Elinor Langer. Northeastern University, $14.95.
The author re-creates the changing world of the 1920's and 30's, a period that Josephine Herbst, a novelist and essayist active in left-wing politics, both witnessed and wrote about. The result is "a dramatically revealing biography," Robert Gorham Davis said here in 1984.
THE PIANO TUNER: Stories
By Peter Meinke. University of Georgia, $11.95.
The 14 pieces in this collection, which won the Flannery O'Connor Award for Short Fiction in 1986, illustrate the potential for sudden chaos and conflict in what appear to be well-ordered lives. One critic said the book "exhibits strong and consistent writing throughout."
BIRD OF JOVE
By David Bruce. Texas A & M University, $13.95.
Previously out of print, this book describes the author's relationship with an Asian golden eagle, a bird he rescued, took home to Wales and taught the ancient art of falconry -- with his own humane modifications. This is a "hypnotic and sometimes hair-raising interlude," Thomas Lask said in The New York Times in 1971.
HERO JESSE
By Lawrence Millman.
University Press of New England, $13.95.
The title character is a retarded adolescent boy whose fantasies of achieving glory in the Vietnam War are translated into horrific crimes. In 1982 one critic said the novel "wrests meaning from the very limitations of its narrator." LAUREL GRAEBER

SECTION: Section 6; Page 34; Column 3; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1080 words

HEADLINE: WORD & IMAGE;
Mediology

BYLINE: By Max Frankel 

 BODY:
Sketch of The Voter, 1994, as currently rendered by The Media: Mad as hell. Hates the Ins. Doubts the Outs. Weary of the world and joyless on the job. Aggrieved by government. Nostalgic for family. Resentful of welfare, immigrants and taxes. Terrorized by crime, at least the news of it. Turned off by integration, even the dream of it. Amused, abashed, misjudged and misled by media -- if you can believe the media.
This depressing portrait is offered a mere three years after America's cold war triumph. The nation is wealthier, freer and more secure than ever; its values -- democracy, individualism and cheap oil -- are captivating the world. And still the media make Americans out to be miserable. No, say many, the media make us miserable; they wallow in violence, rake up muck, stir up strife. They've made the news itself the enemy of hope.
Grains of truth, buckets of hogwash. As the media's own polls should have taught, there's no such animal as Typical Voter. And there's no one beast called Media either. Many media are indiscriminate about voters, overlooking instructive studies of them. Voters, in turn, speak indiscriminately about the media when in fact they pick and choose from a huge and varied information menu. 
 Classifying voters used to be easy: most inherited a party label that they shed only for powerful reasons like Abolition or the Depression. But parties no longer command loyalty with service, and television delivers candidate images directly into the home, devaluing a party endorsement.
That, however, encourages two misconceptions. One is that every voter is a free spirit, uninfluenced by family or fashion. If that were so, we couldn't poll a few thousand to learn the sentiments of millions. The other, contradictory notion is that the media dictate political choices. If that were so, a few press lords would rule in ways they obviously don't.
In fact, sociologists have learned to classify voters in useful ways. They know much less about how different media either reflect or alter the voters' opinions. But pollsters are beginning to match up voters and media. So just as voters can be typed by their views, they may in time come to be known by their news.
One of the best monitors of voter attitudes is the Times Mirror Center for The People and The Press. It has just broadened its classification of Americans into 10 new groupings, an exercise that illuminates the tensions between and among Republicans, Democrats and independents. In the process, the Center measured voters' media habits, suggesting that Americans are more likely to be defined by their choice of media than they are indoctrinated by the content of the media. Why has such a useful study drawn so little interest? Well, just imagine the media having to admit that their vaunted influence results less from their leadership than from their catering.
Here then, in time for Election Day, are the highlights: Three groups form what the Times Mirror Center calls "The Divided Right."
Enterprisers (12 percent of registered voters) -- anti-government, pro-business, anti-welfare; fiercely Republican, white, mostly married. Media: TV network news (watch it but dislike it), daily paper (Wall Street Journal?), Fortune, "MacNeil/Lehrer."
Moralists (20 percent) -- religious, socially intolerant, anti-welfare, anti-business, anti-government; heavily Republican, mostly white. Media: Radio news, Rush Limbaugh.
Libertarians (4 percent) -- pro-business, anti-government, anti-welfare, highly tolerant, not religious; leaning Republican, mostly white, male. Media: Daily paper, Forbes, CNN, C-Span.
There is much mediological work to be done with this group. Which network news? Do Enterprisers prefer ABC to CBS? Do Libertarians prefer Safire to Will? The fast-growing Moralists despise MTV -- betraying a cultural conservatism that may stunt this right-wing coalition.
At the other end of the spectrum, Times Mirror finds four types grouped in "The 'Not So' Left":
Partisan Poor (8 percent) -- strongly pro-government, anti-business, religious and socially intolerant; overwhelmingly Democratic, poor, 40 percent nonwhite. Media: Network news (like it), MTV, "60 Minutes" et al., "A Current Affair" et al.
New Dealers (8 percent) -- conservative on race and welfare, religious, patriotic, pro-government, mistrust politicians and business; strongly Democratic, elderly. Media: Network news, TV magazines like "Hard Copy."
New Democrats (8 percent) -- pro-business, pro-government, religious, socially tolerant; for Bush in 1988, Clinton in 1992. Media: Every kind of television, lots of newspapers, MTV, The National Enquirer, Imus.
Seculars (10 percent) -- pro-government, mistrustful of business, strong on environment, sympathetic to minorities, low church attendance; proudly "liberal," heavily Democratic, 90 percent white. Media: Daily paper, Newsweek or Time, "All Things Considered," "MacNeil/Lehrer," C-Span.
A weak coalition. The Seculars' strong dislike of TV news and tabloids portends dislike of the other three groups. A shared distaste for Limbaugh is a poor glue.
Most important to political understanding are two of the three groups that make up "The Detached Center." Beyond the totally uninvolved Bystanders there are:
The Embittered (7 percent) -- distrust government, politicians and business, religious and tolerant; half for Clinton, 25 percent black, very poor. Media: Average commitments to daily paper and TV news.
New Economy Independents (19 percent) -- pro-welfare but not sympathetic to minorities; largely in service industries, precarious economically; 30 percent for Perot, mostly female. Media: Average commitments to daily paper, Time or U.S. News.
This independent quarter of the electorate, representing a post-industrial working class, accounts for most of the anger and frustration that The Media have been loosely ascribing to The Voter. These are voters most drawn to a new political party, most eager for change. More than any other group, they believe that the biases and sensations of the media "get in the way" of solving their problems. And their media preferences remain ill defined.
Small wonder. Track the best of the media and see how much attention is paid to the poor and to the rich -- but how little to the most vulnerable voters in beween. In the media, they would call that a market waiting to be served. In politics, they say just watch the explosion, next week.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 40; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1115 words

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
A Show Brings On A Severe Case Of Period Envy

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp 

 BODY:
ARCHITECTURE GETS A somewhat desiccated treatment in "The Italian Metamorphosis, 1943-68," the Guggenheim Museum's epic survey of postwar Italian culture. Rows of somber little black-and-white photographs, lined up on racks that look like stylized gutters, scarcely throb with the poetry that architects like Carlo Scarpa, Pier Luigi Nervi, Gio Ponti and Franco Albini brought to modern architecture at midcentury. Still, the show (on view until Jan. 22) can bring on a serious case of period envy. What is most enviable about the presentation is not the quality of individual buildings designed in the postwar decades. It is the extent to which the period produced a sense of itself as a period: an era when architects believed that they were collectively shaping a time and place.
That faith, a cornerstone of the modern movement, has largely disappeared from architecture today. Where architects once drew meaning from being part of something larger than themselves, many now derive it from the distance they can place between themselves and their contemporaries. Certainly there has been no shortage of architectural movements since 1968; indeed, so many have come and gone that even the tireless chronicler Charles Jencks has grown weary of tracking them. But these movements have tended, on the whole, to splinter architecture rather than unify it. 
 It's customary to blame the media for this atomized state of affairs. Post-modernism, in particular, has been widely dismissed as a creature of the media's insatiable appetite for novelty. And it is true that much of the movement's intellectual substance seemed to fade in the paparazzi glare that bathed architecture -- and everything else -- in the 1980's. By the end of the decade, when Deconstruction and then New Modernism rolled around, people were tired of feeling bamboozled into thinking that they had to keep up. They had come to believe that these movements were driven not by ideas but by the marketplace imperative to search out trends, invent them when necessary and kill them off before boredom set in.
And if the point of the whole game was planned obsolescence, it became logical to ask: Why not beat the system? Why not just refuse to go along with the next thing? Whatever comes along, just say no. Sorry, no more movements. No more shiny new playthings. Folded planes? Sorry, can't use it. Green architecture? Not today, thank you. Infrastructure? Not in my backyard. The New Urbanism? Return to sender. We like the old urbanism just fine.
This knee-jerk resistance to movements may be an understandable antidote to media manipulation. But it has also bred a kind of nihilism, an indifference to architecture's public dimension. A movement doesn't have to be a grand design on the world; it can also be simply one of many stories about the world. And tuning out on what movements have to tell can be as pernicious as the withdrawal of the middle class into gated residential enclaves. And it's not even that effective a form of resistance to market pressures. In the 1980's, with the proliferation of unbuilt "paper" architecture as a form of alternative practice, dropping out became a commodity, too.
Compared with the state of exhausted fragmentation in which much of the profession now finds itself, Italian postwar architecture does indeed resemble a model of solidarity. Expressed or exposed structure; volumes reduced to geometric abstraction; unadorned surfaces; flat roofs, and the occasional free-form fantasy, like Luciano Baldessari's 1952 pavilion for the Fiera Internazionale in Milan: the buildings represented at the Guggenheim share a common vocabulary of forms. But this picture of unity is partly the illusion of hindsight. As the Guggenheim show makes clear, architects of the period split off into factions without any help from the paparazzi: Rationalists, neo-realists, inspired by a rural vernacular, and organicists, descended from Frank Lloyd Wright, competed to define the postwar moment. Indeed, in his excellent essay in the show's catalogue, the architectural historian Dennis Doordan persuasively argues that this period witnessed the first major challenge to the solidarity of the modern movement.
Italian architects had political as well as esthetic reasons for mounting such a challenge. In the 1930's, many of them believed that modernism -- clean, muscular, transparent -- was the ideal style for a Fascist society. Mussolini gave them a good deal of support. After the war, architects were naturally eager to put the Fascist connection behind them.
One way they did this was to relax the regimentation of orthodox modernism and call for a more diverse vocabulary of forms. By the 1950's, architects like Ernesto Nathan Rogers had begun to advocate an approach that prefigured what Kenneth Frampton calls critical regionalism -- the adjustment of modern concepts to local traditions and methods of building. Italian architects, for instance, showed relative restraint in the use of glass, an iconic modern material. Masonry walls, they believed, were effective for integrating modern buildings into the historic context of Italian cities.
DOORDAN CAUTIONS AGAINST regarding Italian architects as precursors of post-modernism. They did not fundamentally reject the ideological framework of modern architecture, nor did they abandon the sense of international solidarity it conferred upon them. They sought merely to adapt modern ideas to regional conditions: in effect, to supervise a collision between a global sense of time and a local sense of place.
Today, the situation has completely flipped around. The solidarity of the modern movement is barely a memory, while the only movement that has come close to replacing it on a global scale is the movement for historic preservation.
If there's an international movement in contemporary architecture, it is found in the travel itineraries of architectural superstars as they jet around the world, inscribing their distinctive signatures on sites in Singapore, Prague, Seoul and Berlin.
Far from imposing upon the world the kind of universal order envisioned by modernism, today's leading architects now create something closer to what is known in chaos theory as the Butterfly Effect. Consider, for instance, the recent reaction to the news that Zaha Hadid had won a competition to design a new opera house for Cardiff, in Wales. Just as (in James Gleick's words) "a butterfly stirring the air today in Beijing can transform storm systems next month in New York," so Hadid's outrageously beautiful design produced waves of delight and dismay from London to Tokyo. Some may say that's movement enough.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 3; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 625 words

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Air Fares in Europe Dip a Bit as Rules Ease

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: ROME

 BODY:
FOR Americans, airline deregulation, bringing no-frill flights and lower ticket prices, if also a degree of turmoil, is by now old hat.
But in Europe, airlines were until recently under the tight control of governments that not only owned the national flag carriers, but also dictated where they should fly, how often and at what fare. 
 As Keith MacMullan, the director of Avmark, London-based airline consultants, points out, the system was geared to creating jobs; partly, too, it was a matter of prestige and, often, history.
One result of all this indulgence, as anyone who has flown in Europe will know, is that ticket prices are often shockingly higher than those for comparable flights in the United States.
For example, although distance is not the sole determining factor of price, last month United quoted a fare of $634 for a round-trip economy flight from Chicago to New York, a distance of roughly 750 miles; its lowest cut-rate fare was $125 round trip. In Europe, Alitalia was charging $785 round trip for its flight from Rome to Berlin, an equivalent distance. Its lowest cut-rate fare was $410.
The system has started to change, though, since 1992, when the 11-member European Union decided on radical deregulation of the airline industry, borrowing heavily from the one carried out in the United States in the 1980's. It's a gradual evolution, however, that will slowly lift barriers until Jan. 1, 1997, the target date for fully open skies over Europe. But the effects are already being felt. Competition is increasing and, in some cases, fares are already coming down.
For one thing, national carriers may now plunge into markets from which they were once banned. British Airways, for example, now operates a subsidiary in France, TAT European Airlines, and one in Germany, Deutsche BA. This summer Lufthansa was forced to offer reduced one-way fares, some as low as $65, for flights between German cities, to compete with the British.
The new rules also permit a carrier like British Airways, on a route from say, London via Paris to Lyons, France, to fill up to 50 percent of the seats on its plane in Paris with passengers going to Lyons. By 1997 the 50 percent limit will be lifted entirely.
In some cases, new private lines, like Hamburg Air in Germany, have been founded. In others, charter airlines are going after scheduled routes. Thus, in France, Air Liberte, one of the country's largest charter carriers, is bidding for a license to offer scheduled flights on the heavily-traveled route from Paris to Toulouse, to break the monopoly of the Air France subsidiary Air Inter. In Switzerland, which though not a European Union member has been swept along on the wings of deregulation, a small private airline, TEA Basel, is seeking a license for the busy Geneva-to-Zurich link. TEA plans to set its fare at 240 Swiss francs, roughly $187, or 40 percent below Swissair's price of 398 francs, and only slightly higher than the 194 francs it costs for a first-class train ticket on the same route.
The competition is upsetting some European governments, whose unprofitable national carriers can only be kept aloft thanks to immense subsidies. But industry analysts expect the trend to continue.
One result of the current domination of national carriers is a skewed system of hubs and spokes. Air traffic is often not where the travelers are, but where the national capitals are. Thus, hand in hand with deregulation comes an ambitious plan, the European Air Traffic Control Harmonization and Integration Program, to overhaul Europe's clogged air traffic control system. The plan will not be fully in place until 2015, but by next year a central office in Brussels will begin tracking European flights.

HEADLINE: Should UConn Football Go Big Time?

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
IN the classic Marx brothers movie "Horse Feathers," Groucho Marx as Professor Wagstaff, the new president of Huxley College, faces with a dilemma. Professor Wagstaff wants to field a football team to draw attention to the school. But that would necessitate the building of a stadium. When told by the trustees that the school can't afford both a stadium and a college, Wagstaff replies, "Well, then let's tear down the college."
No one has suggested that the University of Connecticut, in its zeal to upgrade its football team to major-power status, take a similar tack. But at least some members of the UConn faculty think that the proposed upgrade, if implemented, could cause a university already hard-pressed for funds even more serious financial problems. 
 Finding the money to build a stadium that would hold at least 30,000 spectators (necessary to qualify for Division I-A standing, the highest in collegiate sports) to replace the existing 16,200-seat Memorial Stadium on campus is one of major obstacles the university would face if the school's trustees approve (as expected) a recommendation to upgrade the football program.
At a time when many of its buildings are in disrepair, the staff is being sharply reduced, new equipment is badly needed, the budget deficit is rising and the enrollment shrinking, the trustees believe they can solve many problems by spending millions of dollars to field a football team that would compete against schools like Syracuse, Miami and Pittsburgh. The rationale, as explained in a report by a 20-member committee composed primarily of UConn faculty, is that a big-time football program would generate substantial revenue that would benefit the entire university and put it in a class with state universities in Michigan, Virginia and Wisconsin.
While most students appear to favor the proposed shift -- which, if it develops, would not occur for at least four years -- about two-thirds of the faculty feel that it would diminish the perception of the university, according to a poll taken last March. Last week, the University Senate, which is made up largely of faculty members, plus administrators, staff members and students, voted down, 29-21, a motion by the group's executive committee favoring the upgrading of the football program to Division I-A status.
Much of the impetus for the football upgrade stems from the success of the men's and women's varsity basketball teams, which have attracted national attention in recent years. Those successes created "Husky mania" throughout the state. Largely because of the inordinate attention given to the men's basketball tem, which is already at the Division I-A level, coupled with the proposed shift by the football program, Bruce M. Stave, the chairman of the history department, was moved to say, "Sometimes I get the feeling that we're the Husky University, as opposed to the University of Connecticut."
Regarding the proposed upgrading of the football team, Dr. Stave said, "The big question is how such an upgrading would affect the academics at the university."
"Athletics is an important part of academic life, but in some cases it puts the emphasis in the wrong place," said Dr. Stave, who is the head of the UConn chapter of the American Association of University Professors. "It's nice to be known for your athletics, but it's even more important to be known for your academics. You have to ask whether a kid is coming to UConn because of the excellent education it offers or to go to a basketball game. The real question is balance. If we'e going to upgrade the football team, I personally would like some guarantees. For example, for every dollar put into upgrading football, I'd like to see three dollars go toward academic needs. And I'd also like to be assured that academic standards won't be lowered for football players."
Members of the committee that recommended the football upgrading have insisted that neither admission requirements nor academic standards would be lowered. "That would not be done," said John Allen, a professor of geography at UConn and the committee member who drafted most of the 35-page report submitted to the trustees earlier this month following a detailed analysis by the consulting firm Coopers & Lybrand. "It used to be you could admit athletes and sort of tuck them away academically, but you can't do that anymore."
What makes the football plan somewhat paradoxical is both the team's mediocre record on the Division I-AA level (the team lost five of its first eight games this season) and the relatively small number of spectators (an average of about 8,500 to a home game, although attendance has been up this season, in part because of a new coach with a famous football name: Skip Holtz, the son of Notre Dame coach Lou Holtz). Why would a divisional upgrade make a difference?
"It would be a totally different situation," said Lew Perkins, the UConn director of athletics. "First of all, as a member of the Big East in football, as well as basketball, we'd be much more attractive to prospective recruits and would recruit nationally. And now, while we might draw a crowd of 10,000 against Rhode Island, which is a big rival, we probably would have 45,000 for a game against Boston College or Syracuse if we were upgraded to Division I-A."
Mr. Perkins, who is a member of the committee on I-A football, pointed out that the idea of UConn moving up to I-A in football is not a new one. "When I came in more than four years ago, I was asked to put together all the necessary facts pertaining to a possible move to I-A," said Mr. Perkins who had been athletic director at two Division I-A schools, Maryland and Wichita State. "And when the Big East decided to expand as a football conference, it opened a window of opportunity for us."
Mr. Perkins also cited the committee report's warning that schools in major sports conferences might eventually form a "super tier" exclusive of the National Collegiate Athletic Association. "Schools that are Division I-A in only one major sport, as we are, could be left out," he said. "So it's in our interest to upgrade to I-A as soon as we can. And if we do, academic standards will not be compromised. They shouldn't be and they won't."
But several faculty members are concerned that they might. "You need both quality and quantity on the Division I-A level and the temptation to bend the rules is very strong," said Peter Barth, a professor of economics who previously taught at Ohio State University. "When I was at Ohio State, there was an excessive degree of concentration on the football team, and it was common knowledge that if Woody Hayes wanted a player, he was in, and stayed in, regardless of his academic work. And it scares me that we might do something to lower our standards."
Dr. Barth, who received his graduate degree at Michigan, a longtime national footbll power, also said he was skeptical that a UConn I-A football team would be a revenue producer. (This year's team is expected to lose $1.9 million, about average for the Connecticut football program.) "You can wind up losing big time by going to Division I-A," he said. "You're bound to spend much more money for everything from scholarships to a stadium, to more sophisticated weight rooms, academic counselors and so on. As the revenues go up, so, too, will the costs.
"If you win, then even more money will be spent on athletics. And if you fail, people aren't going to pay to see the games. And I'm very suspicious that we can have a winning football team on the I-A level since we haven't been successful in the past or even now. I don't think there's any way the university will become economically enriched by upgrading the football program."
To upgrade the football program, the budget for the team would have to be more than doubled -- to about $6 million from $2.26 million. As a Division I-A member, UConn would increase the number of its football scholarships from 62 to 85, with about $1.3 million allocated to the university's women's sports programs in accordance with the requirements of Title IX, a Federal regulation that mandates matching funds for women's sports programs.
Beyond those costs would be the expense of building a new stadium, most likely in Hartford, 22 miles west of the UConn campus in Storrs. A year and a half ago, the state's legislature authorized the expenditure of $252.1 million for construction of a 65,000-capacity stadium in downtown Hartford in an unsuccessful effort to lure the New England Patriots of the National Football League.
At least one study has said that a 40,000-seat stadium could be built for about $120 million. That money would have to come from the state, posing a major issue for a new governor. (While a stadium was being built, UConn might play its home games at the 67,000-seat Yale Bowl.)
For all the euphoria that the proposal has created -- visions of UConn playing Miami in a spanking new stadium in a nationally televised football game -- skeptics abound.
"In my opinion, it represents a perversion of values and the idea is outlandish," said David Ivry, a UConn professor emeritus of insurance. "We need a new chemistry building, the library is in very bad shape, and we have so many other major needs."
Professor Ivry and others feel that the committee that recommended the upgrading was not representative. "I think it was a rigged committee," he said. "For instance, it does not include anyone from the faculty who has spoken out publicly against the proposal." Members were picked primarily by Lewis B. Rome, the chairman of the university's board of trustees and a strong supporter of the move to Division I-A.
Like many faculty members and some alumni, Professor Ivry thinks sports, and particularly basketball, has come to overshadow the school's academic achievements.
"I go into the Hartford Club and everyone is talking about the UConn basketball team -- never about anything else at the school," he said. "I think that far too much attention is paid to athletics at UConn. And that's a shame. You seldom hear the University of Connecticut associated with high-quality academics, and it's an excellent school, which I love very much."
But John Allen, the geography professor who wrote most of the committee's report, said he was convinced that upgrading the football program would enhance the university's reputation as an academic institution. "Upgrading the football program is a mechanism to get our name before the public on a broader scale," he said. "It will give UConn greater national visibility and it will better enable us to focus on the excellence of our faculty and our academic programs. In the long run, it will help us improve our physical plant and increase our research, among other things. If I and the committee as a whole didn't think it would do these things, we would not have recommended that the football program be upgraded."
Professor Ivry and many faculty members disagree. "The idea of going to Division I-A is plain crazy," he said. "Our focus should be on making UConn a great school, not elevating its mediocre football program."
But Professor Ivry and others on the faculty feel there is nothing they can do to prevent the trustees from approving the committee's recommendation, perhaps as early as next month.
"This is a done deal," said Edward Kostiner, a professor of chemistry and an outspoken opponent of the proposal. "We're talking about a situation where we have totally skewed priorities among the administration, meaning President Harry Hartley and the board of trustees."
"We cannot afford the luxury of what it would cost to go to Division I-A in football when it would be at the expense of other areas on campus where there are tremendous needs," Professor Kostiner said. "It would be obscene to spend $150 to $200 million on a new football stadium when we need new dormitories and so many other things and when the faculty is being cut. How can you in good conscience spend that kind of money to upgrade a football team?"

HEADLINE: Franchised Hayrides: Halloween Hits

BYLINE: By ALBERT J. PARISI 

 BODY:
AMID the glow of a harvest moon, a cold wind rustles leaves down a country lane. With a mechanical groan, a tractor tows its burden: a hay-strewn wagon packed with both young and old.
In the distance looms a hangman's tree with a fresh victim. As the wagon passes beneath the swaying figure, its noosed head cocked to one side, the dangling body bellows an unearthly shriek and wriggles in apparent pain. 
 Some passengers scream, others recoil and parents clutch children protectively. Around the bend, the glow of a witch's bubbling cauldron comes into view. A thrill of fear is in the air, as well as the aroma of doughnuts and fresh apple cider.
Across the state with Halloween fast approaching, traditional hayrides organized by farmers on their acreage or by community groups in public parks are making way for haunted hayrides offering good-natured scares. In recent years, imaginative entrepreneurs are taking advantage of the short festive season and the chance to generate profits.
The latest marketing trend: franchised haunted hayrides complete with a training staff, how-to manuals and a suggested checklist of frights and horrors to make even the bravest souls squirm.
Haunted Hay Rides Inc., of Liverpool, N.Y., just north of Syracuse, has several franchises in New Jersey, New York and Pennsylvania. For Robert Paige, who owns and operates the Suntan Lake recreation area in Riverdale, in Morris County, the hayride venture has been his hedge against a sluggish local economy.
"In the last few years here, we've had some pretty tough times," Mr. Paige said. In past years, vacationers spent freely, and with outdoor concerts and corporate picnics, he said, "we did O.K., but lately people have less in their pockets to spend, thanks to the economy, and lots of companies have scaled down, so we needed to find something do something to carry us through." Mr. Paige's answer was to extend his season through Halloween and to buy into the franchise.
He invested $30,000 last year -- $10,000 for a franchising fee and the rest toward the purchase or rental of such equipment as tractors and wagons, costumes, sound systems and special effects. Mr. Paige and his regular staff then rounded up part-time employees to portray ghosts and goblins and to be tour guides and tractor drivers, "all types and ages who could use the money and didn't mind having a lot of fun while on the job," he said.
The venture has been a success, Mr. Paige says, and while he admits that he could have undertaken such a project on his own, the franchise offers support and logistics that would have taken him months if not years to prepare.
"Bang, it was all right there and the bases were covered," he said. "All we needed to do was put it all together like a puzzle and remember what we had done for the following year."
Last season, he said, "I broke about even, but this year we should do very well for ourselves, if the weather is kind to us and everything goes according to schedule, which it never seems to do."
Under the franchise agreement, Mr. Paige must return 10 percent of his gross profits to the parent company each year. Tickets for the 35-minute-long hayride are $9.95 for adults and $7.95 for children 5 to 12 years old. Even though his season consists of only 16 evenings, he has averaged 1,200 customers a night, with as many as 2,000 a night on Saturdays and Sundays. His season comes to an end on Nov. 1, All Saints' Day.
There are rules and regulations as well. Tour guides tell rider not to kick or punch the specters that stalk the ride. And above all, there is no smoking.
Since a 1984 blaze at a haunted castle attraction at the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park in Jackson that killed eight teen-agers, municipalities have given closer scrutiny to such operations.
Lisa Beach, a spokeswoman for Great Adventure, said the park follows local fire safety rules and enforces a no-smoking policy at its hayride, part of a Halloween-themed program called Frightfest that runs through Monday. The park management chose not to rebuild the popular attraction after the fire.
For Richard A. Singer of Wyckoff, who operates the "Greenhouse of Fear" attraction at Tice's Farm in Woodcliff Lake, fire and safety regulations meant that he needed to spend some $5,000 on fire-retardant materials before he could open for business.
"The place was crawling with inspectors, and that's only right," he said. "There's not one thing in here that isn't fire retardant, from black tarps to costumes. You have to think about safety above anything else."
For Kathleen L. Vryhof and her husband, Michael, the Suntan Lake operation is a saving grace against unemployment. The West Milford couple portray the "butcher and his latest victim" at one of 15 stops on the route.
While her husband's income as a laundry service deliveryman is steady, she recently lost her job at a pet shop and has had little luck finding other work.
"I've got applications all over the place, at least a dozen, and I know at the very least one will come through for me," Mrs. Vryhof said, "and while this particular night job might be a bit unusual, it's still a job and it still helps out with the bills."
For $5.35 an hour, she gets lopped into pieces by her mad butcher husband and made into a stew. Mrs. Vryhof said that they are usually giddier than the children they entertain and that they are having "a bloody good time of it, at that."
Robert and Joi Small, also of West Milford, say the extended season also helps them financially. Both are beer concessionaires at Suntan Lake in the summer, and their combined income at odd jobs carries them through the winter.
"I can't say that this is the oddest job that we've both had, but it sure ranks up there," said Mrs. Small, who was a guide on the wagon tour for which her husband drives the tractor. "We're making some extra money, and as a team we have this great banter back and forth which really draws in the audience," she said.
Not everyone agrees that the rapid growth of the haunted hayrides is a good idea. Richard Hanf of Hamburg and Mr. Singer say that a Halloween franchise is an insult to a tradition based on spontaneity.
"When I think of a franchise, I think of McDonald's, I think of Burger King or a car dealership," said Mr. Hanf, known by many in Sussex County as the "Phantom of Hamburg" and for his transformation of a fairytale gingerbread castle, a children's attraction off Route 23N, into a haunted castle each year at this time.
"You have to have originality, not a script or a how-to book that says, 'This will scare people and this will not,' " he said. "If I want a cold piece of chicken, extra crispy, I go to a franchise, but if I want something different, I cook it up myself. Preferably in a cauldron."
Mr. Singer, who calls himself the "King of Halloween," said: "Fear is best when it's imagined and comes from some place in the deepest innermost recesses of your mind. What we do has to be born from a nightmare, not a manual; otherwise people see right through it and that trick-or-treat anticipation, which is what Halloween is all, about is lost."
Mr. Hanf and Mr. Singer, who as youngsters so overdecorated their front lawns for the day that the displays caused traffic jams in their neighborhoods, have another thing in common that might explain their fondness for Halloween: it is their birthday.
Mr. Paige brushes aside such criticism.
"Our franchise guidelines are just that, and nothing is cut in stone, no pun intended," he said. "Each actor, each person brings a little special magic into the part they play. After all, beyond the bump in the night, it's a little bit of magic that we're all after in our lives, isn't it?"
In Woodcliff Lake, a hayride haunted the dreams of Peter Van Riper until he decided to put one in place on land he and his Dutch ancestors had farmed since 1791. Buying into a franchise was the farthest thing from his mind, he said.
"We started off with a tractor pull through a cornfield, called it the Moonlight Hay Ride and charged a buck a ride," Mr. Van Riper said. "That was four years ago, and you should have seen the lines! The next year we added scares for the kids, and it just got bigger and better."
Pumpkin sales went up and so did business in general, but most of all, he recalled, was the satisfaction he derived from making a traditional holiday more enjoyable for children.
"This ride is a lot of work, a lot of time and preparation," he said, adding that because his farm was a popular spot for pumpkin picking, "I didn't need to do this."
"But I see the glow in these kids' eyes, just as I see it in my grandchildren's eyes," he said, "and all the trouble that it might be doesn't seem to matter very much."
Open from Wednesday through Saturday from 7:30 to 10 P.M., the hayride costs $5 for an adult and $3 for a child. It includes a stop at a ghastly cemetery where ghouls have been known to rise from the grave and where a menacing Jason chases the unwary with a chain saw.
In past years, Mr. Van Riper said, he has averaged 6,000 visitors a season. "My staff gets as much fun out of this as the kids do," he said, saying that they also like the extra money. They create their own costumes "and usually fight amongst themselves about who is on schedule for the night."
But the fall pumpkin picking that has spanned generations at his farm is about to end. Mr. Van Riper's children have pursued careers other than agriculture. The property has been sold, and the farm will close when he retires at the end of the year.
"For all the years here, I guess I just wanted to be remembered for doing something special for people," he said, "and this hayride is something that myself and others will carry with them for a lifetime."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Scaring people for fun and profit at Halloween time is the idea of hayrides at the Suntan Lake recreation area in Riverdale. (Photographs by Lenore Davis for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 372 words

HEADLINE: What Do Women Earn?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In her letter (Oct. 9) responding to my review of Judy Mann's book "The Difference: Growing Up Female in America," Valerie J. Lofland takes me to task for the statement that "the wage gap . . . has almost closed for young women," and reels off some statistics to prove me wrong. Yet most of her statistics have nothing to do with young women (to whom I specifically referred); the only one that is age-specific proves my point: "Among workers between the ages of 15 and 24, women earn 93 percent of what men make." (In fact, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the 1993 figure was 94.8 percent; for women between the ages of 20 and 24, it was 95.4 percent.) 
 Ms. Lofland asserts, however, that "the wage gap widens as women mature," since women between 55 and 59 years of age make only 62 percent of their male counterparts' earnings. This assertion is pure fallacy, since it seems to assume that these wage ratios apply to the same women at different stages in their lives. The women who are now between the ages of 55 and 59, as a rule, did not expect to be in the labor force for any significant portion of their adult lives; few of them trained for careers the way their male peers did. Many of them have resumed work after a 20- or 30-year hiatus.
The consensus among economists today is that while a small part of the wage gap may be due to sexual discrimination, there are too many other factors involved -- the fact that women are more likely to take time off from labor force participation, work fewer hours in a week and are less likely to take jobs requiring long commutes; differences in education and experience -- to pinpoint sexist bias as the primary reason. One may say that the social patterns responsible for these differences are also sexist. They are, however, changing rapidly.
Ms. Lofland asks whether I have been "on Mars" for the last 20 years. I must wonder where she has been for the last 15, when the female-to-male earnings ratio, after stagnating or even declining for years, began to rise dramatically as millions of young women with career aspirations similar to those of the men in their age group began to enter the market.
 
CATHY YOUNG
Middletown, N.J.

HEADLINE: PAYING FOR KEEPS

 BODY:
All New Yorkers, regardless of economic class, are poor when it comes to trees and fresh air (The Big City: "Paying for Keeps," by John Tierney, Oct. 9). Central Park has been providing a bit of nature to rich and poor alike as part of its mandate since its inception, this despite many historical attempts to restrict its use. While the park's restoration funding may come from private sources, this has never compromised its access, remarkable in a city that sets standards for high-priced luxuries and services. 
 Central Park is the one great place in New York where I can go without measuring the experience against the amount of money it costs me. The last thing those who enjoy the park want is to have a policeman stop them and demand to see admission tickets. (I'd love to see this tried on some of the Rollerblade enthusiasts.)
 
ROBERT EGERT
New York

HEADLINE: Now, It's the Rick Scott Health Plan

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla.

 BODY:
THE Clinton health plan flopped. All the alternatives that 435 Representatives and 100 Senators could concoct went nowhere.
Now, it's time for the Scott plan. 
 "What's happening in Washington is not health care reform," said Richard L. Scott, founder and chief executive of the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, the world's largest hospital chain. "Health care reform is happening in the marketplace."
Mr. Scott, tall and rousing, traverses the nation as if running to take Mr. Clinton's place. Last Tuesday, he was speaking to local officials and hospital executives over dinner here. In a hotel setting that called to mind a political fund raiser, he presented, often by tactful implication, the day's campaign theme: Choose me and my company, and your Tampa General Hospital could become a money maker, delivering improved health care -- just like my 14 area hospitals and 6 centers for day surgery that are taking away at least a few of Tampa General's patients.
No need for Mr. Scott to note that Tampa General, tax-supported but almost two-thirds empty, is heading for financial disaster.
"We can provide a better product at a better price. And by the way," he later said, pausing to sneer at the nonprofit hospitals that account for the bulk of the health care industry, "we pay taxes."
With slides and maps and statistics, he explained how the Scott plan is taking effect at the 311 hospitals and 125 clinics his company owns or has agreed to buy in 37 states and two foreign countries, a network that comprised fewer than 30 hospitals just 14 months ago. Employers are out to curb health care expenses, and through managed care organizations, they are steering employees away from proud research, teaching and indigent care institutions like Tampa General and toward hospitals like his that boast of lower costs.
"If you can't appeal to managed care providers, you will not be in business," Mr. Scott warned his Tampa listeners. Hospitals like his, he continues, have helped to cut health care inflation from the double digits to 4.7 percent.
In a heavily regulated and Government-financed business, Mr. Scott, a 41-year-old lawyer, has become the unelected champion of the relentlessly free market. Earlier this month, he topped off the American medical industry's greatest shopping spree with a deal to add Healthtrust Inc.'s 116 hospitals for $5 billion. Last year, he agreed to buy the HCA-Hospital Corporation of America, which had been the largest hospital company, and Galen Health Care Inc., one of the largest, for a total of more than $13 billion. He added Medical Care America Inc., the largest chain of day, or outpatient, surgery centers, for another billion earlier this year. His company, only seven years old, is now three times the size of the next-largest hospital chain, the soon-to-merge National Medical Enterprises and American Medical Holdings.
But with numbers like those, and much bigger ones in his plans, critics are asking whether Mr. Scott is growing too big, too fast.
"Mr. Scott seems intent on purchasing almost any institution at any price to get into a market," said Daniel P. Bourque, the research manager for VHA Inc., an association of the nation's nonprofit, or voluntary, hospitals. "He likes to say they're going to be the Wal-Mart of health care. The question is, when you get sick do you want to go to Wal-Mart?"
The financial stakes many Columbia/HCA doctors have in their local hospital networks, some outsiders say, can conflict with the best medical decisions. In the race for profits, some fear that the poor and uninsured may be left behind. As the company snaps up market share, they say, Mr. Scott could end up with local monopoly control, able to raise prices even as he slashes costs.
Mr. Scott says he is prepared to match the quality of care at his hospitals with that of any in the industry. And he is clearly not about to stop growing. To a questioner last week, who raised antitrust issues, Mr. Scott said he has never captured as much as 40 percent of any major local market, and has slightly more than 4 percent of a huge but fragmented national market.
"The Catholics have 16 percent," he said. "Now, they're not all organized into one system. But we pay $750 million in state, Federal and local income taxes, and we provide $750 million in uncompensated care."
Now he is going after the heart of the medical business: the not-for-profits -- or the "non-taxpaying," as he insistently says -- among them all the academic, religious and public hospitals that still account for more than five-sixths of the industry. He wants to expand the strong, shut down the weak and leave rival hospitals wondering where their patients went.
"Whenever he is riding into town, the hospital people are soiling their diapers," said Uwe E. Reinhardt, a health economist at Princeton University. "He can get things done that Government hasn't been able to do in 20 years. He is a private capitalist dictator."
In states like Florida, where Columbia/HCA already has more than 20 percent of the market, competing hospitals are rapidly forming their own networks and cutting their costs. State by state, Mr. Scott is urging the repeal of certificate-of-need laws, which limit his expansion, and the passage of indigent care laws requiring nonprofits to provide treatment worth as much as the taxes they would otherwise pay. Although nonprofits were founded to provide charity care, Mr. Scott says, many now virtually exclude the poor.
Since the Scott plan has no place for the Clinton plan's medical spending limits, he encouraged his hospitals to organize political committees to survey and interview candidates at all levels, then circulate the candidates' views. Employees conduct voter registration drives and contribute to a company political action committee. "I WANT YOU TO WRITE A LETTER," a stern Uncle Sam commands Mr. Scott's staff from a poster near his office in the company's headquarters in Louisville, Ky.
THE big political figures he takes on face-to-face. He has lectured Federal Reserve Board chairman Alan Greenspan on how to gather reliable medical cost statistics. He warned the Senate Majority Leader, George Mitchell, who tried to pass the Clinton plan in some form, that any attempt to cap overall medical spending would provoke him to open hospitals across the Canadian and Mexican borders. He told Hillary Rodham Clinton that he could do more to control medical costs than she could.
Ira Magaziner, a senior health care adviser to the President, responded in an interview that the private sector often fails to provide enough care, especially for center cities, rural areas and the poor. "Competition among integrated health plans can help bring down growth in costs," he said. "Our only concern is now it's happening out there in the marketplace without adequate consumer protection."
So far, it's unclear whether patients will have as much to cheer about as Mr. Scott's investors. Mr. Bourque's organization provides studies indicating that the nonprofits deliver proportionally more Medicare and Medicaid treatment and charge lower prices than the profit-making chains. In Florida, where investor-owned hospitals are especially strong, they provided less than a fifth the rate of charity care as the nonprofits in 1992.
In fact, investor-owned chains long specialized in skimming off the wealthy and well-insured, leaving others to the nonprofits. Mr. Bourque finds Mr. Scott's strategy especially galling since he captures doctors and their patients by inviting the physicians to invest in his hospitals.
Mr. Scott says that his company has broken sharply with the industry's past by giving doctors and employees incentives to economize. Only about 12 percent of his revenues come from traditional insurers willing to pay full price. The rest is roughly split between Government health plans and managed care groups, who demand fixed discounts.
Industry analysts say his mergers appear to be delivering the hundreds of millions of dollars in annual savings he predicted.
"We are the largest buyers of medical supplies in the world," Mr. Scott told his Tampa audience last week. "Baxter Travenol has $5 billion worth of U.S. sales. I can give them $800 million or nothing. You think they will give me a better price?"
Mr. Scott delivered his comments rapidly but in a manner so calmly matter-of-fact that they were somehow reassuring. Listeners who had expected a medical robber baron instead got a practiced politician, one who took pains to avoid visibly pressuring them into what would be an unpopular decision.
Mr. Scott struggles to keep himself from thumping his chest too loudly, now that he is learning how poorly the public, not to mention the Federal Trade Commission, might take his talk of seizing markets and killing off competitors in a field whose leaders are supposed to speak of providing selfless care and humane treatment.
"It doesn't sound so good when I say that, 'Golly, I'm going to compete against a tax-exempt hospital,' " he said in an interview earlier in the week at his Louisville headquarters.
Only when told that Richard E. Rainwater, the Fort Worth investor and cofounder of Columbia/HCA, expects the company to grow fourfold or more over the next 10 or 12 years, owning as many as a fifth of the nation's hospitals, does Mr. Scott drop his guard a bit. Yes, some company will probably get there, he said, and yes, it will probably be his.
For a company already one of the nation's 40 largest, in a league with Time Warner and Coca-Cola, that growth would vault it into the top six or eight, up there with I.B.M., G.E. and, yes, Wal-Mart.
His company, still less well known than others of its size, avoids slapping the Columbia name on its hospitals. They remain concentrated in the Sunbelt, but Mr. Scott says that his drive to buy nonprofit hospitals will lead to all 50 states.
HE is bent, however, on forging a huge company without becoming a huge target. There is no hiding his net worth of $240 million in Columbia/HCA stock, nor the company jet. But Mr. Scott now camps out in a squat office building furnished with steel file cabinets and plastic laminated conference tables.
He stands as ready to help the United Way and other charitable causes as companies accused of blackening smokers' lungs or Alaskan shorelines. He brings up his humble origins, in Kansas City, Mo., so often -- his father a trucker, his mother a clerk at J. C. Penney, among other jobs -- that his aides have asked him to give some of his yarns a rest.
"You'll hear a lot of doughnut shop stories," said David T. Vandewater, an evidently secure chief operating officer, referring to the business Mr. Scott ran with his mother and brother while in college. "I'm glad he's had other experiences in life."
Mr. Scott now accumulates those experiences beginning at 5 A.M. daily. He works out on a treadmill, stair climber and weight machine, catches the morning news and begins concentrating on his next steps toward the short, medium and long-term goals he keeps on lists in his desk drawer. As if to make his own streamlined form a model for his company, he neither smokes nor drinks.
He is one of the few whose discipline, in exercise and in business, inspires awe even in Mr. Rainwater. "Probably the lowest body fat of anybody I've been in business with," said Mr. Rainwater, whose standard of comparison includes partners like Roger Staubach, the former Dallas Cowboys star.
Mr. Scott's wife, Ann, with whom he has two daughters, and his board chairman, Thomas F. Frist Jr., have asked him to lighten up. Mr. Scott's reluctant response has been to delay his 6 A.M. Monday teleconferences by an hour, after Mr. Frist and other executives of his newly acquired HCA hospital chain, based in Nashville, complained that the time difference forced them to stand ready at 5 A.M.
Mr. Scott usually devotes three days a week to his campaign swings, which have already taken him to 141 of his 195 hospitals, not counting the Healthtrust properties. To check up on competitors and expand his list of acquisition targets, currently at 75 hospitals or companies, he drops in on other hospitals, often unannounced.
HIS Florida trip included a meeting with The Tampa Tribune editorial board, on a day when the paper's lead story was about the resignation of Tampa General's president, under pressure from board members who feared that he was too ready to deliver his hospital into Mr. Scott's arms.
"We would be a logical partner for Tampa General," Mr. Scott told the somewhat skeptical writers. He mentioned Columbia's partnerships with other teaching hospitals, including the University of Louisville, with Emory in Atlanta in the works. But just the next day, on Wednesday, Emory ended discussions, amid misgivings about the sharing of profits and authority.
Still, the writers noted that other hospital chains, long active in Florida, had never bothered sending their chief executives around.
"What you are doing really seems to be in the mainstream of what American businesses are doing, whether it's Wal-Mart or the banks," said the editorial page editor, Edwin A. Roberts Jr., before starting another Q. and A. volley over whether Mr. Scott had monopolistic designs.
From there, Mr. Scott and his aides raced a half hour or so across a Tampa Bay bridge to their St. Petersburg General Hospital. Mr. Scott thanked his 30 administrators, seated like campaign workers around a candidate, for letting politicians know how they felt about health care reform.
Then he zipped through the hospital, fertilizing his company's grass roots by handing out company pins and shaking as many of his employees' 700 right hands as he could.
"Whose patients are you stealing?" he demanded of one administrator as he toured obstetrics.
"Community Health Systems," she answered. "We want their deliveries."
"I don't understand why they're open," he said.
"We're hurting them," she assured him.
He then sped back across the bay, where the departed Tampa General Hospital president had invited Mr. Scott's regional manager to speak that night. Mr. Scott came instead.
"Did he arrive in a stretch limo?" asked Lois L. Nixon, a medical professor and board member who favors keeping the hospital public. (No, it was his regional manager's Lexus.)
AFTER Mr. Scott finished his slide show and speech, Ms. Nixon asked whether he even saw a reason to keep the big urban hospitals public.
"You have a hard time staying in business if all you attract is indigent care," he answered, having noted that his network could feed these hospitals paying patients as well.
Listeners who found his message unwelcome were, by evening's end, at least willing to consider questions beyond his executive travel style. Having resented other proposals to privatize Tampa General, Fred M. Kanter, a maverick board member, found Mr. Scott's talk disarming. Maybe too much so.
"Of all the proponents of the various plans, he's probably the most dangerous," Mr. Kanter said. "Because he's the most skilled."
 
 
 
FROM TEXAS TO KENTUCKY TO . . .
 LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- MEMO to Columbia/HCA headquarters employees here: Keep your bags and boxes packed. A year is enough time in one place for Rick Scott.
Mr. Scott, the chief executive, moved his headquarters from Fort Worth in August 1993 when he bought Galen Health Care, based here.
Two months later, when he agreed to buy the HCA chain, based in Nashville, he reopened the question. Soon after, "Louisville Loves Columbia Healthcare" billboards sprouted by the highways and 200 local businesses offered discounts and gifts to any company employee moving from Nashville.
"Recruiting Columbia/HCA is a lot like trying to date the richest kid in school," wrote Bob Hill, a Louisville Courier-Journal columnist. "Where do you draw the line between good-faith guarantees and groveling?"
In March, after Columbia exacted a promise from state lawmakers to let a 2.5 percent tax on doctors and hospitals lapse and reached a lucrative new contract to manage the University of Louisville Hospital, Mr. Scott agreed to stay.
Then, he says, the lawmakers extended the tax. When the city's corporate recruiters ran a full-page magazine advertisement boasting of Columbia's decision to stay, Mr. Scott sent angry letters to 300 executives and public officials.
Now, he is very publicly looking for a new home. While in Tampa last week, he dangled the possibility of moving there. "We just bought a 19-foot boat for water skiing," he told the Tampa Tribune editorial board.
Any coincidence that he is also seeking to run Tampa General Hospital? "None," he later said.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Fear of Mutual Fund Flows: Relax

BYLINE: By Leslie Eaton 

 BODY:
THERE are ghouls and ghosts and things that go bump in the night. And then there is the most frightening specter of them all (at least on Wall Street): the Mutual Fund Death Spiral.
This is the fear that a decline in the stock market will cause investors to bail out of equity mutual funds. That would force fund managers to sell stocks, driving prices down. That would spook more fund investors into fleeing into money markets, forcing fund managers to sell more stocks, driving prices down still more, spooking more fund investors and -- well, you get the picture. 
 The companies that sell funds have been arguing for years that such fears are overblown and that fund investors are in there for the long haul. Now these would-be ghostbusters have some new ammunition in the form of a statistical study done by Zwen Goy, an economist at CS First Boston.
Looking at data from 1987 through mid-1994, she found that mutual fund flows do not cause changes in the stock market. True, the market has been rising since '87, and so have sales of mutual funds. But statistically, Ms. Goy could not find a cause and effect relationship. "It's not that mutual fund flows have no consequence," she said. "But they are not the most important thing -- it's a very minor effect."
The Death Spiral is haunting the Street right now because investors seem finally to have cooled a bit on stock funds. Money is still flowing in, to be sure, but at a slower pace than earlier in the year. In September, the most recent month for which complete data are available, Americans put $8.1 billion into stock funds, a huge sum but still less than the record $14.1 billion they invested in August, according to the Investment Company Institute, the mutual fund industry's trade and lobbying association.
And an awful lot of that money is not even going into the domestic stock market. Last month, 35 percent of the inflows went to funds specializing in foreign securities; in August, it was closer to 40 percent. Furthermore, many funds categorized as "domestic" stock funds increasingly hold big chunks of foreign stocks, though few have gone quite as far as Fidelity Capital Appreciation, which at the end of July had more than 40 percent of its assets overseas.
This month, investors cooled still further on stock funds, according to figures compiled by AMG Data Services of Arcata, Calif. Investors put an average of $1.4 billion a week into the stock funds AMG tracks, an impressive number but down sharply from an average of $2.1 billion a week back in August. The sharpest cutbacks appeared in the most aggressive United States stock funds; investors actually yanked money out of aggressive growth funds in the week ended Oct. 26.
Investors may have been reacting to lackluster market performance -- but maybe not. Ms. Goy found that not only do fund investors not cause stock market changes, they also do not react much to the market after it moves. In fact, investors put about the same amount of money into funds no matter how the stock market is doing. The reason, she said, is that most households are saving for long-term goals and don't generally play the market with mutual funds.
Admittedly, fund investors do take money out -- redeem -- or switch into money market funds more if the stock market is falling, or if they suspect it may soon do so. Even so, "we had huge redemptions in 1988, yet the market went up 15 percent that year," she noted.
At first blush, Ms. Goy's findings seem to fly in the face of the laws of supply and demand, which many people assume mean that if demand for stocks increases (as investors throw money into equity mutual funds), stock prices should rise, too. Conversely, if demand for stocks plunges (because people stop investing in mutual funds), stock prices should fall, too.
"If nothing else changes, that may be true, but so many other factors are involved," she said. Corporate earnings, overall economic growth, inflation and, primarily, interest rates all have a bigger effect on stock prices than just fund flows.
There is also the not insignificant matter of supply, noted Charles Biderman, editor of a newsletter called Liquidity Trim Tabs. For example, he said, in 1988, leveraged buyouts reduced the amount of stock outstanding while increasing the amount of cash investors had to buy stocks. This effect, he argued, more than outweighed the mutual fund redemptions.
Nevertheless, Mr. Biderman thinks that fund flows are very significant. "In every market there's a different key component to liquidity, and funds are probably key in this market," he said. "If there's an outflow from stock funds, it would be very important regardless of anything else that is going on; psychologically, fund flows are underlying everybody's bullishness."
Certainly, investors in bond funds have not sat quietly and watched their money evaporate. Through September, they pulled almost $29 billion out of funds that invest in government and mortgage-backed bonds.
And to participants in that market, these outflows seem to have had an effect on prices. As Ned Davis, a well-known technical analyst, wrote recently to his clients: "Believe me, those who have lost 19 percent in bonds over the last year know there were risks when the public wanted out of bond funds."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Procter's Tale: Gambling in Ignorance

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
THE wonderful world of interest rate swaps has largely been hidden from public view. Now, as some of the big losers in the game cry foul and sue, more of it is coming to light.
Last week, Procter & Gamble became the second Cincinnati company to sue Bankers Trust. Like Gibson Greeting Cards a few weeks earlier, P.& G. sees itself as a swindled innocent that relied on the advice of a slick New York hustler and lost millions. 
 Bankers Trust, in its response to the Gibson suit, paints a far different picture. It was no trusted adviser, it says, just a trader. Gibson was a sophisticated company that made a bet on interest rates, and Bankers Trust took the other side. Gibson lost. Too bad. Its response to P.& G. is likely to be similar.
It is far too early to judge the merits of the claims, but several things are clear. Both Gibson and P.& G. ended up taking amazing risks, with the potential of huge losses if interest rates rose. Gibson says it took the riskiest of those chances only under duress, when losses were piling up from other bets whose details it will not disclose. P.& G. says it relied on promises from Bankers Trust that it could get out before the losses mounted.
Behind both cases is a trend that built up in the 1980's, of the corporate treasurer as a profit center, able to use sophisticated techniques to get more money on idle cash while saving money on borrowing. More and more they turned to banks for clever ideas and, if these cases are any example, accepted risks that they did not understand.
In a simple interest rate swap, a company that is paying a fixed rate on a bond issue is relieved of the duty to pay it, instead agreeing to pay a floating rate. That was what happened to both P.& G. and Gibson, but in their cases they agreed to complicated formulas that meant the rates they paid could soar to incredible heights. P.& G.'s formula was as follows: Six months after the deal was signed, multiply the yield on 5-year Treasuries by 17.0415 and then subtract the price of the outstanding 30-year Treasury, which had a coupon of 6.25 percent. That figure, less 0.75 percentage points, was the margin above commercial paper that would be paid, in most cases.
Under that formula, P.& G. stood to save a little if rates fell or rose just a bit, but to lose big if rates jumped. Given what actually happened to rates, P.& G. could have been forced to pay more than 30 percent a year.
P.& G. says Bankers Trust promised it could get out well before that happened, under a complicated option that Bankers Trust did not explain. P.& G. says it was told that changes in interest rates and the volatility of rates would have little effect on the price of the option. If that was said, and believed, it is breathtaking. Anyone who knew anything about option pricing would have laughed at such a claim. (Bankers Trust says there was no option deal at all, just a promise to quote a price if P.& G. wanted out early.) Eventually, P.& G. got out, but it will pay rates approaching 20 percent for four years unless the court intervenes.
These suits make it clear that corporate treasurers who said they were hedging were really gambling on declining interest rates. Perhaps they were misled by Bankers Trust, whose stock certainly has suffered since the ruckus began. But it is hard to escape the conclusion that big companies like this should not be playing games they don't understand.
