HEADLINE: DONORS URGE HAITI TO TAX THE RICH

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29

 BODY:
As the United States and the World Bank seek to round up the $550 million in international aid planned for Haiti this year, they are urging President Jean-Bertrand Aristide to make sweeping changes in the way Haiti's Government works, including collecting far more in taxes from the rich.
As the effort to restore democracy in Haiti shifts gears with President Aristide now back in office, officials from the Clinton Administration, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund are laying out the steps they want taken to put the Government on a solid footing. 
 The task, both immediately and in the long run, is enormous. The economy of what was already the hemisphere's poorest country has been devastated by the three years of military rule and the international embargoes imposed against it.
International aid officials worked with President Aristide on his economic plan during his exile, and it reads like an I.M.F. primer, calling for privatizing industry, slashing the budget deficit and bureaucracy, expanding education programs, removing most price controls and improving tax collection.
But the officials are expressing worry now about the slow pace at which the President is moving to assemble his Government, warning that there would be little point in pouring in anything more than aid until there is a bureaucratic structure in place to accept it.
And while American officials have long urged Father Aristide to abandon his class-conscious, anti-rich oratory, they have joined in the concerted call for making wealthy Haitians pay a greater share of taxes.
"There were lots of exemptions, and tax evasion was pervasive," said an official from the International Monetary Fund. "We're not calling for increasing taxes on the rich so much as collecting taxes from them."
Another recommendation is that President Aristide needs to move decisively to clean up the Government bureaucracy, which under years of military dictatorship focused on lining its pockets instead of providing basic services to the country's 6.7 million people.
"We're making a recommendation to aggressively put into place an anti-corruption mechanism at all levels of the Haitian Government," said Mark Schneider, the Agency for International Development official who is the Clinton Administration's point man on economic aid to Haiti.
Officials in the Administration and international lending agencies say President Aristide has been receptive to their recommendations on taxation and revamping the bureaucracy, but they are waiting to see how he fleshes out the details of his program. It is easy to talk of moving toward a balanced budget or slashing the bureaucracy, these officials say, but it is far harder to make the painful choices required to achieve those goals.
The Administration has pledged $200 million in aid to Haiti this year, a large part of the $550 million that the World Bank estimates the country will need. The Administration anticipates contributing about $100 million a year in subsequent years toward an international aid effort that is expected to reach $1.5 billion over five years.
The European Union has tentatively committed $160 million in aid over the next 15 months. The World Bank is unblocking $100 million in loans for education, health care and small businesses and for cleaning the water supply that were not disbursed because of the 1991 military coup. The Inter-American Development Bank is also unfreezing $100 million in loans.
"With the corrupt military and police gone, this is clearly Haiti's single greatest opportunity to do something significant to improve the life of its people," Mr. Schneider said.
After being brutalized by dictatorship and squeezed by a trade embargo, Haiti is in such wretched shape that aid donors are acting with uncommon urgency.
The Agency for International Development is increasing its feeding program to 1.3 million meals a day and has made an emergency $15 million loan to pay for crucial imports like seed, fertilizer and fuel. Foreign donors plan to put at least 50,000 Haitians to work on cleanup and road-building projects.
To quell dissent from the military, the United States has agreed to finance new jobs for laid-off soldiers when President Aristide shrinks Haiti's army from 7,000 to 1,500.
There is widespread recognition that the President has a daunting task. More than two-thirds of the population is unemployed, and just one in four adults knows how to read. Three-fourths of the children are undernourished, and the Agency for International Development sees an annual food shortage of 740 million pounds -- about 110 pounds for every Haitian. Per capita income has plunged 25 percent in the last two years, to less than $250, the lowest in the hemisphere.
Haiti has the hemisphere's worst infant mortality rate, with more than one in 10 children dying before their first birthday. Much of its once-verdant countryside has been denuded by people who have chopped down trees to make charcoal, causing alarming soil erosion.
President Aristide's economic program, Administration officials say, partly reflects the intensive consultations that the President and his aides had with the Clinton Administration, the I.M.F. and the World Bank when they lived in exile. Several officials say President Aristide has come around to the view that the best way to create jobs and end poverty is to create an environment in which the private sector can flourish.
"His program is like motherhood," said an economist with the International Monetary Fund, which is known for supporting free-market policies and budget discipline. "It's the kind of things we go for."
Believing that many of the 45,000 civil servants are no-shows who owe their jobs to nepotism, President Aristide plans to slash the bureaucracy in half, mostly through buyouts. In trimming the security forces, he plans to salve their reaction by giving many members of the military new jobs, primarily building roads.
Recognizing that the central Government has long been a parasite living on corruption, he has vowed to decentralize power and strengthen local governments. He has also asked the United States and international financial institutions to send teams of experts to teach his Government proper auditing techniques for its ministries and central bank.

HEADLINE: Hyperbole Takes to the Runway;
The Sirens of Fashion Beckon for a Week -- and Then Some

BYLINE: By TRIP GABRIEL 

 BODY:
A year ago, when leading New York fashion designers moved their runway shows to a central location -- two white tents behind the New York Public Library in Bryant Park -- they spoke of the convenience, the added seats for buyers and press and a hoped-for economic lift for one of the city's major industries. They got that, and more: a social juggernaut.
Today, when the semiannual fashion week opens in New York, the hottest shows will tingle with the excitement of an old-time movie premiere, and the status conferred by an invitation is leading the socially ambitious to beg, cry and threaten their way in. The siren call of paparazzi will cause V.I.P.'s, both rising and fading, to elbow their way to the front rows, and designers will be shameless about planting celebrities in the seats. 
 Fashion week, once a nuts-and-bolts market, has become a happening, as surely as when a political convention or the United States Open tennis tournament comes to town.
"There was a time in New York in the late 70's and early 80's when you went out and could cut the electricity in the air," said Ian Schrager, the Studio 54 founder-turned-hotelier. "The only other time I sense that energy is during fashion week. You can't get taxi cabs. You can't get reservations in a restaurant. It's not only restricted to fashion people. It's like when high tide comes in and all the boats get lifted."
Although there are no studies of fashion week's economic impact on hotels, restaurants or the $22 billion New York fashion industry in general, individual businesses say they have noticed a difference. The designer Cynthia Rowley said her orders were up about 30 percent this year over last year, from $12 million to about $15.5 million, a gain she traces to the higher profile she has had since showing in the tents.
Fashion has always been a glamorous industry. But lately it is occupying a larger place in the culture, a development seen everywhere from the apotheosis of models into household names (Naomi, Linda, Cindy) to Robert Altman's warily anticipated movie, "Pret-a-Porter," a fashion spoof, to this week's all-fashion issue of The New Yorker. A party on Friday night to celebrate the issue, at the Academy Theater on West 42d Street, drew Giorgio Armani, Donna Karan and Isaac Mizrahi, as well as the actress Lauren Hutton, Tabitha Soren of MTV, the art gallery owner Larry Gagosian and the financier Teddy Forstmann.
In all, there are 51 shows planned for the tents or the library's auditoriums, beginning with Nancy Severin's presentation at noon today and ending with Donna Karan's on Friday night. The fact that there are many more seats available than when the shows were held in cramped designers' showrooms -- 800 in the larger of the two tents and 600 in the smaller -- has not quenched the desire to get in, only increased it.
"We could hold Todd's show at Madison Square Garden and fill it easily," Kevin Krier, a leading fashion show producer, said with perhaps understandable hyperbole, since he is staging Todd Oldham's show on Tuesday. It is one of the most sought-after invitations because of its mix of Hollywood flash and downtown trash. "People have offered money for a ticket," said Mr. Krier, the owner of Kevin Krier & Associates, a production and public relations company. "People cry. People scream and yell and tell me how important they are."
The invitation-only audiences for the shows include mostly working fashion editors and buyers. But now that most presentations are in the tents and the crowds have increased greatly, there is room for everyone from entertainment moguls to "Entertainment Tonight," from fashion students to fashion groupies.
"You have journalists and models and celebrities and retailers and V.I.P.'s descending upon a centralized location, and you're creating the opportunity for a buzz to be created," said Ed Filipowski, a partner in Keeble Cavaco & Duka, which is producing shows for Calvin Klein, Anna Sui and others. "The paparazzi have come out of the woodwork since the tents began. It's like a feeding frenzy."
 
For Businesses, An Early Christmas
 Photographers who chronicle celebrities are just one of many ancillary businesses that thrive during fashion week. For them, the arrival of the fashion circus is like Christmas, with so many beautifully wrapped packages all in one place.
"It used to be all the people around the runway were photographing just the outfits," said Patrick McMullan, a photographer who covers the shows for magazines like New York. "Now, every photographer with a camera tries to get in to shoot the audience as well as the supermodels. It's not about the outfits anymore. It's about the personalities."
It is the same for editors of celebrity-driven magazines like Vanity Fair and for gossip columnists, who can take an instant reading of who is in and who is out from the seating plans at the shows. Invitees have their names taped to seats, with the front rows the object of all eyes.
"There's definitely a meaning to the rows -- everyone's seated really carefully," said Peter Davis, who writes a gossip column for Paper magazine.
With nightclubs on the wane, fashion shows are filling a void for the glitter crowd: socializing lite. "The shows last all of 20 minutes, but it's like a whole schmooze fest before and after," said Nancy Kane of the public relations firm Jason Weinberg & Associates. "If you could say, 'I was backstage at Isaac Mizrahi's show this year,' that's the coolest thing to say in the New York social world."
Mr. Filipowski assigns the seats for Ms. Sui's show as carefully as for a dinner party, though one intended to transmute rubbernecking and conversation into golden sales. He seats retailers who adore Ms. Sui near reporters for Women's Wear Daily, who look for quotes afterward. Editors from Elle, Vogue and Harper's Bazaar are clustered in flocks to be able to trade gossip. A critic who may not be a fan is seated across from one who is, to witness the enthusiasm. And a Conde Nast celebrity like James Truman or Grayden Carter is seated beside a Hollywood celebrity as a kind of conversational party favor.
 
Fashion Purists Long For Old Days
 Not everyone approves of the new prominence. Fashion purists, upset at the attention paid to the audience at the expense of clothes, are nostalgic for the old days.
"They've become a little, how should I put this, popular for my taste," said Fran Lebowitz, the author, who has attended Mr. Klein's shows for years. "All these boys come now, young actors who come to look at the girls. There's a hockey game atmosphere. I never had a drink spilled on me at a fashion show before."
Clubs and certain small restaurants know that if they corral the fashion types, they will coast on the word of mouth long afterward.
"It sets the tone for the rest of the year," said Mark Baker, a co-owner of Flowers, a restaurant on West 17th Street in Chelsea, and Buddha Bar on Varick Street in SoHo. "There's no way in a year you'll get that many people of that quality in your restaurant at one time. It's a big social event. It's huge. You'll live off that press for the next six months."
When it comes to choosing locations for parties, it's the newest places in town that have an edge, and some clubs and restaurants time their openings to the shows.
"The fashion industry tends to become very jaded, always looking for something more stimulating," said Derek Anderson, who selected the just-reopened Studio 54 for the show and post-show party on Friday for Laura Whitcomb, a designer who is showing a line with a James Bond theme.
Casa La Femme, a SoHo restaurant that was hot after it opened during the shows in October 1991 and then cooled, felt the cruel sting of fashion's infatuation with the new. The restaurant sent more than 100 letters to designers offering to hold parties, and virtually all declined. But the restaurant did land at least one prize, a dinner to view a video of the collection by Jennifer George, who was unable to stage a traditional show because she is about to give birth.
 
Everyone Has A Finger In It
 Hotels, too, seek to minister to the itinerant fashion tribes, in the hope that their cachet will attract other business. The Royalton and the Paramount near Times Square, known for their avant-garde decor, are booked solid. The Mayfair on Park Avenue specializes in Italian fashion people, enticing journalists and designers like Ottavio Missoni and Miuccia Prada with room upgrades and other courtesies. The Macklowe on West 45th Street offers corporate discounts to Macy's, Donna Karan New York and others, with the result that 22 percent of the hotel's annual business is derived from the fashion industry.
"Everyone wants to have their finger in it," said Maureen O'Brien, a sales manager at the Macklowe.
A clear indicator of the shows' new status is the number of celebrities and would-be celebrities in the audience, drawn like moths to a flame. "Celebrities want to come because it puts them in the spotlight," Mr. Filipowski said bluntly.
To be sure, some of the A-list names who have attended in recent seasons, like Julia Roberts, Barbra Streisand and Barry Diller, probably have all the attention they want. They go to show support for a designer they know, for the fun of it or even to shop.
But insiders agree that most celebrities in attendance are looking to be seen and talked about.
"I think a lot of publicists encourage their clients to attend shows, especially ones looking to plug something," said Mr. Davis, the columnist. "They're going to get interviewed. It's one paparazzi trap after the next, outside the tents, inside, right at the entrance."
This season, many designers have received requests for invitations on behalf of the singer Crystal Waters, who recently released an album. Representatives for Janet Jackson have fished for invitations for herself and a bodyguard from Mr. Mizrahi, Mr. Oldham, Ralph Lauren and Ms. Sui, all of whom were happy to seat them. And Mickey Rourke, regularly named to worst-dressed lists, has blitzed designers with faxes asking for seats. "Being that Mr. Rourke has never attended the shows before, we would like to request front row seating," read the fax sent by the office of Mr. Rourke's publicist, Richard Pollmann.
Other sought-after invitations are for a party for 200 to be given by Mr. Klein at Nell's on Friday night, and a post-show party for the design house Ghost in a former synagogue downtown on Wednesday night.
"It seems the party rivals the fashion show as an important thing to go to," said Benjamin Liu, a consultant to Ghost's designer, Tanya Sarne. "I told Tanya the other day, 'Maybe we should all go into the nightclub business.' "

HEADLINE: A Kennedy-C.I.A. Plot Returns to Haunt Clinton

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29

 BODY:
It was a small clandestine operation in a little South American country three decades ago. President Kennedy ordered the Central Intelligence Agency to subvert the country's leader. The leader fell, and the C.I.A.'s men quietly left town.
Time passed, and the wheels of history turned. The cold war ended, and with its end the fallen leader was elected President of what is now independent Guyana. United States law says it is time to unseal the secret documents that detail Kennedy's plot against him. 
 But State Department and C.I.A. officials refuse to release them, saying it is not worth the embarrassment.
Keeping secrets can cause embarrassment too. In June the Clinton Administration prepared to send a new Ambassador to the little country -- apparently unaware that the prospective nominee had helped to undermine the restored leader.
The events of 30 years ago may be filed and forgotten in Washington; they are fresh in the memory of those who lived through them.
The story begins in 1953, when British Guiana, an English-speaking colony peopled by the descendants of slaves and laborers from Africa and India, elected its first native-born Prime Minister: Cheddi Jagan, a son of the colonial plantations, an American-educated dentist and an admirer of the works of Karl Marx.
Four months later, Churchill suspended British Guiana's Constitution and ordered its Government dissolved. Dr. Jagan was too leftist for Churchill's taste, though the people of British Guiana liked him.
Dr. Jagan and his wife, the former Janet Rosenberg of Chicago, were freed from jail after the British restored constitutional government, and he was re-elected in 1957 and 1961.
The latter year saw Kennedy's disastrous Bay of Pigs invasion, aimed at overthrowing Cuba's leader, Fidel Castro. A newspaper cartoon of the day depicted a double-barrel shotgun aimed at the United States. One barrel was labeled "Cuba," the other "British Guiana."
On Oct. 25, 1961, Prime Minister Jagan went to the White House, seeking financial aid and offering assurances.
"I went to see President Kennedy to seek the help of the United States, and to seek his support for our independence from the British," he said in a recent interview. "He was very charming and jovial. Now, the United States feared that I would give Guyana to the Russians. I said if this is your fear, fear not. We will not have a Soviet base. I raised the question of aid. They did not give a positive response. The meeting ended on this note."
The meeting was recorded by the historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. in "A Thousand Days," his memoir of the Kennedy White House. "Jagan was unquestionably some sort of a Marxist," he wrote, but also "plainly the most popular leader in British Guiana," adding, "The question was whether he was recoverable for democracy." Another question was whether he and his nation of 600,000 represented a threat to the United States.
Kennedy told Dr. Jagan that United States policy toward his country was clear: "National independence. This is the basic thing. As long as you do that, we don't care whether you are socialist, capitalist, pragmatist or whatever. We regard ourselves as pragmatists." A joint statement was issued, committing Dr. Jagan "to uphold the political freedoms" that were his inheritance.
After Dr. Jagan left Washington, Kennedy met in secret with his top national security officers. A pragmatic plan took shape.
Still-classified documents depict in unusual detail a direct order from the President to unseat Dr. Jagan, say Government officials familiar with the secret papers.
Though many Presidents have ordered the C.I.A. to undermine foreign leaders, they say, the Jagan papers are a rare smoking gun: a clear written record, without veiled words or plausible denials, of a President's command to depose a Prime Minister.
In short order, things started going badly for British Guiana.
"It was after the meeting with Kennedy that the cold war heated up here," recalled Janet Jagan, then a minister in her husband's Government.
Previously unheard-of radio stations went on the air in the capital, Georgetown. The papers printed false stories about approaching Cuban warships. Civil servants walked out. The labor unions revolted. Riots took the lives of more than 100 people.
The key was the unions, whose rebellion crippled the Government and the economy. And the unions were taking advice and money from an interesting assortment of American organizations.
Among them, say the Jagans and historians familiar with the events, was the American Institute for Free Labor Development, headed by a labor official named William C. Doherty Jr.
The institute, an international program run by the A.F.L.-C.I.O., long has aided anti-Communist unions abroad. In the 1950's and early 1960's, former United States intelligence officers say, the C.I.A. slipped money to the institute. The ties between the agency and the institute have long since been severed.
The agitation grew throughout 1962 and 1963. "A fire was set in the center of town," Dr. Jagan said. "The wind fanned the flames, and the center of the city burned. There are still scars. Then they changed their tactics. This is where the C.I.A. support came in full. They imposed a full blockade on shipping and airlines. We were helpless. We had no power."
The British, at the suggestion of the Kennedy Administration, delayed their colony's scheduled independence and changed its electoral system in October 1963. Now the electorate had to vote for parties instead of people, and a still popular but politically weakened Dr. Jagan fell from power. Once he fell, the British granted independence to the new republic of Guyana.
For the next 20 years the country was governed by Forbes Burnham -- "as the British described him, an opportunist, racist and demagogue intent only on personal power," to quote from "A Thousand Days." He held power through force and fraud until his death in 1985.
He ran up a foreign debt of more than $2 billion, a sum more than five times Guyana's gross domestic product. Interest on that debt now consumes 80 percent of the country's revenue and more than half of its foreign earnings.
"They made a mistake putting Burnham in," Janet Jagan said. "The regrettable part is that the country went backwards." One of the better-off countries in the region 30 years ago, Guyana today is among the poorest. Its principal export is people.
In 1992, in the country's first free elections in three decades, Dr. Jagan was elected President. In June of this year, unaware of the still-classified Kennedy-Jagan documents, the Clinton Administration prepared to nominate a new Ambassador to Guyana: William C. Doherty Jr., executive director of the American Institute for Free Labor Development.
"I was flabbergasted," President Jagan said. "We let it be known that we were not happy." His unhappiness derailed plans to nominate Mr. Doherty, who has declined several requests for an interview.
Dr. Jagan said the documents about the plot against him should be published, and he laughed at the idea that they might anger him or embarrass the United States.
"Everybody in Guyana knows what happened," he said. "I don't understand why they should be kept secret. I'm not going to use these documents to blackmail the United States. Maybe President Clinton doesn't know our history, but the people who advise him should at least know their own history."
The law demands the declassification of Government papers after 30 years, unless they compromise national security secrets. Dozens of Kennedy Administration documents on British Guiana remain locked away, and the State Department and the C.I.A. say they should stay that way.
Another volume dealing with Japan is in limbo, because it details the Kennedy Administration's secret support for Japanese conservatives, Government officials said. If either set is blocked, it would a first. No full volume of the State Department's foreign policy documents has ever been withheld because of Government secrecy.
Mr. Schlesinger, whose "Thousand Days" offers the best-known account of the Kennedy-Jagan encounter -- an account that he now acknowledges is incomplete -- said the documents should be released, so history can be revised.
"We misunderstood the whole struggle down there," Mr. Schlesinger said. "He wasn't a Communist. The British thought we were overreacting, and indeed we were. The C.I.A. decided this was some great menace, and they got the bit between their teeth. But even if British Guiana had gone Communist, it's hard to see how it would be a threat."
The full story, he said, proved the truth of Oscar Wilde's witticism: "The one duty we owe to history is to rewrite it."

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE VOTERS;
Campaigns' Tenor Disappoints Black Voters

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29

 BODY:
T. J. Smith is a lifelong resident of west Philadelphia who eagerly voted for Bill Clinton in 1992, thinking a new administration would bring him a better job and a safer neighborhood. But he is still doing odd jobs, and Mr. Smith now fears that he and his wife will be unable to provide properly for their first child, due in May.
Disappointed in President Clinton and put off by hostile television commercials in which the statewide candidates seem to talk about nothing but locking up criminals, Mr. Smith and his wife, Bernadette, said they would not vote this year. And they complained that no one was trying to change their minds. The politicians, they say, are more interested in courting white middle-class voters than blacks like them. 
 "It took us black people so long to get to vote," said Mr. Smith, who is 29. "Now, they're making us not want to vote."
It is a tale heard from black voters around the country -- and one that spells trouble for Democrats counting on a respectable black turnout to win several closely contested races for Federal, state and local offices.
Here in Pennsylvania, where Senator Harris Wofford, a Democrat, is struggling to fight off Representative Rick Santorum, a Republican, backing from black voters could make the difference. That is also the case in several other tight contests, including the race in Virginia of Senator Charles S. Robb, a Democrat, against Oliver L. North, a Republican, and battles for the Senate or governorships in California, Georgia, Massachusetts, Michigan, Missouri, New Jersey, New York and Ohio.
If this is the season of voter discontent, it is particularly true among black voters, who have long been the most dependable Democratic partisans, casting 82 percent of their ballots for Mr. Clinton in 1992, and 89 percent for Democratic House candidates that year.
But registered black voters traditionally go to the polls less frequently than whites. In the 1990 Congressional election, 39 percent of registered blacks voted, compared with nearly 49 percent of whites, according to the Census Bureau.
Though black voters are not about to defect to the Republican Party, many say that as they watch their neighborhoods fall into neglect, they have no patience for the new tough lines from Democrats on crime and welfare, which many interpret as anti-black.
"All I hear is these Democratic candidates talking about the crime bill," said Chris Williams, 46, an iron worker here. "But why do they talk about just building jails? Why don't they talk about building schools? That's not asking a lot."
But unlike other loyal Democrats, many blacks said in interviews that they had not soured on Mr. Clinton and gave him credit for intervening in Haiti and for trying on issues like health care.
Still, their bottom line was that Washington seemed to have done little to help them. And they said that they felt neglected and that Democratic candidates were not even making the effort to get them to vote.
"What politicians offer blacks is no good to us," said Willie A. Parham, a 25-year-old maintenance worker in Richmond who, after steadily voting for years, has no interest in the elections this year. "It's like the Janet Jackson song, 'What Have You Done For Me Lately?' " He said that he lost faith in the system when the Government refused to pay for burials after a mass slaying in a local housing project.
In Cleveland, Teralawanda Aron, 24, a market researcher, said she was fed up with Democrats who did not seem to care about crime in the inner cities. "Every election we always come up with the short end of the deal," she said. "In Cleveland, you can walk down the street and get robbed, and nobody will say anything; the police won't stop or anything."
Black voters in Georgia are so disillusioned with Gov. Zell Miller that some, like Joe Beasley, southeast director for the Rainbow Coalition, said they would probably vote for the Republican, Guy Millner. "We are ready to cast our lot with the devil," Mr. Beasley told The Atlanta Journal and Constitution.
And Mario Morrow, a political consultant in Detroit, put it this way: "You get to the point where some African-Americans say, why bother, unless there's some candidate so offensive they just have to vote against."
The sense that Democrats have not done enough to court black voters is well founded. After an intense battle with the Democratic National Committee, the White House prevailed last week and decided that several hundred thousand dollars for radio advertisements that were to be narrowly aimed at black and Hispanic voters should instead go to an effort to reach a broader audience with television commercials attacking the Republican Party's "Contract With America."
Some Democratic Party officials argued that it was a serious mistake to ignore these minority voters. But Tony Coelho, dispatched by the White House as a senior adviser to the party, said it would do no good to focus too narrowly on one or two voting groups when all Democratic voters of all demographic groups were inclined to stay home.
"The wind was so strong against us that we had to do something to calm it down," Mr. Coelho said. "It doesn't do you any good just to target certain areas if the gale winds are blowing because minority areas are just like any other areas -- they are impacted by national psychological moods."
Jesse Jackson, the two-time Presidential candidate who is mulling over challenging Mr. Clinton for the Democratic nomination in 1996, is nevertheless traveling from city to city this week and next week encouraging black voters to participate this year. The problem, he said, is that Democrats have become too caught up in trying to look tough on crime and should instead highlight the Democratic achievements that would give hope to the inner cities -- and the voters there.
"The crime message is being oversold," Mr. Jackson said. "The assumption is that Americans are so petrified of crime that they cannot think about the earned income tax credit to help people work their way out of poverty, or the legitimate struggle for a health care bill, or that the deficit is down and the market's up."
The second part of Mr. Jackson's message is to scare blacks into voting -- a tactic that some local politicians are trying here. In a radio commercial for a candidate for state Senate, broadcast today on a popular black radio station here, the announcer warned, "If we want to stop the Republicans from abusing our families and ignoring our community, then we've got to come out and vote on Tuesday, Nov. 8, and vote Democrat."
David A. Bositis, a senior analyst at the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, which examines issues facing blacks, said that in several states there might be a replay of what happened last year when former Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey took for granted that he would win strong support from black voters and stressed a centrist Democratic campaign message. He lost. The same thing happened to former Gov. James Blanchard of Michigan, who lost by one percentage point four years ago to Gov. John Engler, who is running again this year.
"Florio has one of the absolute best records of any Governor in the country with policies relating to black people," Mr. Bositis said. "Yet he ran as a 'New Democrat' and did nothing to court the black vote. And right now, the Democrats aren't going after the black votes. Their message is aimed almost entirely, exclusively at the white vote."
Kevin Gray, a Democratic organizer in Columbia, S.C., said the problem was compounded by the disarray among national black leaders, like the upheaval at the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. "With the civil rights leadership under attack," he said, "there's no organizing, no overwhelming reason why people should be excited."
In Pennsylvania, Senator Wofford has an impeccable record on civil rights and was a confidant of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. He was also the catalyst for the debate over a new health care system that so many black voters say they want.
Yet even Mr. Wofford has failed to energize black voters in his race against Mr. Santorum. "People want to know what these candidates will do for them," said Marian Tasco, a City Councilwoman here since 1988. "Why should they vote for Wofford over Santorum? It's got to mean something to the person who lives on Fayette Street, mean something for their lives."
Indeed, in a series of interviews here in west Philadelphia, where paint is peeling off the doors of buildings and drug addicts seem more prevalent than in the past, several residents complained that Mr. Wofford had done little campaigning in their neighborhoods. And they said that whatever he had done, they had not felt the benefits.
"He's been a little too quiet, he hasn't done enough," Mr. Williams, the iron worker, said of Mr. Wofford. "I'm going to hold my nose and vote for him because a vote is all I have."
Gordon Brown, a volunteer who was raking leaves at the Lombard Central Presbyterian Church but who does not have a paying job, said, "The thing I respect Clinton for is that he tried to get into the churches, the community." As for Mr. Wofford and other Democrats, like Mark S. Singel, the lieutenant Governor who is running for Governor, he said: "I don't see them in the neighborhoods."
As she was buying a 25-cent pretzel from a street vendor, Renee Harris, a 26-year-old service representative at an auto repair shop, was surprised anyone would ask her if she would vote. "Am I going to vote? Honestly? No," she said. "The politicians are ignoring the black community."
J. G. Kirk, a 69-year-old retired Army maintenance worker, was one of many residents who ticked off how much it cost the Government to jail a prisoner for a year. He said the money could be better spent if it were sent directly to communities so they could improve conditions from the bottom up. "We've got a three-ring circus here: suburbia, the Main Line and the ghetto," he said on the steps to his walk-up apartment, separating his mail into piles. "They should drop $20 million in each place."
Asked what it would take to get him to the polls on Nov. 8, Mr. Smith, the father-to-be, said the answer was easy: "The main issue is getting us jobs so people don't have to do crime. I'd like to hear from the politicians, 'We're not doing it for ourselves but for you guys.' "

HEADLINE: Despite Critics, Dairy Farmers Increase Use of a Growth Hormone In Cows

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: VOGEL CENTER, Mich., Oct. 29

 BODY:
Despite consumer wariness about milk produced by cows injected with a genetically engineered hormone, thousands of dairy farmers across the country are adopting the new drug to increase production in their cows.
The drug's manufacturer, the Monsanto Company, estimates that 7 percent of the nation's roughly 150,000 dairy farmers are using the drug and says it has been satisfied with sales. 
 But Jeremy Rifkin, president of the Pure Food Campaign in Washington and a critic of biotechnology, noted that more than 90 percent of dairy farmers were not using the hormone, which he cited as evidence of the effectiveness of the national boycott that his group is leading of milk produced with the drug.
Both Monsanto and Mr. Rifkin said there had been scattered reports from New York, Florida and Michigan of significant problems with cows injected with the hormone, including severe udder infections and deaths, that some farmers attributed to the drug.
The drug, bovine somatotropin, or BST, went on sale in early February. A nearly exact copy of a cow's natural growth hormone, it is produced by inserting a gene from a cow into the genetic code of bacteria that reproduce rapidly.
The drug, injected twice monthly at the base of a cow's tail, is designed to increase milk production 5 percent to 20 percent.
BST is the first economically important product of genetic engineering to be widely used on American farms and has drawn protests and sharp attacks from critics. Some of the nation's largest supermarket chains and dairy cooperatives have refused to buy dairy products from cows treated with the drug.
Consumers Union, publisher of Consumer Reports magazine, said the drug was a threat to the health of people and cows, a view disputed by the Food and Drug Administration. Opponents in the farm community said that by increasing milk supplies, the drug would lower prices and put thousands of family-owned dairy farms out of business. And last spring, several Congressmen asserted that the drug's approval might have been improperly influenced by three officials at the F.D.A. who were closely allied with Monsanto.
After investigating the F.D.A.'s work on reviewing and approving BST, the General Accounting Office released a report on Friday that cleared the three officials of those claims and said their work had met Government ethics standards.
Never before has a new farm technology attracted such attention at its outset, and even farmers who use BST are concerned that it carries a stigma.
"More and more farmers around here are using it," said Jim Winkel, a 31-year-old dairy farmer in this tiny northern Michigan town. "They just aren't talking about it. You just are never sure where a person stands on the thing."
Last March, just weeks after BST went on sale, Mr. Winkel and his older brother, Jack, conducted a private test on 50 cows. The results were so encouraging that the Winkels said they now used BST in 150 of their 330 cows and had not experienced health problems in the herd.
"We figured that to make it pay, we had to increase milk production six pounds a day in the animals we treat," said Mr. Winkel, whose farm spans 1,100 acres here. "In our young heifers, the 2-year-old cows, we are getting seven pounds more a day. In our mature cows, we are getting 14 pounds more. Our herd average was 80 pounds of milk a day per cow last year. Now it's 85 to 90 pounds. So we're making money with it."
Monsanto says that in the six months after BST went on sale, some 10,000 dairy farmers tried the genetically engineered hormone. More than 800,000 of the nation's 9.5 million cows were treated with 6.8 million doses, the company said.
"The product is doing well," said Walter P. Hobgood, vice president of Monsanto's animal science division. "It's meeting our expectations, and our expectations were high. Our target for the year was to break even, and we are on track to do that."
Mr. Rifkin, president of the Washington group leading the national boycott of dairy products produced with the drug, said: "The real story is that Monsanto has launched the biggest sales promotion campaign of any drug in U.S. history, and it is not successful. The overwhelming majority of dairy farmers are not using it."
The Department of Agriculture said that the use of BST was the most important reason that milk production in September was 10.5 billion pounds, 3 percent more than in the same month last year. Higher production pushed prices down to an average of $12.70 per hundred pounds of milk, 10 cents lower than last year.
The department also said that farmers were generally cautious about adopting new technology, and that for 7 percent of dairy farmers to have accepted the hormone within the first six months of its introduction was a higher rate than they had expected.
Mark A. Kastel, a staff member with the Wisconsin Farmers Union, a group in Chippewa Falls that opposes the drug, said the lower prices were threatening small dairy farmers. Mr. Kastel said his group had also received more than 40 reports from farmers across the country who blamed BST for infections and other health problems in their herds.
John Shumway, a dairy producer from Lowville, N.Y., told the farmers group that he had stopped using BST and had been forced to sell 34 of his 200 cows because they had developed mastitis, a potentially severe udder infection. Charles Knight, a dairy farmer from Florida, reported similar problems.
Here in Michigan, Larry Siemen, a farmer from Harbor Beach, about 100 miles north of Detroit, reported that two of his cows had died after he used BST and that using the hormone had not significantly increased milk production.
Steve Schulte, a farmer who lives nearby, said one of his cows died in mid-March, eight days after receiving a third treatment with the drug. An autopsy revealed that the cow had died of an internal hemorrhage.
"I gave her the shots, and her milk production went up 50 percent," Mr. Schulte said. "She may have had a bit of a problem internally and all that extra production, it just burst something in there."
Monsanto said that in the first six months of sales, it received 95 reports from farmers who were having problems. The company said 36 cows treated with the drug had died, and 14 farmers had reported problems with mastitis.
Dr. Steve Sundlof, a veterinarian and Director of the F.D.A.'s Center for Veterinary Medicine, said his agency was monitoring the reports of problems but did not consider them worrisome. Mastitis is a common bacterial disease on dairy farms and is generally caused by inadequately cleaning milking equipment or other herd management problems, Dr. Sundlof said.
Jim O'Hara, the F.D.A's chief spokesman, added that the mortality rate of cows in modern herds is 1.5 percent per year and that 36 deaths reported among the hundreds of thousands of cows treated with BST was unusually low.
"We have a monitoring program in place that over time should tell us if there are any problems," said Dr. Sundlof. "The numbers we are receiving don't indicate a problem."
Dr. Simon Kenyon, an associate professor at the Purdue University School of Veterinary Medicine in West Lafayette, Ind., said that BST was being used on about 10 percent of Indiana's 2,500 dairy farms. Dr. Kenyon added that neither he nor Purdue's veterinary school accepted research funds from Monsanto.
"The use of BST requires that people pay attention," Dr. Kenyon said. "The condition of the cows is important. It's a new tool and like other tools that have come along in the dairy industry, it has to be managed to work effectively."

HEADLINE: Failure Calls Illinois City Home Turf

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill.

 BODY:
Here, in one of the United States' worst school districts, this is what children could expect this fall: Classes led by janitors or other students. An hour wasted in a gym every day because a math class had no teacher. Kindergarten classes with 50 children, and a hot-lunch choice of bologna or hot dogs.
Substandard schools were tolerated here for years, but this fall the the system completely broke down, leading the State of Illinois to take financial control of it on Oct. 20, as it had of City Hall several years ago. And if the takeover of the East St. Louis School District promised some relief, it also raised two questions: Does it take a total collapse, as occurred here, to be seen as educational malpractice? And will the solution go much beyond a return to the merely substandard? 
 Routine failure in this impoverished district has been accepted almost as a matter of course. These are schools, after all, where Gloria Dismuke, who teaches a class of fifth and sixth graders mixed together at Mandela Elementary School, had to pause when asked to recount any success stories.
She thinks of one girl who became her high school valedictorian and went on to a state college in Illinois. "We don't see too many of the boys, after they leave," she said. "But I know of one who finished high school and is working in two fast-food restaurants."
Whether the state can raise expectations is an open question. In assuming financial oversight of the schools here, the Illinois Board of Education approved a plan that would allow the district to rehire 41 teachers released a year ago in the midst of a financial crisis. It also clears the way for state oversight of a district long known for inadequate resources, financial mismanagement and nepotism and cronyism in hiring.
"What's happened this year hasn't been a disaster, or at least it's been a wonderful disaster," said Irl Solomon, who has taught for 30 years in the district. "It's finally making people take notice of what's happening here."
But for now, the takeover means no more money to fix broken furnaces, replace the missing sinks in the fetid bathrooms, repair the worn-out buildings or upgrade the lunch programs. In "Savage Inequalities," Jonathan Kozol's angry look at the way urban schools so often fail the poor, the East St. Louis district was Exhibit A.
And in the long term, some skeptics say, dealing with this year's crisis does not guarantee that any of the district's chronic problems will be solved.
"I think the district can do a lot more with what it has, so to that extent this is positive," said Thomas E. Kennedy 3d, a lawyer who has sued the district in the past on behalf of students and parents. "But what this does is get us back to square one, and square one is just no good."
Located on the Mississippi River flood plain just across the river from St. Louis, East St. Louis since World War II has gone from a bustling industrial community to a forlorn eyesore. The only new industry to locate here in years is a riverboat casino, the Casino Queen, but all of its tax revenue goes to the city and state, not to the schools. The schools, which have 14,000 students, have the poorest tax base per student and the highest property tax rate in the state.
The population of 40,000, half what it was in 1945, is virtually all black, and about two-thirds are on some form of public assistance. The city government, on the verge of its own collapse a few years back, is also being run with state oversight.
Problems in the schools themselves are nothing new. Mr. Kozol's book, which he researched from 1988 to 1990, portrays East St. Louis as a place where lead poisoning is endemic, where science laboratories are 30 to 50 years outdated, where teachers pay for their own supplies and schools were periodically closed because of raw sewage that overflowed into the buildings.
Amid mounting financial problems, the district last year laid off 114 teachers and 94 other employees and agreed not to replace 120 teachers who retired. Two years ago the district had about 1,000 teachers and now it has about 750. "We do not believe that the impact will be negative," the district said into a memorandum to the state.
But even here, the fallout became impossible to ignore. Special education teachers were shunted into regular classes, and their students left without the extra help they need. Classes of 40 or 50 students were common.
To walk the halls of schools like East St. Louis's decrepit Lansdowne Junior High, where students like Vanessa Wright spend an hour each day in the school gym doing nothing because their math class has no teacher and the din of shouting students produces an incessant cacophony, is to see a school in total chaos.
"We've always had problems, but this year the system just imploded," Mr. Solomon said. "That's the difference between now and other years."
Students and teachers went through eight weeks of such chaos before the Illinois Board of Education finally established a Financial Oversight Panel on Oct. 20 to monitor the district's finances. In the middle of the uproar, the district and the state uncovered more than $2 million in extra money that had been lost to accounting errors, including retirement allocations that were entered twice in the district records.
Almost everyone agrees that aside from the poverty and dislocation in the community, there have been two main problems in the district.
One is the level of financing. The state provides $51 million of the district's $67 million education budget, bringing total per capita spending in the district to $5,775, slightly above the state average. But with so many impoverished students needing extra help and aging, decrepit buildings, few discount the need for more money.
The other is management. Almost everyone familiar with the district agrees it has been horribly mismanaged over the years, with contracts and jobs apportioned to friends or relatives of school board members.
The state oversight promises to address the most glaring management issues. And Joseph A. Spagnolo, the Illinois Superintendent for Education, said the oversight panel would likely request emergency state financing to deal with what he calls "the health and life-safety issues" in the school district.
But he and others say that while the system in East St. Louis finally collapsed this year, the problems differed more in degree than in kind from what has happened over the years in East St. Louis and in other poor school districts, like Jersey City and Paterson, which were taken over by New Jersey.
Indeed, success has always had a different meaning here than in healthier districts.
"The one thing my teen-agers look forward to in the summer is to live, to make it, to be alive," said Diane Sonneman, who runs a tutoring and recreation program through the Griffin Center at a local public housing complex. "When you have kids with that sort of mentality, and you send them to schools that don't expect them to be on time, to do homework, to bring books to class, you're just perpetuating the cycle of failure."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Students in East St. Louis, Ill., leaving Lansdowne Junior High School, one of the city's troubled schools where students in a math class spend the class time amid shouting students in the gym because they have no teacher. The state has taken over the schools because of financial difficulties. (Bill Stover for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Wave of Migration Is Altering East Timor

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 29

 BODY:
The exiled leader of an independence movement in East Timor, Jose Ramos-Horta, said on Friday that growing numbers of non-Timorese migrants were changing the character of the territory, which Indonesia annexed by force in 1975.
Mr. Ramos-Horta, the civilian face of the guerrilla movement Fretilin, which continues to wage a low-level war in East Timor, said that as many as 1,000 Indonesians from other islands in the huge archipelago are arriving each week. He said that the numbers are larger than at any time in the past. 
 "They have taken over the best land, the best jobs, even the small shops in the streets," Mr. Ramos-Horta said in an interview here, where he has been lobbying for nearly two decades from his base in Europe.
"In public service jobs only 3 out of 10 is Timorese. In the streets, selling in the markets, the average we estimate is one Timorese for nine Indonesians."
Indonesian officials say that the influx of settlers in East Timor is not part of the controlled program of "transmigration," which moves people from the most populated islands to less dense ones. They say that since East Timor was opened in 1989 to other Indonesians, people have flocked there for a better life.
Mr. Ramos-Horta said that trade in East Timor's resources -- marble, coffee, sandalwood and oil -- is dominated by non-Timorese.
East Timor, a Portuguese colony that was more or less abandoned by Lisbon after the 1974 revolution, has more than 800,000 people, a mix of indigenous people and descendants of Portuguese migrants and political prisoners banished there as punishment. Timorese still outnumber other Indonesians by at least five to one, Mr. Ramos-Horta said.
"But if the trend continues for the next 10 years, the Timorese will be completely outnumbered," he said.
The status of East Timor is one of several issues being raised by international rights organizations in advance of a visit by President Clinton to the Indonesian capital, Jakarta, for an Asian-Pacific economic meeting beginning on Nov. 14.
Talks between Indonesians and Timorese at several levels have begun to make some headway, but rights groups want to sustain pressure on President Suharto.
"The Indonesians have tried to solve the problem by force and that hasn't worked," said John A. Bresnan, director of the East Asian Institute at Columbia University and the author of "Managing Indonesia." "Now the only solution left is a political one."
East Timor is largely a foreign policy problem for Indonesia, a country of about 200 million people trying to play a more prominent role in international affairs.
Mr. Bresnan said discussions on the future of East Timor were going on through a variety of channels in Indonesia, with the encouragement of the United States, which has urged the Indonesians to reduce their huge military presence in the disputed territory.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE MIDWEST;
In 2 Bellwether States, Republicans See the Chance to Relive a Landslide

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 29

 BODY:
Michigan Republicans still talk about 1966. George Romney won a third term as Governor, Bob Griffin was elected to the Senate, beating former Gov. G. Mennen Williams, five incumbent Democrats in the House were ousted, and Republicans captured both houses of the state legislature.
"The year the elephants got loose," an old party retainer calls it. 
 This could be that kind of year, local politicians believe, not only here but also in Ohio. And the prospect of a Republican sweep in these neighboring Rust Belt states, noted for their ticket-splitting, watched since the Civil War as bellwethers of Middle America, gives a sense of the dangers facing Democrats across the nation.
The closest major contest in the region, now likely to be decided in the final week, is the race for the United States Senate seat being vacated by Donald W. Riegle Jr., a Michigan Democrat who is retiring. For more than three months now, Representative Bob Carr, a Democrat, and Spencer Abraham, a Republican, have been struggling for dominance, but the polls have consistently shown a virtual dead heat, with first one man, then the other holding an inconclusive lead of three to five percentage points.
Mr. Carr led with 39 percent in the most recent survey, compared with Mr. Abraham's 34 percent. Minor-party candidates drew 13 percent, and 14 percent were undecided. The poll, taken by Michigan State University from Oct. 6 to Oct. 24, covered 1,001 likely voters and had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3.1 percentage points, meaning that either of the two might actually be ahead.
With 10 campaign days left, the Republican Governors in both states, John Engler of Michigan and George V. Voinovich of Ohio, appear to be coasting to re-election (as do Jim Edgar in Illinois and Tommy G. Thompson in Wisconsin, two other states in the industrial Midwest). Lieut. Gov. Michael DeWine, also a Republican, seems set to take the open Senate seat in Ohio, which Howard M. Metzenbaum, the retiring Democrat, had hoped to hand over to his son-in-law, Joel Hyatt.
Republicans have mounted forceful, well-financed challenges in no less than five House races in both Michigan and Ohio, all in districts now held by Democrats; if they were to win them all, it would give them a quarter of the net gain of 40 seats that they need to control the House for the first time since President Dwight D. Eisenhower's first term.
Some Democrats see last-minute signs that the threat is receding. Tim Hagan, a commissioner in Cuyahoga County, Ohio, said that "this won't be 1966, because toward the bottom of the ticket, our people have finally raised some money and started to shake the baleful effect of the weaker candidates above them." Others take hope from the recent improvement in President Clinton's ratings, his foreign-policy successes and encouraging reports on the economy.
In a year of anti-incumbent fever, Mr. Carr, a lanky 51-year-old, seems a vulnerable figure; he has been on Capitol Hill for nine terms, and he holds one of the classic pork-dispensing slots in Congress -- the chairmanship of the Transportation Subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee, which doles out dollars for roads and such. But David Rohde, the professor who oversees Michigan State University polls, said that by avoiding "the unremitting negativism" of most campaigns this year, Mr. Carr may have distanced himself from Washington a bit.
Mr. Abraham is ill-placed to campaign as an outsider. A former state party chairman, a onetime aide to former Vice President Dan Quayle and an unsuccessful candidate for chairman of the Republican National Committee last year, he has been portrayed by Mr. Carr as "a doctrinaire, down-the-line, playbook-following Republican back-room operative." In fact, though, Mr. Abraham is much less negative and less ideological than many Republican Senate candidates this year.
Visiting Focus Hope, a highly successful inner-city project to train minority youths for skilled factory jobs, the Republican drew distinctions between what the Federal Government could and could not do to aid such community efforts, rather than suggesting that Washington was useless in fighting poverty.
As the poll figures suggest, neither candidate has really caught on.
A bit stiff in manner to begin with, Mr. Abraham wore a pinstriped suit and black wingtips on his visit to Focus Hope, which immediately set him apart. He has also been hurt by campaign missteps, like an advertisement suggesting that Mr. Carr would receive millions of dollars, not thousands, from his Government pension. Backpedaling, Mr. Abraham pulled the commercial off the air for revision, but he refused in an interview to apply the word "wrong" to the original.
Mr. Carr has spent more time than he would like showing up at campaign events where the promised television cameras or crowds never materialized, most recently at the huge Fairlane Shopping Center in Dearborn on Friday morning.
Nor has the Clinton Administration helped him much. He was enraged, for example, when Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena said that the General Motors Corporation was more interested in sales than in safety, the day before the company's president, John F. Smith Jr., was to be host of a fund-raising event for Mr. Carr. Still angry, Mr. Carr commented today: "As far as I'm concerned, they ought to send him back to wherever he came from. What the hell does he think I am, a potted plant out here?"
Mr. Abraham, an affable 42-year-old, is doing his utmost to hitch his wagon to Governor Engler's star, speaking of the "Engler-Abraham ticket," planning joint campaign events and reminding a visitor that Mr. Engler served as best man in his wedding. Under Mr. Engler, he said, "Michigan has proved you can cut taxes and create jobs at the same time, and I want to take that message to Washington."
The Michigan House seat most likely to fall to the Republicans, experts in the state say, is that of Mr. Carr, which includes the capital city, Lansing.
Challenged two years ago by the wealthy owner of an auto customizing company, Dick Chrysler, Mr. Carr won by fewer than 4,000 votes. Mr. Chrysler is back this year, and in the changed political climate, with no incumbent to contend against, he has taken the lead, though he has been hit with legal troubles lately.
A pair of Democratic incumbents are threatened by candidates who gave them scares in 1992, a Democratic year. They are Dale E. Kildee, who represents a district including the auto-making cities of Flint and Pontiac, and Sander M. Levin, whose district includes parts of suburban Oakland and Macomb counties, which became famous in the 1970's and 1980's as the home of blue-collar Reagan Democrats. Mr. Kildee's opponent is Megan O'Neill, once a member of Mr. Bush's campaign staff. Mr. Levin, who is spending lavishly on television advertisements, unusual for a House member in an urban area, faces John Pappageorge, a retired Army colonel.
In Ohio, Representative David Mann, a Democrat who was surprise winner in 1992, is under assault for having supported the North American Free Trade Agreement, which is widely unpopular among Ohio trade unionists. In his struggle to hold onto his marginal Cincinnati district, Mr. Mann has done everything possible to distance himself from Mr. Clinton, asserting that, like his opponent, Steve Chabot, a former city councilman, the President "chose not to wear the uniform of this country."
Union members in Representative Tom Sawyer's district tried to punish him for backing Nafta by voting for a primary rival, which may have weakened him slightly. He and two other northern Ohio Democrats, Representatives Sherrod Brown of Lorain and Eric D. Fingerhut of Cleveland, all face county prosecutors in a year when crime is one of the Republicans' best issues.
In the end, turnout may decide not only the Carr-Abraham race but the close House contests as well. Robert Teeter, a campaign consultant based in Ann Arbor, Mich., who worked for George Bush in 1992, said his studies indicated that major sweeps like the Republicans' landslide in 1966 or the Democrats' in 1974 usually occurred when one party's bedrock supporters stayed home in large numbers.
Ed Sarpolus of EPIC-MRA, a polling firm in Lansing, said his surveys showed a sharp drop in the last two months in the number of voters planning to turn out on Nov. 8.
Apathy, anger and simple boredom with politics are certainly contributing to the falloff. But relative prosperity may be playing a role, too. The auto industry has finally bounced back, and Michigan's unemployment rate this year may well be lower than the national average for the first time since the 1960's.
Four years ago, Gov. James J. Blanchard, a Democrat, was unexpectedly beaten in his bid for re-election. Only 1.2 million Democratic votes were cast, compared with 1.8 million cast two years later for President Clinton. This year, all the elements of the old Democratic coalition -- mayors, black leaders, teachers, trade unions -- have united in a giant, computer-driven get-out-the-vote operation to try to overcome what Mr. Carr described as "a certain lethargy among those who should be backing us."
Mike Duggan, the deputy Wayne County executive, is running the operation.
"We know who those missing 600,000 people are, and we're going after them," he said. "If this thing works, we'll run three or four points ahead of the polls, and they'll be using our techniques nationally in '96. If not, nobody will ever speak to me again."

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE PRESIDENT;
Clinton Flies Back Home And Prepares To Campaign

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29

 BODY:
President Clinton returned to the White House this morning after a grueling trip to the Middle East and prepared to redirect his energies toward helping Democrats fend off heavy election losses.
Mr. Clinton said he believed that his four-day journey had speeded progress toward a wider peace in the region, and he pledged that the United States would play a central role in working toward that goal with Israel and its neighbors. 
 In an arrival ceremony at the White House, the President made no direct mention of election politics. But a Democratic Senator who accompanied him aboard Air Force One on an overnight flight from Saudi Arabia said Mr. Clinton had talked "quite a lot" about the party's prospects in crucial races around the country. The Senator, Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont, described Mr. Clinton as having been "very optimistic" about Democratic chances on Election Day, Nov. 8.
After a foreign trip so close to the elections, however, the President and his advisers were clearly eager to remind voters that he was working on problems at home as well.
"We've made a start in putting government on the side of ordinary Americans," Mr. Clinton declared at the White House ceremony, presenting an argument that he will take on the road next week in a final flurry of politicking on Democrats' behalf. "We must turn from the past and embrace the future."
Beginning with a trip to Pennsylvania on Monday, Mr. Clinton plans to campaign for eight straight days before the elections, a mission that will also take him to Michigan, New York, Iowa, California, Washington State and Minnesota.
Although many of his advisers said there had been more political benefit in his traveling to the Middle East than in staying home, even before the President returned they began calling attention to what they still regard as his strongest card: the health of the economy.
Senior White House officials said they found nothing particularly unusual in their having urged Mr. Clinton to deliver, in the setting of the Emir's palace in Kuwait on Friday, a statement in which he welcomed the news that the American economy continued to grow robustly, and with subdued inflation, in the third quarter. "That's just something you can't pass up, wherever you might be," one senior aide said.
Asked at that session whether distance had left him disengaged from what was going on at home, Mr. Clinton quickly replied, "I haven't been gone long enough to be unplugged."
Israeli officials have expressed disappointment that the boldest move made by Mr. Clinton on his journey -- his visit to Syria, where no American President had traveled for 20 years -- did not do more to advance the peace process in the Middle East. And American officials have conceded that they expected Syria's President, Hafez al-Assad, to make a stronger public gesture of willingness to move toward a peace-for-land deal with Israel.
This morning Mr. Clinton called attention first to the peace treaty between Israel and Jordan that was signed on Wednesday, saying it was "a crucial step on the road to a comprehensive peace." But he also cast the Administration's future in the peace process as critical, since Arabs and Israelis alike would "look to America" for guidance and reassurance.
"The United States," he declared, "will continue to stand shoulder to shoulder with those who seek the peace, with those who take risks for peace, with those who stand up for change in the face of terrorists and extremists who seek to destroy the peace by killing the innocent."
On his last stop in the region, late Friday night, Mr. Clinton won support from King Fahd of Saudi Arabia. In a communique, the two leaders called for "widening the circle of peacemakers" in the Middle East, an apparent reference to efforts to persuade Syria and Israel to strike a bargain with each other.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Let's Play Two: Expansion and Creation

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Baseball will have a doubleheader Tuesday. That's not Major League Baseball. Major League Baseball, which hasn't played a real game since Aug. 11, will play only one of the games. That's the one in Chicago. The other game, baseball with a small "b," is scheduled for New York.
Against the backdrop of what on that day will be an 82-day-old strike in Major League Baseball, a committee of some of the employers of the striking players will listen in Chicago to presentations from four groups seeking expansion franchises for three areas that aren't in the major leagues. 
 Expansion will be the theme of the baseball -- small "b" -- game in New York, too. Instead of seeking to add new teams to an old structure, the men who step to the plate in this game will seek to add a new structure to an old game. They will be the founders of the United Baseball League (finally, a capital "B," which heretofore Major League Baseball had claimed for itself).
For now, the game in Chicago may turn out to be exactly that, a game. Unless circumstances prompt a change of strategy, Major League Baseball will not vote on expansion until it has settled its labor dispute with its players. That stance would leave Phoenix; St. Petersburg-Tampa, Fla., and northern Virginia waiting, perhaps in vain.
The New York game also could turn out to be only a game -- rival professional sports leagues have not fared well generally -- but the serious nature of the United Baseball League's effort is seen instantly in the presence of Richard Moss.
A lawyer who has been involved, albeit on the players' side, in Major League Baseball longer than all of its owners except Gene Autry, Moss won landmark cases as general counsel of the Players Association, then became one of the best-known player agents.
What the new league announces Tuesday remains to be seen, but it has an impetus that upstart leagues before it in other sports did not have -- a climate in Major League Baseball that has created mistrust and animosity and a desire in the hearts of some players, the number unknown, to start over.
While the United Baseball League offers that new, even if unpredictable, enterprise, Major League Baseball continues to wallow in a morass.
The owners soon will present the players with a new proposal. They have to because the drastic change in economics, the result of the strike, prevents them from implementing the proposal they made last June 14. The new proposal will be less attractive to the players than the existing one because, among other things, it no longer will guarantee them $1 billion of the owners' revenue for their salaries and other costs.
This anticipated scenario would ensue: the owners will negotiate the new proposal to death. Depending on how much of a game the union wants to make of it, prolonging the bargaining to delay the owners' next move as long as possible, the proposal will keep the recently appointed mediator, Bill Usery Jr., earning his $120,000-a-month fee.
Eventually, perhaps in late November or early December, the new proposal will run its course, and so will Usery. At that time, the owners will declare an impasse in negotiations and implement their salary cap.
Management's quick acceptance and embrace of the mediation effort by Usery seemed curious, but the owners may have concluded that Usery would give them the shield they need to get to impasse through ostensible good-faith bargaining. Had they tried the impasse gambit without Usery's involvement, they would have run the risk of being found to have negotiated in bad faith.
Meanwhile, the skirmishes rage. Eleven players file for free agency and are rejected because, the clubs say, they lack sufficient service time. Mike Stanley files for free agency on the grounds that the Yankees exercised the option in his contract prematurely, and the clubs reject him.
Grievance hearings before a baseball arbitrator and impasse hearings before the National Labor Relations Board will take the place of the games missed in the final 52 days of the regular season and the 28 days of the post-season.
Next spring the owners plan to open their Florida and Arizona facilities, hoping to lure players disenchanted with the strike into training camps. But when the dispute is settled and the striking players return to work, the clubs will probably jettison those who went back early. Can't have team unity undermined.
Meanwhile, St. Petersburg-Tampa will spurn the United Baseball League and continue to wait, perhaps in vain, for a Major League Baseball franchise that may not get there in this century.
 
Steinbrenner's Generosity
 Unbelievable. Shocking. A mind-blower.
Those were some of the words used by people on management side upon hearing that George Steinbrenner gave Paul O'Neill a $2.2 million signing bonus, $1.2 million of it payable Dec. 15, as part of a new four-year contract worth $19 million. The words they surely used privately in conversations with one another were not as mild.
If the American League's leading hitter in this year's strike-shortened season has encountered financial difficulties with the loss of $994,535.51 in pay, that signing bonus payment will help him buy more than a few Christmas presents.
"With respect to signing bonuses," club lawyers wrote in a memo to their clients less than two weeks ago, "clubs are free to make decisions in their own individual interest. Clubs should keep in mind the payment of the bonus amounts to a decision by the club to help fund the continuing players strike. Moreover you should be aware employers are generally entitled to avoid taking action that amounts to funding of a strike against themselves."
But Steinbrenner long has been a benevolent chap, sending needy kids to college, buying lights for baseball fields and giving money to amateur athletes for training. Funding a players' strike fits right in.
 
They Hardly Knew Ye
 Free agents can begin signing with anyone today, but four free agents would have to re-sign with their last teams to play for them for the first time.
Norm Charlton, whom Philadelphia acquired from Seattle last winter, was hurt all season and didn't play for the Phillies. The other three were traded or sold during the strike -- Dave Winfield from Minnesota to Cleveland, Scott Bankhead from Boston to the Yankees and Paul Gibson from the Yankees to Milwaukee.
 
Just Another M.V.P.
 When Houston's Jeff Bagwell learned last week that he had been named the National League most valuable player, he was attending his team's Fall Frolic at the Pine Valley Golf Club in New Jersey, an annual gathering of present and former members of the Astros hosted by the team's former owner, John McMullen.
Returning from the telephone call that informed him of his award, Bagwell quickly had it put in perspective.
"He came in," McMullen said, "and we said, 'That's O.K., Jeff, but Yogi has three and Joe has two. Yours is only the sixth here.' "
Yogi Berra, a former Astros coach and a friend of McMullen, and Joe Morgan, a former second baseman with Houston, were among the other guests.
Bagwell is one of McMullen's legacies in Houston. The Astros' acquisition of him for relief pitcher Larry Andersen in 1990 is one of the great trades ever.
"The Red Sox had that other kid they thought was going to be better at third," McMullen said, referring to Scott Cooper. "Bagwell was the one they offered and I said take him. My theory is I trade the old guys for young guys. In Houston they castrated me for trading a veteran pitcher for an untried kid. The trade was criticized. People forget that."
No one is critical now.
 
A Game 7 Highlight Reel
 Tonight could have been the seventh game of the World Series. Maybe it would have produced the kind of Game 7 like in 1991, when Jack Morris pitched 10 shutout innings for Minnesota; or in 1962, when Willie McCovey's line drive was caught by Bobby Richardson, or in 1960, when Bill Mazeroski hit the decisive home run.
Many people believe the sixth game of the 1975 World Series, which Carlton Fisk won for Boston with a 12th-inning home run, was the greatest Series game ever. Others opt for the seventh game in 1960, when Mazeroski's ninth-inning shot cleared the left-field fence at Forbes Field in Pittsburgh as the Yankees' Yogi Berra watched helplessly.
Berra, who watched the Fisk game on television, was asked his opinion.
"It was exciting when Fisk hit the home run," Berra said, "but it wasn't too exciting with that other guy hitting the home run against us."
