LENGTH: 1081 words

HEADLINE: Governor Cuomo, Beyond a Doubt

 BODY:
Mario Cuomo seems always to have been a creature of expectations -- his own and those that others have conferred upon him. Ever since his incandescent speech to the 1984 Democratic National Convention, people have spoken of him in terms of what "could be" and, later, of what "might have been." He might have been President of the United States. He surely could have been a justice of the Supreme Court. Although it is not too late for the Court, there seems only one certain way for him to claim an exalted place in the history books. That is to have a memorably successful fourth term.
This newspaper thinks he can do that. We not only recommend his re-election; we urge it as essential to New York's progress. We are mindful of his shortcomings and we are sometimes annoyed by the gap between the Cuomo rhetoric and the Cuomo reality. It is also true that New York has lagged behind a nationwide economic recovery. We nevertheless believe that Mr. Cuomo towers above his opponents. His intellect is formidable, his values sound, his understanding of the state's complex needs and opportunities unmatched. 
 In addition to Mr. Cuomo's clear advantage in leadership capacity, there is another overarching reason for a fourth term. This election is as much about the future of the city as it is about the state as a whole. As Mayor Rudolph Giuliani observed in explaining his decision to endorse Mr. Cuomo over a fellow Republican, George Pataki, the Governor is certain to be far more sympathetic to the city's huge burdens than Mr. Pataki or the Independence Fusion Party candidate, B. Thomas Golisano.
Mr. Pataki is no slouch. He is the first plausible, serious Republican contender since Lewis Lehrman, the man Mr. Cuomo beat in his first gubernatorial race in 1982. He and Mr. Golisano, a self-made businessman, both believe that New York suffers from an inefficient government. Their diagnosis of the state's ills contains a lot of uncomfortable truths, some of which Mr. Cuomo concedes.
Mr. Pataki's prescriptions, however, are simplistic and alarmingly indifferent to the needs of the cities, especially New York. Mr. Cuomo puts it bluntly and Mr. Giuliani agrees: "If you cut $7 billion out of the state budget, you kill the city." Mr. Pataki is a member of that large and growing army of manipulative politicians wheedling votes with the seductive message that the only things standing between us and happiness are criminals and high taxes. Ergo: fry the criminals, lower the taxes.
Even if this page could ignore Mr. Pataki's relentless campaign for the death penalty -- something Mr. Cuomo has courageously opposed at considerable political cost -- it cannot buy his economic program. He proposes to cut taxes by 25 percent over four years and pay for those cuts through what he confidently describes as normal revenue growth and painless belt-tightening in programs like welfare and Medicaid.
Most economists, not to mention Mr. Giuliani, think this is poppycock. What Mr. Pataki proposes will not really cut the overall tax burden. It will shift the cost of essential services to cities and counties and require them to levy new taxes to pay for them. Mr. Giuliani recognized the trickery of the Pataki plan, and so should every responsible voter.
Mr. Pataki's statewide experience is limited and that raises the question of how he got where he is. The answer is not pleasant. He is the political creation of Senator Alfonse D'Amato. The Senator stage-managed his nomination, raised his campaign funds and provided his staff. Mr. D'Amato has gone into hiding now because he was dragging his protege down in the polls. But knowledgeable Republicans know that a vote for Mr. Pataki is a vote for the D'Amato machine. That is why moderate Republicans like State Senator Ralph Marino are keeping Mr. Pataki at arm's length. He is not, to use the Mayor's cutting phrase, "his own man."
As all three candidates have acknowledged, New Yorkers are overtaxed and overregulated. Despite Mr. Cuomo's largely uncelebrated efforts to ease the tax burden and cut red tape, New York's combined state and local tax burden is the nation's heaviest after Alaska. The government bureaucracy is shamefully bloated. New businesses do not want to come here and a lot of old businesses want to leave. The economic turnaround that saw the nation as a whole gain 5.5 million jobs also saw New York lose jobs.
Mr. Pataki's fiscal shell game is not the answer to these problems. Still, there is a huge task ahead and what that task will require is total commitment. For Mr. Cuomo, that means the days of playing Hamlet on the Hudson must end. He must swear off his reflexive tendency to attribute New York's ills to an obdurate State Senate, a stubborn economy, Reaganomics, crack and AIDS and heaven only knows what else. He will have to complain less and work harder at the nitty-gritty of government if he seriously wishes to be remembered as being as good at governing as he is at campaigning.
This contest has already been a humbling experience for Mr. Cuomo. At the very least it should have taught him that what New Yorkers really want -- indeed desperately need -- are results. That involves a level of risk-taking that Mario Cuomo has not so far achieved but which we firmly believe he is capable of reaching if he can muster the legislative concentration and stamina to match his intelligence and compassion.
This brings us to the unique resource that Mr. Cuomo represents for New York and the nation. His critics have tried to depict him as liberalism's last buffalo. Indeed, Mr. Cuomo's skills as a communicator make him an easy target when his achievements fail to live up to the promise of his rhetoric. But the fact is that Mr. Cuomo's compassion, his good heart and hard head, his rootedness in our forebears' struggle against poverty and ignorance are values that government needs.
New York voters have a unique opportunity to weld Mr. Cuomo's lofty ambitions to practical politics. His re-election will create a powerful Cuomo-Giuliani axis that will strengthen government in New York City and Albany. These two men have made a public compact to work together. Given the chance, they can create a mold-breaking bipartisanship that invigorates New York while it helps American politics through a poisonous period.
As a matter of practicality, philosophy and, yes, passion for good government, Mario Cuomo deserves re-election. He is the class of the field.

HEADLINE: Journal;
The Final Curtain?

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
You know Broadway is dead as a showcase for American drama when a) there are no new plays running there; b) Neil Simon announces he would rather be in Greenwich Village; c) New York's Attorney General is closing in on its box offices, or d) the theater industry's leaders are fighting in public, like passengers on the Titanic shoving each other out of the lifeboats.
The answer is, e) all of the above. 
 Right now, Broadway is down to two plays -- the sadly inexorable result of production costs so high that only musical spectacles with huge audiences can afford them. Facing this reality, Mr. Simon, the street's most commercially successful writer for 30 years, is defecting with his newest comedy to a small theater Off Broadway. Attorney General G. Oliver Koppell, meanwhile, plans to finish out his term with a bang: his full-speed-ahead ticket-scalping investigation may soon explain why the public can never buy good seats for the few shows that are running. And Emanuel Azenberg, Mr. Simon's producer, told a Times reporter he had declared "war" on Gerald Schoenfeld of the Shubert Organization, the all-powerful Broadway landlord.
Should Mr. Simon put all these doings in a farce, he might have his biggest hit since "The Odd Couple."
But that's precisely the problem. It is no longer possible to have a cat-or-chandelier-free hit on Broadway -- a non-musical play that makes a profit for its investors -- because the investment cannot be recouped, no matter how astronomic the ticket price. Even "Angels in America," the most acclaimed drama of the last decade, will be in the red when it closes early next year, according to one of its producers, despite a 20-month Broadway run that "Long Day's Journey Into Night" would have envied.
Only lunatics would produce plays on a street where "Angels" fears to tread. Which is not to say that good plays disappear: When Mr. Simon goes Off Broadway, he'll find Edward Albee, Sam Shepard and Terrence McNally among his neighbors. But some of the most beautiful theaters in the world -- all of them perfect for intimate dramas by such writers -- are on the brink of permanent obsolescence. No sooner has the long-defunct 42d Street reached the brink of redevelopment -- Disney's renovation of the New Amsterdam Theater should start this spring -- than the other theatrical blocks just to its north are going dark.
This is both an urban and cultural crisis. Yet the Broadway establishment's response is to deny that anything is wrong. Mr. Schoenfeld told Donald McNeil of The Times "a lot of producers" are bringing plays to Broadway, though he could only come up with a tiny list of mostly British imports.
In private, almost any major player in the theater will say the truth: Not only has the curtain fallen on the Broadway play, but nothing short of a complete overhaul of Broadway business practices from ground zero will bring it back. Mr. Azenberg unfairly blamed Mr. Schoenfeld for the entire mess, when in truth inefficient labor practices, greedy big-name talent and rising advertising costs are as much a part of the problem as high-handed management.
With the old-timers either in denial or combat, only newcomers can break the deadlock. One hopeful sign is a recent move by Rocco Landesman, the one Broadway theater operator under 70 and the only one who flatly concedes, "Unless we do something, there won't be a dramatic theater on Broadway."
Shortly after Jeffrey Katzenberg, David Geffen and Steven Spielberg announced their new Hollywood studio, Mr. Landesman, eyeing a theatrical link, phoned to set up a meeting. Even before he did, the Katzenberg trio, theater fans all, had talked seriously about adding theater to their studio's announced list of activities. What finally stopped them was in part a fatalism about Broadway economics, as experienced by Mr. Geffen when he co-produced with the Shuberts in the 1980's and by Mr. Katzenberg with Disney's "Beauty and the Beast."
But Mr. Geffen has been a vocal Landesman enthusiast since they worked together on "M. Butterfly," a rare dramatic hit of recent Broadway vintage. Should the persistent Mr. Landesman enlist the new studio's tough businessmen in his ambitions, he might not only light up some dark marquees but light a fire under a Broadway establishment that dozes and bickers even as its quarter-century-long epic of decline hurtles to its tragic end.

HEADLINE: Love the House -- But Can We Afford It?

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
BUYING a house concentrates the mind, and not least on matters of money. In the current housing market, the experience of recession appears to have led buyers into more conservative financial planning than their predecessors practiced a decade ago.
The recession retarded the pace of sales and frustrated the ability of many people to make long-term decisions on a house or a community or both. Slower sales and lower prices made it difficult -- and for many still do make it difficult -- to recover the cash applied to one purchase to make another. It even affected the attitudes of those who had never bought. 
 "People find they're stuck in their first house and that's scary to people who are in the market," said Lisa Rosenthal, who in May of last year moved into a house that she and her husband, David, bought in Montclair, N.J. "If you can't turn it over, you figure, 'Why bother?' "
But the Rosenthals, in their mid-30's, are among those who decided they were at a stage in life when it was necessary to bother about long-term stability. They skipped the starter-house phase -- in which a first-time buyer purchases a house with the intention of holding it only a few years before moving up to something bigger and better -- and bought the house in which they intend to stay indefinitely. They had been living for several years as renters in Little Neck, Queens.
They have joined the broad class of people bound by the invisible cord of concern over housing costs. What will it cost to own a house? Or, perhaps more to the point, how much housing cost is affordable?
Conversations with recent buyers suggest that many have thought deeply about it. Most seem to have tried to make conservative decisions about affordability. Buyers at the lower end of the income scale have in general stretched to make down payments and taken advantage of recent programs that make it possible for them to get mortgages with high loan-to-value ratios, sometimes with as little as 3 percent down.
But middle- to upper-middle-income buyers seem to be striving, often successfully, to hold down their housing debt as a percentage of their gross household income.
At a 9 percent interest rate, every additional $10,000 borrowed on a 30-year loan makes a difference of $80.47 a month, or $965.64 a year, in out-of-pocket (pre-tax-deduction) debt-payment costs. Many buyers try to work out their anticipated costs on an annual basis. The exercise serves to underscore the diversity of choice, financial and otherwise, available in the metropolitan area. They can save on commutation, but spend for what they perceive to be better schools. They can hold off on needed home improvements or go forward with them, at varying levels of thoroughness. They can buy more space or less, with older equipment and appliances or newer ones. And they can relate these costs to their annual income.
In the end, it develops that first-time buyers, the most likely to make minimum down payments and take the maximum loan the lender will grant, will be largely influenced by the debt-to-income ratios acceptable to mortgage lenders. On the second purchase, buyers have more leeway.
Lenders define housing costs as mortgage debt plus taxes and insurance, which for buyers will normally range between 28 percent and 33 percent of gross family income.
USUALLY, for loans up to $203,000, lenders use the debt-to-income guidelines set by the secondary mortgage market -- the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae) or the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation (Freddie Mac). These agencies buy loans up to that amount from banks or mortgage-servicing companies, which originate the loans, and then package them with other mortgages for resale in the securities markets.
The standard for these "conforming" loans is that with a 20 percent down payment, housing debt should not exceed 28 percent of household income (and total debt should not exceed 36 percent). With a larger down payment, and other "compensating factors" such as the borrower's savings, length of employment and credit record, the secondary market may accept a higher debt-to-income ratio. Various lenders have different programs adapted to these standards. Recent programs developed in the secondary market let first-time buyers and buyers in central cities have debt-to-income ratios of 33 percent to 38 percent, purchasing houses with low down payments.
Conforming loans accounted for about 64 percent of all home mortgage loans originated in the metropolitan area last year, according to DRI/McGraw Hill, the Lexington, Mass., economic research arm of McGraw-Hill Inc.
Despite the allowable ratios, many recent buyers, on average older than their predecessors of 10 years ago, seem eager to stay below lenders' limits. They appear to sales brokers to be more cautious and planning-minded that their predecessors.
"There's a higher proportion of trade-up buying these days than in the 80's and the trade-up buyers aren't leveraging as much with debt," said Susan Goldy, broker at ERA Susan Goldy & Company Realtors in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.
"The bulk of our buyers are buying well below their maximum buying power -- the exception being the lowest end of the market, where buyers are squeezing," said Marcia S. Levy, manager of the Montclair office of Burgdorff Realtors. "Very often in two-income families they are choosing to base the housing purchase on just one income."
"It used to be that the first house that people bought in this area was a co-op, and then they sold and bought a house," said Liz Lindsey, owner of Lindsey Real Estate in Mount Vernon, N.Y. "But because the co-op market has been on its side in the last five years, people will now rent and save money and skip over the co-op process and buy the house they are planning to stay in longer. They don't necessarily stay as long as they think they will, because their work takes them away."
And Ralph Artigliere, assistant vice president at Chemical Residential Mortgage Corporation in northern New Jersey, said that buyers were more worried than they were 10 years ago about how long their jobs will last. "We had a lot more aggressive buyers in the 80's than we have today," he said.
The median price of a resale house in the New York metropolitan area was $173,200 last year, according to the National Association of Realtors. Holding housing costs to 28 percent of gross income, a household earning $66,400 a year could afford the median-priced house, from the lender's standpoint. The income figure assumes a 20 percent down payment and a mortgage-interest rate of 9 percent for 30 years. It also assumes taxes of $4,000 a year and insurance costs of $1,200 a year. The taxes and the total interest payment on the mortgage are tax deductible; the amount of savings to the owner depends on the household's tax bracket.
These days buyers with strong credit records who can make a 20 percent down payment probably could find a loan with a ratio as high 40 percent, said Helene Wald, loan director at H-R Loan Representatives Inc. in Manhattan. "Some banks have gotten less conservative on the ratios," she said.
But cautious buyers, unsure of future income, don't necessarily take the highest-ratio loans. From their standpoint, "housing" expenses also imply the related costs of commutation, heating and utilities, car insurance, repair and maintenance obligations, grounds maintenance, possible day-care expenses and longer-term building-improvement requirements.
Some of these costs are related to location as much as to the house itself, and personal preferences will influence the level of spending. The price of the house, and the amount of debt accepted, obviously bear on the buyer's ability to handle other house-related costs.
Interviews with recent buyers of houses costing somewhat more than the $173,200 areawide median confirm that conservative attitude. They also shed light on how the diversity of local conditions and personal values, as well as income, affect the cost of home ownership.
In Mount Vernon, in lower Westchester County, for example, Philip C. Zach and his wife, Joanne, bought a spacious house on Pondfield Parkway in the higher-priced Auburn Manor section of the mixed-income city. They paid $445,000, using the proceeds from the $310,000 sale of a house in the Randall Manor section of Staten Island.
Mr. Zach, an agent with Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company in Manhattan, said that if they had bought in the more exclusive village of Bronxville less than half a mile away he would have paid perhaps double for a comparable house. "Based on family income, we underbought," Mrs. Zach said. "We found a lovely house that meets our needs, and now we have more disposable income to spend on other things."
Without much difficulty, they calculated the total annual expense of ownership (before tax deductions for mortgage interest and property tax) at around $36,000. They broke it down as follows: $26,000 for debt service and taxes; $1,400 for Mr. Zach's commuting by train to Manhattan; $2,200 for heating oil; $1,500 for electricity; $1,500 for a gas-heating system that handles an addition to the 3,500-square-foot house, built 12 years ago; $1,500 for landscaping and grounds maintenance (the plot is 100 by 140 feet) and $2,200 to insure their one car.
They report that they were fortunate in the mortgage market, managing to lock in a mortgage rate of under 7 percent on a 30-year loan just before rates rose last year.
Besides mortgage terms, another key variable in housing expenses is local taxes. In general they tend to be higher in Westchester and on Long Island than they are in New Jersey, brokers say, and lower in New York City with its unusually large commercial tax base. But the view from up close -- a particular buyer's bill -- often presents a picture different from the generalizaion.
THE Zachs' total tax bill at present, for instance, is $8,690 a year. That produces an effective tax rate of 1.9 percent. The effective rate is the tax bill divided by the value of the house. Their bill shows that $4,600 of the total pays for schools. The couple plans to adopt children and send them to a public elementary school.
In their former house on Staten Island, the property taxes they paid to New York City were only $1,500 a year. But though their taxes are higher in Mount Vernon, they no longer pay a New York City income tax, but rather a payroll tax, since Mr. Zach's job is in the city. The decline in city taxes has offset the increase in property tax.
In the end, the Zachs calculate that they spend about half the amount on housing costs, as a percentage of their income, that lenders prescribe as maximum, not an unusual situation for well-to-do buyers who refrain from stretching into more exclusively high-income communities.
"My observation is that those who trade up nowadays are looking for space, not for glitz," said Lynn Graham, a sales associate at the Stanton Company in Montclair, N.J., where local taxes on a $200,000 house are about $2,000 a year higher than they are in neighboring communities, largely because the community spends more on schools. "Even people in high-bonus jobs are probably buying less than they can afford."
But that is not likely to be the case for first-time buyers, who are the stretchers on debt. A case in point is that of Jesus Ramos, 32, and his wife Donna Perez-Ramos, 31, who were renters in the South Bronx. Mr. Ramos is a social worker and Ms. Perez-Ramos is in charge of a traders' support group at CS First Boston in Manhattan. They have two boys, 7 and 3.
Ms. Perez-Ramos had a good year at CS First Boston last year, with a year-end bonus that enabled the couple to spend more for their first house than they expected when they started looking last year. They wound up getting a traditional 1925 house on tree-lined North Fulton Avenue in Mount Vernon for $220,000 last May.
"WE had been planning to put only 5 percent down but it turned out we could put down 10 percent," said Ms. Perez-Ramos. "That was the key."
She still calculates that they spend 28 percent of their gross income for housing costs, but they had the income to deal with an unexpected surprise: After-school day care for children was not available beyond 4 P.M. at the elementary school they had planned for their 7-year-old son. So he is back at his old parochial school in the Bronx at an unanticipated tuition cost of $110 a month. He is dropped off at school and his younger brother is dropped off at his grandmother's house for day care every weekday morning by Mr. Ramos on his way to work.
"I've learned to be more planful, less impulsive in spending," said Ms. Perez-Ramos, who works unusually long hours at her job while her husband, with more regular hours, delivers and picks up the children from school and at a grandmother's house.
At a higher level of housing expense, Lia and David Rosenthal, who bought in Montclair, represent attitudes similar to the Ramoses. Mr. Rosenthal, 33, owns a database software company called Comsult, based in Montclair. Mrs. Rosenthal is a freelance writer of corporate training programs. They had their first child, a girl, just 10 days ago.
They bought a four-and-a-half-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath 1928 house on a 70- by 152-foot lot on Montclair Avenue last spring at a price they declined to disclose. Mrs. Rosenthal had worked for eight years before they bought, and Mr. Rosenthal for 11, so they were able to save and make a substantial down payment on a house they intend to remain in indefinitely.
One priority for the Rosenthals was Montclair's highly regarded school system. It accounts for about half of their local tax bill in a town in which buyers who spend, for example, $250,000 for a house will pay about $7,500 a year in taxes.
"What we have done is skipped over the starter house and jumped to the second house," Mrs. Rosenthal said. Over time the couple expect to spend a great deal on home improvements. "There's a lot of work to do here," Mrs. Rosenthal said.
But not nearly as much as Vincent Amesse, a photographer, and his wife, Ellyn, faced when they bought a five-room 1940's ranch house last year on Manor Court in the exclusive Lighthouse Hill section of Staten Island. They built an entire second floor on the house, which they bought for $250,000, paying largely for the land value rather than the existing structure.
It is another approach to home buying, possible when the residence on the land is not of a quality that the value of the land would justify. The buyer usually expects that the cost of the improvement ultimately will be recoverable in a sale, making the project worthy as an investment.
But as is normally the case in home buying and home improvements, the search for personal satisfaction, not cold financial calculation, played the central role.
"It's a quiet street, and a beautiful location," Mrs. Amesse said. "We have almost wiped out our savings, but it's for something we can enjoy every day."

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Mortgage Outreach Efforts

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS 

 BODY:
EVERY now and then the mortgage lending community rolls out the impressive dollar amounts it intends to set aside to help inner-city, immigrant and minority families buy homes.
Until recently, however, these families had good reason to be cynical. Despite the fanfare, they were still being asked to demonstrate the kind of employment and borrowing history that bore little resemblance to the way many really lived their lives. 
 But the gap between promise and reality may be over. An informal sampling of mortgage brokers and lenders in the New York metropolitan area shows increasing evidence of a new attempt to reach those who were formerly unacceptable, an attempt that seems not only genuine but also wide in scope.
The Chemical Bank released figures in June, for example, showing that minority loans accounted for 20.1 percent of all home purchasing borrowing in 1993, up from 16.1 percent in 1992. Further, loan rejection rates among Asian, black and Hispanic applicants had been cut in half. And a group of Federal regulators, the Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council, reported last week that the number of home mortgages issued to blacks in the New York metropolitan area soared 44.8 percent in 1993 from the year before. Loans to Asian-American and Hispanic applicants increased by 19.9 percent, roughly the same rate as loans to whites.
It's happening for several reasons. First, the volume of business from existing homeowners eager to refinance -- a market that kept lenders afloat in the early 90's -- is drying up now that interest rates are rising. Thus bankers have been forced to look elsewhere for customers.
As they did so, they became increasingly aware that the complexion of America was changing. They saw that "they could no longer impose middle-class life style judgments on people with a very different culture," said Cheryl Hoffman, senior vice president of risk management at Arbor National Mortgage of Uniondale, L.I.
Further, secondary market investors like the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac -- which buy mortgages from the local lenders and thus set lending standards for the industry -- also discovered that their former practices disqualified a growing segment of the home-buying public. So they have been gradually changing their guidelines, too, encouraging even more banks to do so.
Those changes in lending policy now include:
* Permitting people with seasonal employment, like construction, to qualify provided their employment reoccurs on a regular basis.
* No longer considering job-hopping as a sign of instability.
* No longer viewing credit problems, such as overdue loan payments, as a reason for automatic rejection, provided the borrower can provide a verifiable excuse like a prolonged illness.
* No longer requiring a cash amount equal to two months of future mortgage payments at the closing.
* Allowing a down payment or closing costs to be provided by one of the lending-and-savings clubs popular among West Indian and Asian immigrants, rather than requiring personal assets to cover these needs.
* Lending on formerly disqualified homes such as those in commercial neighborhoods and on properties offering unorthodox living arrangements, like homes with multigenerational setups and apartments that require walking through one to reach the other
* Allowing a mortgage to be combined with a rehabilitation loan so that someone willing to buy, say, a home without a functioning heating system can get money to immediately install that heat.
Yet another catalyst for change has been pressure from Federal and state government regulators. Karen Hill, executive director of the Fair Housing Interfaith Office in Yonkers, finds these officials increasingly requiring lenders to show they are meeting the needs of inner-city and minority communities as a trade-off, say, for approving a bank merger.
This, she noted, is why recently merged banks are often proving to be particularly friendly toward the nonconventional borrower.
Some lenders have become more willing to keep some of these loans in their own portfolios, allowing for even greater flexibility. Chemical, for example, uses this method to extend the debt-to-income ratio of otherwise qualified borrowers above the industry limit of 38 percent, said Wesley Wainwright, a senior vice president at Chemical.
Selling the loan to an agency that puts it into a pool of loans for resale means that the loan must satisfy the agency's regulations. By keeping the loan for its own portfolio, Mr. Wainwright said, Chemical can more readily qualify someone without a traditional credit history but with a solid record of paying utility bills or rent on time.
Other lenders use private secondary market investor pools for similar purposes. Arbor, for example, has thus been able to introduce a loan called Home Flex, which allows people with plenty of cash but poor credit or irregular income to buy a home.
In the last year about 200 borrowers have taken advantage of the program. It requires a down payment of 30 percent or more, depending on circumstances, though it does carry an interest rate that is two percentage points higher than the rate paid by traditional borrowers.
How can a borrower find out about these offers? Ms. Hill suggested starting by attending one of the many housing fairs and seminars for inner-city home buyers that lenders are now sponsoring. They are regularly announced in the local press and with posters and flyers.
It is at those fairs that potential borrowers can meet the lenders most eager to reach out to this newer market. In the New York metropolitan area they include the Banco Popular de Puerto Rico, the Bank of New York, Chase Manhattan, Citibank, the Dime Savings Bank and the Republic National Bank.
For a complete listing call the New York Mortgage Coalition at (212) 493-7419. The coalition is a year-old organization that fosters alternative lending standards. And it will also refer callers to a community group in their own neighborhoods that can provide free house-buying counseling.
"We had found that not having basic information was a barrier in itself," said Bonnie O'Donnell, director of consumer affairs at Fannie Mae, which is co-sponsoring some of the initiatives. "We're also trying to reach people who don't speak English and who have never had a home owner in their family."
Another entry point might be through a church, trade, ethnic or professional group. Prudential Home Mortgage of St. Louis, for example, is offering special deals to members of certain minority organizations. The Urban League has become equally active as a home-buying counselor, noted Ms. Hill.
Ms. Hill also recommended contacting a lower-income housing or home-buying counseling agency, such as her own. Approaching a lender with this sort of an advocate in tow, she said, helps a lot. But care should always be taken to make sure that there are no hidden additional fees for the counseling service.
The nontraditional borrower may also find a warmer welcome among mortgage brokers who never courted these clients before, either. For example, Skyscraper Mortgage, which has offices throughout the New York area, hired a minority loan specialist in September -- yet another harbinger of change.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: State Report;
Rent Regulation From 1943 to '93

 BODY:
On Nov. 1, 1943, the Federal Office of Price Administration issued regulations freezing New York City rents at their March 1, 1943, levels. There have been rent rules ever since, and their first half century is the subject of "Rent Regulation After 50 Years," a report recently issued by the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal.
The report, an overview of one of the most hotly debated public policy issues in New York, provides detailed statistical information on New York's regulatory system, which affects 2.5 million tenants in more than 1 million privately owned housing accommodations in New York City and in municipalities in Nassau, Westchester, Rockland and several upstate counties. 
 The publication, more than 300 pages, includes a history of rent regulation, an overview of the housing market with a focus on rent-stabilized and rent-controlled housing stock and a glossary of rent terms.
The report's statistics for 1992, the latest available, show that there were 855,923 registered rent-stabilized apartments in New York City, half of the city's occupied rental units. The report also contains a list of buildings in New York City and Westchester, Nassau and Rockland Counties with rent-regulated units.
It may be obtained free by writing to Rent Publication, Office of Public Information, Division of Housing and Community Renewal, One Fordham Plaza, Bronx, N.Y. 10458.

HEADLINE: ART;
The Cone Sisters: Shoppers or Connoisseurs?

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER

 BODY:
FOR ANYONE INTERESTED IN experiencing the punch and variety of avant-garde European art, the city of Baltimore was surely not the place to be during the first decades of this century. Or was it?
 In 1905, a city native, Etta Cone, went with her friend Gertrude Stein -- another Baltimorean, by adoption -- to Picasso's Paris studio and, on impulse, bought an etching. It was the first purchase of what turned out to be a vast, decades-long shopping spree. By the time Etta bought her last Picasso 44 years later, she and her older sister, Claribel, had filled their Baltimore apartment with some 3,000 art objects, among which were now-legendary masterpieces of 20th-century art, including Matisse's "Blue Nude" (1907), Gauguin's "Woman With a Mango" (1892) and Cezanne's drop-dead "Mont Sainte-Victoire Seen From the Bibemus Quarry" (circa 1897). 
The sisters bequeathed their collection to the Baltimore Museum of Art (on the condition, Claribel stipulated in her will, that "the spirit of appreciation of modern art in Baltimore becomes improved"). With the museum's recent inauguration of a new wing dedicated to 20th-century postwar art, the adjoining Cone Galleries have been refurbished and reorganized.
 The bumperlike wooden platforms that ran under the paintings to prevent viewer encroachment have been replaced by low metal railings, a change that helps open up the galleries visually. More important, the once crowded display of Matisse paintings, in which the great, the good and the indifferent hung side by side, has been slimmed down to a smaller number of top-of-the-line works, letting the collection put its very best foot forward. The only hold-over problem is the continued use on the Matisses of modern recessed box frames, an unfortunate choice, as the museum is in possession of many of the original frames.
 The carefully edited hanging not only affords a chance to review the work itself, much of which has been on the road in the recent Matisse retrospective, but to reconsider the Cones' accomplishment. Was their collecting simply the leisure activity of a pair of Yankees blessed with excess capital and a yen for cultural credentials, as it has sometimes been portrayed? Or was it the result of truly adventurous eyes bringing back to America art it had barely sampled up to that time? A definitive answer is impossible to give, but both factors played a part.
 "Dr. Claribel & Miss Etta," a 1985 biography of the Cones written by Brenda Richardson, the Baltimore museum's curator of modern painting and sculpture, remains the primary source of information about their lives. It tells a classic American story of a self-made economic aristocracy. The sisters' father, Herman Cone, immigrated to America from Germany in 1846, and peddled dry goods throughout the South before opening a grocery store in Tennessee. After the business grew into a lucrative export company, he moved to Baltimore. Claribel (1864-1929) and Etta (1870-1949) were born there. Neither married. Claribel became a gynecologist. Etta took charge of managing the household.
 Although very different as personalities -- Claribel was the more severe and independent, Etta the more garrulous and sociable -- they spent much of their time together and made several trips to Europe. In Paris, they often visited Gertrude Stein, who as a young woman had lived in Baltimore after the death of her parents in California in 1892.
 Ms. Richardson's book devotes a considerable amount of speculation to the degree of intimacy between Etta Cone and Gertrude Stein, concluding that they were very likely lovers at some point. Of greater interest in understanding the sisters as collectors, however, is Stein's own slightly fictionalized psychological portrait of them, written between 1908 and 1912 and titled "Two Women." In a series of notes jotted down while composing the essay, Stein reminds herself to work from personal observation of the sisters' behavior: "what effect they had when they were traveling, how they quarreled, how they spent money. . . . buying scarfs, handling things, patting hair, a little crazy."
 Money the Cones certainly had (the equivalent of $30,000 a year each in today's currency, a comfortable income at the time), and once their buying started in earnest it took on a feverish life of its own. "We are being drowned in things," Etta wrote to Gertrude in 1922, and among those things they counted not only modern European art but Egyptian sculpture, Middle Eastern textiles, Indian metalwork, 18th-century French jewelry and African sculpture. (The two recreated rooms in the Cone Galleries from the sisters' Baltimore apartments -- they lived in the same building -- show a decor verging on clutter, though contemporary photographs suggest it was as much a period style as a personal one.)
 The modern art they acquired was often superb, though it was superb within certain limits. As Ms. Richardson has observed, while the Cones were interested in some of the most radical artists of their day, they were also inclined to buy those artists' most conservative works. This was the case with Picasso, for example. They treasured his "Mother and Child" of 1922, a sentimental image redeemed only by its gossamer brushwork, but when Etta bought one of his bold "Demoiselles"-period Cubist studies of a female nude, she made it clear that she had done so reluctantly and only to fill out the collection.
 The Cones made their most serious commitment to the work of Matisse, and it is for the Matisse paintings, sculptures and works on paper that their collection is most celebrated. These include the 1917 "Woman in a Turban (Lorette)," an elegant portrait of an Italian model swathed in white against a sea-green ground; "Seated Odalisque, Left Knee Bent, Ornamental Background and Checkerboard" (1928), in which hot red and yellow patterning is taken to near-hallucinatory extremes, and "Interior, Flowers and Parakeets" (1924), Etta's favorite.
 The Cones often bought work directly from Matisse's studio, and it is possible that his gentleman-artist demeanor appealed to them as much as his work. In any case, artist and patrons had a warm enough friendship to warrant his stay at their home when he visited America in 1930.
 Despite the depth of their Matisse collecting, the Cones chose from within an extremely narrow range of his work, favoring small-scale, highly decorative images over his large-scale geometric paintings of interiors or his later cutouts. Charm rather than audacity was the effect they preferred, though in fact Etta's two largest purchases were daring in the extreme. One was the "Large Reclining Nude," a 1935 extravaganza in pink for which Matisse supplied his patron with dozens of working photographs. The other was the great early "Blue Nude" of 1907, one of the artist's darkest and most provocative images.
 The "Blue Nude" was bought from Stein, who, financially strapped at the time, was trying to unload her own collection. But did Etta Cone buy the painting for the Stein pedigree alone? There is evidence that the Cones' own collective eye had sharpened and refined with time. They began to view themselves as art collectors rather than shoppers, and they took ever greater pains to give their accumulated holdings a historical shape. It was with this in mind that they added, for example, a stunning Courbet (his "Shaded Stream at le Puits Noir," circa 1860-65), and van Gogh's "Pair of Boots" (1887), both of which are on view in Baltimore, along with a selection of engaging works by such minor figures as Marie Laurencin and the American Leon Kroll.
 It is the lesser work -- and there's a fair amount of it, including a good many of the Matisses -- that makes their collection an erratic affair artistically but a fascinating document in human terms. What began as a whim, perhaps an effort on the part of two bright, inquisitive women to perk up the walls of a somber Victorian apartment in what was then an American backwater town, gradually became a valuable and directed life's work. It not only brought to America the fresh air of the European avant-garde but indirectly it also helped preserve the taste of a great expatriate, Gertrude Stein, many of whose pioneering purchases the Cones later made their own.
 AND, OF COURSE, THE CONES PUT Baltimore on the map. By the time of her death, Etta had been wooed by many art-world luminaries (among them Alfred Barr, director of the Museum of Modern Art throughout the 30's), hoping that her collection might come their way. But Baltimore, improved or not, got the nod. It is appropriate that in approaching the museum's handsome new wing for postwar art one must pass through their legacy, and it is nice to imagine them viewing the new art themselves -- bored, perhaps, by Jackson Pollock, interested in Andy Warhol, puzzled and possibly shocked by Gilbert and George, all the while keeping prices and available wall space at home firmly in mind. Whatever their final evaluation of the art on view might be, it is in some measure thanks to their keen eyes and their faith in the new that it is there at all.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 20, 1994, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Oct. 30 about the Cone sisters, the art collectors for whom the Baltimore Museum of Art's newly refurbished Cone Galler ies are named, misstated Claribel Cone's birthplace and profession. She was born in Jonesboro, Tenn., not in Baltimore, and was a patholo gist, not a gynecologist. The article also misstated the ownership of Pi casso's painting "Mother and Child." It did not belong to both sisters; Etta bought it after Clari bel's death. The article also referred incorrectly to the purchase of Ma tisse's "Blue Nude." That painting was bought by Claribel, not by Etta, and not from Gertrude Stein but at an auction of the estate of the lawyer and arts patron John Quinn.

HEADLINE: STRENTHENING THE DOLLAR;
An Exercise In Making Change

BYLINE: By HOLLY BRUBACH

 BODY:
Officials at the Treasury Department recently announced that our currency is being redesigned -- not for esthetic reasons, they claim, but in an attempt to foil counterfeiters. (The difference, it is said, will be practically negligible to the naked eye.) As it happened, this news coincided with the complaints of a friend, Dutch by birth -- a world traveler who had lived in several countries before moving not too long ago to New York. He found American money confusing, he said. "It's all the same color and all the same size, and you actually have to look at the numbers to see how much a bill is worth." He had a point, come to think of it. In the wake of the new French 50-franc note, featuring a drawing of the Little Prince -- a whimsical sort of tribute that would seem somehow heretical in America, where we take our money very seriously -- we invited seven "experts" to reconceive the dollar bill. The results, seen on these pages, are on exhibit at Artists Space, 38 Greene Street, through Jan. 7. HOLLY BRUBACH

GRAPHIC: Photos: SEED MONEY: I chose engravings of cash crops -- peanuts, soybeans, cotton, tobacco -- because that's what made America strong. I put a roadway on the $10 bill because that also made us great: distribution. It is the transportation network that really fuels our economy -- both physically (with roads) and ephemerally (with the information highway). Also, I wanted to celebrate the idea that our streets are paved with gold. (Karen Bausman, Architect) (Pg. 70)
 
HOLLYWOOD SCRIP: I took an existing design and thought subversively about it, to make some comment about America. (My favorite bill is Austria's 50-schilling note with Freud on it. It's a great bill considering all the psychological implications of touching and spending money.) Since we are such a culture of cliches, I thought, why not put what America stands for around the world -- film culture -- on the money? If we can have Bambi on our stamps, we can have scenes from movies on our money. (Barbara Bloom, Artist) (Pg. 71)
 
PLAY DOUGH: I like to think of the happier things money can buy. To remove it from government as much as possible. It would be nice to get back to the barter system, and make money more of an offering. I tried to find the most colorful and interesting images. An animal is much more interesting than a politician. (Todd Oldham, Fashion Designer) (Pg. 72)
 
OLD MONEY: Paper currency will soon be obsolete, so redesigning it would be like designing a new rotary phone. In the future, routine financial transactions will be conducted electronically. Cash will survive, however, in the underground economy, where it will be used for exchanges that shouldn't be traced -- from buying black-market cigarettes to making illicit babysitter payments. Old reserves of paper, officially "canceled," will be the new cash. In an economy where paper is rare and electronic signals cheap, the paper standard will replace the gold one. (J. Abbott Miller and Ellen Lupton, Graphic Designers) (Pg. 72)
 
SPENDER FRIENDLY: Our teacher at Pratt used to say that pure unadulterated beauty should be the goal of civilization. Since money is so central to civilization, it make sense that it should be beautiful. For that reason we chose Don Freeman's photographs of nature for the background -- they are so obviously beautiful and inherently hard to copy. We used different color to help differentiate the denominations (now bigger and clearer), and instead of "legal tender" in fine print, we wrote, "collect 'em or trade 'em with your friends," which is much friendlier. (Tucker Viemeister and Rie Norregaard, Industrial Designers) (Pg. 73)

HEADLINE: Outdoor Home Lighting Takes On a Softer Look

BYLINE: By JOYCE JONES 

 BODY:
EARLY this evening, now that the clocks have been turned back an hour to Eastern Standard Time, the landscape will be suddenly plunged into darkness. One outdoor lighting specialist often jokingly approaches homeowners by saying: "It's 6 P.M. Do you know where your flowers are?"
Where once the extended period of darkness had limited remedies -- a splash of light at the front door, a floodlight over the garage -- today people are using far more sophisticated methods of illuminating their homes, for security and esthetic reasons. 
 "Homeowners in New Jersey have taken to the concept of outdoor lighting very quickly," said David DePorter, the customer service manager at Hadco, a division of the Genlyte Company that manufactures outdoor lighting fixtures. "In the last three years our sales have doubled, with New Jersey only topped by California in volume of sales."
The trend in outdoor residential lighting has also created a concern: light trespassing. Laura Rhodes, whose house in Short Hills is illuminated by a process called moonlighting, a soft method of diffusing light, said: "Harsh spotlights that glare on to another person's property are as aggravating and thoughtless as noise pollution. Living in the suburbs, you have to consider your neighbor's needs as well as your own."
Any lighting is welcomed by law-enforcement agencies, which consider it a major tool in crime prevention. Larry Vardell, the supervisor of community relations for the Dade County, Fla., Public Safety Department, in a report circulated to police departments in the area, wrote: "The notion that good lighting is a prerequisite for safety is as old as civilization."
"Equally ancient is the problem of providing good light," he added, citing the Babylonians' burning thick wicks in bowls of fat during crowded festival times.
For whatever reason it is installed, outdoor lighting has been a boon to landscape architects, who now include it in their garden plans; outdoor lighting specialists; electricians and electrical supply companies. An electrician in Morris County, Art Ayres, said his outdoor lighting jobs had easily doubled in the last five years.
"Currently, only 35 percent of my work is for security lighting," Mr. Ayres said. "The remainder is spent on lighting to enhance the property."
Ira Margolis, the manager of Domb Lighting, an electrical supply company in Morristown, said, "The introduction of low-voltage lighting also has been a boost to the industry." To keep up with customers' questions, employees attend classes taught at the Genlyte Company in Secaucus. In turn, they offer seminars at the store on topics like the advantages of economical 12-volt systems.
Mr. Margolis said that the harsh, glaring floodlight, once thought to be a bane for the burglar has actually been an aid. Floodlights create pools of bright light and leave darker areas, sometimes close to windows, where burglars can hide. He added, "The old-fashioned floodlight has been replaced with lighting techniques that produce special effects like moonlighting, silhouetting, mirror lighting, shadow and grazing where lighting enhances the texture of a vertical surface like a brick or stone wall."
Some of these lighting concepts are not necessarily new, said Vernon Daniel, president of Vernon Daniel Associates, which has an office in Millburn. He has been moonlighting gardens for 30 years, bathing them in light that gives the illusion of the moon's shining on them.
"People are now grasping the esthetics of night lighting, aware that they can do away with ugly floodlights on the back of a house that make the property look like a prison yard," Mr. Daniel said.
"It really is a matter of educating people about lighting," he said. "Lighting is an abstract effect; people can't hold it in their hand."
For example, he said floodlights should be installed high in trees, beaming down. But if a floodlight is installed lower down on the house, special shields can be installed to reduce the glare.
Gauging the public's interest, outdoor lighting manufacturers have developed a variety of products. Copper tulips and shell designs when grouped together light floral beds; accent lights draw attention to a fountain or a favorite tree; pagodas highlight pathways, and small lanterns cast a soft glow in low-level areas.
"In the past 10 years, the demand for outdoor lighting has risen dramatically," said Mark Mosello, president of Design Lighting by Marks, based in White Plains. His company illuminates houses and gardens for prices ranging from $1,000 to $50,000 and beyond.
But business has not always been so good. Twenty-seven years ago when he suggested that he put lights on a specimen oak tree in one client's garden, her reaction, he said, was one of bewilderment: "Why would I want to light up a tree?"
Mr. Mosello recalled, "I told her because the tree was beautiful and should be enjoyed at night, too. Once the tree was illuminated, she loved it and so did her neighbors."
Mr. Mosello added: "Everyone knows that we need light at night. Today that concept is being marketed in a different way. Let us light up the night, putting in view what is seen during the day in an esthetically pleasing manner. It's creating a soft welcoming glow that makes you view the night in a whole new manner."
That's the way Mrs. Rhodes and her husband, Frederick, looked at it when they had outdoor lighting installed. In addition to illuminating their garden by moonlighting, they wanted to light up a pond in front of their house -- but only the portion that touched their property. They did not want light to reflect onto their neighbors' portion of the pond.
"With downlighting in the trees, the water came into view but the lights were not visible on the other side of the pond," Mrs. Rhodes said. "It's so soothing to enjoy the pond during the day. In the evening before we had the lighting installed, while we knew it was just beyond the terrace, we couldn't see it.
"Now we can, and yet we have made sure that our pleasure and sense of security have not, in effect, robbed our neighbors of their right to privacy."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Homeowners are turning to new kinds of exterior lighting systems for security and esthetic reasons. The home of Dr. Samara Singhe in Saddle River was illuminated by Mark Mosello, president of Design Lighting by Marks. (Frank C. Dougherty for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: UNIVERSITY PRESSES;
Gasoline Dreams

BYLINE: By Thomas Hine; Thomas Hine is the author of "Populuxe" and "The Total Package," a forthcoming study of the history and meaning of containers.

 BODY:

THE GAS STATION IN AMERICA
By John A. Jakle and Keith A. Sculle.
Illustrated. 272 pp. Baltimore:
The Johns Hopkins University Press. $32.95. 
GASOLINE is one of the few commodities in America whose consumption has, in recent years, become more public and less segmented by class, age and income.
My humble Geo Prizm drinks from the same pump as the burnished Infiniti alongside it, the fierce Dodge Ram pickup behind it and the oversized, superannuated Buick, held together with wire and duct tape, waiting its turn. And (except in New Jersey and Oregon, where self-service is illegal) the driver of each must soil his hands with gasoline and stand in line to pay a young woman who asks, vacantly, "What pump was that?"
Such low-quality equality is a long way from those uniformed men from Texaco who worked from Maine to Mexico and loved their job of servicing your car, from the days of "registered rest rooms" and the mysteries of "Marfak lubrication." It's true, of course, that such things were more a phenomenon of advertising than of real life. But now we are so dependent on automobiles that, like hard-core addicts of any kind, we can expect to be abused, not seduced, by those who sell us what we can't go on without.
In "The Gas Station in America," John A. Jakle, a professor of geography and landscape architecture at the University of Illinois, Urbana, and Keith A. Sculle, the head of research and education at the Illinois Historic Preservation Agency, recount the history of a form of business and social institution they say is fast disappearing. Although the mini-mart where I fill my tank happens to be owned by a large oil company, most of its profits come from Snapple, Doritos and milk, so it's not exactly a gas station.
The mini-mart can also be seen as another stage in the gas station's nearly nine-decade evolution. But Mr. Jakle and Mr. Sculle seem particularly eager to declare that the gas station is history -- largely in order to define it as a worthy area for study in their disciplines.
Unlike such books as Daniel I. Vieyra's "Fill 'Er Up!" and John Margolies's "Pump and Circumstance," which concentrate on design and celebrate the personal and the outrageous, "The Gas Station in America" strives for a more complex understanding of the typical. "The gasoline station, as the other commercial form-types of the roadside," the authors write, "redefines localities intruded upon according to the fashionable universals of modern economy." The authors' prose could use a tuneup, but their approach is valid.
Gasoline stations were, for the most part, local representatives of businesses that operated on a global scale and were usually trying to increase their marketing reach. They were among the first buildings to represent a standardization of quality and service -- the branding of place. The expansion of "automobility" had paradoxically increased people's desire for things that were just like those at home.
Mr. Jakle and Mr. Sculle demonstrate this phenomenon in several ways. They describe the Pure Oil Company's famous "English cottage" design style and discuss the upper-middle-class mania for the suburban picturesque as a decisive reason for it. But they also give due emphasis to the use of distinctive blue tile for the roofs, which allowed these seemingly modest buildings to function as signs.
In a particularly useful chapter they discuss the process by which the oil companies colonized a road linking Champaign and Urbana, Ill., turning it into a commercial strip, and then receded in importance as other sorts of businesses grew to dominate it. This is the sort of thing most middle-aged people have observed in their lifetimes, but it is good to have an example documented.
THE book is weaker in making connections between its themes. For example, the disappearance of houses from roads that became strips seems to have diminished the need for gas stations to feign domesticity. That, along with the expansion of products and services in the stations themselves, suggests that the cottagelike station was doomed, and that the modern, streamlined horizontal box that took its place was a more visible, more commodious creature in a less respectable environment. The way the packagelike building changes the nature of the place it's in and induces a whole new kind of environment is interesting and important to understand. But station design is discussed in Chapters 5 and 6, while the strip is in Chapter 8, and the authors don't attempt to relate them.
An interminable account of corporate territoriality -- the oil marketers' often thwarted attempts to extend their sales areas -- is nowhere connected to the descriptions of the stations' designs or the shaping of the landscape. The oil companies' territorial struggles were complicated, to be sure, and it must have been a lot of work to pull this information together. But the authors don't link those struggles to their subject.
When Mr. Jakle and Mr. Sculle do hazard explanations for a phenomenon, they tend to be unimpressive. They speculate that the conversion of gas stations into convenience stores with pumps was an effort to make women more comfortable. They seem not to have noticed changes in automobiles that made their repair more specialized and dependent on diagnostic tools available primarily to dealers. The gas station may be endangered; the old-time grease monkey is extinct. The former service bays have filled up with snacks and staples.
Mr. Jakle and Mr. Sculle argue, a bit defensively at times, that the gas station and the roadside are entitled to serious study, and that theirs is an attempt to go beyond the mere description that has characterized the field thus far. "The Gas Station in America" does advance that study. It provides important information and insights for those who will explain more fully the American landscape of consumption.

GRAPHIC: Drawing: An illustration of a curbside gasoline pump, 1915. (NATIONAL PETROLEUM NEWS/FROM "THE GAS STATION IN AMERICA")

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: UNIVERSITY PRESSES;
A Long Line of Optimists

BYLINE: By Jonathan Spence; Jonathan Spence teaches modern Chinese history at Yale. He is currently writing a book on the 19th-century Taiping Rebellion.

 BODY:

MOUNTAIN OF FAME
Portraits in Chinese History.
By John E. Wills Jr.
Illustrated. 403 pp. Princeton, N.J.:
Princeton University Press. $24.95. 
 THE term he translates as "Mountain of Fame," John E. Wills Jr. tells us in the opening pages of this spirited and highly intelligent book, is an ambiguous one in the original Chinese. Composed of two simple Chinese characters, those for "name" and "mountain," it at once invites anyone familiar with traditional Chinese thought and culture to speculate on all the different historically famous scenic mountains and the emotions they have evoked over time. At the same time, the phrase invites reflection on the force of having a name, in the sense either of personal identity, or of fame, be it contemporary or posthumous.
The most celebrated use of this ambiguous phrase occurs in an intensely personal letter to a friend written by the man generally recognized to be China's greatest historian, Sima Qian, who lived from about 145 to 86 B.C. Sima Qian told his friend that since his manuscript meant everything to him, he was determined to finish it at all costs, despite unbearable pain and humiliations, so that it would live on for all time on this "name mountain." And what a book it would be, Sima Qian assured his friend, a book that "gathered up and brought together the old traditions of the world which were scattered and lost"; a book that "examined the
deeds and events of the past and investigated the principles behind their success and failure, their rise and decay" as well as "all that concerns heaven and man." As if that were not enough, the book would "penetrate the changes of the past and present."
As a manifesto for ambitious historians, Sima Qian's letter has perhaps no rivals, and it leads Mr. Wills, in "Mountain of Fame: Portraits in Chinese History," to a splendid reflection on the nature of the Chinese relationship to history, culture and morality: "The optimism about human potentialities that runs through the Chinese tradition from Confucius to Mao has been inseparable from stories of the realization of the highest values in actual lives. Moreover, all these famous people, even legendary ancestors and heroes who after their deaths became gods, were conceived of as real, mortal, limited human beings, living in society and dependent on others, not gods on earth. Often their stories can be read at many levels, so that their moral and intellectual brilliance is not lost sight of, but the complexities, the hidden chains of cause, the flaws of heroes and the unwanted consequences of virtuous action also are revealed. It is, I suspect, in large part because of its obsession with the stories of its famous people that Chinese culture is so rich and varied in its moral imagination, so at home, indeed delighted, with the complexities and ambiguities of human character and action."
It was because of this rich and varied material that Mr. Wills, a professor of history at the University of Southern California, decided to draw together some 20 Chinese biographical case studies garnered from his lifetime of teaching Chinese history in the United States, so as to offer the general reader "a quick and graspable introduction" to "some main themes" in China's history.
Few things are harder in writing about China than to find the right mix for such a "quick and graspable" introduction. The sweep of time is daunting -- at least 4,000 years -- if one wants to explore key conceptual and spatial continuities. The names both of places and of people are baffling and elusive to Western eyes and ears. The risk of seeming repetitious to glazed readers is formidable, as Han succeeds Qin, Tang follows Sui, Qing smashes Ming. And evasiveness about many of the intimate aspects of the human experience that are dear to contemporary readers is pervasive in the long succession of Chinese state-sponsored histories. Thus the use of linked biographical sketches as the pegs on which to hang the rough fabric of a manageable analysis is an understandable and even valuable technique.

OTHER historians, of course, have tried this strategy at various times. What gives Mr. Wills's attempt its originality and its effectiveness is the artful span of examples he has chosen, examples that not only range across time from the very early cultural hero Emperor Yu to Mao Zedong, but also are chosen to illuminate major themes and continuities within the Chinese universe. Thus the reader does indeed learn -- in a sprightly yet most effective way -- much about China's statist values, its modes of political behavior, Chinese definitions of courage and loyalty, the broad outlines of Buddhism and of Taoism, coastal trade, the impact of the West and the rise of Communism.
There is high drama, cruelty and excess in many of these stories, especially those about the first Qin Emperor and the Empress Wu, for as Mr. Wills nicely says, "many people who seek great power have a little bit of monster in their makeup" (Mr. Wills does not belabor such themes unduly). But there is also much subtlety and intellectual adventure, especially in the studies of Sima Qian himself, of the early woman historian Ban Zhao, of the military strategist Zhuge Liang, the intuitionist philosopher Wang Yangming and the nationalist politician and theorist Liang Qichao. And there is also wit and charm mixed with the telling of great events, most of all in the portraits of Confucius and of Su Dongpo, the Song politician, painter and poet who is clearly a personal favorite of Mr. Wills, as he has been for generations of Chinese in the past.
My one main regret is that Mr. Wills does not bring in more people outside what one might still call the mainline intellectual and educated ruling circles of China. Yes, there are two women (and brief vignettes of some others) in the collection, along with revolutionaries and religious leaders. But it would have been grand to have at least one scientist in whatever sphere, and a merchant or businessman operating within the Chinese economic structure (to complement the man on the edge, Zheng Chenggong), and some thinker -- perhaps an iconoclast of the May 4, 1919, movement -- who really grappled deeply with the full 20th-century range of challenges posed to Chinese values by the West.
There are surprises, even for those who have read the same kind of materials at various times and pondered the best way to present the insights buried in them. Perhaps the most striking is the inclusion of Chiang Ching-kuo, the son of Chiang Kai-shek by his first marriage. Moscow-educated and married enduringly to a Russian woman, the younger Chiang dominated Taiwan as President from 1978 until his death in 1988, and masterminded the first stages of its transition to democracy, a transition continued by his chosen vice president, Lee Teng-hui, who is a Christian, born in Taiwan and educated in Japan and the United States. As Mr. Wills politely phrases it: "Leadership in nation-building requires vision, discipline and an ability to pay attention to the common people and meet their needs. The leadership of the Kuomintang has provided a good measure of all three, but only in three successive generations. The third of these figures is the least known, and fully as important and intriguing as Sun Yat-sen and Chiang Kai-shek."

 This judgment, a complex one historically, but neatly put, explains the chapter broadly called "The Kuomintang Legacy." Since these three formidable men were so tightly interconnected and presided at grand events even when they could not control them, this device works well. Less successful, I feel, is the attempt to bring the book up-to-date with a closing chapter on "Names in the News," which has brief vignettes of Deng Xiaoping, the writer and astrophysicist Fang Lizhi, the journalist Liu Binyan and a scattering of economic entrepreneurs and young leaders of the democracy movement of 1989. Mr. Wills is right when he says we cannot know where China is heading, and thus we cannot be sure who will have enduring significance. But if he had been just a little bolder, could he not have emulated Sima Qian and thrown all his narrative and historical skills behind one contemporary exemplar, and helped endow him or her with significance? As Mr. Wills himself has so well shown us, it is people who put other people on that elusive Mountain of Fame. None can do it for themselves.

HEADLINE: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: THE VOTERS;
Paradox of '94: Gloomy Voters In Good Times

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LORAIN, Ohio, Oct. 28

 BODY:
The ornery and ill-tempered voters who will sit in judgment on Election Day cannot exactly put a finger on why they are so disgusted with Washington and politics.
They know that inflation is low and unemployment is down. They know that the country is not at war, that even the disparaged expedition into Haiti turned out better than many of them expected. Sure, some were disappointed that no health care plan was voted on. But others were relieved because they did not want to lose their own coverage or pay any more for it. 
 So what are they complaining about? "The unknown," said Russ Carver, a Michigan steelworker standing in a union office. "What could be."
That may be a nearly impossible thing to campaign against, the vague notion that no matter what anybody does, things might get worse. But that is exactly what politicians are facing from a mercurial and bored electorate.
To listen to voters in two Midwestern steel towns where things are better than they were in the 1980's but a long way from booming, it has gotten to the point where some seem to think there is very little that politicians contribute to the country.
In River Rouge, Mich., a city of about 11,000 just south of Detroit, a retiree standing in line at a drugstore said, "They're doing absolutely nothing for the citizens."
Here in Lorain, about 30 miles west of Cleveland, Al Fuzy, the owner of a karate school, said he did not even know whether to believe the inflation and unemployment figures that he said some politician somewhere would take credit for.
"We don't really know what's going on in Washington at all," Mr. Fuzy said. "There are so many facts and statistics. They don't use a language that normal, everyday people can understand. It's nothing more than a spider web of deceit."
In recent years, it has, of course, become fashionable to attack Washington and politicians in general. Whether the bad mood comes from alienation, ignorance, indifference or "did not-did too" campaigning is hard to tell.
But all of this has made things harder for precinct captains like Michael Koury, an old-time Democrat who is a real estate agent when he is not passing out political literature. He has not been thrown off porches or anything, but he said he knew not to try the hard sell that might have worked a generation ago.
"Everybody is a free-thinker nowadays," Mr. Koury said. "Nobody likes to be told how to vote. They want to go their own way."
The problem now, he said, is that people may have it too good. "They forget where they came from," Mr. Koury said. "Business is good. The people are working. It's a great time to live in America. They got it good, and they want it better."
Mayor Alex Olejko of Lorain, a Democrat, said he could not figure it out. The Ford plant in this city of 71,000 cannot churn out minivans and Thunderbirds fast enough, the steel mill started hiring this year for the first time since 1982, and unemployment has gone to 6 percent now from 24 percent a decade ago.
"We're doing as good as we did with Truman," the Mayor said. "Your son is working. Your daughter is working. You're working. You're getting your pension. What more can you ask for?"
He caught his breath and thought of something else. "Housing is going up," he said. "What more do you want?"
The answer from voters in both Lorain and River Rouge was as vague and unformed as their general discontent. People mentioned the idea of a third party or term limits, but not with any particular fervor. The only thing clear was their lack of interest.
"Politics is like life insurance," said Bob LaForest, president of Local 1299 of the United Steelworkers union in River Rouge. "It's something I got to have, but I don't want to know nothing about it."
Whereas bad news bounced off President Ronald Reagan like oil on Teflon, bad news seems to be sticking to President Clinton, at least in the minds of many voters interviewed, like lint to Velcro.
To hear the impressions of voters in the last week is to be transported back to 1992, as if the last two years never happened.
Gennifer Flowers, the President's statement that he smoked marijuana but did not inhale, his absence from the Vietnam War, all seem to be as fresh in voters' minds as they were when Mr. Clinton was riding the bus across the country instead of Air Force One.
"He flip-flops," said Nancy Sabath, a program coordinator at Head Start in Lorain. "He just doesn't stay with things. And underlying that, he didn't serve in the military. That's part of being American."
For some people, whatever Teflon President Clinton may have seems to work only with good news. Many voters seem to look past the low inflation and drop in unemployment and give him no credit for a favorable economy.
"The economy is cyclical," said Bob Orlowski, a sales representative in River Rouge. It was an observation made over and over in the two steel towns, where people seem to conclude that their jobs depend on things other than politics when the going is good.
Mr. Orlowski said he had not decided who would get his vote in the various Michigan races, but he said he was getting little help from the finger-pointing in campaign advertisements.
"They muddy the water to purposely confuse the voter," said Mr. Orlowski, who works for an industrial gas company. "Even if it's not true, it's what you remember when you pull the lever."
With so many races involving candidates whom voters do not know or do not care about, people are having a hard time distinguishing the players.
In the Ohio Senate race, in which Joel Hyatt, a Democrat, is running against Lieut. Gov. Mike DeWine, a Republican, only two things stood out to Ruth Wilhelm, a Lorain steelworker. This is what she gleaned from the gauzy DeWine advertisements that paint the usually dark-suited politician as a down-home family man.
"DeWine?" she asked. "Plaid shirt. Lots of kids."
Mayor Olejko of Lorain said he missed the old days. "Years ago you'd see Kennedy and Nixon debate," he said. "They'd shake hands and talk about the issues. Now they're talking about families and scandals. It's sickening. I've been in politics since 1957, and I've never seen such crappy ads."
Rick Crum, a steelworker in River Rouge, said politicians could not be believed anyway. "They're all a bunch of leeches," said Mr. Crum, who added that politicians must have been looking at different economic figures than he was. "If inflation is so low, how come cereal is $4.75 a box?"
He is tough on all politicians except his own. His Congresswoman is Barbara-Rose Collins, a Democrat. He said she was doing a good job, as best as he could tell. "I get a lot of mail from her," Mr. Crum said. "She seems to be trying."
Some voters said they did not want to be bothered with having to watch every step made by their members of Congress. "You put these guys in office so you don't have to keep an eye on them," said Frank Shonebarger, sales manager at a tool repair shop in Lorain.
But Mr. Shonebarger has noticed the gridlock and grandstanding, and it angers him. "As long as there's Republicans and Democrats going at each other on both sides of the street, nothing gets done," he said.
He shook his head. "There's too much politics in politics," he said. Yogi Berra could not have said whatever was meant any better.
But some voters are not so hard on politicians. Elected officials are, after all, people too, Mr. Fuzy conceded. "On an individual basis, they are probably some of the nicest people you would ever want to meet," he said. "But get them together and put them in Washington and we still don't know how low they'll stoop. Your standard American is just tired of everything."
